The Volvo sputtered a warning as the crew of Spooktacular Investigations pulled up to the tall white gate. As hard as West squinted through his glasses, he could not see the seam that almost magically appeared after Nellie practically fell out of the driver’s side window to type in the gate code. The illusion of seamlessness was slightly ruined when the gates sputtered to a halt halfway to opening, and Nellie was not sure if Devi coughed or laughed in the backseat as an unsettling smoky smell gently wafted through the window. “Is the gate smoking?” asked West. “Would you rather it was the gate or the car?” Nellie asked. “I’d rather it was neither,” grumbled West. “I think it’s wide enough for you to just drive in,” Devi interrupted. She was right, but Nellie was careful as she maneuvered through the gap that was just wide enough for the protesting Volvo. It didn't close as they passed through and Nellie hoped the owner wouldn't blame them for that if she stopped in to check on their progress. “We’ve been to Victorian ruins less run-down than this,” West said as they parked in front of the Bennington Mansion. “It has retro charm,” Nellie countered. She looked in the rearview mirror at Devi, who had somehow already opened her briefcase and was setting up the sound equipment, headphones secure over her curls and mind miles away. Nellie rolled her eyes at West as she accepted the mic pack, but he was still glaring dubiously at the mansion. “I’m sure you’ll make it look much more impressive,” Nellie insisted, but West was less sure. His camera wasn’t magical. It could only film what Bradford Bennington wanted his guests to see – an enigma, unimpressive from the outside, full of secrets within. Looking at the front door, the crew could have been convinced that the house was quite small, just the rounded front they could see with windows like portholes evenly spaced high above their heads. But they had each glanced at the guidebook, a vintage item that neither West nor Devi would have guessed Nellie was clever enough to get into her clutches, and while it did not have a map, it was easy enough to follow. They knew the rooms spiralled inside, and the mansion was more like an enthusiastic question mark than a circle. The guidebook also warned that moving through the house could be a bit disorienting, especially for the customers following along without eyes on the instructions. West would probably have known more if he bothered to read it more closely, but after so many film shoots it was hard to stay enthusiastic. West slid out of the drivers' seat, tossing the keys to Devi who fumbled to catch them before she put them safely in her briefcase. She wondered if Nellie noticed how clumsy she was around her, how her professional demeanor slipped under their star's attention. But Nellie's friendliness seemed doomed to be only that: friendly. “Okay,” said Nellie, popping out of the car, rubbing her arms for warmth in the chilly California desert air. “Who has the guidebook?” [[Nellie]] [[Devi]] [[West]] “The guidebook is sticking out of your back pocket, Nellie,” said West, rolling his eyes. “Don’t give me that sass,” Nellie said, swatting playfully at West before bounding up to the front door. “Shouldn’t you look at the map first?” West asked, but he still followed, hoisting his camera onto his shoulder. “Pretty sure the entrance is the first step.” “You’d be 100% sure if you opened the guidebook.” “Can you all please annunciate, I’m having trouble picking you up,” Devi said as she followed them. “Oops, sorry, Devi. I’m not even clipped in yet.” Nellie didn’t notice that West held the door open for her as she stepped into the house, replacing the guidebook in her back pocket with the mic pack, securing the mic itself to her turtleneck. She was glad she dressed warm. If it was cold outside in the desert it was even colder in Bennington manor. She hefted her pack higher on her shoulder, slightly regretting the amount of snacks she had brought. But who knew how long they would be here? She wasn’t leaving until they got something good. Or, something she could edit later to make look compelling. But it shouldn’t be hard. Nellie craned her neck as she stared up at a ceiling of glass that curved upwards into a point, like the world’s most fragile circus tent. There was something strange about how the ceiling met the walls, neatly on the right but… shadowy on the left. It was asymmetrical, but it couldn’t have been, or it should have been slanted, right? Nellie could barely see the lights embedded in the frame that held the wide glass planes above them, but she counted the burnt-out bulbs and was surprised that there were more on the right than the left. Recounting them just made her dizzy. But it would make great B-roll, maybe for the intro - Nelli jumped when the door slammed shut behind them. Devi looked bored, already yawning even though it wasn’t even midnight yet, and she probably didn’t even notice Nellie’s reaction, but Nellie glared at West anyway. “It’s a heavy door,” West shrugged. “If the footage is wobbly, I swear I’ll-” “Fix it in post?” West suggested. “Guys. Be professional,” Devi said, one hand holding her headphones in place. “Okay, Nellie. What does the guidebook say?” Nellie opened the guidebook. “This is the entry room,” she said, careful to annunciate for Devi. “Riveting stuff,” West mumbled. “Okay then… This is the entry room of Bennington Mansion, constructed in 1975 by Bradford Bennington, oil tycoon, arms dealer, but more officially, movie producer. Wait, no, construction was completed in 1975, but started in 1969. It was beset by… wow, earthquakes, which made building hazardous. Ha. Understatement. Though he dreamed of making it a family home, but the time it was finished, his youngest was a teenager, and his oldest kids were enjoying the groovy times of disco. And hard drugs. But the mansion got a reputation for the dance parties, live music, and… oops, yeah, as a solid place to secure a mind-bending trip. Not the homely vibe he was going for but hey, he did manage to keep the family together. All of his children lived here until tragedy struck.” Nellie waited for Devi’s thumbs up then massaged her cheeks from the smile she had plastered on. “Until tragedy struck who?” West asked. “All of them,” Nellie said, exasperated. “An earthquake?” West asked. “Not all at once,” Devi interrupted. “How do you not know the stories?” “I never research a haunting before we film, it makes it more exciting.” “I didn’t research either,” Devi admitted. “But I know the legends. Even in elementary school my teachers would talk about the Bennington Mansion as, like, a morality slasher tale. One man, three children by three women, all living under the same roof? It was doomed.” "But very 70s, free love and all that," West said. “You learned that in elementary school?” Nellie asked, impressed. “Your teachers were hardcore. But don’t worry, West, I’ve got the guide, I did the research, I am our fearless leader-” “I forgot my phone in the car,” West said. “One sec.” Nellie watched him struggle with the door for long enough that she considered opening one of the granola bars in her pack. “Please don’t break it, we barely got permission to be here,” Devi finally said. “It’s like it’s locked,” West muttered, still fighting with the door. “This is the kind of thing I need you filming, not fighting against,” Nellie laughed. “Get me in frame. Shh. Viewers, we have just entered, and already the ghosts seem intent on keeping us here. You know what they always said… once you enter Bennington house, you’ll never want to leave. They probably said it because Bradford had an infamously well-stocked wine cellar, but of course, we get the ghastly version." West gave the door a strong kick while still filming and the door popped open. "Nevermind," he said. "I'll just be a minute." "Nope," said Nellie, blocking his path, making sure to stay in the shot. "You've lost your phone privileges by ruining a haunted moment. Also, it might mess with Devi's equipment. Shut the door and let’s go people!” West laughed and shut the door, lowering the camera. Devi gave her a thumbs up and after she turned away, Nellie’s wide smile dropped. She became a different person when she was “on.” There was always a bit of stress nagging at her when she saw the red recording light, but she liked that person who seemed so confident in the edits. Devi didn’t yawn when that Nellie was performing, and West didn’t talk back when she was in a monologue. That Nellie was powerful. The kind of Nellie that deserved nice things, like granola bars, and ten thousand subscribers. Maybe more. Chocolate cake and fifty thousand subscribers. “Where to, fearless leader?” West asked, and Nellie’s genuine smile didn’t hurt her cheeks nearly as much as her filmed version. Nellie skimmed the guidebook. "Let's see where the good stuff's at," Nellie laughed. "Ha, she's probably going to start pocketing shit by the time we hit our first room," West grinned. "I am not!" Nellie said, though she did enjoy keeping a thing or two from each shoot. "I can wait until... the third room. Probably." "Guys," said Devi. "Options. Let's go." “Dining Room to the right, or we can see the Séance... um pit? And whatever else is down the hall to the left.” [[Dining Room – Nellie’s Tour]] [[Hallway 1 – Nellie’s Tour]] West pulled the guidebook out of Nellie’s back pocket before she could claim her role as leader of the pack. “I’ll be in charge,” West said. He waited for Nellie and Devi to stop laughing. “Oh, you’re serious?” Nellie asked. “Yes,” West said. “Nellie, you need to focus on being the star, and Devi, you arranged this whole thing, you should get to take a break.” Nellie shrugged, but Devi looked suspicious. She had a right to be. This was going to be West’s last tour with Spooktacular Investigations, and he intended for it to be a short one. He was tired of ghosts. Nellie insisted that her crew have experience with the supernatural. She claimed a haunted history because of her childhood trauma that, to West, sounded more like an imaginary friend situation or mental illness than an actual haunting. Devi had that weird encounter with a voodoo doll ceremony. And he told them he saw his grandmother’s ghost after she died when he was six. Which was true. He just didn’t mention that he hadn’t stopped seeing ghosts since. There were already three lurking in the entry hall, and not the harmless confused kind. These timeless hippies were glaring at him, like they wanted him to leave. Well, he would make sure they were out as soon as possible. He couldn’t even appreciate the curving glass ceiling above him when he was distracted by the ghostly overlay of mid-century modern elegance flickering over the dilapidated reality the mansion. In especially haunted locations, reality seemed more like an option than… well, a reality. “Can you read the entry for this room, then?” Devi asked, arching an eyebrow at him and he pulled his attention away from the ghosts and back to the guidebook. “Why would I read the entries when we could just look at the pictures?” West asked, laughing, as he showed her the first page that featured a color-block illustration of three disco dancing faceless figures – a woman with a blond fringe, a girl in a frilly dress, and a man with a perfectly round afro. “Also, why would I read the entries now when you’ll just have Nellie record them later and add the voice over in post?” “So we’re not confused while we explore?” Devi asked, exasperated. “I know you did enough research beforehand to keep us on track,” Nellie said, surprising West by taking his side. “And if we know too much, we might try to see something that’s not actually there to match our expectations.” “I didn’t do any research,” Devi protested, then sighed in defeat. “But I know the legends. Even in elementary school my teachers would talk about the Bennington Mansion as, like, a morality slasher tale. One man, three children by three women, all seven of them living under the same roof? No wonder they met tragic ends. It was doomed.” "But very 70s, free love and all that," West said. He went to check the time, already anxious from loitering in the entry room this long, and realized his phone wasn’t in his pocket. “I forgot my phone in the car. One sec.” He went to open the door, and found that it wouldn’t budge. He gave the handle a few hard tugs. “Please don’t break it, we barely got permission to be here,” Devi sighed. “It’s like it’s locked,” West muttered, still fighting with the door. “This is the kind of thing you should be filming, not fighting against,” Nellie laughed, gesturing for West to shoot her, and he struggled to open the door and keep her in the shot. “Viewers, we have just entered, and already the ghosts seem intent on keeping us here. You know what they always said… once you enter Bennington Mansion, you’ll never want to leave. They probably said it because Bradford had an infamously well-stocked wine cellar, but of course, we get the ghastly version." West gave the door a strong kick while still filming and the door popped open. "Nevermind," he said. "I'll just be a minute." "Nope," said Nellie, blocking his path. "You've lost your phone privileges by ruining a haunted moment. Also, it might mess with Devi's equipment.” West laughed and shut the door, lowering the camera, and Devi gave a thumbs up to reassure them that she captured the audio. “Where to, fearless leader?” Nellie asked, grinning at him but there was an edge to her smile. “Show us where the good stuff’s at.” “Nellie, you are not taking any //souvenirs// from this mansion,” Devi warned her. Nellie shrugged at Devi and West flipped to the map at the front of the guidebook. “Okay,” he said. “The Dining Room is to the right, or the hallway continues to the left starting with the door to the Séance Pit.” [[Hallway 1 - West's Tour]] [[Dining Room - West's Tour]] Nellie had shoved the guidebook in her back pocket, but enough of it was sticking out that Devi was able to pull it free easily. “Hey!” Nellie protested. “I should be in charge. You’ll need to record me reading the entries anyway for the shoot.” “We’ll get better sound if we do that in post in the studio,” Devi said, already flipping to the first page that featured a color-block illustration of three disco dancing faceless figures – a woman with a blond fringe, a girl in a frilly dress, and a man with a perfectly round afro. “Besides, we don’t want to waste your voice reading every entry. When we get home, we can figure out what information is relevant based on what contact we make.” “Very logical,” Nellie agreed, but she sounded a little on edge. “You seem pretty confident that we’re going to make contact,” West said, settling the weight of the camera on his shoulder. “This is the Bennington Mansion, if we don’t get strange occult contact here then there is no strange occult stuff anywhere,” Devi said, letting West hold open the door to the Entry Room. It was cold in the mansion, colder than the desert air Nellie was rushing inside to escape. Devi had told her she needed to dress warmly, and it looked like their star’s turtleneck was not enough to protect against the chill. Devi was glad she wore her hoodie. It was a few sizes too big, making her tiny stature look even tinier, but it was warm, like filming while wrapped up in a blanket. Devi took a brief moment to admire the ceiling of glass above them that curved upwards into a point, like Devi’s Nana’s crystal bowls that always seemed too fragile and sharp to use safely. The ceiling met the walls neatly on the right but disappeared into shadows on the left as it continued over a connecting room on the upper floor. Devi couldn’t remember which one it was, but she guessed they would find out as they explored. Staring up at the ceiling made her dizzy, so she turned her attention to the guidebook and read from the introductory page. “This is the entry room of Bennington Mansion, built and designed by Bradford Bennington, oil tycoon, arms dealer, and movie producer. Construction was completed in 1975, but started in 1969. Several earthquakes that occurred during the building process created hazardous conditions that slowed construction, but Bradford insisted that the mansion had to be built on this exact location to his exact specifications. Though Bennington dreamed of making it a family home, by the time it was finished, his youngest was a teenager with little interest in forming a close relationship with her much older siblings. His other children were distracted by thrills of disco and rock’n’roll, lured by the party scene of the time and indulging in recreational drug use. The mansion got a reputation for dance parties, live music, and famed séances performed by several members of the Bennington family (particularly Bradford’s three lovers) that made contact with spirits from other dimensions. All of his children lived here until tragedy struck.” “Until tragedy struck who?” West asked. “All of them,” Devi said, incredulous. “How do you not know the stories?” “I never research a haunting before we film, it makes it more exciting.” “I didn’t research either,” Devi admitted. “But I know the legends. Even in elementary school my teachers would talk about the Bennington Mansion as, like, a morality slasher tale. One man, three children by three women, all living under the same roof? It was doomed.” "But very 70s, free love and all that," West said. “You learned that in elementary school?” Nellie asked, impressed. “Your teachers were hardcore.” Devi coughed, and hoped her crew members didn't guess she was hiding something. Her mother's history with the Bennington mansion, her secrets from the past, were not Devi's to tell. “You should film Nellie admiring the glass or something,” Devi said. “And I can see if we pick anything up in the audio.” “I forgot my phone in the car,” West said. “One sec.” Devi read ahead a few pages, not realizing that West was struggling with the door until she heard Nellie snort a laugh. “Please don’t break it, we barely got permission to be here,” Devi sighed. “It’s like it’s locked,” West muttered, still fighting with the door. “This is the kind of thing you should be filming, not fighting against,” Nellie laughed, gesturing for Devi to record, as if Devi wasn’t recording everything all the time. “Get me in frame. Shh. Viewers, we have just entered, and already the ghosts seem intent on keeping us here. You know what they always said… once you enter Bennington Mansion, you’ll never want to leave. They probably said it because Bradford had an infamously well-stocked wine cellar, but of course, we get the ghastly version." West gave the door a strong kick while still filming and the door popped open. "Nevermind," he said. "I'll just be a minute." "Nope," said Nellie, blocking his path, making sure to stay in the shot. "You've lost your phone privileges by ruining a haunted moment. Also, it might mess with Devi's equipment.” West laughed and shut the door, lowering the camera, and Devi gave a thumbs up to reassure Nellie that she captured the audio. She could listen back later to see if there were any extra voices, whispers, knocks, all that necessary tedious work. In many ways, the exploration was the easiest part of her job. At least for this one, she had managed to steal the role of reading guidebook entries. It would keep her from nodding off in one of the rooms. West would have used her napping as proof that she didn’t actually think they would make contact, but the truth was she just wasn’t worried about the ghosts. She was sure they had made a few connections in the past with the spirit world, but none of those had come close to being frightening. The most frightening thing she had come into contact with so far on this job was the owner, a severe woman with Botox-tight skin who grilled Devi like she expected they were only getting permission to film there in order to rob the place. “Where to, fearless leader?” West asked, and Devi couldn’t tell if he was mocking her. “Let’s see where the good stuff’s at,” Nellie laughed. “Ha, she's probably going to start pocketing shit by the time we hit our first room," West grinned. “Not with me in charge she’s not,” Devi said, and West and Nellie both nodded sheepishly under her glare like mischievous children. Devi glanced at the guidebook. “Okay. The Dining Room is to the right, or the hallway continues to the left starting with the door to the Séance Pit.” [[Dining Room - Devi's Tour]] [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour]] “Since I am left-handed, we shall be going left,” Nellie said. “Flawless logic,” West laughed, but Nellie was pleased that he followed her all the same. “Hold on guys,” said Devi. Nellie stumbled in her skip and made a conscious effort not to resent Devi for breaking her stride. “Is that…” Devi was staring intently at a photo on the wall. Nellie thought the woman looked vaguely familiar, probably one of the Bennington family members. She knew she should have flipped through the guidebook to find out which one, but the way that Devi was staring so intently unsteadied her. That, or the way the woman looked directly at the frame, like she was looking at them, looking at Nellie. Like she wanted to be seen behind that fluffy blond fringe, like should couldn’t help but always be “on” for her camera. She smiled like she was happy. Her fringe drooped like she was exhausted. “Is that David Bowie?” Devi finally asked. “Oh shit, it is!” West said, and Nellie realized she was right. The man who had casually tossed his arm over the woman’s shoulder was definitely David Bowie. “Holy shit, Mick Jagger is in this pic!” Nellie vaguely noticed West pan down the pictures clustered in this part of the hall, but she could not tear her attention away from the woman, her smiling mouth, her sad eyes, how her hand gripped Bowie’s like the contact was the only thing keeping her here. Like she couldn’t bear being alone in the frame. Devi’s touch on Nellie’s shoulder was gentle. West didn’t seem to notice that anything was wrong, he was so completely enthralled with the celebrities partying in a distant past with the doomed Benningtons. “Looks like we have options,” Devi said. “Where to next?” [[Groove Room – Nellie’s Tour]] [[Séance Room – Nellie’s Tour]] [[Girls’ Bathroom – Nellie’s Tour]] [[Hallway 2 - Nellie's Tour]] Nellie looked around the room in wonder. It was large, built large but the wide steps that led to an indented space in the center that must have been a dance floor made it look even larger. A disco ball still hung above it, ready to shimmer, if only there was light. Nellie thought there might have been at least an nearly full moon out, but the small porthole windows did not let in enough light to allow the lazily turning disco ball to do its magic. Nellie did not know where the breeze came from. She didn’t feel one. It could have been a breeze from the memory of people dancing, living, in this room covered floor to wall in a green shaggy carpet material. She rested her hand on the wall closest to the door, surprised as how dry it was, how soft it still felt under her hand. She knew there were plumbing issues in the building and expected dampness and immediately, grimy regret. West and Devi passed by her, West filming the disco ball, then closing in on the carpeted green stairs that led to some unknown location, while Devi listened intently to her headphones. “This place is…” West began. “I know,” said Nellie, her voice full of awe. She knew that the room had seen better days, but god, she loved that joy of the 70s, the disco vibes that brought people together more than the drinks or drugs ever could. Devi was saying something, concerned once again about the sound, and Nellie could hear West placating her, but she didn’t care. She could imagine the music that was swallowed by this soft green room, by the smooth bodies that writhed together. Her arms caught a beat that only she could hear, her hips swaying to a base riff from her imagination. “Doing okay, Nellie?” West asked with a chuckle. She looked up just in time to see that he was filming and gave a few extra turns just for the camera. “Anything ghostly going on?” she asked them when the rhythm faded from her body. “Devi thought she heard a song,” West said. “A disco song?” Nellie asked, her heart skipping a beat, but West shook his head. “It was quiet,” said Devi. “Hard to make out. I’ll play it back when we get home.” “I bet it was contact,” Nellie grinned and Devi did something between a headshake and a shrug, indecipherable to Nellie but that was fine. Devi would tease out the sound, and even if it was nothing, she could make it something with the right gothic soundtrack behind it. “Anything we should know about this room?” West asked. “They called it the Groove Room,” Nellie said and shook her head at West and Devi’s disbelief. “It was a very 70s thing, to have a space specifically for grooving. Those rock stars in the hall definitely came in here to groove.” “What a decade,” West said, and Nellie grinned in agreement. “Unfortunately, without anyone to groove in here, this room is… um… dead, even for a haunted house. There are some groovy stairs we can check out, or back to the hallway.” [[Hallway 1 - Nellie's Tour Cont. From Groove Room]] [[Upper Séance Room - Nellie's Tour]] The salmon pink of the tiles, toilet, and tub made Nellie want to throw up. Like looking at pictures of her swollen throat at the doctor’s office after the bad bulimia episode. An inside view that should never be outside. “Looks like a bathroom,” said West, nodding officially to himself. Nellie opened the guidebook, if anything for an excuse to look away from the pink. “Says here that it’s specifically the Girls’ Bathroom,” she said. “Like, a gendered bathroom for parties?” West asked. “Is there a boys’ bathroom somewhere?” “No, one sec,” said Nellie, skimming the chunk of text. “It was used for the public who came for parties or Bradford’s more intimate get-togethers, but privately, it was for the girls to use. The daughters and the wives.” “Wives, multiple?” West asked. “Yeah, I guess, there’s not anymore info on that on this page, but I did know he was a misogynistic creep,” Nellie said, flipping through the book before settling back on her page. “Okay, so the five girls, um, women I mean, Bradford's three lovers and two daughters would use this bathroom and it led to a lot of drama, blah, blah, blah-” “Fascinating stuff, Nellie,” said West. “In conclusion, it’s a bathroom, and it was themed for the girls,” Nellie said, snapping the book shut. “There’s no boy-themed bathroom, if you’re wondering,” Devi quietly added, making both Nellie and West jump from her sudden presence behind them. “Bradford and his son had private bathrooms connected to their bedrooms. But there was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and they got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. So if you want bathroom footage, now’s the time.” [[Hallway 1 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom)]] [[Explore the Tub - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom]] [[Explore the Toilet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom]] Nellie tried to catch the eye of the woman with the fringe once more, but whatever strange connection she had felt before was gone. Nellie shook her head. There was no reason to feel so forlorn. “Next stop?” West asked. [[Séance Room - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]] [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]] [[Hallway 2- Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]]“Holy shit,” Nellie whispered. “West, are you getting this?” “Please, both of you,” Desi pleaded, standing by herself at the top of the stairs. “Stay a little further away from the giant hole in the floor leading down to…” “The Pit,” Nellie grinned. God, it looked terrifying. It was perfect. Even if they didn’t get any ghostly encounters, this was just so haunted. No matter how hard she looked, Nellie only saw darkness. Who knew how deep it went? Who knew how long she would fall if she just tipped over the edge? Nellie didn’t want to tip over the edge, but what a way to go, right? Falling into some Amityville-style Hell portal. They would get so many views. “How about less leaning over the death hole and more reading from the guidebook?” Devi suggested. Nellie pulled out the book, distracted by the darkness in front of her. “Okay, so, while Bradford might have preferred to keep the séance room secure in the case terrible dark forces got out, his kids used this room for more… private party activities.” “You are not suggesting that this hole is the result of violent 1970s sex, are you?” West laughed. “No, apparently the damage originated on the ground floor, in the main séance room,” Nellie said, frowning as she read. “That doesn’t quite make sense. The giant hole is up here.” “An earthquake at the time caused structural damage to a lot of the mansion, and is said to have upset some poorly made support beams that collapsed, making the center of the floor collapse,” Devi said. “But some people think there was an explosion of dark energy after a séance went wrong, and the explosion caused the hole. It was in the papers. And my mom remembered it.” “Doesn’t look burnt…” Nellie murmured as she touched the edge of the green carpet, torn and drooping towards the darkness below. “Maybe dark energy doesn’t burn,” West said. “Most of the dark energy we’ve faced has been cold.” “I don’t trust you two to keep your balance,” Devi said, cutting off their speculation. “Come on. We’ve leaving.” [[Hallway 1 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room and Séance Room)]]Nellie looked around the room in wonder. It was large, built large but the wide steps that led to an indented space in the center that must have been a dance floor made it look even larger. A disco ball still hung above it, ready to shimmer, if only there was light. Nellie thought there might have been at least an nearly full moon out, but the small porthole windows did not let in enough light to allow the lazily turning disco ball to do its magic. Nellie did not know where the breeze came from. She didn’t feel one. It could have been a breeze from the memory of people dancing, living, in this room covered floor to wall in a green shaggy carpet material. She rested her hand on the wall closest to the door, surprised as how dry it was, how soft it still felt under her hand. She knew there were plumbing issues in the building and expected dampness and immediately, grimy regret. West and Devi passed by her, West filming the disco ball, then closing in on the carpeted green stairs that led to some unknown location, while Devi listened intently to her headphones. “This place is…” West began. “I know,” said Nellie, her voice full of awe. She knew that the room had seen better days, but god, she loved that joy of the 70s, the disco vibes that brought people together more than the drinks or drugs ever could. Devi was saying something, concerned once again about the sound, and Nellie could hear West placating her, but she didn’t care. She could imagine the music that was swallowed by this soft green room, by the smooth bodies that writhed together. Her arms caught a beat that only she could hear, her hips swaying to a base riff from her imagination. “Doing okay, Nellie?” West asked with a chuckle. She looked up just in time to see that he was filming and gave a few extra turns just for the camera. “Anything ghostly going on?” she asked them when the rhythm faded from her body. “Devi thought she heard a song,” West said. “A disco song?” Nellie asked, her heart skipping a beat, but West shook his head. “It was quiet,” said Devi. “Hard to make out. I’ll play it back when we get home.” “I bet it was contact,” Nellie grinned and Devi did something between a headshake and a shrug, indecipherable to Nellie but that was fine. Devi would tease out the sound, and even if it was nothing, she could make it something with the right gothic soundtrack behind it. “Anything we should know about this room?” West asked. “They called it the Groove Room,” Nellie said and shook her head at West and Devi’s disbelief. “It was a very 70s thing, to have a space specifically for grooving. Those rock stars in the hall definitely came in here to groove.” “What a decade,” West said, and Nellie grinned in agreement. “Unfortunately, without anyone to groove in here, this room is… um… dead, even for a haunted house. There are some groovy stairs we can check out, or back to the hallway.” [[Hallway 1 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room and Séance Room)]] [[Upper Séance Room - Nellie's Tour]]Nellie tried the handle of the Séance Room. It was firmly locked, but even the slight pressure Nellie put on it made the hinges groan with a dying cry. Nellie wished she had said that bit out loud. It was the perfect amount of melodrama for her hands. Devi pulled back on Nellie’s shoulder. “Okay miss I’ve-got-the-guidebook,” Devi said, teasing but not mean. “The ground floor of the Séance Room is now the Séance Room Pit.” “Damn, Nellie,” West said. “You were going to lead us into the pit.” Nellie hoped the shadows hid her blush from West’s camera. She shouldn’t make these kinds of mistakes. This was her show. She was the face of the show. She was the fearless leader. She had the guidebook. “Well if they were so worried about the danger, they would have reinforced the door,” Nellie huffed. She tested her weight against the groaning hinges and Devi winced. “I could push this open if I had to. Hell, Devi could do it if she had to.” “I could do it without trying,” West offered. “Yeah, West, I know, I was making a point… Forget it,” said Nellie. “Let’s keep going.” [[Hallway 1 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room and Séance Room)]] The salmon pink of the tiles, toilet, and tub made Nellie want to throw up. Like looking at pictures of her swollen throat at the doctor’s office after the bad bulimia episode. An inside view that should never be outside. “Looks like a bathroom,” said West, nodding officially to himself. Nellie opened the guidebook, if anything for an excuse to look away from the pink. “Says here that it’s specifically the Girls’ Bathroom,” she said. “Like, a gendered bathroom for parties?” West asked. “Is there a boys’ bathroom somewhere?” “No, one sec,” said Nellie, skimming the chunk of text. “It was used for the public who came for parties or Bradford’s more intimate get-togethers, but privately, it was for the girls to use. The daughters and the wives.” “Wives, multiple?” West asked. “Yeah, I guess, there’s not anymore info on that on this page, but I did know he was a misogynistic creep,” Nellie said, flipping through the book before settling back on her page. “Okay, so the five girls, um, women I mean, Bradford's three lovers and two daughters would use this bathroom and it led to a lot of drama, blah, blah, blah-” “Fascinating stuff, Nellie,” said West. “In conclusion, it’s a bathroom, and it was themed for the girls,” Nellie said, snapping the book shut. “There’s no boy-themed bathroom, if you’re wondering,” Devi quietly added, making both Nellie and West jump from her sudden presence behind them. “Bradford and his son had private bathrooms connected to their bedrooms. But there was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and they got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. So if you want bathroom footage, now’s the time.” [[Explore the Tub - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Groove Room)]] [[Explore the Toilet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Groove Room)]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Groove Room)]]Nellie tried to catch the eye of the woman with the fringe once more, but whatever strange connection she had felt before was gone. Nellie shook her head. There was no reason to feel so forlorn. [[Séance Room - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom)]] [[Groove Room - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom)]] [[Hallway 2 - Nellie's Tour]]Nellie put her hand over her nose. It smelled almost like… chicken soup? She had to assume that the smell was coming from the brown goop congealed around the tub’s plug. “Are you going to touch it?” asked West. “Don’t touch it,” said Devi. “I’m not going to touch it!” Nellie snapped. She kind of wanted to, though. It was like the smell. It attracted and repulsed her. A bad memory of childhood sickness that you could never forget. [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom)]] Nellie leaned over the toilet. “Don’t think we have time for that, Nel,” West mumbled. “What the Hell, West?” Nellie snapped at him, but if West’s continued mumbles were an apology, she did not care. “And you two were doing so well at getting along,” Devi sighed. “Did you hear… Whatever,” Nellie said, deflating a little though she knew she was as pink as the room. “Screw you, West.” [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom)]] “Anything illegal in there?” Devi asked. “Devi!” Nellie gasped and West chuckled with her. “I just mean… this place has a reputation and that’s a medicine cabinet.” “And when a place has a reputation like this one does, you’re not going to find any remnants of a fun time fifty years after the party ended,” Nellie joked. “Actually, you probably wouldn’t find anything halfway through the party. The Benningtons went hard. But…” Nellie pulled a white ribbon out of the cabinet. It was carefully wound, but Nellie did not think twice before unwinding it to its full length. “Thrilling,” West said dryly. “Ribbons were big in the 70s,” Devi said, a faint smile on her lips. “Like The Cars’ song. 'Perfume... ribbons.. etc...’” Nellie hummed the tune to the song, rocking a bit to an imaginary beat. “Did you get that?” she asked and West gave a thumbs up. As her crew left the bathroom, Nellie tucked the ribbon into her pocket. [[Hallway 1 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom with Ribbon)]]"I'm getting a little tired of this hallway, Nellie," West grumbled. [[Hallway 2- Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]] [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room and Séance Room)]] "We have time to explore a bit more," Devi said. [[Explore the Cabinet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom]] Nellie put her hand over her nose. It smelled almost like… chicken soup? She had to assume that the smell was coming from the brown goop congealed around the tub’s plug. “Are you going to touch it?” asked West. “Don’t touch it,” said Devi. “I’m not going to touch it!” Nellie snapped. She kind of wanted to, though. It was like the smell. It attracted and repulsed her. A bad memory of childhood sickness that you could never forget. [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Groove Room)]] Nellie leaned over the toilet. “Don’t think we have time for that, Nel,” West mumbled. “What the Hell, West?” Nellie snapped at him, but if West’s continued mumbles were an apology, she did not care. “And you two were doing so well at getting along,” Devi sighed. “Did you hear… Whatever,” Nellie said, deflating a little though she knew she was as pink as the room. “Screw you, West." [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Groove Room)]]“Anything illegal in there?” Devi asked. “Devi!” Nellie gasped and West chuckled with her. “I just mean… this place has a reputation and that’s a medicine cabinet.” “And when a place has a reputation like this one does, you’re not going to find any remnants of a fun time fifty years after the party ended,” Nellie joked. “Actually, you probably wouldn’t find anything halfway through the party. The Benningtons went hard. But…” Nellie pulled a white ribbon out of the cabinet. It was carefully wound, but Nellie did not think twice before unwinding it to its full length. “Thrilling,” West said dryly. “Ribbons were big in the 70s,” Devi said, a faint smile on her lips. “Like The Cars’ song. 'Perfume... ribbons.. etc...’” Nellie hummed the tune to the song, rocking a bit to an imaginary beat. “Did you get that?” she asked and West gave a thumbs up. As her crew left the bathroom, Nellie tucked the ribbon into her pocket. [[Hallway 1 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. From Girls' Bathroom with Ribbon and Groove Room)]]"Why are we still in this bathroom?" West asked. [[Explore the Cabinet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Groove Room)]] [[Hallway 1 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Groove Room)]]"Any last stops?" Devi asked. [[Séance Room – Nellie’s Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Groove Room)]] [[Hallway 2- Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]]"Any last stops?" Devi asked. [[Séance Room - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom with Ribbon and Groove Room)]] [[Hallway 2 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]]The salmon pink of the tiles, toilet, and tub made Nellie want to throw up. Like looking at pictures of her swollen throat at the doctor’s office after the bad bulimia episode. An inside view that should never be outside. “Looks like a bathroom,” said West, nodding officially to himself. Nellie opened the guidebook, if anything for an excuse to look away from the pink. “Says here that it’s specifically the Girls’ Bathroom,” she said. “Like, a gendered bathroom for parties?” West asked. “Is there a boys’ bathroom somewhere?” “No, one sec,” said Nellie, skimming the chunk of text. “It was used for the public who came for parties or Bradford’s more intimate get-togethers, but privately, it was for the girls to use. The daughters and the wives.” “Wives, multiple?” West asked. “Yeah, I guess, there’s not anymore info on that on this page, but I did know he was a misogynistic creep,” Nellie said, flipping through the book before settling back on her page. “Okay, so the five girls, um, women I mean, Bradford's three lovers and two daughters would use this bathroom and it led to a lot of drama, blah, blah, blah-” “Fascinating stuff, Nellie,” said West. “In conclusion, it’s a bathroom, and it was themed for the girls,” Nellie said, snapping the book shut. “There’s no boy-themed bathroom, if you’re wondering,” Devi quietly added, making both Nellie and West jump from her sudden presence behind them. “Bradford and his son had private bathrooms connected to their bedrooms. But there was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and they got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. So if you want bathroom footage, now’s the time." [[Explore the Tub - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room and Séance Room)]] [[Explore the Toilet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room and Séance Room)]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room and Séance Room)]]Nellie tried the handle of the Séance Room. It was firmly locked, but even the slight pressure Nellie put on it made the hinges groan with a dying cry. Nellie wished she had said that bit out loud. It was the perfect amount of melodrama for her hands. Devi pulled back on Nellie’s shoulder. “Hey, fearless leader,” Devi said. “This is the ground floor of the Séance Room. The Séance Room Pit.” “Damn, Nellie,” West said. “You were going to lead us into the Pit.” Nellie hoped the shadows hid her blush from West’s camera. She shouldn’t make these kinds of mistakes. This was her show. She was the face of the show. She was the fearless leader. She had the guidebook. “Well if they were so worried about the danger, they would have reinforced the door,” Nellie huffed. She tested her weight against the groaning hinges and Devi winced. “I could push this open if I had to. Hell, Devi could do it if she had to.” “I could do it without trying,” West offered. “Yeah, West, I know, I was making a point… Forget it,” said Nellie. “Let’s keep going.” [[Hallway 2- Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]]Nellie shivered. “You alright, Nel?” asked Devi. “Getting some static on the mic.” “Sorry.” “Did anyone else feel it get colder?” asked West. Nellie shook her head. She didn’t feel it get colder. That wasn’t why she shivered. As they rounded the curve, it was like… well, not like she could feel someone’s eyes on the back of her head. More like, she couldn’t feel someone’s eyes on the back of her head anymore. She had been observed, but not anymore. It was always a terrible feeling for Nellie. That feeling of the camera being shut off, of going home, pulling the covers over your head and waiting to work, to get it done, to post it, to see the likes come in, to be seen. “I wasn’t paying attention,” said Devi, frowning at her briefcase like it held all of her problems, and if it was a sound problem then it probably did. “But I believe you.” “Maybe I should have worn a jacket,” West shrugged. “You guys came prepared.” Nellie rested her hand on the wall. It was colder in here. “West. Film,” she demanded, before turning to the red light and smirking. “I think we have company, viewers. Does anyone want to make contact? It’s safe here. We’re listening.” Despite the silliness of its name, Spooktacular Investigations didn’t use EVP, radio channels, any of the tricks popular on other streaming shows because as far as Nellie was concerned, they were just tricks. All you need to communicate was an open mind. An entire team of open minds. All three of them had a history of paranormal connection. All of them had proved to the other side that they were willing to lend an ear. Nellie counted thirty seconds of silence before she shrugged at the camera. “Guess they’re shy. We’ve got some chilly, shy ghosts or demons in the mansion.” “Maybe I should play ‘Running With the Devil,’” Devi suggested. “Only if we’re desperate for contact,” Nellie said. She pulled out the guidebook, allowing its weight and vintage cartoons of stars (or pentagrams?) to pull her back to the mundane of reality. Nothing really “haunted” had happened yet. Devi might have heard something in the groove room, but Nellie wouldn’t be satisfied unless she heard it herself. Half the time Devi thought she could some otherworldly voice it was the sound of the mic picking up the friction from Nellie’s turtleneck. Maybe she should stop wearing turtlenecks. “It smells a little… funky,” West said, wrinkling his nose. “The 70s were a funky time,” Devi grinned. “These three rooms belonged to Bradford’s children,” Nellie said. “Again, they lived here as adults, except the youngest. And they should be… ah!” Nellie pointed at the molding mantels above each door, where pieces of metal twisted into the shape of a letter were still securely nailed: M, T, D. “What’s the plan, Nel?” asked West. “We probably have time to explore two of the rooms.” [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Groove Room)]] [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Groove Room)]] [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Groove Room)]]Nellie tried the handle of the Séance Room. It was firmly locked, but even the slight pressure Nellie put on it made the hinges groan with a dying cry. Nellie wished she had said that bit out loud. It was the perfect amount of melodrama for her hands. Devi pulled back on Nellie’s shoulder. “Hey, fearless leader,” Devi said. “This is the ground floor of the Séance Room. The Séance Room Pit.” “Damn, Nellie,” West said. “You were going to lead us into the Pit.” Nellie hoped the shadows hid her blush from West’s camera. She shouldn’t make these kinds of mistakes. This was her show. She was the face of the show. She was the fearless leader. She had the guidebook. “Well if they were so worried about the danger, they would have reinforced the door,” Nellie huffed. She tested her weight against the groaning hinges and Devi winced. “I could push this open if I had to. Hell, Devi could do it if she had to.” “I could do it without trying,” West offered. “Yeah, West, I know, I was making a point… Forget it,” said Nellie. “Let’s keep going.” [[Hallway 2 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]]Nellie shivered. “You alright, Nel?” asked Devi. “Getting some static on the mic.” “Sorry.” “Did anyone else feel it get colder?” asked West. Nellie shook her head. She didn’t feel it get colder. That wasn’t why she shivered. As they rounded the curve, it was like… well, not like she could feel someone’s eyes on the back of her head. More like, she couldn’t feel someone’s eyes on the back of her head anymore. She had been observed, but not anymore. It was always a terrible feeling for Nellie. That feeling of the camera being shut off, of going home, pulling the covers over your head and waiting to work, to get it done, to post it, to see the likes come in, to be seen. “I wasn’t paying attention,” said Devi, frowning at her briefcase like it held all of her problems, and if it was a sound problem then it probably did. “But I believe you.” “Maybe I should have worn a jacket,” West shrugged. “You guys came prepared.” Nellie rested her hand on the wall. It was colder in here. “West. Film,” she demanded, before turning to the red light and smirking. “I think we have company, viewers. Does anyone want to make contact? It’s safe here. We’re listening.” Despite the silliness of its name, Spooktacular Investigations didn’t use EVP, radio channels, any of the tricks popular on other streaming shows because as far as Nellie was concerned, they were just tricks. All you need to communicate was an open mind. An entire team of open minds. All three of them had a history of paranormal connection. All of them had proved to the other side that they were willing to lend an ear. Nellie counted thirty seconds of silence before she shrugged at the camera. “Guess they’re shy. We’ve got some chilly, shy ghosts or demons in the mansion.” “Maybe I should play ‘Running With the Devil,’” Devi suggested. “Only if we’re desperate for contact,” Nellie said. She pulled out the guidebook, allowing its weight and vintage cartoons of stars (or pentagrams?) to pull her back to the mundane of reality. Nothing really “haunted” had happened yet. Devi might have heard something in the groove room, but Nellie wouldn’t be satisfied unless she heard it herself. Half the time Devi thought she could some otherworldly voice it was the sound of the mic picking up the friction from Nellie’s turtleneck. Maybe she should stop wearing turtlenecks. “It smells a little… funky,” West said, wrinkling his nose. “The 70s were a funky time,” Devi grinned. “These three rooms belonged to Bradford’s children,” Nellie said. “Again, they lived here as adults, except the youngest. And they should be… ah!” Nellie pointed at the molding mantels above each door, where pieces of metal twisted into the shape of a letter were still securely nailed: M, T, D. “What’s the plan, Nel?” asked West. “We probably have time to explore two of the rooms.” [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Groove Room with Ribbon)]] [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Groove Room with Ribbon)]] [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Groove Room with Ribbon)]]Nellie put her hand over her nose. It smelled almost like… chicken soup? She had to assume that the smell was coming from the brown goop congealed around the tub’s plug. “Are you going to touch it?” asked West. “Don’t touch it,” said Devi. “I’m not going to touch it!” Nellie snapped. She kind of wanted to, though. It was like the smell. It attracted and repulsed her. A bad memory of childhood sickness that you could never forget. [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom, Groove Room, and Séance Room)]] Nellie leaned over the toilet. “Don’t think we have time for that, Nel,” West mumbled. “What the Hell, West?” Nellie snapped at him, but if West’s continued mumbles were an apology, she did not care. “And you two were doing so well at getting along,” Devi sighed. “Did you hear… Whatever,” Nellie said, deflating a little though she knew she was as pink as the room. “Screw you, West." [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom, Groove Room, and Séance Room)]]“Anything illegal in there?” Devi asked. “Devi!” Nellie gasped and West chuckled with her. “I just mean… this place has a reputation and that’s a medicine cabinet.” “And when a place has a reputation like this one does, you’re not going to find any remnants of a fun time fifty years after the party ended,” Nellie joked. “Actually, you probably wouldn’t find anything halfway through the party. The Benningtons went hard. But…” Nellie pulled a white ribbon out of the cabinet. It was carefully wound, but Nellie did not think twice before unwinding it to its full length. “Thrilling,” West said dryly. “Ribbons were big in the 70s,” Devi said, a faint smile on her lips. “Like The Cars’ song. 'Perfume... ribbons.. etc...’” Nellie hummed the tune to the song, rocking a bit to an imaginary beat. “Did you get that?” she asked and West gave a thumbs up. As her crew left the bathroom, Nellie tucked the ribbon into her pocket. [[Hallway 2 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]]"Weird tile," Nellie shuddered. [[Explore the Cabinet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room and Séance Room)]] [[Hallway 2- Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]]Nellie looked around the room in wonder. It was large, built large but the wide steps that led to an indented space in the center that must have been a dance floor made it look even larger. A disco ball still hung above it, ready to shimmer, if only there was light. Nellie thought there might have been at least an nearly full moon out, but the small porthole windows did not let in enough light to allow the lazily turning disco ball to do its magic. Nellie did not know where the breeze came from. She didn’t feel one. It could have been a breeze from the memory of people dancing, living, in this room covered floor to wall in a green shaggy carpet material. She rested her hand on the wall closest to the door, surprised as how dry it was, how soft it still felt under her hand. She knew there were plumbing issues in the building and expected dampness and immediately, grimy regret. West and Devi passed by her, West filming the disco ball, then closing in on the carpeted green stairs that led to some unknown location, while Devi listened intently to her headphones. “This place is…” West began. “I know,” said Nellie, her voice full of awe. She knew that the room had seen better days, but god, she loved that joy of the 70s, the disco vibes that brought people together more than the drinks or drugs ever could. Devi was saying something, concerned once again about the sound, and Nellie could hear West placating her, but she didn’t care. She could imagine the music that was swallowed by this soft green room, by the smooth bodies that writhed together. Her arms caught a beat that only she could hear, her hips swaying to a base riff from her imagination. “Doing okay, Nellie?” West asked with a chuckle. She looked up just in time to see that he was filming and gave a few extra turns just for the camera. “Anything ghostly going on?” she asked them when the rhythm faded from her body. “Devi thought she heard a song,” West said. “A disco song?” Nellie asked, her heart skipping a beat, but West shook his head. “It was quiet,” said Devi. “Hard to make out. I’ll play it back when we get home.” “I bet it was contact,” Nellie grinned and Devi did something between a headshake and a shrug, indecipherable to Nellie but that was fine. Devi would tease out the sound, and even if it was nothing, she could make it something with the right gothic soundtrack behind it. “Anything we should know about this room?” West asked. “They called it the Groove Room,” Nellie said and shook her head at West and Devi’s disbelief. “It was a very 70s thing, to have a space specifically for grooving. Those rock stars in the hall definitely came in here to groove.” “What a decade,” West said, and Nellie grinned in agreement. “Unfortunately, without anyone to groove in here, this room is… um… dead, even for a haunted house. There are some groovy stairs we can check out, or back to the hallway.” [[Upper Séance Room - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom)]] [[Hallway 1 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Groove Room)]] Nellie tried the handle of the Séance Room. It was firmly locked, but even the slight pressure Nellie put on it made the hinges groan with a dying cry. Nellie wished she had said that bit out loud. It was the perfect amount of melodrama for her hands. Devi pulled back on Nellie’s shoulder. “Hey, fearless leader,” Devi said. “This is the ground floor of the Séance Room. The Séance Room Pit.” “Damn, Nellie,” West said. “You were going to lead us into the Pit.” Nellie hoped the shadows hid her blush from West’s camera. She shouldn’t make these kinds of mistakes. This was her show. She was the face of the show. She was the fearless leader. She had the guidebook. “Well if they were so worried about the danger, they would have reinforced the door,” Nellie huffed. She tested her weight against the groaning hinges and Devi winced. “I could push this open if I had to. Hell, Devi could do it if she had to.” “I could do it without trying,” West offered. “Yeah, West, I know, I was making a point… Forget it,” said Nellie. “Let’s keep going.” [[Groove Room - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom and Séance Room)]] [[Hallway 2 - Nellie's Tour]]Nellie shivered. “You alright, Nel?” asked Devi. “Getting some static on the mic.” “Sorry.” “Did anyone else feel it get colder?” asked West. Nellie shook her head. She didn’t feel it get colder. That wasn’t why she shivered. As they rounded the curve, it was like… well, not like she could feel someone’s eyes on the back of her head. More like, she couldn’t feel someone’s eyes on the back of her head anymore. She had been observed, but not anymore. It was always a terrible feeling for Nellie. That feeling of the camera being shut off, of going home, pulling the covers over your head and waiting to work, to get it done, to post it, to see the likes come in, to be seen. “I wasn’t paying attention,” said Devi, frowning at her briefcase like it held all of her problems, and if it was a sound problem then it probably did. “But I believe you.” “Maybe I should have worn a jacket,” West shrugged. “You guys came prepared.” Nellie rested her hand on the wall. It was colder in here. “West. Film,” she demanded, before turning to the red light and smirking. “I think we have company, viewers. Does anyone want to make contact? It’s safe here. We’re listening.” Despite the silliness of its name, Spooktacular Investigations didn’t use EVP, radio channels, any of the tricks popular on other streaming shows because as far as Nellie was concerned, they were just tricks. All you need to communicate was an open mind. An entire team of open minds. All three of them had a history of paranormal connection. All of them had proved to the other side that they were willing to lend an ear. Nellie counted thirty seconds of silence before she shrugged at the camera. “Guess they’re shy. We’ve got some chilly, shy ghosts or demons in the mansion.” “Maybe I should play ‘Running With the Devil,’” Devi suggested. “Only if we’re desperate for contact,” Nellie said. She pulled out the guidebook, allowing its weight and vintage cartoons of stars (or pentagrams?) to pull her back to the mundane of reality. Nothing really “haunted” had happened yet. Maybe this would just be one of those episodes that focused on the house’s architecture and the owner’s taste. She shifted on the thick shag carpet, eyeing the cracked popcorn ceiling before she skimmed the pages. Perhaps it would focus on the owner’s tastelessness. “It smells a little… funky,” West said, wrinkling his nose. “The 70s were a funky time,” Devi grinned. “These three rooms belonged to Bradford’s children,” Nellie said. “Again, they lived here as adults, except the youngest. And they should be… ah!” Nellie pointed at the molding mantels above each door, where pieces of metal twisted into the shape of a letter were still securely nailed: M, T, D. “What’s the plan, Nel?” asked West. "We probably have time to explore two of the rooms." [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour]] [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour]] [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour]]Nellie looked around the room in wonder. It was large, built large but the wide steps that led to an indented space in the center that must have been a dance floor made it look even larger. A disco ball still hung above it, ready to shimmer, if only there was light. Nellie thought there might have been at least an nearly full moon out, but the small porthole windows did not let in enough light to allow the lazily turning disco ball to do its magic. Nellie did not know where the breeze came from. She didn’t feel one. It could have been a breeze from the memory of people dancing, living, in this room covered floor to wall in a green shaggy carpet material. She rested her hand on the wall closest to the door, surprised as how dry it was, how soft it still felt under her hand. She knew there were plumbing issues in the building and expected dampness and immediately, grimy regret. West and Devi passed by her, West filming the disco ball, then closing in on the carpeted green stairs that led to some unknown location, while Devi listened intently to her headphones. “This place is…” West began. “I know,” said Nellie, her voice full of awe. She knew that the room had seen better days, but god, she loved that joy of the 70s, the disco vibes that brought people together more than the drinks or drugs ever could. Devi was saying something, concerned once again about the sound, and Nellie could hear West placating her, but she didn’t care. She could imagine the music that was swallowed by this soft green room, by the smooth bodies that writhed together. Her arms caught a beat that only she could hear, her hips swaying to a base riff from her imagination. “Doing okay, Nellie?” West asked with a chuckle. She looked up just in time to see that he was filming and gave a few extra turns just for the camera. “Anything ghostly going on?” she asked them when the rhythm faded from her body. “Devi thought she heard a song,” West said. “A disco song?” Nellie asked, her heart skipping a beat, but West shook his head. “It was quiet,” said Devi. “Hard to make out. I’ll play it back when we get home.” “I bet it was contact,” Nellie grinned and Devi did something between a headshake and a shrug, indecipherable to Nellie but that was fine. Devi would tease out the sound, and even if it was nothing, she could make it something with the right gothic soundtrack behind it. “Anything we should know about this room?” West asked. “They called it the Groove Room,” Nellie said and shook her head at West and Devi’s disbelief. “It was a very 70s thing, to have a space specifically for grooving. Those rock stars in the hall definitely came in here to groove.” “What a decade,” West said, and Nellie grinned in agreement. “Unfortunately, without anyone to groove in here, this room is… um… dead, even for a haunted house. There are some groovy stairs we can check out, or back to the hallway.” [[Upper Séance Room - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom)]] [[Hallway 2- Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]]“Holy shit,” Nellie whispered. “West, are you getting this?” “Please, both of you,” Desi pleaded, standing by herself at the top of the stairs. “Stay a little further away from the giant hole in the floor leading down to…” “The Pit,” Nellie grinned. God, it looked terrifying. It was perfect. Even if they didn’t get any ghostly encounters, this was just so haunted. No matter how hard she looked, Nellie only saw darkness. Who knew how deep it went? Who knew how long she would fall if she just tipped over the edge? Nellie didn’t want to tip over the edge, but what a way to go, right? Falling into some Amityville-style Hell portal. They would get so many views. “How about less leaning over the death hole and more reading from the guidebook?” Devi suggested. Nellie pulled out the book, distracted by the darkness in front of her. “Okay, so, while Bradford might have preferred to keep the séance room secure in the case terrible dark forces got out, his kids used this room for more… private party activities.” “You are not suggesting that this hole is the result of violent 1970s sex, are you?” West laughed. “No, apparently the damage originated on the ground floor, in the main séance room,” Nellie said, frowning as she read. “That doesn’t quite make sense. The giant hole is up here.” “An earthquake at the time caused structural damage to a lot of the mansion, and is said to have upset some poorly made support beams that collapsed, making the center of the floor collapse,” Devi said. “But some people think there was an explosion of dark energy after a séance went wrong, and the explosion caused the hole. It was in the papers. And my mom remembered it.” “Doesn’t look burnt…” Nellie murmured as she touched the edge of the green carpet, torn and drooping towards the darkness below. “Maybe dark energy doesn’t burn,” West said. “Most of the dark energy we’ve faced has been cold.” “I don’t trust you two to keep your balance,” Devi said, cutting off their speculation. “Come on. We’ve leaving.” [[Hallway 2- Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]]Nellie tried to shake the pink from her mind, but she could still almost taste it on her tongue, sour bubblegum sweet. "Hey, Nellie, you okay?" West asked. "You look a little-" "Not now, West," Nellie said, but it did not come out quite as sharp as she intended. This wasn't the first time she had kept a little sourvenier from a haunt, but she had never grabbed one so quickly before. The ribbon felt like it was burning a hole in her pocket. She supposed she could turn back and put it in the cabinet again, but how would she explain that to Devi and West? How would West react? She couldn't handle his mockery, not when she was already feeling guilty. "Nellie?" Devi asked, and Nellie realized she had been standing in silence, the red light of the camera waiting for action. "There are still a lot of rooms to-" "We don't have all night to explore," Nellie said, cutting her off with a grin. "Let's just keep going." [[Hallway 2 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. with Ribbon)]]Nellie shivered. “You alright, Nel?” asked Devi. “Getting some static on the mic.” “Sorry.” “Did anyone else feel it get colder?” asked West. Nellie shook her head. She didn’t feel it get colder. That wasn’t why she shivered. As they rounded the curve, it was like… well, not like she could feel someone’s eyes on the back of her head. More like, she couldn’t feel someone’s eyes on the back of her head anymore. She had been observed, but not anymore. It was always a terrible feeling for Nellie. That feeling of the camera being shut off, of going home, pulling the covers over your head and waiting to work, to get it done, to post it, to see the likes come in, to be seen. “I wasn’t paying attention,” said Devi, frowning at her briefcase like it held all of her problems, and if it was a sound problem then it probably did. “But I believe you.” “Maybe I should have worn a jacket,” West shrugged. “You guys came prepared.” Nellie rested her hand on the wall. It was colder in here. “West. Film,” she demanded, before turning to the red light and smirking. “I think we have company, viewers. Does anyone want to make contact? It’s safe here. We’re listening.” Despite the silliness of its name, Spooktacular Investigations didn’t use EVP, radio channels, any of the tricks popular on other streaming shows because as far as Nellie was concerned, they were just tricks. All you need to communicate was an open mind. An entire team of open minds. All three of them had a history of paranormal connection. All of them had proved to the other side that they were willing to lend an ear. Nellie counted thirty seconds of silence before she shrugged at the camera. “Guess they’re shy. We’ve got some chilly, shy ghosts or demons in the mansion.” “Maybe I should play ‘Running With the Devil,’” Devi suggested. “Only if we’re desperate for contact,” Nellie said. She pulled out the guidebook, allowing its weight and vintage cartoons of stars (or pentagrams?) to pull her back to the mundane of reality. Nothing really “haunted” had happened yet. Maybe this would just be one of those episodes that focused on the house’s architecture and the owner’s taste. She shifted on the thick shag carpet, eyeing the cracked popcorn ceiling before she skimmed the pages. Perhaps it would focus on the owner’s tastelessness. “It smells a little… funky,” West said, wrinkling his nose. “The 70s were a funky time,” Devi grinned. “These three rooms belonged to Bradford’s children,” Nellie said. “Again, they lived here as adults, or I guess the youngest moved in as a teen, and they should be… ah!” Nellie pointed at the molding mantels above each door, where pieces of metal twisted into the shape of a letter were still securely nailed: M, T, D. “What’s the plan, Nel?” asked West. "We probably have time to explore two of the rooms." [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (with Ribbon)]] [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (with Ribbon)]] [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (with Ribbon)]]Nellie tried the handle of the Séance Room. It was firmly locked, but even the slight pressure Nellie put on it made the hinges groan with a dying cry. Nellie wished she had said that bit out loud. It was the perfect amount of melodrama for her hands. Devi pulled back on Nellie’s shoulder. “Hey, fearless leader,” Devi said. “This is the ground floor of the Séance Room. The Séance Room Pit.” “Damn, Nellie,” West said. “You were going to lead us into the Pit.” Nellie hoped the shadows hid her blush from West’s camera. She shouldn’t make these kinds of mistakes. This was her show. She was the face of the show. She was the fearless leader. She had the guidebook. “Well if they were so worried about the danger, they would have reinforced the door,” Nellie huffed. She tested her weight against the groaning hinges and Devi winced. “I could push this open if I had to. Hell, Devi could do it if she had to.” “I could do it without trying,” West offered. “Yeah, West, I know, I was making a point… Forget it,” said Nellie. “Let’s keep going.” [[Hallway 2 - Nellie's Tour]] [[Groove Room - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Séance Room)]] [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Séance Room)]]The salmon pink of the tiles, toilet, and tub made Nellie want to throw up. Like looking at pictures of her swollen throat at the doctor’s office after the bad bulimia episode. An inside view that should never be outside. “Looks like a bathroom,” said West, nodding officially to himself. Nellie opened the guidebook, if anything for an excuse to look away from the pink. “Says here that it’s specifically the Girls’ Bathroom,” she said. “Like, a gendered bathroom for parties?” West asked. “Is there a boys’ bathroom somewhere?” “No, one sec,” said Nellie, skimming the chunk of text. “It was used for the public who came for parties or Bradford’s more intimate get-togethers, but privately, it was for the girls to use. The daughters and the wives.” “Wives, multiple?” West asked. “Yeah, I guess, there’s not anymore info on that on this page, but I did know he was a misogynistic creep,” Nellie said, flipping through the book before settling back on her page. “Okay, so the five girls, um, women I mean, Bradford's three lovers and two daughters would use this bathroom and it led to a lot of drama, blah, blah, blah-” “Fascinating stuff, Nellie,” said West. “In conclusion, it’s a bathroom, and it was themed for the girls,” Nellie said, snapping the book shut. “There’s no boy-themed bathroom, if you’re wondering,” Devi quietly added, making both Nellie and West jump from her sudden presence behind them. “Bradford and his son had private bathrooms connected to their bedrooms. But there was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and they got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. So if you want bathroom footage, now’s the time.” [[Explore the Tub - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Séance Room)]] [[Explore the Toilet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Séance Room)]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Séance Room)]]Nellie put her hand over her nose. It smelled almost like… chicken soup? She had to assume that the smell was coming from the brown goop congealed around the tub’s plug. “Are you going to touch it?” asked West. “Don’t touch it,” said Devi. “I’m not going to touch it!” Nellie snapped. She kind of wanted to, though. It was like the smell. It attracted and repulsed her. A bad memory of childhood sickness that you could never forget. [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Séance Room)]]Nellie leaned over the toilet. “Don’t think we have time for that, Nel,” West mumbled. “What the Hell, West?” Nellie snapped at him, but if West’s continued mumbles were an apology, she did not care. “And you two were doing so well at getting along,” Devi sighed. “Did you hear… Whatever,” Nellie said, deflating a little though she knew she was as pink as the room. “Screw you, West.” [[Girls' Bathroom - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom and Séance Room)]]“Anything illegal in there?” Devi asked. “Devi!” Nellie gasped and West chuckled with her. “I just mean… this place has a reputation and that’s a medicine cabinet.” “And when a place has a reputation like this one does, you’re not going to find any remnants of a fun time fifty years after the party ended,” Nellie joked. “Actually, you probably wouldn’t find anything halfway through the party. The Benningtons went hard. But…” Nellie pulled a white ribbon out of the cabinet. It was carefully wound, but Nellie did not think twice before unwinding it to its full length. “Thrilling,” West said dryly. “Ribbons were big in the 70s,” Devi said, a faint smile on her lips. “Like The Cars’ song. 'Perfume... ribbons.. etc...’” Nellie hummed the tune to the song, rocking a bit to an imaginary beat. “Did you get that?” she asked and West gave a thumbs up. As her crew left the bathroom, Nellie tucked the ribbon into her pocket. [[Hallway 1 - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Girls' Bathroom with Ribbon)]]"Does this tile make anyone else a little... gag-y?" asked Nellie. "Only ever you, Nel," said West. "Shut up." [[Explore the Cabinet - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Séance Room)]] [[Groove Room - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from the Girls' Bathroom and Séance Room)]]The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, flipping through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark, reading quickly as she trusted the red light was on. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. Oh damn, it actually says that. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. He found that life, but tended to bring it back home, which led to the numerous photos of rockstars and celebrities in the hall. Apparently Mark was an amateur musician himself and his guitar is… you know what, I’m going to assume it rotted. Anyway, he often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, and would bad-mouth him to the press who loved the father-son drama. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, kick him out, but someone else in his family always let him back in whenever he hit rock bottom. Which was often. One night, this is from a police report, one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other from… hm, from Bradford’s bedroom or from the kitchen, they couldn’t agree which was one of the reasons why they couldn’t convict… getting ahead of myself. Bradford was screaming at Mark to get out of the house, that this time he had to leave for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. And then Bradford had the whole garden redone, new earth put in, oooh the press claimed Bradford killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive and oh my god I can’t take the smell anymore.” [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Tara's Room)]] [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Dawn's Room)]]The room looked like it had been wrecked on purpose, probably after the mansion was abandoned, but she had a terrible certainty that it was before. She could see, not a woman, but the movement of the woman, rushing across the room in desperate, jerky motions, gouging deep into the walls with broken fingernails to make those jagged scratches, chewing on the bedposts, leaving those crushed bits of costume jewellery on the floor. It was not the most harrowing part of the room, but Nellie could not take her eyes of the jewellery, those broken bits of plastic, the tones still so bright despite the years and the decay. Surely, a Bennington daughter could have afforded better? Maybe she bought it outside her allowance. Maybe it was a gift. Sentimental value. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Nellie flipped through the book, forcing suddenly heavy fingers to find the page, keeping her drooping lids open. It would be easy to sleep in this room, even on that stripped bed with no sheets. “Dawn was Bradford’s oldest daughter. She grew up in Mississippi with her mother, one of Bradford’s lovers, the one who apparently encouraged him to build this house for the whole family. The press described her as a Southern Belle, or a Peach Flower forced to live as a Cactus. She was sweet to her friends and family but downright prickly to anyone who came courting. Ha. ‘Came courting.’ However, rumor has it that she did fall in love, and not with one of those rich Hollywood types that were always shmoozing with Bradford on the estate or cozying up to her brother with their wild lives. She met a folksinger named Emma who snuck into one of their parties because she heard that Janis Ian was there. Emma didn’t meet Janis, but she did meet Dawn. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react, with Emma not being rich or previously approved by Bradford as a romantic interest. Then Dawn’s brother Mark did find out, and he told her father, and her father forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again.
