Some say he arranged for Emma to be murdered, or sacrificed her to a dark spirit in order to ensure the continued wealth of the family… okay, I can’t tell if it would ensure their wealth as a kind of payment from the dark spirit in return for the sacrifice or by forcing Dawn to marry someone wealthier who could add to the family… Wait, doesn’t matter anyway because Dawn committed suicide. Later, her sister Tara would tell the police that she thought she heard Dawn come into her room in the middle of the night, and felt her gently kiss her on the forehead before she left. Oh. She took the sheets from her bed, went to the Upper Séance room, and hanged herself.” “Nel, did you need a sec? Or a tissue?” West asked, surprisingly genuine. “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty.” [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Tara's/Dawn's Room)]] [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Dawn's Room)]] “Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow, and though one could have described it as “worn,” Nellie just thought it looked “loved.” “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie, flipping to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “Okay. This room belonged to Tara. Bradford’s youngest. Younger than her brother Mark by ten years. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, damn, sometimes days in his secret study, conducting all sorts of evil magic and communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mom who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and he told her a terrible secret, so terrible that she fled, never to be seen again. Bradford’s body was found months after his demise by police on a wellness check. Tara’s body was never found, but foul play was never suspected. Against Tara. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or out of resentment for all the work with evil spirits he made her do. And in occult circles, people say she killed him to absorb his power so it wouldn’t be wasted in his death. So either a tragic figure, or a really evil figure. Maybe she’s paying some poor bound spirit to keep her room clean in case she ever returns.” “Is that in the book?” asked Devi. “No, that’s a Nellie original.” [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Tara's/Dawn's Room)]] [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Tara's Room)]]The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, flipping through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark, reading quickly as she trusted the red light was on. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. Oh damn, it actually says that. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. He found that life, but tended to bring it back home, which led to the numerous photos of rockstars and celebrities in the hall. Apparently Mark was an amateur musician himself and his guitar is… you know what, I’m going to assume it rotted. Anyway, he often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, and would bad-mouth him to the press who loved the father-son drama. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, kick him out, but someone else in his family always let him back in whenever he hit rock bottom. Which was often. One night, this is from a police report, one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other from… hm, from Bradford’s bedroom or from the kitchen, they couldn’t agree which was one of the reasons why they couldn’t convict… getting ahead of myself. Bradford was screaming at Mark to get out of the house, that this time he had to leave for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. And then Bradford had the whole garden redone, new earth put in, oooh the press claimed Bradford killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive and oh my god I can’t take the smell anymore.” [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Tara's Room with Ribbon)]] [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Dawn's Room with Ribbon)]]The room looked like it had been wrecked on purpose, probably after the mansion was abandoned, but she had a terrible certainty that it was before. She could see, not a woman, but the movement of the woman, rushing across the room in desperate, jerky motions, gouging deep into the walls with broken fingernails to make those jagged scratches, chewing on the bedposts, leaving those crushed bits of costume jewellery on the floor. It was not the most harrowing part of the room, but Nellie could not take her eyes of the jewellery, those broken bits of plastic, the tones still so bright despite the years and the decay. Surely, a Bennington daughter could have afforded better? Maybe she bought it outside her allowance. Maybe it was a gift. Sentimental value. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Nellie flipped through the book, forcing suddenly heavy fingers to find the page, keeping her drooping lids open. It would be easy to sleep in this room, even on that stripped bed with no sheets. [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Dawn's/Tara's Room with Ribbon)]] [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Dawn's Room with Ribbon)]] “Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow, and though one could have described it as “worn,” Nellie just thought it looked “loved.” “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie, flipping to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “Okay. This room belonged to Tara. Bradford’s youngest. Younger than her brother Mark by ten years. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, damn, sometimes days in his secret study, conducting all sorts of evil magic and communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mom who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and he told her a terrible secret, so terrible that she fled, never to be seen again. Bradford’s body was found months after his demise by police on a wellness check. Tara’s body was never found, but foul play was never suspected. Against Tara. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or out of resentment for all the work with evil spirits he made her do. And in occult circles, people say she killed him to absorb his power so it wouldn’t be wasted in his death. So either a tragic figure, or a really evil figure. Maybe she’s paying some poor bound spirit to keep her room clean in case she ever returns.” “Is that in the book?” asked Devi. “No, that’s a Nellie original.” [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Tara's Room with Ribbon)]] [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Dawn's/Tara's Room with Ribbon)]] The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, flipping through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark, reading quickly as she trusted the red light was on. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. Oh damn, it actually says that. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. He found that life, but tended to bring it back home, which led to the numerous photos of rockstars and celebrities in the hall. Apparently Mark was an amateur musician himself and his guitar is… you know what, I’m going to assume it rotted. Anyway, he often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, and would bad-mouth him to the press who loved the father-son drama. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, kick him out, but someone else in his family always let him back in whenever he hit rock bottom. Which was often. One night, this is from a police report, one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other from… hm, from Bradford’s bedroom or from the kitchen, they couldn’t agree which was one of the reasons why they couldn’t convict… getting ahead of myself. Bradford was screaming at Mark to get out of the house, that this time he had to leave for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. And then Bradford had the whole garden redone, new earth put in, oooh the press claimed Bradford killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive and oh my god I can’t take the smell anymore.” [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Dawn's Room and Groove Room)]] [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Tara's Room and Groove Room)]]The room looked like it had been wrecked on purpose, probably after the mansion was abandoned, but she had a terrible certainty that it was before. She could see, not a woman, but the movement of the woman, rushing across the room in desperate, jerky motions, gouging deep into the walls with broken fingernails to make those jagged scratches, chewing on the bedposts, leaving those crushed bits of costume jewellery on the floor. It was not the most harrowing part of the room, but Nellie could not take her eyes of the jewellery, those broken bits of plastic, the tones still so bright despite the years and the decay. Surely, a Bennington daughter could have afforded better? Maybe she bought it outside her allowance. Maybe it was a gift. Sentimental value. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Nellie flipped through the book, forcing suddenly heavy fingers to find the page, keeping her drooping lids open. It would be easy to sleep in this room, even on that stripped bed with no sheets. “Dawn was Bradford’s oldest daughter. She grew up in Mississippi with her mother, one of Bradford’s lovers, the one who apparently encouraged him to build this house for the whole family. The press described her as a Southern Belle, or a Peach Flower forced to live as a Cactus. She was sweet to her friends and family but downright prickly to anyone who came courting. Ha. ‘Came courting.’ However, rumor has it that she did fall in love, and not with one of those rich Hollywood types that were always shmoozing with Bradford on the estate or cozying up to her brother with their wild lives. She met a folksinger named Emma who snuck into one of their parties because she heard that Janis Ian was there. Emma didn’t meet Janis, but she did meet Dawn. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react, with Emma not being rich or previously approved by Bradford as a romantic interest. Then Dawn’s brother Mark did find out, and he told her father, and her father forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again. Some say he arranged for Emma to be murdered, or sacrificed her to a dark spirit in order to ensure the continued wealth of the family… okay, I can’t tell if it would ensure their wealth as a kind of payment from the dark spirit in return for the sacrifice or by forcing Dawn to marry someone wealthier who could add to the family… Wait, doesn’t matter anyway because Dawn committed suicide. Later, her sister Tara would tell the police that she thought she heard Dawn come into her room in the middle of the night, and felt her gently kiss her on the forehead before she left. Oh. She took the sheets from her bed, went to the Upper Séance room, and hanged herself.” “Nel, did you need a sec? Or a tissue?” West asked, surprisingly genuine. “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty.” [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Dawn's Room and Groove Room)]] [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Dawn's/Tara's Room and Groove Room)]] “Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow, and though one could have described it as “worn,” Nellie just thought it looked “loved.” “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie, flipping to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “Okay. This room belonged to Tara. Bradford’s youngest. Younger than her brother Mark by ten years. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, damn, sometimes days in his secret study, conducting all sorts of evil magic and communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mom who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and he told her a terrible secret, so terrible that she fled, never to be seen again. Bradford’s body was found months after his demise by police on a wellness check. Tara’s body was never found, but foul play was never suspected. Against Tara. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or out of resentment for all the work with evil spirits he made her do. And in occult circles, people say she killed him to absorb his power so it wouldn’t be wasted in his death. So either a tragic figure, or a really evil figure. Maybe she’s paying some poor bound spirit to keep her room clean in case she ever returns.” “Is that in the book?” asked Devi. “No, that’s a Nellie original.” [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Dawn's/Tara's Room and Groove Room)]] [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Tara's Room and Groove Room)]] The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, flipping through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark, reading quickly as she trusted the red light was on. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. Oh damn, it actually says that. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. He found that life, but tended to bring it back home, which led to the numerous photos of rockstars and celebrities in the hall. Apparently Mark was an amateur musician himself and his guitar is… you know what, I’m going to assume it rotted. Anyway, he often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, and would bad-mouth him to the press who loved the father-son drama. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, kick him out, but someone else in his family always let him back in whenever he hit rock bottom. Which was often. One night, this is from a police report, one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other from… hm, from Bradford’s bedroom or from the kitchen, they couldn’t agree which was one of the reasons why they couldn’t convict… getting ahead of myself. Bradford was screaming at Mark to get out of the house, that this time he had to leave for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. And then Bradford had the whole garden redone, new earth put in, oooh the press claimed Bradford killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive and oh my god I can’t take the smell anymore.” [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Dawn's Room, Groove Room with Ribbon)]] [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Tara's Room, Groove Room with Ribbon)]]The room looked like it had been wrecked on purpose, probably after the mansion was abandoned, but she had a terrible certainty that it was before. She could see, not a woman, but the movement of the woman, rushing across the room in desperate, jerky motions, gouging deep into the walls with broken fingernails to make those jagged scratches, chewing on the bedposts, leaving those crushed bits of costume jewellery on the floor. It was not the most harrowing part of the room, but Nellie could not take her eyes of the jewellery, those broken bits of plastic, the tones still so bright despite the years and the decay. Surely, a Bennington daughter could have afforded better? Maybe she bought it outside her allowance. Maybe it was a gift. Sentimental value. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Nellie flipped through the book, forcing suddenly heavy fingers to find the page, keeping her drooping lids open. It would be easy to sleep in this room, even on that stripped bed with no sheets. “Dawn was Bradford’s oldest daughter. She grew up in Mississippi with her mother, one of Bradford’s lovers, the one who apparently encouraged him to build this house for the whole family. The press described her as a Southern Belle, or a Peach Flower forced to live as a Cactus. She was sweet to her friends and family but downright prickly to anyone who came courting. Ha. ‘Came courting.’ However, rumor has it that she did fall in love, and not with one of those rich Hollywood types that were always shmoozing with Bradford on the estate or cozying up to her brother with their wild lives. She met a folksinger named Emma who snuck into one of their parties because she heard that Janis Ian was there. Emma didn’t meet Janis, but she did meet Dawn. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react, with Emma not being rich or previously approved by Bradford as a romantic interest. Then Dawn’s brother Mark did find out, and he told her father, and her father forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again. Some say he arranged for Emma to be murdered, or sacrificed her to a dark spirit in order to ensure the continued wealth of the family… okay, I can’t tell if it would ensure their wealth as a kind of payment from the dark spirit in return for the sacrifice or by forcing Dawn to marry someone wealthier who could add to the family… Wait, doesn’t matter anyway because Dawn committed suicide. Later, her sister Tara would tell the police that she thought she heard Dawn come into her room in the middle of the night, and felt her gently kiss her on the forehead before she left. Oh. She took the sheets from her bed, went to the Upper Séance room, and hanged herself.” “Nel, did you need a sec? Or a tissue?” West asked, surprisingly genuine. “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty.” [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Tara's/Dawn's Room, Groove Room with Ribbon)]] [[Tara's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Dawn's Room, Groove Room with Ribbon)]] “Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow, and though one could have described it as “worn,” Nellie just thought it looked “loved.” “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie, flipping to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “Okay. This room belonged to Tara. Bradford’s youngest. Younger than her brother Mark by ten years. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, damn, sometimes days in his secret study, conducting all sorts of evil magic and communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mom who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and he told her a terrible secret, so terrible that she fled, never to be seen again. Bradford’s body was found months after his demise by police on a wellness check. Tara’s body was never found, but foul play was never suspected. Against Tara. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or out of resentment for all the work with evil spirits he made her do. And in occult circles, people say she killed him to absorb his power so it wouldn’t be wasted in his death. So either a tragic figure, or a really evil figure. Maybe she’s paying some poor bound spirit to keep her room clean in case she ever returns.” “Is that in the book?” asked Devi. “No, that’s a Nellie original.” [[Mark's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Tara's/Dawn's Room, Groove Room with Ribbon)]] [[Dawn's Room - Nellie's Tour (from Mark's/Tara's Room, Groove Room with Ribbon)]] “Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow, and though one could have described it as “worn,” Nellie just thought it looked “loved.” “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie, flipping to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “Okay. This room belonged to Tara. Bradford’s youngest. Younger than her brother Mark by ten years. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, damn, sometimes days in his secret study, conducting all sorts of evil magic and communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mom who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and he told her a terrible secret, so terrible that she fled, never to be seen again. Bradford’s body was found months after his demise by police on a wellness check. Tara’s body was never found, but foul play was never suspected. Against Tara. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or out of resentment for all the work with evil spirits he made her do. And in occult circles, people say she killed him to absorb his power so it wouldn’t be wasted in his death. So either a tragic figure, or a really evil figure. Maybe she’s paying some poor bound spirit to keep her room clean in case she ever returns.” “Is that in the book?” asked Devi. “No, that’s a Nellie original.” “Wait,” said Devi, crouching to look at a little box on the ground, no bigger than a box for a ring, with nine sliding tiles on the top. “There’s some kind of puzzle here.” “No, I see numbers, that counts as math,” Nellie protested. “We’re going to the next room.” [[Tara's Puzzle - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]] [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]] The room looked like it had been wrecked on purpose, probably after the mansion was abandoned, but she had a terrible certainty that it was before. She could see, not a woman, but the movement of the woman, rushing across the room in desperate, jerky motions, gouging deep into the walls with broken fingernails to make those jagged scratches, chewing on the bedposts, leaving those crushed bits of costume jewellery on the floor. It was not the most harrowing part of the room, but Nellie could not take her eyes of the jewellery, those broken bits of plastic, the tones still so bright despite the years and the decay. Surely, a Bennington daughter could have afforded better? Maybe she bought it outside her allowance. Maybe it was a gift. Sentimental value. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Nellie flipped through the book, forcing suddenly heavy fingers to find the page, keeping her drooping lids open. It would be easy to sleep in this room, even on that stripped bed with no sheets. “Dawn was Bradford’s oldest daughter. She grew up in Mississippi with her mother, one of Bradford’s lovers, the one who apparently encouraged him to build this house for the whole family. The press described her as a Southern Belle, or a Peach Flower forced to live as a Cactus. She was sweet to her friends and family but downright prickly to anyone who came courting. Ha. ‘Came courting.’ However, rumor has it that she did fall in love, and not with one of those rich Hollywood types that were always shmoozing with Bradford on the estate or cozying up to her brother with their wild lives. She met a folksinger named Emma who snuck into one of their parties because she heard that Janis Ian was there. Emma didn’t meet Janis, but she did meet Dawn. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react, with Emma not being rich or previously approved by Bradford as a romantic interest. Then Dawn’s brother Mark did find out, and he told her father, and her father forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again. Some say he arranged for Emma to be murdered, or sacrificed her to a dark spirit in order to ensure the continued wealth of the family… okay, I can’t tell if it would ensure their wealth as a kind of payment from the dark spirit in return for the sacrifice or by forcing Dawn to marry someone wealthier who could add to the family… Wait, doesn’t matter anyway because Dawn committed suicide. Later, her sister Tara would tell the police that she thought she heard Dawn come into her room in the middle of the night, and felt her gently kiss her on the forehead before she left. Oh. She took the sheets from her bed, went to the Upper Séance room, and hanged herself.” “Nel, did you need a sec? Or a tissue?” West asked, surprisingly genuine. “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty.” Nellie paused. There was something sticking out of the vanity’s top drawer. She tugged it free, reading the faded lines. “Hey, guys, I think I found a poem.” “Give a dead woman some privacy, Nellie,” said West. “We should go on.” [[Dawn's Poem - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]] [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]]Nellie walked through an ornate archway into a library that was nothing like she expected. She had a “Beast’s Gift for Belle” idea of libraries, a little whimsy and fantasy, vaguely French in an animated kind of way, big windows, big curtains, big ladders to ride across the bookshelves while singing away the pain. The Bennington Mansion library had none of those things. It had severity. If you sang in here, someone, something, would surely come to shut you up. “Is that sludge or a choice?” West asked at Nellie's shoulder. She followed his camera up. The ceiling came to a point, painted all the same black or dark brown, and while it did look wet, fresh, it wasn’t dripping. It reminded Nellie of the entry room ceiling, reversed. All darkness where that was all light. Everything hidden from the moon. She noted that there weren’t any porthole windows in this room either, the only light dimly edging in from the hallway. A beam of light disrupted the darkness. “Probably could have used this earlier, but I wanted to save the battery,” said Devi. Nellie followed Devi’s light as she slowly panned across the depressing room, illuminating bookshelves still filled with books, some rotting, some holding up surprisingly well. The sofa’s, black leather ones that filled the room with a musky smell that was exactly unpleasant, sat low to the ground, cautious, creating a kind of hedge maze path across the sprawling room. Nellie felt an urge to climb on top of them, over them like a child. “The floor is lava,” she said to herself and heard West chuckle politely, his camera following the light across the sofas as well. There was a blinding moment as the light caught on a large globe, the only thing in the room that looked a little like what Nellie had expected, a little bit of wonder in its golden-hued frame and perhaps hand-painted countries. It tilted at an odd, unearthly angle, but was still quite elegant. A tapestry hung behind it, but the corner had come undone and the black fabric folded in on itself, covering whatever image had once been proudly on display. Devi stopped the light at the far end of the room, where a similar archway led further into the mansion, bringing them closer to their final destination. Next to it, a winding staircase of a solid black material that looked surprisingly like plastic led to an upper floor. “Well,” said Nellie. “There’s a lot going on here. I feel like libraries are made to be haunted. Keep that camera on me, West.” [[Upper Floor Obvervatory - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] [[Globe - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] [[Tapestry - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]]“Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow, and though one could have described it as “worn,” Nellie just thought it looked “loved.” “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie, flipping to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “Okay. This room belonged to Tara. Bradford’s youngest. Younger than her brother Mark by ten years. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, damn, sometimes days in his secret study, conducting all sorts of evil magic and communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mom who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and he told her a terrible secret, so terrible that she fled, never to be seen again. Bradford’s body was found months after his demise by police on a wellness check. Tara’s body was never found, but foul play was never suspected. Against Tara. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or out of resentment for all the work with evil spirits he made her do. And in occult circles, people say she killed him to absorb his power so it wouldn’t be wasted in his death. So either a tragic figure, or a really evil figure. Maybe she’s paying some poor bound spirit to keep her room clean in case she ever returns.” “Is that in the book?” asked Devi. “No, that’s a Nellie original.” “Wait,” said Devi, crouching to look at a little box on the ground, no bigger than a box for a ring, with nine sliding tiles on the top. “There’s some kind of puzzle here.” “No, I see numbers, that counts as math,” Nellie protested. “We’re going to the next room.” [[Tara's Puzzle - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]] [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]] The room looked like it had been wrecked on purpose, probably after the mansion was abandoned, but she had a terrible certainty that it was before. She could see, not a woman, but the movement of the woman, rushing across the room in desperate, jerky motions, gouging deep into the walls with broken fingernails to make those jagged scratches, chewing on the bedposts, leaving those crushed bits of costume jewellery on the floor. It was not the most harrowing part of the room, but Nellie could not take her eyes of the jewellery, those broken bits of plastic, the tones still so bright despite the years and the decay. Surely, a Bennington daughter could have afforded better? Maybe she bought it outside her allowance. Maybe it was a gift. Sentimental value. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Nellie flipped through the book, forcing suddenly heavy fingers to find the page, keeping her drooping lids open. It would be easy to sleep in this room, even on that stripped bed with no sheets. “Dawn was Bradford’s oldest daughter. She grew up in Mississippi with her mother, one of Bradford’s lovers, the one who apparently encouraged him to build this house for the whole family. The press described her as a Southern Belle, or a Peach Flower forced to live as a Cactus. She was sweet to her friends and family but downright prickly to anyone who came courting. Ha. ‘Came courting.’ However, rumor has it that she did fall in love, and not with one of those rich Hollywood types that were always shmoozing with Bradford on the estate or cozying up to her brother with their wild lives. She met a folksinger named Emma who snuck into one of their parties because she heard that Janis Ian was there. Emma didn’t meet Janis, but she did meet Dawn. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react, with Emma not being rich or previously approved by Bradford as a romantic interest. Then Dawn’s brother Mark did find out, and he told her father, and her father forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again. Some say he arranged for Emma to be murdered, or sacrificed her to a dark spirit in order to ensure the continued wealth of the family… okay, I can’t tell if it would ensure their wealth as a kind of payment from the dark spirit in return for the sacrifice or by forcing Dawn to marry someone wealthier who could add to the family… Wait, doesn’t matter anyway because Dawn committed suicide. Later, her sister Tara would tell the police that she thought she heard Dawn come into her room in the middle of the night, and felt her gently kiss her on the forehead before she left. Oh. Or a tissue?” West asked, surprisingly genuine. “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty.” Nellie paused. There was something sticking out of the vanity’s top drawer. I feel like libraries are made to be haunted. Keep that camera on me, West.” [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] [[Globe - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] [[Tapestry - Nellie's Tour (GR)]]The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, flipping through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark, reading quickly as she trusted the red light was on. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. Oh damn, it actually says that. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. He found that life, but tended to bring it back home, which led to the numerous photos of rockstars and celebrities in the hall. Apparently Mark was an amateur musician himself and his guitar is… you know what, I’m going to assume it rotted. Anyway, he often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, and would bad-mouth him to the press who loved the father-son drama. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, kick him out, but someone else in his family always let him back in whenever he hit rock bottom. Which was often. One night, this is from a police report, one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other from… hm, from Bradford’s bedroom or from the kitchen, they couldn’t agree which was one of the reasons why they couldn’t convict… getting ahead of myself. Bradford was screaming at Mark to get out of the house, that this time he had to leave for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. And then Bradford had the whole garden redone, new earth put in, oooh the press claimed Bradford killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive and oh my god I can’t take the smell anymore.” West frowned as he stared at piece of the bedframe that had not completely rotted. “There’s some kind of message scratched on here,” West said, leaning down to read it more closely. “West, do not touch the rotten wood,” Devi chided. “Let’s go.” [[Mark's Message - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]] [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]] The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, flipping through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark, reading quickly as she trusted the red light was on. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. Oh damn, it actually says that. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. He found that life, but tended to bring it back home, which led to the numerous photos of rockstars and celebrities in the hall. Apparently Mark was an amateur musician himself and his guitar is… you know what, I’m going to assume it rotted. Anyway, he often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, and would bad-mouth him to the press who loved the father-son drama. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, kick him out, but someone else in his family always let him back in whenever he hit rock bottom. Which was often. One night, this is from a police report, one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other from… hm, from Bradford’s bedroom or from the kitchen, they couldn’t agree which was one of the reasons why they couldn’t convict… getting ahead of myself. Bradford was screaming at Mark to get out of the house, that this time he had to leave for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. And then Bradford had the whole garden redone, new earth put in, oooh the press claimed Bradford killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive and oh my god I can’t take the smell anymore.” West frowned as he stared at piece of the bedframe that had not completely rotted. “There’s some kind of message scratched on here,” West said, leaning down to read it more closely. “West, do not touch the rotten wood,” Devi chided. “Let’s go.” [[Mark's Message - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]] [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]] The room looked like it had been wrecked on purpose, probably after the mansion was abandoned, but she had a terrible certainty that it was before. She could see, not a woman, but the movement of the woman, rushing across the room in desperate, jerky motions, gouging deep into the walls with broken fingernails to make those jagged scratches, chewing on the bedposts, leaving those crushed bits of costume jewellery on the floor. It was not the most harrowing part of the room, but Nellie could not take her eyes of the jewellery, those broken bits of plastic, the tones still so bright despite the years and the decay. Surely, a Bennington daughter could have afforded better? Maybe she bought it outside her allowance. Maybe it was a gift. Sentimental value. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Nellie flipped through the book, forcing suddenly heavy fingers to find the page, keeping her drooping lids open. It would be easy to sleep in this room, even on that stripped bed with no sheets. “Dawn was Bradford’s oldest daughter. She grew up in Mississippi with her mother, one of Bradford’s lovers, the one who apparently encouraged him to build this house for the whole family. The press described her as a Southern Belle, or a Peach Flower forced to live as a Cactus. She was sweet to her friends and family but downright prickly to anyone who came courting. Ha. ‘Came courting.’ However, rumor has it that she did fall in love, and not with one of those rich Hollywood types that were always shmoozing with Bradford on the estate or cozying up to her brother with their wild lives. She met a folksinger named Emma who snuck into one of their parties because she heard that Janis Ian was there. Emma didn’t meet Janis, but she did meet Dawn. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react, with Emma not being rich or previously approved by Bradford as a romantic interest. Then Dawn’s brother Mark did find out, and he told her father, and her father forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again. Some say he arranged for Emma to be murdered, or sacrificed her to a dark spirit in order to ensure the continued wealth of the family… okay, I can’t tell if it would ensure their wealth as a kind of payment from the dark spirit in return for the sacrifice or by forcing Dawn to marry someone wealthier who could add to the family… Wait, doesn’t matter anyway because Dawn committed suicide. Later, her sister Tara would tell the police that she thought she heard Dawn come into her room in the middle of the night, and felt her gently kiss her on the forehead before she left. Oh. She took the sheets from her bed, went to the Upper Séance room, and hanged herself.” “Nel, did you need a sec? Or a tissue?” West asked, surprisingly genuine. “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty.” Nellie paused. There was something sticking out of the vanity’s top drawer. She tugged it free, reading the faded lines. “Hey, guys, I think I found a poem.” “Give a dead woman some privacy, Nellie,” said West. “We should go on.” [[Dawn's Poem - Nellie's Tour (Cont. with Ribbon)]] [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. with Ribbon)]]“Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow, and though one could have described it as “worn,” Nellie just thought it looked “loved.” “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie, flipping to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “Okay. This room belonged to Tara. Bradford’s youngest. Younger than her brother Mark by ten years. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, damn, sometimes days in his secret study, conducting all sorts of evil magic and communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mom who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and he told her a terrible secret, so terrible that she fled, never to be seen again. Bradford’s body was found months after his demise by police on a wellness check. Tara’s body was never found, but foul play was never suspected. Against Tara. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or out of resentment for all the work with evil spirits he made her do. And in occult circles, people say she killed him to absorb his power so it wouldn’t be wasted in his death. So either a tragic figure, or a really evil figure. Maybe she’s paying some poor bound spirit to keep her room clean in case she ever returns.” “Is that in the book?” asked Devi. “No, that’s a Nellie original.” “Wait,” said Devi, crouching to look at a little box on the ground, no bigger than a box for a ring, with nine sliding tiles on the top. “There’s some kind of puzzle here.” “No, I see numbers, that counts as math,” Nellie protested. “We’re going to the next room.” [[Tara's Puzzle - Nellie's Tour (Cont. with Ribbon)]] [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. with Ribbon)]] Nellie walked through an ornate archway into a library that was nothing like she expected. She had a “Beast’s Gift for Belle” idea of libraries, a little whimsy and fantasy, vaguely French in an animated kind of way, big windows, big curtains, big ladders to ride across the bookshelves while singing away the pain. The Bennington Mansion library had none of those things. It had severity. If you sang in here, someone, something, would surely come to shut you up. “Is that sludge or a choice?” West asked at Nellie's shoulder. She followed his camera up. The ceiling came to a point, painted all the same black or dark brown, and while it did look wet, fresh, it wasn’t dripping. It reminded Nellie of the entry room ceiling, reversed. All darkness where that was all light. Everything hidden from the moon. She noted that there weren’t any porthole windows in this room either, the only light dimly edging in from the hallway. A beam of light disrupted the darkness. “Probably could have used this earlier, but I wanted to save the battery,” said Devi. Nellie followed Devi’s light as she slowly panned across the depressing room, illuminating bookshelves still filled with books, some rotting, some holding up surprisingly well. The sofa’s, black leather ones that filled the room with a musky smell that was exactly unpleasant, sat low to the ground, cautious, creating a kind of hedge maze path across the sprawling room. Nellie felt an urge to climb on top of them, over them like a child. “The floor is lava,” she said to herself and heard West chuckle politely, his camera following the light across the sofas as well. There was a blinding moment as the light caught on a large globe, the only thing in the room that looked a little like what Nellie had expected, a little bit of wonder in its golden-hued frame and perhaps hand-painted countries. It tilted at an odd, unearthly angle, but was still quite elegant. A tapestry hung behind it, but the corner had come undone and the black fabric folded in on itself, covering whatever image had once been proudly on display. Devi stopped the light at the far end of the room, where a similar archway led further into the mansion, bringing them closer to their final destination. Next to it, a winding staircase of a solid black material that looked surprisingly like plastic led to an upper floor. “Well,” said Nellie. “There’s a lot going on here. I feel like libraries are made to be haunted. Keep that camera on me, West.” [[Globe - Nellie's Tour (with Ribbon)]] [[Tapestry - Nellie's Tour (with Ribbon)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Nellie's Tour (with Ribbon)]] [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (with Ribbon)]]The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, flipping through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark, reading quickly as she trusted the red light was on. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. Oh damn, it actually says that. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. He found that life, but tended to bring it back home, which led to the numerous photos of rockstars and celebrities in the hall. Apparently Mark was an amateur musician himself and his guitar is… you know what, I’m going to assume it rotted. Anyway, he often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, and would bad-mouth him to the press who loved the father-son drama. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, kick him out, but someone else in his family always let him back in whenever he hit rock bottom. Which was often. One night, this is from a police report, one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other from… hm, from Bradford’s bedroom or from the kitchen, they couldn’t agree which was one of the reasons why they couldn’t convict… getting ahead of myself. Bradford was screaming at Mark to get out of the house, that this time he had to leave for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. And then Bradford had the whole garden redone, new earth put in, oooh the press claimed Bradford killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive and oh my god I can’t take the smell anymore.” West frowned as he stared at piece of the bedframe that had not completely rotted. “There’s some kind of message scratched on here,” West said, leaning down to read it more closely. “West, do not touch the rotten wood,” Devi chided. “Let’s go.” [[Mark's Message - Nellie's Tour (Cont. with Ribbon)]] [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. with Ribbon)]] The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, flipping through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark, reading quickly as she trusted the red light was on. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. Oh damn, it actually says that. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. He found that life, but tended to bring it back home, which led to the numerous photos of rockstars and celebrities in the hall. Apparently Mark was an amateur musician himself and his guitar is… you know what, I’m going to assume it rotted. Anyway, he often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, and would bad-mouth him to the press who loved the father-son drama. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, kick him out, but someone else in his family always let him back in whenever he hit rock bottom. Which was often. One night, this is from a police report, one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other from… hm, from Bradford’s bedroom or from the kitchen, they couldn’t agree which was one of the reasons why they couldn’t convict… getting ahead of myself. Bradford was screaming at Mark to get out of the house, that this time he had to leave for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. And then Bradford had the whole garden redone, new earth put in, oooh the press claimed Bradford killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive and oh my god I can’t take the smell anymore.” West frowned as he stared at piece of the bedframe that had not completely rotted. “There’s some kind of message scratched on here,” West said, leaning down to read it more closely. “West, do not touch the rotten wood,” Devi chided. “Let’s go.” [[Mark's Message - Nellie's Tour]] [[Library - Nellie's Tour]]The room looked like it had been wrecked on purpose, probably after the mansion was abandoned, but she had a terrible certainty that it was before. She could see, not a woman, but the movement of the woman, rushing across the room in desperate, jerky motions, gouging deep into the walls with broken fingernails to make those jagged scratches, chewing on the bedposts, leaving those crushed bits of costume jewellery on the floor.
