"One sec," said Nellie. "I'm not done yet." [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (with Ribbon)]] [[Library 2 Tapestry - Nellie's Tour (from Globe with Diary and Ribbon)]]Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, felt it sag under her weight like loose moss. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. Nellie stared at the tapestry and felt the hairs rise on the back of her neck. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns to give the viewers something to focus on. “Do any of the Benningtons have a ‘V’ name?” “You’re the one with the guidebook,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. "Let's go." [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]]“Oh. My. God.” “What is it, Nel?” West asked, hurrying over with the camera. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” “No sludge?” asked Devi, smirking. “No sludge,” Nellie agreed. She pulled out one of the books, with a picture of Nancy crouching behind a staircase still mostly visible on the cover. “Reading isn’t really captivating TV,” West said. “Shh, it’s good for the soul,” Nellie grinned, but her smile dropped. There was something on the shelf, tucked behind the books, glinting in the light of Devi’s flashlight. Nellie did not know what it was yet, but still, she wanted it more than anything, she wanted it to be hers and hers alone. She reached for the sparkling object and tugged it free. A locket on a thin gold chain, warm in her hand. The only warm thing in the world. “You’re shivering again Nel,” said West. “What is that?” Devi asked. “It’s mine,” Nellie snapped, then she shook her head, smiling a weak apology at Devi. “It’s a locket. Just a trinket. Costume jewellery. Not worth anything… I’m going to keep it.” “You okay, Nel?” West asked. “You look-” “Leave me alone West!” Nellie clutched the locket close, considered, then lifted the chain over her head. The locket slipped down the inside of her turtleneck, sliding against her skin, so warm she could barely feel it. Like fingertips along her sternum. Compared to the warmth of the locket, the library had never felt colder. “Let’s get out of here,” said Nellie. “You don’t want to explore anymore?” Devi asked. “It’s freezing,” said Nellie, shaking her head. “I need… We need to go.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] “Wow.” Nellie, Devi, and West looked up at the ceiling, the glass a continuation from the entry room ceiling, which Nellie thought didn’t make sense with the blueprint but she had been warned the mansion would be confusing. If she had read the guidebook more closely, perhaps she could have pictured it better in her head. And she wasn’t all that worried about picturing it. She was invested in her current view. Maybe the clouds had passed, or maybe it was the occult magic of the Bennington mansion, but Nellie could have sworn that there were not so many stars in the sky when they drove up. That the moon wasn’t so full. It made her feel like crying. It made her feel small and unimportant. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. Nellie could see the shadowed shapes of beds around her, elegant little boxy things with elegant little boxy side tables, but it was hard to care too much about what was in this room when she could look at what was above it. “Hey, Nellie, you’ve been standing there awhile,” Devi said, giving her should a gentle tap or tug. Nellie made sure her smile didn’t fade for the camera as she pulled her gaze away from the stars to the few items still left in a room that had been mostly cleared out. “What does the guidebook say?” asked West. Nellie squinted at the pages. “I should have read this on the stairs,” said Nellie. “It’s definitely a bedroom. Wait, it’s definitely an observatory. Okay, it definitely belonged to the lovers who used it as… yep, a bedroom and an observatory, it was the observatory first, they took it for themselves to not sleep with Bradford after one of the kids died and the romance died too, and the observatory was good for occult stuff-” “Stop saying ‘observatory,’” said West. “Let’s just look around or something. Enjoy the view for a bit.” [[Telescope - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] [[Side Table - Nellie's Tour (GR)]]Nellie ran her hand along the globe, expecting it to spin and feeling silly when it did not. For a moment she thought it was because it was a little broken, that its odd angle was the result of damage from time or vandals or other ghostly investigators who weren’t exactly respectful. Then she suddenly remembered something, a scene in some mobster movie that always struck her as needlessly fancy. “Nellie, don’t break the globe,” Devi warned. “She’s not,” said West. Nellie popped the top off the globe on its hinge, revealing a collection of glass bottles inside half-filled with suspicious brown liquid. “Scotch?” West asked. “I’m not tasting it to find out,” Nellie laughed. “But the crystal’s pretty.” [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] [[Tapestry - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe)]] Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, felt it sag under her weight like loose moss. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. Nellie stared at the tapestry and felt the hairs rise on the back of her neck. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns to give the viewers something to focus on. “Do any of the Benningtons have a ‘V’ name?” “You’re the one with the guidebook,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] [[Globe - Nellie's Gour (GR from Tapestry)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory (GR from Tapestry)]]Nellie ran her hand along the telescope. “Stop being so suggestive,” West laughed. Nellie guessed he could not see her rolling her eyes, but she rolled them anyway. “Does it work?” Devi asked. “Can a telescope stop working?” West asked. “Let’s find out,” said Nellie. She looked through the telescope and for a moment thought that she had forgotten to check for a lens cap, because all she saw was black. But when she checked, there was no cap. Maybe a telescope could stop working, somehow, but in her gut, she doubted it. She did not understand it, but when she looked through the telescope, all of those beautiful stars disappeared… if they were even there at all. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. [[Side Table - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West, already turning the camera away. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said, reaching into the shadows behind the cube. She never would have seen it without the bright moonlight, but there it was, begging her to take it. She lifted up the book, in much better condition than the ones in the library, though the paper was soft against her hands. It wasn’t hardbound. It wasn’t bound at all. It looked like the kind of spiral journal she used to bring to school. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary, too quickly for her to catch or get a good look at. West knelt on the ground, but the floor was in rougher shape than they realized, full of cracks and holes. Whatever fell out of the book could have fallen into any of them. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” "Guys, we've barely looked around this part of the house and you're already..." Devi trailed off, taking deep breaths. Nellie and West glanced at each other. "We always take stuff like this for the show," Nellie said. "I know," Devi snapped. "You usually just do a bit more investigating first. There was a whole library downstairs and you came up here-" "We can still explore the library," Nellie cut in. "Or... we could move on?" West suggested. Devi didn't respond, so Nellie nodded for her. It felt wrong to answer for her, but Devi was already shuffling down the stairs. West shrugged his confusion, and they followed her further into the mansion. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary)]]Devi frowned, one hand on her headphones, the other on the recorder in her hand. "You okay?" asked West. "No," Devi muttered. "I didn't actually catch that audio in the Groove Room." "Right..." Nellie drawled. "I heard something!" Devi insisted. "No use crying over spilled ectoplasm," said West. "Gross," said Devi. "He's right though," said Nellie. "Can't do anything about it except keep moving forward." [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]]“Do you want my hoodie, Nellie?” Devi asked. Nellie was shivering still, but she shook her head. “Continuity,” she said. “I’ll survive. We just need to… keep looking around. Film. Stuff.” Nellie pretended not to see Devi and West share a concerned glance. They had too much to do, and she only had enough energy to try to keep walking with making her trembling too obvious. The locket was not warm enough to ease the chill of the house. She wished she had worn a thicker turtleneck. She didn’t care if it would ruin the audio. Her chattering teeth might do that anyway. She tried to ignore the cold that settled into her bones and focus on the room. Nellie was expecting something a little more sinister from a man who made the papers for claiming to have accessed uncharted netherworlds full of nightmares beyond our comprehension, but she supposed those pursuits were best left to the young. Or at least left in the past with flared jeans and sequin tops. When life came at you hard and fast, or the illusion of fast after decades of smoking cigars and ignoring the persistent cough that came with it, you didn’t have time for spirits and demons anymore. Maybe at one point there was a stately wooden bed or some hyper-modern monstrosity of a bed, but all that was left in the room was one of those hospital-style rolling gurneys. A fancy one, wider and with deeper cushions than anything Nellie saw at her grandmother’s nursing home, but if you didn’t know expensive hospital equipment you wouldn’t have been impressed. “Guidebook?” West asked. “There’s nothing for this room,” Nellie said. “Bradford was alive when the tours were happening, but he would stay shut in his room. No one was allowed to see him or come here. Besides, this was his private space.” “Is that normal?” West asked. “To have tours in a place where someone is actively living?” “I think there are some castle tours in Scotland like that,” said Devi. “Haunted ones?” West asked, perking up. “We should do a trip. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. There was another door on the far wall, as solid as the front door to the entry room, but this handle turned easily. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said and Nellie dropped the handle. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Nellie left the door for later, stepped around a few sunken sections of carpet, and pretended to look thoughtfully at the framed pictures on the wall in case West was filming her. If she looked distressed, it would add to the haunted vibe, she supposed. West was filming a wardrobe in the corner, which may have been engraved in violent gouging designs or else it had been beset by gnawing rats at some point. Devi was standing by the hospital bed, looking particularly forlorn. “Anything interesting?” Nellie asked, but she couldn’t make her voice quite as enthusiastic as she hoped. [[Hospital Bed - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] [[Wardrobe - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]]Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, felt it sag under her weight like loose moss. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. Nellie stared at the tapestry and felt the hairs rise on the back of her neck. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns to give the viewers something to focus on. “Do any of the Benningtons have a ‘V’ name?” “You’re the one with the guidebook,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry)]] Wow.” Nellie, Devi, and West looked up at the ceiling, the glass a continuation from the entry room ceiling, which Nellie thought didn’t make sense with the blueprint but she had been warned the mansion would be confusing. If she had read the guidebook more closely, perhaps she could have pictured it better in her head. And she wasn’t all that worried about picturing it. She was invested in her current view. Maybe the clouds had passed, or maybe it was the occult magic of the Bennington mansion, but Nellie could have sworn that there were not so many stars in the sky when they drove up. That the moon wasn’t so full. It made her feel like crying. It made her feel small and unimportant. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. Nellie could see the shadowed shapes of beds around her, elegant little boxy things with elegant little boxy side tables, but it was hard to care too much about what was in this room when she could look at what was above it. “Hey, Nellie, you’ve been standing there awhile,” Devi said, giving her should a gentle tap or tug. Nellie made sure her smile didn’t fade for the camera as she pulled her gaze away from the stars to the few items still left in a room that had been mostly cleared out. “What does the guidebook say?” asked West. Nellie squinted at the pages. “I should have read this on the stairs,” said Nellie. “It’s definitely a bedroom. Wait, it’s definitely an observatory. Okay, it definitely belonged to the lovers who used it as… yep, a bedroom and an observatory, it was the observatory first, they took it for themselves to not sleep with Bradford after one of the kids died and the romance died too, and the observatory was good for occult stuff-” “Stop saying ‘observatory,’” said West. “Let’s just look around or something. Enjoy the view for a bit.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry)]] [[Telescope - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe)]] [[Side Table - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe)]]“Wow.” Nellie, Devi, and West looked up at the ceiling, the glass a continuation from the entry room ceiling, which Nellie thought didn’t make sense with the blueprint but she had been warned the mansion would be confusing. If she had read the guidebook more closely, perhaps she could have pictured it better in her head. And she wasn’t all that worried about picturing it. She was invested in her current view. Maybe the clouds had passed, or maybe it was the occult magic of the Bennington mansion, but Nellie could have sworn that there were not so many stars in the sky when they drove up. That the moon wasn’t so full. It made her feel like crying. It made her feel small and unimportant. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. Nellie could see the shadowed shapes of beds around her, elegant little boxy things with elegant little boxy side tables, but it was hard to care too much about what was in this room when she could look at what was above it. “Hey, Nellie, you’ve been standing there awhile,” Devi said, giving her should a gentle tap or tug. Nellie made sure her smile didn’t fade for the camera as she pulled her gaze away from the stars to the few items still left in a room that had been mostly cleared out. “What does the guidebook say?” asked West. Nellie squinted at the pages. “I should have read this on the stairs,” said Nellie. “It’s definitely a bedroom. Wait, it’s definitely an observatory. Okay, it definitely belonged to the lovers who used it as… yep, a bedroom and an observatory, it was the observatory first, they took it for themselves to not sleep with Bradford after one of the kids died and the romance died too, and the observatory was good for occult stuff-” “Stop saying ‘observatory,’” said West. “Let’s just look around or something. Enjoy the view for a bit.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry)]] [[Telescope - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry)]] [[Side Table - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry)]]Nellie shuffled back down to the library, leaving the stars and darkness behind her. “I can only read so much,” said West. “Let’s go.” “You didn’t read anything,” said Devi. “One sec,” said Nellie, rubbing her arms. “I’m not done.” [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] Nellie ran her hand along the telescope. “Stop being so suggestive,” West laughed. Nellie guessed he could not see her rolling her eyes, but she rolled them anyway. “Does it work?” Devi asked. “Can a telescope stop working?” West asked. “Let’s find out,” said Nellie. She looked through the telescope and for a moment thought that she had forgotten to check for a lens cap, because all she saw was black. But when she checked, there was no cap. Maybe a telescope could stop working, somehow, but in her gut, she doubted it. She did not understand it, but when she looked through the telescope, all of those beautiful stars disappeared… if they were even there at all. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West, already turning the camera away. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said, reaching into the shadows behind the cube. She never would have seen it without the bright moonlight, but there it was, begging her to take it. She lifted up the book, in much better condition than the ones in the library, though the paper was soft against her hands. It wasn’t hardbound. It wasn’t bound at all. It looked like the kind of spiral journal she used to bring to school. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary, too quickly for her to catch or get a good look at. West knelt on the ground, but the floor was in rougher shape than they realized, full of cracks and holes. Whatever fell out of the book could have fallen into any of them. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” She saw Devi almost protest as Nellie slipped the book into her bag, then change her mind, letting Nellie lead them down the stairs. [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry with Diary)]]Nellie shuffled back down to the library, leaving the stars and darkness behind her. “I can only read so much,” said West. “Let’s go.” “You didn’t read anything,” said Devi. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary)]] Nellie ran her hand along the globe, expecting it to spin and feeling silly when it did not. For a moment she thought it was because it was a little broken, that its odd angle was the result of damage from time or vandals or other ghostly investigators who weren’t exactly respectful. Then she suddenly remembered something, a scene in some mobster movie that always struck her as needlessly fancy. “Nellie, don’t break the globe,” Devi warned. “She’s not,” said West. Nellie popped the top off the globe on its hinge, revealing a collection of glass bottles inside half-filled with suspicious brown liquid. “Scotch?” West asked. “I’m not tasting it to find out,” Nellie laughed. “But the crystal’s pretty.” [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry)]]“Wow.” Nellie, Devi, and West looked up at the ceiling, the glass a continuation from the entry room ceiling, which Nellie thought didn’t make sense with the blueprint but she had been warned the mansion would be confusing. Okay, it definitely belonged to the lovers who used it as… yep, a bedroom and an observatory, it was the observatory first, they took it for themselves to not sleep with Bradford after one of the kids died and the romance died too, and the observatory was good for occult stuff-” “Stop saying ‘observatory,’” said West. “Let’s just look around or something. Enjoy the view for a bit.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry)]] [[Telescope - Nellie's Tour (GR from Tapestry)]] [[Side Table - Nellie's Tour (GR from Tapestry)]]Nellie ran her hand along the telescope. “Stop being so suggestive,” West laughed. Nellie guessed he could not see her rolling her eyes, but she rolled them anyway. “Does it work?” Devi asked. “Can a telescope stop working?” West asked. “Let’s find out,” said Nellie. She looked through the telescope and for a moment thought that she had forgotten to check for a lens cap, because all she saw was black. But when she checked, there was no cap. Maybe a telescope could stop working, somehow, but in her gut, she doubted it. She did not understand it, but when she looked through the telescope, all of those beautiful stars disappeared… if they were even there at all. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West, already turning the camera away. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said, reaching into the shadows behind the cube. She never would have seen it without the bright moonlight, but there it was, begging her to take it. She lifted up the book, in much better condition than the ones in the library, though the paper was soft against her hands. It wasn’t hardbound. It wasn’t bound at all. It looked like the kind of spiral journal she used to bring to school. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary, too quickly for her to catch or get a good look at. West knelt on the ground, but the floor was in rougher shape than they realized, full of cracks and holes. Whatever fell out of the book could have fallen into any of them. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR from Tapestry with Diary)]]Nellie shuffled back down to the library, leaving the stars and darkness behind her. “I can only read so much,” said West. “Let’s go.” “You didn’t read anything,” said Devi. “One sec,” said Nellie, rubbing her arms. “I’m not done.” [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] [[Library 2 Globe - Nellie's Tour (GR from Tapestry with Diary)]]Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, felt it sag under her weight like loose moss. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. "Let's go." Let’s go.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe and Tapestry)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West, already turning the camera away. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said, reaching into the shadows behind the cube. She never would have seen it without the bright moonlight, but there it was, begging her to take it. She lifted up the book, in much better condition than the ones in the library, though the paper was soft against her hands. It wasn’t hardbound. It wasn’t bound at all. It looked like the kind of spiral journal she used to bring to school. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary, too quickly for her to catch or get a good look at. West knelt on the ground, but the floor was in rougher shape than they realized, full of cracks and holes. Whatever fell out of the book could have fallen into any of them. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” She saw Devi almost protest as Nellie slipped the book into her bag, then change her mind, letting Nellie lead them down the stairs. [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe with Diary)]]Nellie shuffled back down to the library, leaving the stars and darkness behind her. “I can only read so much,” said West. “Let’s go.” “You didn’t read anything,” said Devi. “One sec,” said Nellie, rubbing her arms. “I’m not done.” [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR)]] [[Library 2 Tapestry - Nellie's Tour (GR from Globe with Diary)]]Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, felt it sag under her weight like loose moss. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. Nellie stared at the tapestry and felt the hairs rise on the back of her neck. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns to give the viewers something to focus on. “Do any of the Benningtons have a ‘V’ name?” “You’re the one with the guidebook,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. "Let's go." [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary)]] “Wow.” Nellie, Devi, and West looked up at the ceiling, the glass a continuation from the entry room ceiling, which Nellie thought didn’t make sense with the blueprint but she had been warned the mansion would be confusing. If she had read the guidebook more closely, perhaps she could have pictured it better in her head. And she wasn’t all that worried about picturing it. She was invested in her current view. Maybe the clouds had passed, or maybe it was the occult magic of the Bennington mansion, but Nellie could have sworn that there were not so many stars in the sky when they drove up. That the moon wasn’t so full. It made her feel like crying. It made her feel small and unimportant. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. Nellie could see the shadowed shapes of beds around her, elegant little boxy things with elegant little boxy side tables, but it was hard to care too much about what was in this room when she could look at what was above it. “Hey, Nellie, you’ve been standing there awhile,” Devi said, giving her should a gentle tap or tug. Nellie made sure her smile didn’t fade for the camera as she pulled her gaze away from the stars to the few items still left in a room that had been mostly cleared out. “What does the guidebook say?” asked West. Nellie squinted at the pages. “I should have read this on the stairs,” said Nellie. “It’s definitely a bedroom. Wait, it’s definitely an observatory. Okay, it definitely belonged to the lovers who used it as… yep, a bedroom and an observatory, it was the observatory first, they took it for themselves to not sleep with Bradford after one of the kids died and the romance died too, and the observatory was good for occult stuff-” “Stop saying ‘observatory,’” said West. “Let’s just look around or something. Enjoy the view for a bit.” [[Telescope - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] [[Side Table - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] “Oh. My. God.” “What is it, Nel?” West asked, hurrying over with the camera. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” “No sludge?” asked Devi, smirking. “No sludge,” Nellie agreed. She pulled out one of the books, with a picture of Nancy crouching behind a staircase still mostly visible on the cover. “Reading isn’t really captivating TV,” West said. “Shh, it’s good for the soul,” Nellie grinned, but her smile dropped. There was something on the shelf, tucked behind the books, glinting in the light of Devi’s flashlight. Nellie did not know what it was yet, but still, she wanted it more than anything, she wanted it to be hers and hers alone. She reached for the sparkling object and tugged it free. A locket on a thin gold chain, warm in her hand. The only warm thing in the world. “You’re shivering again Nel,” said West. “What is that?” Devi asked. “It’s mine,” Nellie snapped, then she shook her head, smiling a weak apology at Devi. “It’s a locket. Just a trinket. Costume jewellery. Not worth anything… I’m going to keep it.” “You okay, Nel?” West asked. “You look-” “Leave me alone West!” Nellie clutched the locket close, considered, then lifted the chain over her head. The locket slipped down the inside of her turtleneck, sliding against her skin, so warm she could barely feel it. Like fingertips along her sternum. Compared to the warmth of the locket, the library had never felt colder. “Let’s get out of here,” said Nellie. “You don’t want to explore anymore?” Devi asked. “It’s freezing,” said Nellie, shaking her head. “I need… We need to go.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie ran her hand along the globe, expecting it to spin and feeling silly when it did not. For a moment she thought it was because it was a little broken, that its odd angle was the result of damage from time or vandals or other ghostly investigators who weren’t exactly respectful. Then she suddenly remembered something, a scene in some mobster movie that always struck her as needlessly fancy. “Nellie, don’t break the globe,” Devi warned. “She’s not,” said West. Nellie popped the top off the globe on its hinge, revealing a collection of glass bottles inside half-filled with suspicious brown liquid. “Scotch?” West asked. “I’m not tasting it to find out,” Nellie laughed. “But the crystal’s pretty.” [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] [[Tapestry - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Globe)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Globe)]] Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, felt it sag under her weight like loose moss. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. Nellie stared at the tapestry and felt the hairs rise on the back of her neck. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns to give the viewers something to focus on. “Do any of the Benningtons have a ‘V’ name?” “You’re the one with the guidebook,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] [[Globe - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Tapestry)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Tapestry)]]Nellie ran her hand along the telescope. “Stop being so suggestive,” West laughed. Nellie guessed he could not see her rolling her eyes, but she rolled them anyway. “Does it work?” Devi asked. “Can a telescope stop working?” West asked. “Let’s find out,” said Nellie. She looked through the telescope and for a moment thought that she had forgotten to check for a lens cap, because all she saw was black. But when she checked, there was no cap. Maybe a telescope could stop working, somehow, but in her gut, she doubted it. She did not understand it, but when she looked through the telescope, all of those beautiful stars disappeared… if they were even there at all. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. [[Side Table - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West, already turning the camera away. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said, reaching into the shadows behind the cube. She never would have seen it without the bright moonlight, but there it was, begging her to take it. She lifted up the book, in much better condition than the ones in the library, though the paper was soft against her hands. It wasn’t hardbound. It wasn’t bound at all. It looked like the kind of spiral journal she used to bring to school. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary, too quickly for her to catch or get a good look at. West knelt on the ground, but the floor was in rougher shape than they realized, full of cracks and holes. Whatever fell out of the book could have fallen into any of them. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” "Guys, we've barely looked around this part of the house and you're already..." Devi trailed off, taking deep breaths. Nellie and West glanced at each other. "We always take stuff like this for the show," Nellie said. "I know," Devi snapped. "You usually just do a bit more investigating first. First the ribbon, now this? There was a whole library downstairs and you came up here-" "We can still explore the library," Nellie cut in. "Or... we could move on?" West suggested. Devi didn't respond, so Nellie nodded for her. It felt wrong to answer for her, but Devi was already shuffling down the stairs. West shrugged his confusion, and they followed her further into the mansion. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] “Do you want my hoodie, Nellie?” Devi asked. Nellie was shivering still, but she shook her head. “Continuity,” she said. “I’ll survive. We just need to… keep looking around. Film. Stuff.” Nellie pretended not to see Devi and West share a concerned glance. They had too much to do, and she only had enough energy to try to keep walking with making her trembling too obvious. The locket was not warm enough to ease the chill of the house. She wished she had worn a thicker turtleneck. She didn’t care if it would ruin the audio. Her chattering teeth might do that anyway. She tried to ignore the cold that settled into her bones and focus on the room. Nellie was expecting something a little more sinister from a man who made the papers for claiming to have accessed uncharted netherworlds full of nightmares beyond our comprehension, but she supposed those pursuits were best left to the young. Or at least left in the past with flared jeans and sequin tops. When life came at you hard and fast, or the illusion of fast after decades of smoking cigars and ignoring the persistent cough that came with it, you didn’t have time for spirits and demons anymore. Maybe at one point there was a stately wooden bed or some hyper-modern monstrosity of a bed, but all that was left in the room was one of those hospital-style rolling gurneys. A fancy one, wider and with deeper cushions than anything Nellie saw at her grandmother’s nursing home, but if you didn’t know expensive hospital equipment you wouldn’t have been impressed. “Guidebook?” West asked. “There’s nothing for this room,” Nellie said. “Bradford was alive when the tours were happening, but he would stay shut in his room. No one was allowed to see him or come here. Besides, this was his private space.” “Is that normal?” West asked. “To have tours in a place where someone is actively living?” “I think there are some castle tours in Scotland like that,” said Devi. “Haunted ones?” West asked, perking up. “We should do a trip. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. There was another door on the far wall, as solid as the front door to the entry room, but this handle turned easily. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said and Nellie dropped the handle. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Nellie left the door for later, stepped around a few sunken sections of carpet, and pretended to look thoughtfully at the framed pictures on the wall in case West was filming her. If she looked distressed, it would add to the haunted vibe, she supposed. West was filming a wardrobe in the corner, which may have been engraved in violent gouging designs or else it had been beset by gnawing rats at some point. Devi was standing by the hospital bed, looking particularly forlorn. “Anything interesting?” Nellie asked, but she couldn’t make her voice quite as enthusiastic as she hoped. [[Hospital Bed - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Wardrobe - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]]Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, felt it sag under her weight like loose moss. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. Nellie stared at the tapestry and felt the hairs rise on the back of her neck. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Okay, it definitely belonged to the lovers who used it as… yep, a bedroom and an observatory, it was the observatory first, they took it for themselves to not sleep with Bradford after one of the kids died and the romance died too, and the observatory was good for occult stuff-” “Stop saying ‘observatory,’” said West. “Let’s just look around or something. Enjoy the view for a bit.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Globe and Tapestry)]] [[Telescope - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Globe)]] [[Side Table - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Globe)]]“Wow.” Nellie, Devi, and West looked up at the ceiling, the glass a continuation from the entry room ceiling, which Nellie thought didn’t make sense with the blueprint but she had been warned the mansion would be confusing. Enjoy the view for a bit.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Globe and Tapestry)]] [[Telescope - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Tapestry)]] [[Side Table - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Tapestry)]]Nellie shuffled back down to the library, leaving the stars and darkness behind her. “I can only read so much,” said West. “Let’s go.” “You didn’t read anything,” said Devi. “One sec,” said Nellie, rubbing her arms. “I’m not done.” [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] Nellie ran her hand along the telescope. “Stop being so suggestive,” West laughed. Nellie guessed he could not see her rolling her eyes, but she rolled them anyway. “Does it work?” Devi asked. “Can a telescope stop working?” West asked. “Let’s find out,” said Nellie. She looked through the telescope and for a moment thought that she had forgotten to check for a lens cap, because all she saw was black. But when she checked, there was no cap. Maybe a telescope could stop working, somehow, but in her gut, she doubted it. She did not understand it, but when she looked through the telescope, all of those beautiful stars disappeared… if they were even there at all. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Globe and Tapestry)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West, already turning the camera away. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said, reaching into the shadows behind the cube. She never would have seen it without the bright moonlight, but there it was, begging her to take it. She lifted up the book, in much better condition than the ones in the library, though the paper was soft against her hands. It wasn’t hardbound. It wasn’t bound at all. It looked like the kind of spiral journal she used to bring to school. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary, too quickly for her to catch or get a good look at. West knelt on the ground, but the floor was in rougher shape than they realized, full of cracks and holes. Whatever fell out of the book could have fallen into any of them. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” She saw Devi almost protest as Nellie slipped the book into her bag, then change her mind, letting Nellie lead them down the stairs. [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary and Ribbon from Globe and Tapestry)]]Nellie shuffled back down to the library, leaving the stars and darkness behind her. “I can only read so much,” said West. “Let’s go.” “You didn’t read anything,” said Devi. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary and Ribbon)]] Devi frowned, one hand on her headphones, the other on the recorder in her hand. "You okay?" asked West. "No," Devi muttered. "I didn't actually catch that audio in the Groove Room." "Right..." Nellie drawled. "I heard something!" Devi insisted. "No use crying over spilled ectoplasm," said West. "Gross," said Devi. "He's right though," said Nellie. "Can't do anything about it except keep moving forward."
