[[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary and Ribbon from Globe)]]Nellie ran her hand along the telescope. “Stop being so suggestive,” West laughed. Nellie guessed he could not see her rolling her eyes, but she rolled them anyway. “Does it work?” Devi asked. “Can a telescope stop working?” West asked. “Let’s find out,” said Nellie. She looked through the telescope and for a moment thought that she had forgotten to check for a lens cap, because all she saw was black. But when she checked, there was no cap. Maybe a telescope could stop working, somehow, but in her gut, she doubted it. She did not understand it, but when she looked through the telescope, all of those beautiful stars disappeared… if they were even there at all. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon from Globe and Tapestry)]]Nellie ran her hand along the telescope. “Stop being so suggestive,” West laughed. Nellie guessed he could not see her rolling her eyes, but she rolled them anyway. “Does it work?” Devi asked. “Can a telescope stop working?” West asked. “Let’s find out,” said Nellie. She looked through the telescope and for a moment thought that she had forgotten to check for a lens cap, because all she saw was black. But when she checked, there was no cap. Maybe a telescope could stop working, somehow, but in her gut, she doubted it. She did not understand it, but when she looked through the telescope, all of those beautiful stars disappeared… if they were even there at all. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” [[Library 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary and Ribbon from Tapestry)]]Nellie shuffled back down to the library, leaving the stars and darkness behind her. “I can only read so much,” said West. “Let’s go.” “You didn’t read anything,” said Devi. “One sec,” said Nellie, rubbing her arms. “I’m not done.” [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] [[Library 2 Tapestry - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary and Ribbon from Globe)]]Nellie shuffled back down to the library, leaving the stars and darkness behind her. “I can only read so much,” said West. “Let’s go.” “You didn’t read anything,” said Devi. “One sec,” said Nellie, rubbing her arms. “I’m not done.” [[Bookshelves - Nellie's Tour (GR with Ribbon)]] [[Library 2 Globe - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary and Ribbon from Globe)]]Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, felt it sag under her weight like loose moss. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. Nellie stared at the tapestry and felt the hairs rise on the back of her neck. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns to give the viewers something to focus on. “Do any of the Benningtons have a ‘V’ name?” “You’re the one with the guidebook,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. "Let's go." [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie ran her hand along the globe, expecting it to spin and feeling silly when it did not. For a moment she thought it was because it was a little broken, that its odd angle was the result of damage from time or vandals or other ghostly investigators who weren’t exactly respectful. Then she suddenly remembered something, a scene in some mobster movie that always struck her as needlessly fancy. “Nellie, don’t break the globe,” Devi warned. “She’s not,” said West. Nellie popped the top off the globe on its hinge, revealing a collection of glass bottles inside half-filled with suspicious brown liquid. “Scotch?” West asked. “I’m not tasting it to find out,” Nellie laughed. “But the crystal’s pretty. Let's go." [[Bradford's Bedroom - Nellie's Tour (GR with Diary and Ribbon)]] “There’s a letter on this bed,” Devi said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West, squelching across the wet carpet to her. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, Nellie, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. “Careful with that!” Nellie said. “West, film me. He apologizes to Tara, tells her she has responsibilities, and says… this is hard to make out, it’s so dark in here… He says Mark was a threat to the family, he did what he had to do…” “Is he confessing to killing him?” asked West. “He might just be confessing to kicking him out,” Nellie said, shaking her head. “There aren’t any specifics. Okay, then he says his daughter Dawn never understood, she was a danger… she was in danger? Well, there’s a paragraph about Dawn and danger and… Emma?” “Emma was Dawn’s girlfriend,” Devi said, then shook her head. “Well, her tragically dead girlfriend.” “The writing isn't clear there,” said Nellie. “But then he says he’s trapped, he just wants to be free, maybe it’s a final gift he can give Tara… ugh. Oh no.” “What?” asked Devi. “He’s asking her to sacrifice him. For her own freedom.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment, the only sound West’s boots shifting on the wet carpet. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. “We don’t even know if this note is real,” said Nellie, placing the now more crumpled paper back on the hospital bed. “One of Devi’s amateur sleuths could have left it behind.” “They’re not ‘my’ sleuths,” Devi mumbled. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] “If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe appeared to be a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “What do you say, fearless leader? Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. My flashlight’s batteries are dead.” “Well, what else are we going to show our viewers?” asked West, grinning at Devi, but his good cheer felt like more like a challenge than a joke. [[Hospital Bed - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Basement - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] “There’s a letter on this bed,” Devi said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West, squelching across the wet carpet to her. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, Nellie, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. “Careful with that!” Nellie said. “West, film me. He apologizes to Tara, tells her she has responsibilities, and says… this is hard to make out, it’s so dark in here… He says Mark was a threat to the family, he did what he had to do…” “Is he confessing to killing him?” asked West. “He might just be confessing to kicking him out,” Nellie said, shaking her head. “There aren’t any specifics. Okay, then he says his daughter Dawn never understood, she was a danger… she was in danger? Well, there’s a paragraph about Dawn and danger and… Emma?” “Emma was Dawn’s girlfriend,” Devi said, then shook her head. “Well, her tragically dead girlfriend.” “The writing isn't clear there,” said Nellie. “But then he says he’s trapped, he just wants to be free, maybe it’s a final gift he can give Tara… ugh. Oh no.” “What?” asked Devi. “He’s asking her to sacrifice him. For her own freedom.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment, the only sound West’s boots shifting on the wet carpet. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. “We don’t even know if this note is real,” said Nellie, placing the now more crumpled paper back on the hospital bed. “One of Devi’s amateur sleuths could have left it behind.” “They’re not ‘my’ sleuths,” Devi mumbled. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]]“If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe appeared to be a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “What do you say, fearless leader? Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. My flashlight’s batteries are dead.” “Well, what else are we going to show our viewers?” asked West, grinning at Devi, but his good cheer felt like more like a challenge than a joke. [[Hospital Bed - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Basement - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]]Nellie stepped into the hot, dry desert air of the garden and immediately felt a weight lift from her shoulders. A high thick fence, at least ten feet high, kept them enclosed on the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, but the open sky above her felt like freedom. The darkness, the rot of the interior was impossibly oppressive. She took a gulp of air that tasted like salt and strawberries, sweetness sharpened to an edge. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers, some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others speckled in clusters like Nellie had never seen before. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red, so ripe that Nellie expected the petals to stain her fingers. “Hold that position,” said West, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Her pointing finger guided Nellie’s eyes along the swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. If the walls weren’t so smooth, that gentle beige-pink that matched the rest of the mansion’s exterior, she would have guessed it was a gazebo that had been boarded up. The windows, covered by nailed planks of wood, gave that impression. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the path. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, relieved to have an excuse to stay outside a little longer. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. “Nellie, I think that’s the first time you actually read the entry in its entirety,” Devi said, both teasing and pleased. “I wanted to end the show with a professional bang,” Nellie shrugged. She wanted to keep them outside for as long as possible. But her crew was waiting, so she made herself a fearless leader and opened the door to the Gallery. The darkness felt like it was grabbing at her as they went inside. “Keep the door open,” she instructed West who nodded, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like clawing fingers. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Triad - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] [[A Constellation - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]]“Okay, West, but if I die here, I am coming back to haunt you,” said Nellie. “I completely understand, and you have my full permission,” said West. “Devi, if it’s too scary for you-” “I’m coming,” Devi grumbled. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity.” Nellie led the way down the stairs. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down. At least these stairs were broad, and free of that sludge. Nellie kept one hand against the curving wall beside her, surprised at how much warmer it was than her skin. She thought about asking the others if it felt the same to them, but changed her mind. “Are you saying that if monsters strike you won’t be screaming?” Nellie asked, pleased that her voice sounded even despite her growing trepidation. “When it comes to ‘fight’ or ‘flight,’ I’m a straight up ‘freeze,’” Devi said. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Nellie could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid underground. It almost looked like faint starlight, the same light that illuminated the rest of the house, but it was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi, her voice quavering slightly. Nellie walked towards it, though she could feel Devi’s distress at her choice. It did not look like it was glowing, not like a light bulb or some kind of fluorescent novelty item, which wouldn’t have been so strange for an occult 1970s millionaire to have. The light was gentle, if fog could be light that was how it felt to Nellie. It was kind of nice. Warm, like the wall. Soothing. She set a hand on the flat, round surface, and it was perfectly smooth, not dusty like the stairs, except for a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. “A ‘V,’” murmured Devi. “Horns,” said West. Nellie didn’t care. It was warmer than the fog, the walls. It was wrong. It knew they were there. “We should leave the house,” said Nellie before she could think about what she was saying. “We don’t have enough footage yet for the show,” West protested. “This is cool, but it’s not like we can just be done because we found something good.” “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi said. “We can’t lose this opportunity. Unless… unless you’re really not feeling well or something like that?” Nellie shrugged off Devi’s comforting hand on her shoulder. “You’re right,” Nellie said. “Both of you. I’m fine. I’ll be fine. Let’s just get to the gallery… Did you get that West?” “Damn it, Nellie, was that a performance?” Nellie grinned, and hoped it was convincing. “Back up to reality we go,” she said, letting her smile fade as the crew filed in behind her, careful now not to touch the wall, no matter how nice she knew it would feel. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]] Nellie stepped into the hot, dry desert air of the garden and immediately felt a weight lift from her shoulders. A high thick fence, at least ten feet high, kept them enclosed on the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, but the open sky above her felt like freedom. The darkness, the rot of the interior was impossibly oppressive. She took a gulp of air that tasted like salt and strawberries, sweetness sharpened to an edge. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers, some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others speckled in clusters like Nellie had never seen before. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red, so ripe that Nellie expected the petals to stain her fingers. “Hold that position,” said West, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Her pointing finger guided Nellie’s eyes along the swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. If the walls weren’t so smooth, that gentle beige-pink that matched the rest of the mansion’s exterior, she would have guessed it was a gazebo that had been boarded up. The windows, covered by nailed planks of wood, gave that impression. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the path. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, relieved to have an excuse to stay outside a little longer. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. “Nellie, I think that’s the first time you actually read the entry in its entirety,” Devi said, both teasing and pleased. “I wanted to end the show with a professional bang,” Nellie shrugged. She wanted to keep them outside for as long as possible. But her crew was waiting, so she made herself a fearless leader and opened the door to the Gallery. The darkness felt like it was grabbing at her as they went inside. “Keep the door open,” she instructed West who nodded, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like clawing fingers. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[A Constellation - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]] [[The Triad - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]]Nellie stepped into the hot, dry desert air of the garden and immediately felt a weight lift from her shoulders. A high thick fence, at least ten feet high, kept them enclosed on the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, but the open sky above her felt like freedom. The darkness, the rot of the interior was impossibly oppressive. She took a gulp of air that tasted like salt and strawberries, sweetness sharpened to an edge. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers, some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others speckled in clusters like Nellie had never seen before. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red, so ripe that Nellie expected the petals to stain her fingers. “Hold that position,” said West, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Her pointing finger guided Nellie’s eyes along the swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. If the walls weren’t so smooth, that gentle beige-pink that matched the rest of the mansion’s exterior, she would have guessed it was a gazebo that had been boarded up. The windows, covered by nailed planks of wood, gave that impression. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the path. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, relieved to have an excuse to stay outside a little longer. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. “Nellie, I think that’s the first time you actually read the entry in its entirety,” Devi said, both teasing and pleased. “I wanted to end the show with a professional bang,” Nellie shrugged. She wanted to keep them outside for as long as possible. But her crew was waiting, so she made herself a fearless leader and opened the door to the Gallery. The darkness felt like it was grabbing at her as they went inside. “Keep the door open,” she instructed West who nodded, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like clawing fingers. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[A Constellation - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[The Triad - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]]“Okay, West, but if I die here, I am coming back to haunt you,” said Nellie. “I completely understand, and you have my full permission,” said West. “Devi, if it’s too scary for you-” “I’m coming,” Devi grumbled. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity.” Nellie led the way down the stairs. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down. At least these stairs were broad, and free of that sludge. Nellie kept one hand against the curving wall beside her, surprised at how much warmer it was than her skin. She thought about asking the others if it felt the same to them, but changed her mind. “Are you saying that if monsters strike you won’t be screaming?” Nellie asked, pleased that her voice sounded even despite her growing trepidation. “When it comes to ‘fight’ or ‘flight,’ I’m a straight up ‘freeze,’” Devi said. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Nellie could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid underground. It almost looked like faint starlight, the same light that illuminated the rest of the house, but it was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi, her voice quavering slightly. Nellie walked towards it, though she could feel Devi’s distress at her choice. It did not look like it was glowing, not like a light bulb or some kind of fluorescent novelty item, which wouldn’t have been so strange for an occult 1970s millionaire to have. The light was gentle, if fog could be light that was how it felt to Nellie. It was kind of nice. Warm, like the wall. Soothing. She set a hand on the flat, round surface, and it was perfectly smooth, not dusty like the stairs, except for a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. “A ‘V,’” murmured Devi. “Horns,” said West. Nellie didn’t care. It was warmer than the fog, the walls. It was wrong. It knew they were there. “We should leave the house,” said Nellie before she could think about what she was saying. “We don’t have enough footage yet for the show,” West protested. “This is cool, but it’s not like we can just be done because we found something good.” “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi said. “We can’t lose this opportunity. Unless… unless you’re really not feeling well or something like that?” Nellie shrugged off Devi’s comforting hand on her shoulder. “You’re right,” Nellie said. “Both of you. I’m fine. I’ll be fine. Let’s just get to the gallery… Did you get that West?” “Damn it, Nellie, was that a performance?” Nellie grinned, and hoped it was convincing. “Back up to reality we go,” she said, letting her smile fade as the crew filed in behind her, careful now not to touch the wall, no matter how nice she knew it would feel. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]]Nellie stepped into the hot, dry desert air of the garden and immediately felt a weight lift from her shoulders. A high thick fence, at least ten feet high, kept them enclosed on the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, but the open sky above her felt like freedom. The darkness, the rot of the interior was impossibly oppressive. She took a gulp of air that tasted like salt and strawberries, sweetness sharpened to an edge. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers, some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others speckled in clusters like Nellie had never seen before. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red, so ripe that Nellie expected the petals to stain her fingers. “Hold that position,” said West, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Her pointing finger guided Nellie’s eyes along the swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. If the walls weren’t so smooth, that gentle beige-pink that matched the rest of the mansion’s exterior, she would have guessed it was a gazebo that had been boarded up. The windows, covered by nailed planks of wood, gave that impression. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the path. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, relieved to have an excuse to stay outside a little longer. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. “Nellie, I think that’s the first time you actually read the entry in its entirety,” Devi said, both teasing and pleased. “I wanted to end the show with a professional bang,” Nellie shrugged. She wanted to keep them outside for as long as possible. But her crew was waiting, so she made herself a fearless leader and opened the door to the Gallery. The darkness felt like it was grabbing at her as they went inside. “Keep the door open,” she instructed West who nodded, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like clawing fingers. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[A Constellation - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[The Triad - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]]“There’s a letter on this bed,” Devi said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West, squelching across the wet carpet to her. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, Nellie, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. “Careful with that!” Nellie said. “West, film me. He apologizes to Tara, tells her she has responsibilities, and says… this is hard to make out, it’s so dark in here… He says Mark was a threat to the family, he did what he had to do…” “Is he confessing to killing him?” asked West. “He might just be confessing to kicking him out,” Nellie said, shaking her head. “There aren’t any specifics. Okay, then he says his daughter Dawn never understood, she was a danger… she was in danger? Well, there’s a paragraph about Dawn and danger and… Emma?” “Emma was Dawn’s girlfriend,” Devi said, then shook her head. “Well, her tragically dead girlfriend.” “The writing isn't clear there,” said Nellie. “But then he says he’s trapped, he just wants to be free, maybe it’s a final gift he can give Tara… ugh. Oh no.” “What?” asked Devi. “He’s asking her to sacrifice him. For her own freedom.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment, the only sound West’s boots shifting on the wet carpet. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. “We don’t even know if this note is real,” said Nellie, placing the now more crumpled paper back on the hospital bed. “One of Devi’s amateur sleuths could have left it behind.” “They’re not ‘my’ sleuths,” Devi mumbled. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]]“If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe appeared to be a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “What do you say, fearless leader? Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. My flashlight’s batteries are dead.” “Well, what else are we going to show our viewers?” asked West, grinning at Devi, but his good cheer felt like more like a challenge than a joke. [[Hospital Bed - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Basement - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]]Nellie stepped into the hot, dry desert air of the garden and immediately felt a weight lift from her shoulders. A high thick fence, at least ten feet high, kept them enclosed on the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, but the open sky above her felt like freedom. The darkness, the rot of the interior was impossibly oppressive. She took a gulp of air that tasted like salt and strawberries, sweetness sharpened to an edge. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers, some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others speckled in clusters like Nellie had never seen before. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red, so ripe that Nellie expected the petals to stain her fingers. “Hold that position,” said West, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Her pointing finger guided Nellie’s eyes along the swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. If the walls weren’t so smooth, that gentle beige-pink that matched the rest of the mansion’s exterior, she would have guessed it was a gazebo that had been boarded up. The windows, covered by nailed planks of wood, gave that impression. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the path. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, relieved to have an excuse to stay outside a little longer. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. “Nellie, I think that’s the first time you actually read the entry in its entirety,” Devi said, both teasing and pleased. “I wanted to end the show with a professional bang,” Nellie shrugged. She wanted to keep them outside for as long as possible. But her crew was waiting, so she made herself a fearless leader and opened the door to the Gallery. The darkness felt like it was grabbing at her as they went inside. “Keep the door open,” she instructed West who nodded, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like clawing fingers. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[A Constellation - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] [[The Triad - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]]“Okay, West, but if I die here, I am coming back to haunt you,” said Nellie. “I completely understand, and you have my full permission,” said West. “Devi, if it’s too scary for you-” “I’m coming,” Devi grumbled. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity.” Nellie led the way down the stairs. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down. At least these stairs were broad, and free of that sludge. Nellie kept one hand against the curving wall beside her, surprised at how much warmer it was than her skin. She thought about asking the others if it felt the same to them, but changed her mind. “Are you saying that if monsters strike you won’t be screaming?” Nellie asked, pleased that her voice sounded even despite her growing trepidation. “When it comes to ‘fight’ or ‘flight,’ I’m a straight up ‘freeze,’” Devi said. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Nellie could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid underground. It almost looked like faint starlight, the same light that illuminated the rest of the house, but it was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi, her voice quavering slightly. Nellie walked towards it, though she could feel Devi’s distress at her choice. It did not look like it was glowing, not like a light bulb or some kind of fluorescent novelty item, which wouldn’t have been so strange for an occult 1970s millionaire to have. The light was gentle, if fog could be light that was how it felt to Nellie. It was kind of nice. Warm, like the wall. Soothing. She set a hand on the flat, round surface, and it was perfectly smooth, not dusty like the stairs, except for a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. “A ‘V,’” murmured Devi. “Horns,” said West. Nellie didn’t care. It was warmer than the fog, the walls. It was wrong. It knew they were there. “We should leave the house,” said Nellie before she could think about what she was saying. “We don’t have enough footage yet for the show,” West protested. “This is cool, but it’s not like we can just be done because we found something good.” “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi said. “We can’t lose this opportunity. Unless… unless you’re really not feeling well or something like that?” Nellie shrugged off Devi’s comforting hand on her shoulder. “You’re right,” Nellie said. “Both of you. I’m fine. I’ll be fine. Let’s just get to the gallery… Did you get that West?” “Damn it, Nellie, was that a performance?” Nellie grinned, and hoped it was convincing. “Back up to reality we go,” she said, letting her smile fade as the crew filed in behind her, careful now not to touch the wall, no matter how nice she knew it would feel. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]]Nellie stepped into the hot, dry desert air of the garden and immediately felt a weight lift from her shoulders. A high thick fence, at least ten feet high, kept them enclosed on the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, but the open sky above her felt like freedom. The darkness, the rot of the interior was impossibly oppressive. She took a gulp of air that tasted like salt and strawberries, sweetness sharpened to an edge. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Her pointing finger guided Nellie’s eyes along the swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. If the walls weren’t so smooth, that gentle beige-pink that matched the rest of the mansion’s exterior, she would have guessed it was a gazebo that had been boarded up. The windows, covered by nailed planks of wood, gave that impression. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the path. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, relieved to have an excuse to stay outside a little longer. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. “Nellie, I think that’s the first time you actually read the entry in its entirety,” Devi said, both teasing and pleased. “I wanted to end the show with a professional bang,” Nellie shrugged. She wanted to keep them outside for as long as possible. But her crew was waiting, so she made herself a fearless leader and opened the door to the Gallery. The darkness felt like it was grabbing at her as they went inside. “Keep the door open,” she instructed West who nodded, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like clawing fingers. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[A Constellation - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]] [[The Triad - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]]“There’s a letter on this bed,” Devi said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West, squelching across the wet carpet to her. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, Nellie, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. “Careful with that!” Nellie said. “West, film me. He apologizes to Tara, tells her she has responsibilities, and says… this is hard to make out, it’s so dark in here… He says Mark was a threat to the family, he did what he had to do…” “Is he confessing to killing him?” asked West. “He might just be confessing to kicking him out,” Nellie said, shaking her head. “There aren’t any specifics.
