It did not look like it was glowing, not like a light bulb or some kind of fluorescent novelty item, which wouldn’t have been so strange for an occult 1970s millionaire to have. The light was gentle, if fog could be light that was how it felt to Nellie. It was kind of nice. Warm, like the wall. Soothing. She set a hand on the flat, round surface, and it was perfectly smooth, not dusty like the stairs, except for a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. “A ‘V,’” murmured Devi. “Horns,” said West. Nellie didn’t care. It was warmer than the fog, the walls. It was wrong. It knew they were there. “We should leave the house,” said Nellie before she could think about what she was saying. “We don’t have enough footage yet for the show,” West protested. “This is cool, but it’s not like we can just be done because we found something good.” “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi said. “We can’t lose this opportunity. Unless… unless you’re really not feeling well or something like that?” Nellie shrugged off Devi’s comforting hand on her shoulder. “You’re right,” Nellie said. “Both of you. I’m fine. I’ll be fine. Let’s just get to the gallery… Did you get that West?” “Damn it, Nellie, was that a performance?” Nellie grinned, and hoped it was convincing. “Back up to reality we go,” she said, letting her smile fade as the crew filed in behind her, careful now not to touch the wall, no matter how nice she knew it would feel. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]]“There’s a letter on this bed,” Devi said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West, squelching across the wet carpet to her. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, Nellie, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. “Careful with that!” Nellie said. “West, film me. He apologizes to Tara, tells her she has responsibilities, and says… this is hard to make out, it’s so dark in here… He says Mark was a threat to the family, he did what he had to do…” “Is he confessing to killing him?” asked West. “He might just be confessing to kicking him out,” Nellie said, shaking her head. “There aren’t any specifics. Okay, then he says his daughter Dawn never understood, she was a danger… she was in danger? Well, there’s a paragraph about Dawn and danger and… Emma?” “Emma was Dawn’s girlfriend,” Devi said, then shook her head. “Well, her tragically dead girlfriend.” “The writing isn't clear there,” said Nellie. “But then he says he’s trapped, he just wants to be free, maybe it’s a final gift he can give Tara… ugh. Oh no.” “What?” asked Devi. “He’s asking her to sacrifice him. For her own freedom.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment, the only sound West’s boots shifting on the wet carpet. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. “We don’t even know if this note is real,” said Nellie, placing the now more crumpled paper back on the hospital bed. “One of Devi’s amateur sleuths could have left it behind.” “They’re not ‘my’ sleuths,” Devi mumbled. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]]“If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe appeared to be a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “What do you say, fearless leader? Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. My flashlight’s batteries are dead.” “Well, what else are we going to show our viewers?” asked West, grinning at Devi, but his good cheer felt like more like a challenge than a joke. [[Hospital Bed - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] [[Basement - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]]Nellie stepped into the hot, dry desert air of the garden and immediately felt a weight lift from her shoulders. A high thick fence, at least ten feet high, kept them enclosed on the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, but the open sky above her felt like freedom. The darkness, the rot of the interior was impossibly oppressive. She took a gulp of air that tasted like salt and strawberries, sweetness sharpened to an edge. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers, some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others speckled in clusters like Nellie had never seen before. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red, so ripe that Nellie expected the petals to stain her fingers. “Hold that position,” said West, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Her pointing finger guided Nellie’s eyes along the swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. If the walls weren’t so smooth, that gentle beige-pink that matched the rest of the mansion’s exterior, she would have guessed it was a gazebo that had been boarded up. The windows, covered by nailed planks of wood, gave that impression. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the path. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, relieved to have an excuse to stay outside a little longer. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. “Nellie, I think that’s the first time you actually read the entry in its entirety,” Devi said, both teasing and pleased. “I wanted to end the show with a professional bang,” Nellie shrugged. She wanted to keep them outside for as long as possible. But her crew was waiting, so she made herself a fearless leader and opened the door to the Gallery. The darkness felt like it was grabbing at her as they went inside. “Keep the door open,” she instructed West who nodded, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like clawing fingers. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[A Constellation - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] [[The Triad - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]]“Okay, West, but if I die here, I am coming back to haunt you,” said Nellie. “I completely understand, and you have my full permission,” said West. “Devi, if it’s too scary for you-” “I’m coming,” Devi grumbled. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity.” Nellie led the way down the stairs. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down. At least these stairs were broad, and free of that sludge. Nellie kept one hand against the curving wall beside her, surprised at how much warmer it was than her skin. She thought about asking the others if it felt the same to them, but changed her mind. “Are you saying that if monsters strike you won’t be screaming?” Nellie asked, pleased that her voice sounded even despite her growing trepidation. “When it comes to ‘fight’ or ‘flight,’ I’m a straight up ‘freeze,’” Devi said. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Nellie could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid underground. It almost looked like faint starlight, the same light that illuminated the rest of the house, but it was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi, her voice quavering slightly. Nellie walked towards it, though she could feel Devi’s distress at her choice. It did not look like it was glowing, not like a light bulb or some kind of fluorescent novelty item, which wouldn’t have been so strange for an occult 1970s millionaire to have. The light was gentle, if fog could be light that was how it felt to Nellie. It was kind of nice. Warm, like the wall. Soothing. She set a hand on the flat, round surface, and it was perfectly smooth, not dusty like the stairs, except for a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. “A ‘V,’” murmured Devi. “Horns,” said West. Nellie didn’t care. It was warmer than the fog, the walls. It was wrong. It knew they were there. “We should leave the house,” said Nellie before she could think about what she was saying. “We don’t have enough footage yet for the show,” West protested. “This is cool, but it’s not like we can just be done because we found something good.” “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi said. “We can’t lose this opportunity. Unless… unless you’re really not feeling well or something like that?” Nellie shrugged off Devi’s comforting hand on her shoulder. “You’re right,” Nellie said. “Both of you. I’m fine. I’ll be fine. Let’s just get to the gallery… Did you get that West?” “Damn it, Nellie, was that a performance?” Nellie grinned, and hoped it was convincing. “Back up to reality we go,” she said, letting her smile fade as the crew filed in behind her, careful now not to touch the wall, no matter how nice she knew it would feel. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]]“There’s a letter on this bed,” Devi said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West, squelching across the wet carpet to her. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, Nellie, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. “Careful with that!” Nellie said. “West, film me. He apologizes to Tara, tells her she has responsibilities, and says… this is hard to make out, it’s so dark in here… He says Mark was a threat to the family, he did what he had to do…” “Is he confessing to killing him?” asked West. “He might just be confessing to kicking him out,” Nellie said, shaking her head. “There aren’t any specifics. Okay, then he says his daughter Dawn never understood, she was a danger… she was in danger? Well, there’s a paragraph about Dawn and danger and… Emma?” “Emma was Dawn’s girlfriend,” Devi said, then shook her head. “Well, her tragically dead girlfriend.” “The writing isn't clear there,” said Nellie. “But then he says he’s trapped, he just wants to be free, maybe it’s a final gift he can give Tara… ugh. Oh no.” “What?” asked Devi. “He’s asking her to sacrifice him. For her own freedom.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment, the only sound West’s boots shifting on the wet carpet. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. “We don’t even know if this note is real,” said Nellie, placing the now more crumpled paper back on the hospital bed. “One of Devi’s amateur sleuths could have left it behind.” “They’re not ‘my’ sleuths,” Devi mumbled. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]]“If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe appeared to be a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “What do you say, fearless leader? Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. My flashlight’s batteries are dead.” “Well, what else are we going to show our viewers?” asked West, grinning at Devi, but his good cheer felt like more like a challenge than a joke. [[Hospital Bed - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Basement - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]]Nellie stepped into the hot, dry desert air of the garden and immediately felt a weight lift from her shoulders. A high thick fence, at least ten feet high, kept them enclosed on the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, but the open sky above her felt like freedom. The darkness, the rot of the interior was impossibly oppressive. She took a gulp of air that tasted like salt and strawberries, sweetness sharpened to an edge. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers, some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others speckled in clusters like Nellie had never seen before. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red, so ripe that Nellie expected the petals to stain her fingers. “Hold that position,” said West, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Her pointing finger guided Nellie’s eyes along the swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. If the walls weren’t so smooth, that gentle beige-pink that matched the rest of the mansion’s exterior, she would have guessed it was a gazebo that had been boarded up. The windows, covered by nailed planks of wood, gave that impression. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the path. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, relieved to have an excuse to stay outside a little longer. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. “Nellie, I think that’s the first time you actually read the entry in its entirety,” Devi said, both teasing and pleased. “I wanted to end the show with a professional bang,” Nellie shrugged. She wanted to keep them outside for as long as possible. But her crew was waiting, so she made herself a fearless leader and opened the door to the Gallery. The darkness felt like it was grabbing at her as they went inside. “Keep the door open,” she instructed West who nodded, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like clawing fingers. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[A Constellation - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[The Triad - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]]“Okay, West, but if I die here, I am coming back to haunt you,” said Nellie. “I completely understand, and you have my full permission,” said West. “Devi, if it’s too scary for you-” “I’m coming,” Devi grumbled. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity.” Nellie led the way down the stairs. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down. At least these stairs were broad, and free of that sludge. Nellie kept one hand against the curving wall beside her, surprised at how much warmer it was than her skin. She thought about asking the others if it felt the same to them, but changed her mind. “Are you saying that if monsters strike you won’t be screaming?” Nellie asked, pleased that her voice sounded even despite her growing trepidation. “When it comes to ‘fight’ or ‘flight,’ I’m a straight up ‘freeze,’” Devi said. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Nellie could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid underground. It almost looked like faint starlight, the same light that illuminated the rest of the house, but it was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi, her voice quavering slightly. Nellie walked towards it, though she could feel Devi’s distress at her choice. It did not look like it was glowing, not like a light bulb or some kind of fluorescent novelty item, which wouldn’t have been so strange for an occult 1970s millionaire to have. The light was gentle, if fog could be light that was how it felt to Nellie. It was kind of nice. Warm, like the wall. Soothing. She set a hand on the flat, round surface, and it was perfectly smooth, not dusty like the stairs, except for a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. “A ‘V,’” murmured Devi. “Horns,” said West. Nellie didn’t care. It was warmer than the fog, the walls. It was wrong. It knew they were there. “We should leave the house,” said Nellie before she could think about what she was saying. “We don’t have enough footage yet for the show,” West protested. “This is cool, but it’s not like we can just be done because we found something good.” “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi said. “We can’t lose this opportunity. Unless… unless you’re really not feeling well or something like that?” Nellie shrugged off Devi’s comforting hand on her shoulder. “You’re right,” Nellie said. “Both of you. I’m fine. I’ll be fine. Let’s just get to the gallery… Did you get that West?” “Damn it, Nellie, was that a performance?” Nellie grinned, and hoped it was convincing. “Back up to reality we go,” she said, letting her smile fade as the crew filed in behind her, careful now not to touch the wall, no matter how nice she knew it would feel. [[Gallery - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]]Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from The Triad)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] Nellie stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe, the same woman she had seen in the photo in the hallway. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Nellie knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders that must have taken hours to style. Dawn lounged, uncomfortably, in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Nellie could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. It gave the oddest impression, like he was playing at nonchalance, waiting for the perfect moment to run away, off-frame. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and while Nellie thought his neatly cut afro was impressive she suspected it might have been of a rather modest size for the time. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt, a stance that reminded Nellie of old portraits of Napoleon, and though he seemed to be aiming for a neutral expression, he could not quite hold back the hint of a smirk. Either he thought this posturing was a joke, or he thought whoever would bother to view this painting in the future was a joke. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The curls looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The girl perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, making her pensive expression appear uneasy. The reddish undertones of her brown skin were highlighted by the pink of the dress, or else the artist had captured her while blushing. If she was blushing, Nellie wondered if it was just because she did not like the attention of being painted, or if it had something to do with whatever was drawing her gaze. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. Nellie did not blame her. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder in a way that made Nellie’s stomach turn. But besides that, it was impossible to determine the specifics of his features. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Nellie did not want to leave Tara alone with her family, with that hand gripping her shoulder. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. Nellie barely heard them. That shadowed hand looked like a claw now. The urge to remove it from the girl’s shoulder was more compelling than the knowledge that she could do nothing for Tara, that whatever Tara had gone through was already done. She reached out and her fingers pressed against the faded paint. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands to their ears, Devi giving a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her head to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Nellie thought one of them was laughing as they struggled to stand upright, but it could have been no one, or just noise, or even Nellie herself getting hysterical as she tried to keep her balance without removing her hands from her ears. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, but she could barely hear it or worry about what it meant with that overwhelming sound shrieking at her. Though she was trying not to listen, Nellie picked up noises from the chaos that sounded familiar, snatches of familiar melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Nellie to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Hotel California]]Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from A Constellation)]]“Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain of Life 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] “Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from The Triad)]] [[The Fountain of Life 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from The Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] “Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from The Triad 1 and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from The Fountain of Life 1 and A Constellation)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from The Fountain of Life 1 and The Triad)]]Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from A Constellation 1 and The Triad)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from The Triad 1 and The Fountain of Life)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary from A Constellation 1 and The Fountain of Life)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon from A Constellation)]]Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon from The Triad)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] Nellie stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. And yet, two sad eyes still managed to hold Nellie’s rapt attention. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe, the same woman she had seen in the photo in the hallway. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Nellie knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore, the same one that now burned hot on Nellie’s skin. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders that must have taken hours to style. Nellie self-consciously fussed with her bangs, the blunt cut nothing like Dawn’s, but Nellie suspected no amount of styling could make her own cut compare with this woman’s beauty. Dawn lounged, uncomfortably, in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Nellie could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. It gave the oddest impression, like he was playing at nonchalance, waiting for the perfect moment to run away, off-frame. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and while Nellie thought his neatly cut afro was impressive she suspected it might have been of a rather modest size for the time. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt, a stance that reminded Nellie of old portraits of Napoleon, and though he seemed to be aiming for a neutral expression, he could not quite hold back the hint of a smirk. Either he thought this posturing was a joke, or he thought whoever would bother to view this painting in the future was a joke. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The curls looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The same ribbon that Nellie had hidden away in her pocket. The girl perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, making her pensive expression appear uneasy. The reddish undertones of her brown skin were highlighted by the pink of the dress, or else the artist had captured her while blushing. If she was blushing, Nellie wondered if it was just because she did not like the attention of being painted, or if it had something to do with whatever was drawing her gaze. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. Nellie did not blame her. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But besides that, it was impossible to determine the specifics of his features. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Nellie did not want to leave Dawn alone with her family. With her sad eyes, and beautiful hair, and expression so full of a lovely despair that Devi and West could never hope to understand. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. Nellie barely heard them. Dawn’s honeyed skin called to her, looking so impossibly soft, she could not help but reach out and stroke the hand that sat weary in her lap. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands to their ears, Devi giving a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her head to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Nellie thought one of them was laughing as they struggled to stand upright, but it could have been no one, or just noise, or even Nellie herself getting hysterical as she tried to keep her balance without removing her hands from her ears. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, but she could barely hear it or worry about what it meant with that overwhelming sound shrieking at her. Though she was trying not to listen, Nellie picked up noises from the chaos that sounded familiar, snatches of familiar melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Nellie to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] “Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon from The Triad 1 and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life 1 and A Constellation)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon from A Constellation 1 and The Triad)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life 1 and The Triad)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket and Ribbon)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary from A Constellation)]]Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary from The Triad)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] Nellie stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe, the same woman she had seen in the photo in the hallway. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Nellie knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders that must have taken hours to style. Dawn lounged, uncomfortably, in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Nellie could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. It gave the oddest impression, like he was playing at nonchalance, waiting for the perfect moment to run away, off-frame. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and while Nellie thought his neatly cut afro was impressive she suspected it might have been of a rather modest size for the time. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt, a stance that reminded Nellie of old portraits of Napoleon, and though he seemed to be aiming for a neutral expression, he could not quite hold back the hint of a smirk. Either he thought this posturing was a joke, or he thought whoever would bother to view this painting in the future was a joke. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The curls looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The girl perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, making her pensive expression appear uneasy. The reddish undertones of her brown skin were highlighted by the pink of the dress, or else the artist had captured her while blushing. If she was blushing, Nellie wondered if it was just because she did not like the attention of being painted, or if it had something to do with whatever was drawing her gaze. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. Nellie did not blame her. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder in a way that made Nellie’s stomach turn. But besides that, it was impossible to determine the specifics of his features. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Nellie did not want to leave Tara alone with her family, with that hand gripping her shoulder. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. Nellie barely heard them. That shadowed hand looked like a claw now. The urge to remove it from the girl’s shoulder was more compelling than the knowledge that she could do nothing for Tara, that whatever Tara had gone through was already done. She reached out and her fingers pressed against the faded paint. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands to their ears, Devi giving a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her head to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Nellie thought one of them was laughing as they struggled to stand upright, but it could have been no one, or just noise, or even Nellie herself getting hysterical as she tried to keep her balance without removing her hands from her ears. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, but she could barely hear it or worry about what it meant with that overwhelming sound shrieking at her. Though she was trying not to listen, Nellie picked up noises from the chaos that sounded familiar, snatches of familiar melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Nellie to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Hotel California.]]“Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary from The Triad 1 and The Fountain of Life)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary from A Constellation 1 and The Fountain of Life)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures.
