[[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon from The Triad)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] Nellie stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe, the same woman she had seen in the photo in the hallway. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Nellie knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders that must have taken hours to style. Dawn lounged, uncomfortably, in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Nellie could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. It gave the oddest impression, like he was playing at nonchalance, waiting for the perfect moment to run away, off-frame. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and while Nellie thought his neatly cut afro was impressive she suspected it might have been of a rather modest size for the time. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt, a stance that reminded Nellie of old portraits of Napoleon, and though he seemed to be aiming for a neutral expression, he could not quite hold back the hint of a smirk. Either he thought this posturing was a joke, or he thought whoever would bother to view this painting in the future was a joke. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The curls looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The same ribbon that Nellie had hidden away in her pocket. The girl perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, making her pensive expression appear uneasy. The reddish undertones of her brown skin were highlighted by the pink of the dress, or else the artist had captured her while blushing. If she was blushing, Nellie wondered if it was just because she did not like the attention of being painted, or if it had something to do with whatever was drawing her gaze. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. Nellie did not blame her. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder in a way that made Nellie’s stomach turn. But besides that, it was impossible to determine the specifics of his features. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Nellie did not want to leave Tara alone with her family, with that hand gripping her shoulder. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. Nellie barely heard them. That shadowed hand looked like a claw now. The urge to remove it from the girl’s shoulder was more compelling than the knowledge that she could do nothing for Tara, that whatever Tara had gone through was already done. She reached out and her fingers pressed against the faded paint. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands to their ears, Devi giving a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her head to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Nellie thought one of them was laughing as they struggled to stand upright, but it could have been no one, or just noise, or even Nellie herself getting hysterical as she tried to keep her balance without removing her hands from her ears. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, but she could barely hear it or worry about what it meant with that overwhelming sound shrieking at her. Though she was trying not to listen, Nellie picked up noises from the chaos that sounded familiar, snatches of familiar melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Nellie to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Knockin' on Heaven's Door]]“Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon from A Constellation 1 and The Fountain of Life)]]Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon from The Triad 1 and The Fountain of Life)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] “Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain of Life 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon from The Triad 1 and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life 1 and A Constellation)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from The Triad)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] Nellie stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe, the same woman she had seen in the photo in the hallway. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Nellie knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders that must have taken hours to style. Dawn lounged, uncomfortably, in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Nellie could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. It gave the oddest impression, like he was playing at nonchalance, waiting for the perfect moment to run away, off-frame. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and while Nellie thought his neatly cut afro was impressive she suspected it might have been of a rather modest size for the time. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt, a stance that reminded Nellie of old portraits of Napoleon, and though he seemed to be aiming for a neutral expression, he could not quite hold back the hint of a smirk. Either he thought this posturing was a joke, or he thought whoever would bother to view this painting in the future was a joke. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The curls looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The same ribbon that Nellie had hidden away in her pocket. The girl perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, making her pensive expression appear uneasy. The reddish undertones of her brown skin were highlighted by the pink of the dress, or else the artist had captured her while blushing. If she was blushing, Nellie wondered if it was just because she did not like the attention of being painted, or if it had something to do with whatever was drawing her gaze. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. Nellie did not blame her. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder in a way that made Nellie’s stomach turn. But besides that, it was impossible to determine the specifics of his features. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Nellie did not want to leave Tara alone with her family, with that hand gripping her shoulder. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. Nellie barely heard them. That shadowed hand looked like a claw now. The urge to remove it from the girl’s shoulder was more compelling than the knowledge that she could do nothing for Tara, that whatever Tara had gone through was already done. She reached out and her fingers pressed against the faded paint. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands to their ears, Devi giving a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her head to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Nellie thought one of them was laughing as they struggled to stand upright, but it could have been no one, or just noise, or even Nellie herself getting hysterical as she tried to keep her balance without removing her hands from her ears. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, but she could barely hear it or worry about what it meant with that overwhelming sound shrieking at her. Though she was trying not to listen, Nellie picked up noises from the chaos that sounded familiar, snatches of familiar melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Nellie to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Knockin' on Heaven's Door.]]“Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from The Triad 1 and The Fountain of Life)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from A Constellation 1 and The Fountain of Life)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] “Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain of Life 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from The Triad 1 and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life 1 and A Constellation)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] “Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from The Triad)]] [[The Fountain of Life 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from The Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from A Constellation 1 and The Triad)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life 1 and The Triad)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Diary and Ribbon)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket from A Constellation)]]Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket from The Triad)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] Nellie stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. And yet, two sad eyes still managed to hold Nellie’s rapt attention. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe, the same woman she had seen in the photo in the hallway. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Nellie knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore, the same one that now burned hot on Nellie’s skin. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders that must have taken hours to style. Nellie self-consciously fussed with her bangs, the blunt cut nothing like Dawn’s, but Nellie suspected no amount of styling could make her own cut compare with this woman’s beauty. Dawn lounged, uncomfortably, in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Nellie could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. It gave the oddest impression, like he was playing at nonchalance, waiting for the perfect moment to run away, off-frame. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and while Nellie thought his neatly cut afro was impressive she suspected it might have been of a rather modest size for the time. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt, a stance that reminded Nellie of old portraits of Napoleon, and though he seemed to be aiming for a neutral expression, he could not quite hold back the hint of a smirk. Either he thought this posturing was a joke, or he thought whoever would bother to view this painting in the future was a joke. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The curls looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The girl perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, making her pensive expression appear uneasy. The reddish undertones of her brown skin were highlighted by the pink of the dress, or else the artist had captured her while blushing. If she was blushing, Nellie wondered if it was just because she did not like the attention of being painted, or if it had something to do with whatever was drawing her gaze. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. Nellie did not blame her. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But besides that, it was impossible to determine the specifics of his features. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Nellie did not want to leave Dawn alone with her family. With her sad eyes, and beautiful hair, and expression so full of a lovely despair that Devi and West could never hope to understand. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. Nellie barely heard them. Dawn’s honeyed skin called to her, looking so impossibly soft, she could not help but reach out and stroke the hand that sat weary in her lap. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands to their ears, Devi giving a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her head to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Nellie thought one of them was laughing as they struggled to stand upright, but it could have been no one, or just noise, or even Nellie herself getting hysterical as she tried to keep her balance without removing her hands from her ears. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, but she could barely hear it or worry about what it meant with that overwhelming sound shrieking at her. Though she was trying not to listen, Nellie picked up noises from the chaos that sounded familiar, snatches of familiar melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Nellie to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Night Moves]]“Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] “Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket from The Triad)]] [[The Fountain of Life 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket from The Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket from A Constellation 1 and The Triad)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket from The Fountain of Life 1 and The Triad)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket from A Constellation)]]Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket from The Triad)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] Nellie stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. And yet, two sad eyes still managed to hold Nellie’s rapt attention. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe, the same woman she had seen in the photo in the hallway. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Nellie knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore, the same one that now burned hot on Nellie’s skin. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders that must have taken hours to style. Nellie self-consciously fussed with her bangs, the blunt cut nothing like Dawn’s, but Nellie suspected no amount of styling could make her own cut compare with this woman’s beauty. Dawn lounged, uncomfortably, in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Nellie could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. It gave the oddest impression, like he was playing at nonchalance, waiting for the perfect moment to run away, off-frame. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and while Nellie thought his neatly cut afro was impressive she suspected it might have been of a rather modest size for the time. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt, a stance that reminded Nellie of old portraits of Napoleon, and though he seemed to be aiming for a neutral expression, he could not quite hold back the hint of a smirk. Either he thought this posturing was a joke, or he thought whoever would bother to view this painting in the future was a joke. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The curls looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The girl perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, making her pensive expression appear uneasy. The reddish undertones of her brown skin were highlighted by the pink of the dress, or else the artist had captured her while blushing. If she was blushing, Nellie wondered if it was just because she did not like the attention of being painted, or if it had something to do with whatever was drawing her gaze. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. Nellie did not blame her. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But besides that, it was impossible to determine the specifics of his features. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Nellie did not want to leave Dawn alone with her family. With her sad eyes, and beautiful hair, and expression so full of a lovely despair that Devi and West could never hope to understand. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. Nellie barely heard them. Dawn’s honeyed skin called to her, looking so impossibly soft, she could not help but reach out and stroke the hand that sat weary in her lap. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands to their ears, Devi giving a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her head to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Nellie thought one of them was laughing as they struggled to stand upright, but it could have been no one, or just noise, or even Nellie herself getting hysterical as she tried to keep her balance without removing her hands from her ears. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, but she could barely hear it or worry about what it meant with that overwhelming sound shrieking at her. Though she was trying not to listen, Nellie picked up noises from the chaos that sounded familiar, snatches of familiar melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Nellie to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Night Moves.]]“Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket from The Triad 1 and The Fountain of Life)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket from A Constellation 1 and The Fountain of Life)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (from Basement with Locket from The Triad 1 and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon from The Triad)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. It gave the oddest impression, like he was playing at nonchalance, waiting for the perfect moment to run away, off-frame. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and while Nellie thought his neatly cut afro was impressive she suspected it might have been of a rather modest size for the time. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt, a stance that reminded Nellie of old portraits of Napoleon, and though he seemed to be aiming for a neutral expression, he could not quite hold back the hint of a smirk. Either he thought this posturing was a joke, or he thought whoever would bother to view this painting in the future was a joke. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The curls looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The same ribbon that Nellie had hidden away in her pocket. The girl perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, making her pensive expression appear uneasy. The reddish undertones of her brown skin were highlighted by the pink of the dress, or else the artist had captured her while blushing. If she was blushing, Nellie wondered if it was just because she did not like the attention of being painted, or if it had something to do with whatever was drawing her gaze. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. Nellie did not blame her. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But besides that, it was impossible to determine the specifics of his features. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Nellie did not want to leave Dawn alone with her family. With her sad eyes, and beautiful hair, and expression so full of a lovely despair that Devi and West could never hope to understand. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. Nellie barely heard them. Dawn’s honeyed skin called to her, looking so impossibly soft, she could not help but reach out and stroke the hand that sat weary in her lap. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands to their ears, Devi giving a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her head to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Nellie thought one of them was laughing as they struggled to stand upright, but it could have been no one, or just noise, or even Nellie herself getting hysterical as she tried to keep her balance without removing her hands from her ears. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, but she could barely hear it or worry about what it meant with that overwhelming sound shrieking at her. Though she was trying not to listen, Nellie picked up noises from the chaos that sounded familiar, snatches of familiar melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Nellie to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Psycho Killer]]“Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon from The Triad 1 and The Fountain of Life)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon from A Constellation 1 and The Fountain of Life)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain of Life 1 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon from The Triad 1 and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life 1 and A Constellation)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip.
