I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon from The Fountain of Life 1 and The Triad)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (with Locket and Ribbon)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from A Constellation)]]Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from The Triad)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] Nellie stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. And yet, two sad eyes still managed to hold Nellie’s rapt attention. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe, the same woman she had seen in the photo in the hallway. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Nellie knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore, the same one that now burned hot on Nellie’s skin. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders that must have taken hours to style. Nellie self-consciously fussed with her bangs, the blunt cut nothing like Dawn’s, but Nellie suspected no amount of styling could make her own cut compare with this woman’s beauty. Dawn lounged, uncomfortably, in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Nellie could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. It gave the oddest impression, like he was playing at nonchalance, waiting for the perfect moment to run away, off-frame. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and while Nellie thought his neatly cut afro was impressive she suspected it might have been of a rather modest size for the time. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt, a stance that reminded Nellie of old portraits of Napoleon, and though he seemed to be aiming for a neutral expression, he could not quite hold back the hint of a smirk. Either he thought this posturing was a joke, or he thought whoever would bother to view this painting in the future was a joke. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The curls looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The girl perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, making her pensive expression appear uneasy. The reddish undertones of her brown skin were highlighted by the pink of the dress, or else the artist had captured her while blushing. If she was blushing, Nellie wondered if it was just because she did not like the attention of being painted, or if it had something to do with whatever was drawing her gaze. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. Nellie did not blame her. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But besides that, it was impossible to determine the specifics of his features. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Nellie did not want to leave Dawn alone with her family. With her sad eyes, and beautiful hair, and expression so full of a lovely despair that Devi and West could never hope to understand. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. Nellie barely heard them. Dawn’s honeyed skin called to her, looking so impossibly soft, she could not help but reach out and stroke the hand that sat weary in her lap. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands to their ears, Devi giving a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her head to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Nellie thought one of them was laughing as they struggled to stand upright, but it could have been no one, or just noise, or even Nellie herself getting hysterical as she tried to keep her balance without removing her hands from her ears. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, but she could barely hear it or worry about what it meant with that overwhelming sound shrieking at her. Though she was trying not to listen, Nellie picked up noises from the chaos that sounded familiar, snatches of familiar melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Nellie to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Heroes]]“Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] “Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[The Triad 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain of Life 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] Nellie fought the urge not to touch the smooth marble of the dancing figures. It was such a strong compulsion she would have been suspicious that it was an otherworldly pull if she didn’t feel this way every time she was in an art gallery. The texture always called to her. Her mom had to keep her on one of those leashes when she was in elementary school after an embarrassing incident at the Met. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo of at least four buns on her head, but Nellie had an oddly difficult time counting them. Each statue was poised on the tips of its toes and in a state of almost turning, either towards the woman next to her or away from the group entirely. Nellie was unsure if the dance was leading them to embrace each other or flee the room. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Wherever she was running to, she would not be hindered by the long fabric. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents that indicated freckles or some kind of tattoo, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “This should be in a museum, no offense to Bradford and his privacy,” Nellie said. [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from The Triad 1 and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from The Fountain of Life 1 and A Constellation)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Triad 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] “Are you okay, Nellie?” Devi asked. “Yeah,” Nellie said. “Just tired. Let’s film a bit more.” [[A Constellation 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from The Triad)]] [[The Fountain of Life 1 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from The Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] Six blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “They’re all part of the same art installation, A Constellation,” Devi said. The blocks were all grayish beige, or beigeish gray. Probably white at some point, but faded with time. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, but she couldn’t hide a smile. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from A Constellation 1 and The Triad)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. “Oh god,” Devi moaned. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” she said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket from The Fountain of Life 1 and The Triad)]]Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[The Fountain of Life 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] Nellie could hear Devi whispering with West, the concern in her voice obvious even if the words were muted. “I’m fine guys,” Nellie said, though she realized her teeth were chattering. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation 2 - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Nellie's Tour (GR with Locket)]] Devi and West were saying something, but Nellie felt far away, lighter than she had in years, free from a body that always felt like a gross cage, too much and not enough at the same time. The stars that shone through the open door were brighter than she could have imagined. They must have made her eyes bluer, her skin glow like honey, she could feel it, as hot as the locket burning the skin on her chest. She deserved nice things, like the ribbon in her pocket, like… Emma. She deserved nice things, and the people who would take those things from her deserved to pay. “We need to go!” Mark shouted, grabbing her arm. Not Mark. West. Mark? Who was this man? Who were these people? “Nellie, come on!” Emma insisted. Not Emma. Devi. Emma was dead. Emma was dead because Mark couldn’t keep his mouth shut. Why did she have to lose everything, lose all the good things along with that terrible aching grief, because one man could not hold a secret in his heart. Men talking to men who thought they knew better than the little girls around them. They did not deserve nice things, like the lights in the sky or the breath in their lungs. A part of Nellie knew that these thoughts were not her own. She was not alone in her head. Dawn was here, Dawn was thinking for her, these were Dawn’s thought and desires influencing her, taking over. But when she tried to warn West and Devi, no words came out of her mouth. And then confusion overtook her. The two strangers, two memories, held her firmly, ran with her through the garden, the beautiful bleeding cacti that still grew tall and strong after so many years. She had it wrong, all those years ago. He knew it, too. Not Mark, not Father, the other one. The man she had glimpsed once, in the basement, before deciding she would never be a part of that darkness, before realizing she had no choice if she wanted to keep Emma with her. If they could not be bound in life, if Mark would take Emma’s warmth and life and light out of her life, then she would bind them in the world that comes after. She would sacrifice anyone to make that happen, especially someone who deserved it. They passed bedrooms, dark and unfamiliar in their disorder, in their decay, a dizzying mix of memories old and new clamoring in her mind. When she had a sense of the house, her spirit tucked away lonely with the books she once adored, she would sometimes think the man had not taken her soul because it could not be consumed incomplete, not without its other half. Now she was sure he had not taken in because she was the wrong sacrifice. She could do nothing about it, gathering dust, a curl of blond hair intermingled with a curl of black hair, together in the locket, but apart as ghosts for reasons she did not comprehend until this moment. She needed to right that past wrong. And with this body, she could. They passed photos in the hall, from when she was happy, when she could perform the mask of happiness more convincingly. The hands were still on her, insisting, pulling her forward, but she dug her heels into the thick shag rug. “We have no idea what damage that quake did to the house,” Devi was saying. “Don’t you hear it?” “Hear what?” asked West, West who was not who she wanted, but West who was here, and he would do. “One last thing, it’s just what we need, it’s perfect.” She pointed towards the door to the Séance Room. West was hesitant, but he walked to the door, pressing his ear against the wood. Neither crew member expected Nellie to lunge at him, pushing with all her strength, the strength of two women sharing one body. West’s body struck the door and the fragile frame snapped open, leading to the deep Pit below. The camera fell from his hands into a darkness so deep they did not hear a crash. And for a moment, West teetered on the edge of the longest fall. Devi reached past Nellie to catch him. [[Stop Devi]] [[Don't Stop Devi]] Devi and West were saying something, but Nellie felt far away, lighter than she had in years, free from a body that always felt like a gross cage, too much and not enough at the same time. The stars that shone through the open door were brighter than she could have imagined. They must have made her eyes bluer, her skin glow like honey, she could feel it, as hot as the locket burning the skin on her chest. She deserved nice things, like the ribbon in her pocket, like… Emma. She deserved nice things, and the people who would take those things from her deserved to pay. “We need to go!” Mark shouted, grabbing her arm. Not Mark. West. Mark? Who was this man? Who were these people? “Nellie, come on!” Emma insisted. Not Emma. Devi. Emma was dead. Emma was dead because Mark couldn’t keep his mouth shut. Why did she have to lose everything, lose all the good things along with that terrible aching grief, because one man could not hold a secret in his heart. Men talking to men who thought they knew better than the little girls around them. They did not deserve nice things, like the lights in the sky or the breath in their lungs. A part of Nellie knew that these thoughts were not her own. She was not alone in her head. Dawn was here, Dawn was thinking for her, these were Dawn’s thought and desires influencing her, taking over. But when she tried to warn West and Devi, no words came out of her mouth. And then confusion overtook her. The two strangers, two memories, held her firmly, ran with her through the garden, the beautiful bleeding cacti that still grew tall and strong after so many years. She had it wrong, all those years ago. He knew it, too. Not Mark, not Father, the other one. The man she had glimpsed once, in the basement, before deciding she would never be a part of that darkness, before realizing she had no choice if she wanted to keep Emma with her. If they could not be bound in life, if Mark would take Emma’s warmth and life and light out of her life, then she would bind them in the world that comes after. She would sacrifice anyone to make that happen, especially someone who deserved it. They passed bedrooms, dark and unfamiliar in their disorder, in their decay, a dizzying mix of memories old and new clamoring in her mind. When she had a sense of the house, her spirit tucked away lonely with the books she once adored, she would sometimes think the man had not taken her soul because it could not be consumed incomplete, not without its other half. Now she was sure he had not taken in because she was the wrong sacrifice. She could do nothing about it, gathering dust, a curl of blond hair intermingled with a curl of black hair, together in the locket, but apart as ghosts for reasons she did not comprehend until this moment. She needed to right that past wrong. And with this body, she could. They passed photos in the hall, from when she was happy, when she could perform the mask of happiness more convincingly. The hands were still on her, insisting, pulling her forward, but she dug her heels into the thick shag rug. “We have no idea what damage that quake did to the house,” Devi was saying. “Don’t you hear it?” “Hear what?” asked West, West who was not who she wanted, but West who was here, and he would do. She pointed towards the door to the Séance Room. After a moment’s hesitation West turned to the door, but froze as Devi spoke. “Oh my god,” she whispered. “I do hear it.” Nellie frowned. There was nothing to hear. She just need to get West close to the Pit… “It’s the music I heard in the Groove Room,” Devi continued, holding her headphones tight to her ears. “That song.” “Devi, you can take the headphones off,” West said, voice soft, his wide eyes looking past his two crew members. He was right. Even without Devi’s sensitive equipment, Nellie could hear it, too. A voice she thought she would never hear again, singing a song that she had written herself. She could have been a folk singer, as influential as Joni Mitchell, as beloved as Karen Carpenter. Dawn had loved her, and she had the money, her family had the connections. It should have all worked out. They should have been happy. Instead… Emma let her song slip into an unsettling quiet before Nellie turned to face her. Those deep black almond eyes, that carefree cropped haircut. The smile that had never looked so sad when she was alive. She did not even looked at Devi as she passed through her, her form insubstantial, though Devi still let out a soft “oh” and stumbled back to the wall. Emma’s body felt solid to Nellie when she grabbed her hands, but she guessed it was not quite Nellie’s hands she was holding, but the ghost who was puppeteering her underneath that convenient skin. “Oh, Dawn,” Emma said, her voice mournful. “You have to let it go.” Indignation burned through Nellie’s throat. “No,” she hissed. “It’s not fair.” “You’re right, it’s not,” Emma nodded, her eyes gliding towards West who cowered under the ghost’s attention. “But it was not Mark’s fault. And it is definitely not this boy’s fault. Killing him won’t make the pain go away.” [[Kill West]] [[Let it go]] Devi and West were saying something, but Nellie’s head ached. A voice whispered to her to let go of this body that had always felt like a gross cage, too much and not enough at the same time. The stars that shone through the open door were brighter than she could have imagined, too many, like she was seeing double. She shook her head and immediately regretted it, stumbling to the side, her weight wrong, her body ungainly. “We need to go!” Mark shouted, grabbing her arm. Not Mark. West. Mark? Who was this man? Who were these people? “Nellie, come on!” Emma insisted. Not Emma. Devi. Emma was dead. Emma was dead because Mark couldn’t keep his mouth shut. Why did she have to lose everything, lose all the good things along with that terrible aching grief, because one man could not hold a secret in his heart. Men talking to men who thought they knew better than the little girls around them. “Something’s wrong…” Nellie began. “Yeah, something’s wrong, that was an earthquake!” West shouted, grabbing her arm, steering her out of the gallery to the cacti with their bleeding petals. She had it wrong, all those years ago. He knew it, too. Not Mark, not Father, the other one. The man she had glimpsed once, in the basement, before deciding she would never be a part of that darkness, before realizing she had no choice if she wanted to keep Emma with her. If they could not be bound in life, if Mark would take Emma’s warmth and life and light out of her life, then she would bind them in the world that comes after. She would sacrifice anyone to make that happen, especially someone who deserved it. She had to get to the Séance Room door, to that fragile barrier to the Pit, and then throw him down below where he belongs - “No!” Nellie shouted, digging her heels into the gravel. “Nellie, what’s wrong?” Devi asked, stopping beside her. “We don’t have time for this!” West shouted. “There’s something in my head!” That stopped West’s anxious pacing. Nellie tried to take off her necklace and gasped at the pain. She pulled down the loose cowl of her turtleneck and Devi and West saw the locket glowing red-hot against her skin. “What the hell?” West muttered. //No, no!// a voice screamed in Nellie’s ears, and she closed her eyes against the pain. //He must pay!// “Stop it, I won’t do it!” Nellie screamed. “Won’t do what?” Devi asked. “She… she wants me to throw West into the Pit,” she said. “I think it’s Dawn. She’s in my head. Shit.” “Um, wait,” Devi said, eyes widening. “Dawn is trying to possess you because she wants to kill West?” “Why?” West asked, taking a step back from Nellie. “She says he belongs down below,” Nellie said. “Again, why would she want that?” West demanded. A soothing warmth ran up her skin. “It’s not just about what she wants,” Nellie said, the stars going blurry once more, and she was struck with a fear as cold as death. “The man below must be satisfied. Or he will never leave the three of us alone. He will never let us leave.” “Yeah, big no to that,” West laughed, a tight pained sound. “If there is something in the Pit that wants to us, we should get as far away from the ground as possible. Preferable before it quakes again and, I don’t know, swallows me? Can it do that? Crap, we need to go!” Nellie heard Dawn scream in her head. //Don’t take us to the black stars, I don’t want to go, I don’t want to go!// [[Defy Dawn and Go to the Upper Observatory]] Devi and West were saying something, but Nellie’s head ached. A voice whispered to her to let go of this body that had always felt like a gross cage, too much and not enough at the same time. The stars that shone through the open door were brighter than she could have imagined, too many, like she was seeing double. She shook her head and immediately regretted it, stumbling to the side, her weight wrong, her body ungainly. “We need to go!” Mark shouted, grabbing her arm. Not Mark. West. Mark? Who was this man? Who were these people? “Nellie, come on!” Emma insisted. Not Emma. Devi. Emma was dead. Emma was dead because Mark couldn’t keep his mouth shut. Why did she have to lose everything, lose all the good things along with that terrible aching grief, because one man could not hold a secret in his heart. Men talking to men who thought they knew better than the little girls around them. “Something’s wrong…” Nellie began. “Yeah, something’s wrong, that was an earthquake!” West shouted, grabbing her arm, steering her out of the gallery to the cacti with their bleeding petals. She had it wrong, all those years ago. He knew it, too. Not Mark, not Father, the other one. The man she had glimpsed once, in the basement, before deciding she would never be a part of that darkness, before realizing she had no choice if she wanted to keep Emma with her. She would sacrifice anyone to make that happen, especially someone who deserved it. She had to get to the Séance Room door, to that fragile barrier to the Pit, and then throw him down below where he belongs - “No!” Nellie shouted, digging her heels into the gravel. “Nellie, what’s wrong?” Devi asked, stopping beside her. “We don’t have time for this!” West shouted. “There’s something in my head!” That stopped West’s anxious pacing. Nellie tried to take off her necklace and gasped at the pain. She pulled down the loose cowl of her turtleneck and Devi and West saw the locket glowing red-hot against her skin. “What the hell?” West muttered. //No, no!// a voice screamed in Nellie’s ears, and she closed her eyes against the pain. //He must pay!// “Stop it, I won’t do it!” Nellie screamed. “Won’t do what?” Devi asked. “She… she wants me to throw West into the Pit,” she said. “I think it’s Dawn. She’s in my head. Shit.” “Um, wait,” Devi said, eyes widening. “Dawn is trying to possess you because she wants to kill West?” “Why?” West asked, taking a step back from Nellie. “She says he belongs down below,” Nellie said. “Again, why would she want that?” West demanded. A soothing warmth ran up her skin. “It’s not just about what she wants,” Nellie said, the stars going blurry once more, and she was struck with a fear as cold as death. “The man below must be satisfied. Or he will never leave the three of us alone. He will never let us leave.” “Yeah, big no to that,” West laughed, a tight pained sound. “If there is something in the Pit that wants to us, we should get as far away from the ground as possible. Preferable before it quakes again and, I don’t know, swallows me? Can it do that? Crap, we need to go!” Nellie heard Dawn scream in her head. //Don’t take us to the black stars, I don’t want to go, I don’t want to go!// [[Defy Dawn and Go to the Upper Observatory]] [[Listen to Dawn and Go to the Basement]]Devi and West were saying something, but Nellie’s head ached. A voice whispered to her to let go of this body that had always felt like a gross cage, too much and not enough at the same time. The stars that shone through the open door were brighter than she could have imagined, too many, like she was seeing double. She shook her head and immediately regretted it, stumbling to the side, her weight wrong, her body ungainly. “We need to go!” Mark shouted, grabbing her arm. Not Mark. West. Mark? Who was this man? Who were these people? “Nellie, come on!” Emma insisted. Not Emma. Devi. Emma was dead. Emma was dead because Mark couldn’t keep his mouth shut. Why did she have to lose everything, lose all the good things along with that terrible aching grief, because one man could not hold a secret in his heart. Men talking to men who thought they knew better than the little girls around them. “Something’s wrong…” Nellie began. “Yeah, something’s wrong, that was an earthquake!” West shouted, grabbing her arm, steering her out of the gallery past the cacti with their bleeding petals, into the Bennington mansion. She had it wrong, all those years ago. He knew it, too. Not Mark, not Father, the other one. The man she had glimpsed once, in the basement, before deciding she would never be a part of that darkness, before realizing she had no choice if she wanted to keep Emma with her. If they could not be bound in life, if Mark would take Emma’s warmth and life and light out of her life, then she would bind them in the world that comes after. She would sacrifice anyone to make that happen, especially someone who deserved it. “No!” Nellie shouted, forcing Devi and West to stumble to a halt in the hallway before they reached the Séance Room door. “Nellie, what’s wrong?” Devi asked, stopping beside her. “We don’t have time for this!” West shouted. “There’s something in my head!” That stopped West’s anxious pacing. Nellie tried to take off her necklace and gasped at the pain. She pulled down the loose cowl of her turtleneck and Devi and West saw the locket glowing red-hot against her skin. “What the hell?” West muttered. //No, no!// a voice screamed in Nellie’s ears, and she closed her eyes against the pain. //He must pay! // “Stop it, I won’t do it!” Nellie screamed. “Won’t do what?” Devi asked. “She… she wants me to throw West into the Pit,” she said. “I think it’s Dawn. She’s in my head. Shit.” “Um, wait,” Devi said, eyes widening. “Dawn is trying to possess you because she wants to kill West?” “Why?” West asked, taking a step back from Nellie. “She says he belongs down below,” Nellie said. “Again, why would she want that?” West demanded. //What is that?// Dawn’s voice had grown quieter. Nellie could sense her straining to hear something. And she heard it, too. A gentle melody, beautiful and faint. “Do you guys hear that?” Nellie asked. “It’s the music I recorded earlier,” Devi said slowly. “It’s coming from the Groove Room.” “So, we’re just dropping the whole ‘the ghost possessing Nellie wants to kill me’ thing?” West asked, almost sounding insulted. Nellie hushed him, reaching towards the Groove Room door. “Nellie, wait a second,” said Devi. "Maybe we should just go." [[Ignore Devi and Follow the Music]] [[Ignore the Music and Follow Devi]] Nellie had been thrown backward onto the floor. Her bag had fallen beside her, the contents spilling around her body. She was dizzy, and thought she had probably hit her head. Did she have a concussion? She couldn’t worry about that now. Devi and West were screaming. “We need to get out of here!” shouted West. Nellie nodded, reaching to gather her things. “We don’t have time,” Devi said, pulling her up. Nellie only managed to grasp the diary before she was being dragged out of the Gallery, through the garden of bleeding petal cacti, back into the Bennington mansion. They stumbled to a halt at a crashing sound ahead of them, past Bradford’s bedroom. “Is the building coming down?” Devi asked, biting her lip. “Where else can we go but forward?” West asked, his voice loud and panicked. [[Forward Towards the Crashing Sound]] Nellie had been thrown backward onto the floor. Her bag had fallen beside her, the contents spilling around her body. She was dizzy, and thought she had probably hit her head. Did she have a concussion? She couldn’t worry about that now. Devi and West were screaming. “We need to get out of here!” shouted West. Nellie nodded, reaching to gather her things. “We don’t have time,” Devi said, pulling her up. Nellie only managed to grasp the diary before she was being dragged out of the Gallery, through the garden of bleeding petal cacti, back into the Bennington mansion. They stumbled to a halt at a crashing sound ahead of them, past Bradford’s bedroom. “Is the building coming down?” Devi asked, biting her lip. “Where else can we go but forward?” West asked, his voice loud and panicked. [[Forward Towards the Crashing Sound]] [[Retreat from the Crashing Sound]] Nellie had been thrown backward onto the floor. Her bag had fallen beside her, the contents spilling around her body. She was dizzy, and thought she had probably hit her head. Did she have a concussion? She couldn’t worry about that now. Devi and West were screaming. “We need to get out of here!” shouted West. Nellie nodded, reaching to gather her things. “We don’t have time,” Devi said, pulling her up. Nellie only managed to grasp the diary before she was being dragged out of the Gallery, through the garden of bleeding petal cacti, back into the Bennington mansion. They stumbled to a halt at a crashing sound ahead of them, past Bradford’s bedroom. “Is the building coming down?” Devi asked, biting her lip. “Where else can we go but forward?” West asked, his voice loud and panicked. [[Forward Towards the Crashing Sound.]] Nellie had been thrown backward onto the floor. Her bag had fallen beside her, the contents spilling around her body. She was dizzy, and thought she had probably hit her head. Did she have a concussion? She couldn’t worry about that now. Devi and West were screaming. “We need to get out of here!” shouted West. Nellie nodded, reaching to gather her things. “We don’t have time,” Devi said, pulling her up. Nellie only managed to grasp the diary before she was being dragged out of the Gallery, through the garden of bleeding petal cacti, back into the Bennington mansion. They stumbled to a halt at a crashing sound ahead of them, past Bradford’s bedroom. “Is the building coming down?” Devi asked, biting her lip. “Where else can we go but forward?” West asked, his voice loud and panicked. [[Forward Towards the Crashing Sound.]] [[Retreat from the Crashing Sound.]] Nellie grabbed the back of Devi’s hoodie, heard a strangled noise as the fabric pressed against her throat, and then the girl froze. West’s hands reached for her, grasping and empty, before he lost his footing completely, falling into the darkness. It was right. It was what he deserved. It should have felt good. “What did you do, Nellie?” Devi was crying, thrashing in the stronger girl’s grasp. She did not feel good. She tried to listen, to hear screams from the Pit, or laughter telling her he was there and he was pleased, but she heard nothing. No music. No relief. Nellie gasped, clutched at the locket that had grown red-hot, confused, angry, despairing. She let go of Devi who ran to the edge of the door, peering down into the Pit. Nellie grabbed the locket, screaming as it burned her hand, ripping it from her throat, tearing the chain. She tossed it onto the ground and Devi let out a soft “oh” as she turned to see the object glowing, sizzling in the heat it produced. It sounded like it was hissing. It sounded like it was crying. Nellie was alone in her body once more. Her limbs felt heavy, her bones almost loose now that there was no one to puppet them. She stumbled, nearly fell to the carpet, but Devi was there beside her, wrapping Nellie’s arm over her shoulder. She took Nellie to the door that opened easily under her hand, offering them the gift of freedom, perhaps for a job well done. “Thank you, Emma,” Nellie whispered as Devi maneuvered her into the passenger seat. Devi raised her eyebrow and Nellie winced. “I mean, Devi. Sorry. I… I don’t know why I did that. I don’t know what happened-” “I can guess,” said Devi. “But I doubt the police will accept ‘Dawn did it.’” Nellie’s eyes grew wet. “What are we going to do?” “Right now,” Devi said, hopping into the drivers’ seat and starting the car. “We’re getting as far away from the Bennington mansion, and the Bennington family, as possible.” Nellie put her hand on Devi’s as she drove and was relieved when Devi did not pull away from the touch. Dawn was gone, the locket was probably burning a hole through the carpet, but Tara’s ribbon was still in her pocket. And Nellie knew that she deserved nice things. [[End of Track]] Devi reached past Nellie, and she watched the girl, a distant part of her that belonged in this post-modern age screaming at her to do something, but that part wasn’t in control right now. Devi grabbed West’s grasping hand, but it was too late. She was too small, and his momentum was too strong. Nellie could not see Devi’s expression, just the back of a dark hoodie, those constant headphone’s resting on her neck like a noose. She did see West’s eyes widen as he realized what he was done, what he was doing, before he pulled both the crew members over the edge of the door, sending them tumbling into the Pit. It was right. It was what he deserved. It should have felt good. She did not feel good. Was it because she lost Devi, too? That shouldn’t have mattered. Devi wasn’t Emma. All that should have mattered was that Mark was dead. Symbolically. That counted, right? It should have counted. She tried to listen, to hear screams from the Pit, or laughter telling her he was there and he was pleased, but she heard nothing. No music. No relief. Nellie gasped, clutched at the locket that had grown red-hot, confused, angry, despairing. She grabbed the cheap jewellery, screaming as it burned her hand, ripping it from her throat, tearing the chain. She tossed it onto the ground. The object glowed, sizzling in the heat it produced. It sounded like it was hissing. It sounded like it was crying. Nellie was alone in her body once more. Her limbs felt heavy, her bones almost loose now that there was no one to puppet them. She stumbled and fell to the carpet, her knees hitting the floor with a soft thud. She half lunged, half crawled to the door that opened easily under her hand, offering the gift of freedom, perhaps for a job well done. Outside, Nellie stared at the closed door of the car. The keys were in Devi’s briefcase. Devi, and her briefcase, and her body, were at the bottom of the pit. Nellie sat down, giving in to exhaustion and tears, leaning against the back of the door. When they didn’t check in at the hotel, maybe someone would call the police. Or the next group that had booked a tour. Or the owner, wondering why her payment didn’t come through, because Nellie knew for a fact that it did not. What would she say? “I was possessed by a ghost and killed my friends?” No. They were in the house, and there was an earthquake, that was what she would say. The door to the Séance Room broke and West fell through, and Devi died trying to save him. Only she got out. Only she survived to tell the tale to the police. To her subscribers. Nellie’s eyes dried. She was going to get so many new subscribers. That would be nice. And after all that she had been through, Nellie deserved to have nice things. [[End of Track]] Thank you for testing Corridors: A Playlist of Possession! So far there are 12 tracks and 24 possible endings. Make new choices to discover them all! Playlist: Psycho Killer - Talking Heads Just What I Needed - The Cars Night Moves - Bob Seger Heroes - David Bowie Hotel California - Eagles Knockin' on Heaven's Door - Bob Dylan Landslide - Fleetwood Mac Evil Woman - Electric Light Orchestra Someone Saved My Life Tonight - Elton John Down Down - Status Quo Barracuda - Heart Born to Run - Bruce Springsteen Queen of Noise - The Runaways All Right Now - Free 25 or 6 to 4 - Chicago Even the Losers - Tom Petty Just the Way You Are - Billy Joel Wish You Were Here - Pink Floyd If you want to continue to explore unguided, stop reading this paragraph! If you want some hints to unlock different endings… THE HINTS START NOW. There are three possessions belonging to each of the Bennington children in the mansion – a locket, a diary, and a doll (the doll is not available at this time). Each investigator has a strong connection to one of the possessions. Even if you find more than one possession, the strong connection possession will be the focus of your ending. If you explore the Groove Room, the Upper Séance Room, Mark’s Room, the tub, the bathroom mirror, and/or the globe, it may affect the ending… depending on who is your lead investigator. And different combinations will lead to different endings too! Exploring the basement initially may unlock extra endings (but they may not always be good endings). Feel free to try again: [[Welcome to Bennington Mansion]] The locket burned hotter against her neck. “I’m sorry, Emma,” Nellie said, refusing to meet the ghost’s eyes. She lunged to push West through the door, and instead felt a sharp pressure against her back that sent her careening forward faster than she anticipated, past West. Her body was flung against the door whose fragile hinges immediately snapped under her weight, and she fell into the darkness of the Pit with a short shriek. “What did you do?” Devi gasped, running towards the door, but West held her back from the edge before she could fall through, too. “It would not have eased her rage,” Emma said, shaking her head. “This would have been just the beginning of a cycle of possession and sacrifice, innocent girls forced to murder innocent boys.” “You just killed in innocent girl!” Devi shouted at her. West looked conflicted, relief and shock keeping him frozen in place. “I’m sorry about your friend,” Emma said, and though she sounded sincere Devi still raged in West unmoving grasp. “But this was the only way I could be certain to save this boy and ensure Dawn would never come back.” “How can you know she’s gone for good?” West asked, his voice a sharp croak. Emma’s face grew serious and West and Devi shivered. There were no shrieks coming from the Pit. “There are secrets in Bennington Mansion that are not mine to tell,” Emma finally said. “Go, now. If something else comes for you, I won’t be able to save you again.” As if to prove her warning, Emma’s body was already fading. Devi let West lead her to the car outside and drive them away from Bennington Mansion, leaving Nellie, or whatever she had become, behind them. [[End of Track]] The locket went cold on Nellie’s neck and she gasped. For a moment it felt like she was suffocating, chocking on vomit that lodged in her windpipe, desperate to get out. Devi screamed and ran to her, grabbing her arm, and it was like the girl had unlocked some final door. Nellie’s jaw stretched and a rush of air escaped her. She fell back, caught by Devi and West before she hit the floor. Briefly, Nellie thought she must have hit her head and was seeing double. But that woman who stood with Emma, still holding her hands, didn’t actually look anything like her. She was almost translucent, as was Emma now, but Nellie could still make out her feathered fringe. Though her eyes did not look sad, not anymore. The ground began to shudder once more, the walls creaking, the hinges on the door to the Séance room snapping before the fragile wood fell into the Pit. A terrible noise rose up from the darkness that Nellie could not immediately identify as laughter. Emma and Dawn embraced, glancing fearfully around them. “Go,” said Emma, her voice almost imperceptible. “What’s going on?” Nellie asked. “There are secrets in Bennington Mansion that are not mine to tell,” Emma said. “Go, now. If something else comes for you, I won’t be able to save you again.” As if to prove her warning, Emma and Dawn’s bodies disappeared completely. Nellie let West and Devi hurry her to the car outside. They drove away from Bennington Mansion, leaving Dawn and Emma, and whatever resided in the Pit, behind them. [[End of Track]] “We should go down to the basement,” Devi said. “Are you insane?” West asked, choking on a laugh. “I’m with West on this one,” Nellie said, though Dawn grumbled and spat in her skull. “Whatever is down there won’t let us leave until it’s satisfied,” said Devi. “It doesn’t matter if we run. If we don’t face what’s down there, we aren’t getting out.” “Maybe Dawn is lying,” said West. “She could say anything just to get you guys to kill me.” Nellie wanted to agree with West, it was a terrible idea, but the heat overwhelmed her and she found her lips moving on their own. “I trust Devi’s opinion more than ours,” Nellie said. West looked like he wanted to argue, but when Nellie grabbed Devi’s hand and ran into Bradford’s bedroom he followed, reluctant to be left behind alone. They hurried down the steps through the wardrobe as carefully as they could, but the light that emanated from below was even brighter now. They stumbled into the room and immediately found that they were not alone. A man sat cross-legged on the altar. Devi and West gasped, but Nellie could not get her body to respond. She felt Dawn’s excitement make her own hands tremble with anticipation. The man was handsome, in an unusual way. His skin was a little too pale, the color of someone naturally pale who has not seen sunlight in a very long time. He blinked slowly at them, and Nellie had the impression that he could not see them very well, if at all. At least, that was her impression until his eyes locked on her. His black hair was thick, pushed back from his forehead. It looked too long to Nellie, but it reminded her of the rockstars in the photos, stylish for another time. His black t-shirt and jeans were tight on his skinny frame, his studded thick boots looking too heavy for his body. He smiled at the crewmembers and Nellie wished she could look away, it was too bright, not with an actual light, but something worse that teased at the edges of her sight like the beginning of an aura migraine. Since she could not look away as long as Dawn had control of her body, Nellie had the time to count six distinct freckles that crossed his cheeks. “Who are you?” Devi whispered. The man raised an eyebrow at Nellie, like they shared a secret, and she felt Dawn recoil from his smirk. “Call me Versus,” the man said. “I’m surprised you don’t know, if you came down here.” “Dawn’s ghost said-” Devi began, but the spirit possessing Nellie cut her off. “I brought you a sacrifice,” she said. “Take him. He deserves it.” West began to back up the stairs but froze suddenly, shivering. Devi’s body began shivering as well. Nellie could imagine the cold that held them in place, as cold as six dark stars in a distant constellation. “While fresh blood is always appealing, I have been waiting too long for what I was promised,” Versus said. His eyes went completely black, and there was the rush of air, like a vacuum opening into pure space. She and Dawn both grasped desperately at Devi, but the vacuum did not pull at their bodies. Versus was consuming their spirits. Both of their spirits. Nellie screamed with two voices, terrified, shrieking, before her body fell to the ground. Devi fell to her knees beside Nellie, shaking the cooling body. “Nellie! Nellie!” “You killed her,” West said, his voice flat, expression wavering between fear and relief. “I was really only after Dawn, but she bound her spirit so tightly to your companion, I hardly had a choice,” Versus said, his eyes vaguely human once more. His voice slurred. He sounded drunk. Amused. “What are you going to do to us?” Devi asked, backing away from Nellie’s body to West. “You’re lucky that consuming two lives leaves me… a little overfull,” he said, giggling, a grotesque inhuman sound. “If you run now, you could be quite far away before I grow hungry again.” “You’d let us go?” West asked, incredulously. “You’re welcome to stay,” Versus laughed. “But I’m not the only monster here that might kill you.” West and Devi bounded up the stairs, leaving Nellie’s body with the laughing creature in the basement. [[End of Track]] “Dawn really doesn’t want to go to… the stars?” “The observatory,” Devi said. “Upper floor of the library.” “Then my vote is we go there,” said West. “If the murderous ghost doesn’t like it, then I’m a big fan.” Nellie couldn’t think straight with Dawn still screaming in her head so she just nodded and followed Devi and West’s footsteps through the house, up the stairs, and into the room with the old unmade beds, the modern furniture, and the telescope. The house began to shake again. “Maybe we should huddle in the doorframe?” Devi asked. “We need to figure out what Dawn is so afraid of!” West argued. “I bet it can get rid of her and free Nellie.” Nellie looked around the room and the locket flashed bright when she looked at the telescope. Good enough for her. She ignored what Dawn was hissing, the way the ghost was trying to take control of her limbs and peered through to look at the night sky. Six stars. So clear. Shining far above them, bright and cold. The screaming was annoying now. An incessant buzzing, small gnats swatting at her ears. Six stars. Closer now. No larger, but Nellie knew, if she reached out, she would be able to touch the constellation. The screaming didn’t even sound like Dawn now. Six stars. It was definitely a constellation, but of what? Three women dancing, reaching out a hand to each other? Three children, bound by a rope of ice? Three crewmembers who were in over their heads? Or just six sharp white teeth? Nellie could barely hear Devi and West’s screaming now. Would the stars be cold to the touch? Her locket burned so hot, the kind of ice those stars promised would be a wonderful relief. Nellie reached into the darkness, and the world went black. [[End of Track]] Nellie opened the door to the Groove Room. At the center of the dance floor stood a figure with dark almond eyes, cropped black hair, swaying slowly. She looked so alive, except for the slightly transparent nature of her skin. Nellie knew that the woman was singing a song that she had written herself. She could have been a folk singer, as influential as Joni Mitchell, as beloved as Karen Carpenter. Dawn had loved her, and she had the money, her family had the connections. It should have all worked out. They should have been happy. Instead… Emma gave a small gasp when she saw Nellie, her song ending abruptly. The sad smile that had touched her lips turned warm and genuine. She reached out her hands and Nellie rushed forward to grasp them, not considering if her transparency meant she would be intangible. And perhaps she was. It was not Nellie’s hands she was holding, but the ghost who was hiding underneath her convenient skin. “Oh, Dawn,” Emma said. “I’ve been waiting here for so long.” The locket went cold on Nellie’s neck and she gasped. For a moment it felt like she was suffocating, chocking on vomit that lodged in her windpipe, desperate to get out. Devi screamed and ran to her, grabbing her arm, and it was like the girl had unlocked some final door. Nellie’s jaw stretched and a rush of air escaped her. She fell back, caught by Devi and West before she hit the floor. Briefly, Nellie thought she must have hit her head and was seeing double. But that woman who stood with Emma, still holding her hands, didn’t actually look anything like her. She was almost translucent, as was Emma now, but Nellie could still make out her feathered fringe. Though her eyes did not look sad, not anymore. “I’m sorry, I’m so sorry I made you wait,” said Dawn, and though her voice was remorseful, the ghost couldn’t contain her grin. “Someone put my locket in the library, and I was trapped inside-” Emma hushed her. “We’re together now.” Dawn’s eyes flickered down for a moment, and Nellie had the oddest feeling that she expected the earth to quake again. “What about-” she began, but Emma cut her off. “We’re together now,” she insisted. “Whatever happens in the future, happens. For now, we have each other. Thanks to them.” Dawn looked sheepishly over her shoulder at the girl she possessed, pointedly avoiding looking at the boy she plotted to kill. “You should go,” she said to Nellie. “Compared to the other monsters in this mansion, I’m downright friendly.” Nellie was overwhelmed by a wave of conflicting emotions. Happiness for these spirits. Disgust over the way Dawn had used her body. Frustration because she knew that West hadn’t filmed any of this, and it would have gotten them so many new subscribers. The crewmembers left the ghosts behind them to what they hoped would be an eternity of happiness and drove away from the Bennington mansion. [[End of Track]] Nellie stopped. “Can we just, please, stop investigating the horrors?” Devi asked. “I don’t know what’s going on, but this is more than we have ever experienced on any other ghost hunt, and it’s obviously real, and dangerous, and I can’t imagine anything good coming from continuing to follow the creepy sounds back into the rooms of the mansion when we are so close to freedom.” Freedom. Devi was right. She was so close. She stepped away from the Groove Room, shaking her head, and the music faded before disappearing entirely. Devi took her hand, gently, so warm and alive and real. Had her hands always been this soft? Or was she just finally able to appreciate it? Appreciate her. Quiet and always there beside her, prepared, careful, waiting. “Do you feel okay?” asked West, frowning. “Or are you… murder-y?” “No, not anymore,” she said, offering a sheepish grin. “I’m so sorry. But after the way you’ve been needling me all night-” “Gentle mocking is not the same as plotting a murder!” West yelled, but he was smiling a little too. The music was gone, the ground was still, whatever had happened in the Gallery already felt far away. Devi was right that this was the most convincing haunt they had been on, but they had all seen videos online of haunts that looked equally convincing, ones the creators had secretly admitted were fake. The owner could have rigged this place. Weren’t the séances in the past all smoke and mirrors? Devi and West relaxed and grinned at Nellie. “I think I got caught up in the moment,” she apologized. “This place is…” “Yeah,” West agreed. “By the way, did you manage to film any of our flight?” “Absolutely not.” The crewmembers left the mansion, piling into the car outside. Devi insisted on driving and also insisted that Nellie ride shotgun, because of the emotional turmoil, she claimed. West grumbled but got into the back seat. She kept her hand next to her, palm up, and was not surprised a few minutes into the drive when Devi intertwined their fingers, accepting the invitation. The mansion was behind them. The horrors still waited there, called to her, would probably lure her back again. But Emma was dead, and Devi was alive beside her. And while Nellie’s skin was an uncomfortable fit, she knew she could get used to it. She had gotten used to being trapped in a locket. This was a much more pleasant way to pass the afterlife, if she could only quiet the sounds of Nellie screaming inside her skull. [[End of Track]] The crewmembers ran into the hallway outside of Bradford’s room, and it was surprisingly intact. They heard another crashing sound, this time accompanied by a soft moan. It was coming from Tara’s bedroom. “Do you think somebody’s in there?” Devi asked. Before she was even done speaking, Nellie was throwing open the door. The room was in disarray. The bed had been flipped over, the drawers from the cabinet pulled out and tossed on the ground, where a woman with curly gray hair lay prone on her stomach, still moaning softly. Nellie didn’t know if she had tripped on one of the objects she had displaced or if she had fallen from exhaustion, and she didn’t care. “Guys, help me!” Devi and West rushed in and immediately assisted Nellie in righting the woman, who staggered briefly before supporting herself against the doorframe. Nellie guessed the woman was in her sixties, but her eyes looked much older. Frightened. Tired. “Who are you?” Devi asked. The woman glared at her like the question was impolite. “You need to get out of here,” West said gently. “The building isn’t safe. Come with us.” The woman’s eyes flicked past him then settled on Nellie before widening. No, not Nellie. The woman was looking at the diary in her hand. She snatched it, flipping through the pages before impatiently opening the book towards the floor and shaking it. But whatever had been hidden inside was gone, lost somewhere in the Upper Observatory. The woman looked at them with fury. “You fools,” she seethed, her voice paper dry and crackling with fury. She stepped out of the room and slammed the door behind her, leaving them in complete darkness. And Nellie heard the distinct sound of a lock clicking into place. The sound unfroze them from their shock. West rushed forward and tried the handle to no avail, then repeatedly slammed his shoulder into the wood. Nellie and Devi joined him, but they could not get this wood to budge. They were still trying to break out when the earth began to shake again. Briefly, Nellie thought she saw light in the darkness, six points of darkness forming a constellation. In the distance she heard Devi screaming her name. And then there was nothing at all. [[End of Track]] “Hello?” a voice called out. “Have you come back for me?” “You all heard that, right?” asked West. Nellie stared at the open wardrobe door, leading down into a darkness that did not seem so dark. “Is someone down there?” Devi asked, shocked. Nellie started forward, shaking off West’s attempt to hold her back. “We can’t go down to the basement if the house is collapsing!” he shouted. “We can’t leave someone in the basement if the house is collapsing!” Nellie shouted back. “I’m with Nellie on this one,” said Devi. “It might just be a ghost,” West insisted. “West, on any of our investigations, when has a ghost actually talked to us in a full, easily understandable sentence?” Nellie asked. West opened his mouth, snapped it shut, and followed Nellie and Devi down the stairs into the basement, where they found a man sitting cross-legged on the altar. “Tara?” the man asked, his voice cool and smooth. He was handsome, in an unusual way. His skin was a little too pale, the color of someone naturally pale who has not seen sunlight in a very long time. His eyes were dark, either gray, brown, or blue, Nellie could not tell. He blinked slowly at them, and Nellie had the impression that he could not see them very well, if at all. At least, that was her impression until his eyes locked on her. His black hair was thick, pushed back from his forehead. It looked too long to Nellie, but it reminded her of the rockstars in the photos, stylish for another time. His black t-shirt and jeans were tight on his skinny frame, his studded thick boots looking too heavy for his body. He smiled at the crewmembers and Nellie wished she could look away, it was too bright, not with an actual light, but something worse that teased at the edges of her sight like the beginning of an aura migraine. “You’ve done something to your spirit, Tara, you clever witch,” the man said, his voice lilting with mockery. “Totally unrecognizable. But if you really wanted to hide, you would have left your precious diary behind. So you must think you have something to offer me that’s more enticing than what I’m due…” Nellie looked down at the diary she held. It did not look so distinctive to her. She immediately regretted taking it. This man was not human and by coming down here with this book she seemed to have invited his undivided attention. “Have you reached out to me for a trade?” the man asked, leaning forward without moving from his seated position. “A couple of lives for a couple of lifetimes? I didn’t think you took an interest-” “Hey, man, I’m sorry,” said Nellie. “I’m not looking for any kind of trade.” The man cocked his head. “I respect your resignation,” the man said. “Though it surprises me. You’ve always struck me as the brave and stupid type. It’s refreshing to be proven wrong.” His eyes went completely black, and there was the rush of air, like a vacuum opening into pure space. A rush of wind whipped her clothes around her, but the vacuum did not pull in her body. It pulled a deeper place inside of her. Her spirit. Nellie shrieked, but only for a split second before her body fell to the ground. “Holy shit,” said West. The man frowned, his eyes returning to their almost human state. “Well, that wasn’t Tara,” he said. West grabbed Devi’s hand and pulled her up the stairs. “Consider yourselves lucky, wayward spirits,” the man called up to them, his laughter echoing even as they ran into the hall, and West swore he could hear it even as the door slammed behind him. They jumped into the car and drove away. “Nellie’s dead,” Devi cried. “Nellie’s dead. She’s dead and we left her there!” “If we had stayed, that thing would have killed us to,” West said. “He was right. We’re lucky.” And as West thought about his future, maybe finding another production team, working with an actor who wasn’t Nellie, a terrible little part of him believed it was true. [[End of Track]] The crewmembers ran into the hallway outside of Bradford’s room, and it was surprisingly intact. They heard another crashing sound, this time accompanied by a soft moan. It was coming from Tara’s bedroom. “Do you think somebody’s in there?” Devi asked. Before she was even done speaking, Nellie was throwing open the door. The room was in disarray. The bed had been flipped over, the drawers from the cabinet pulled out and tossed on the ground, where a woman with curly gray hair lay prone on her stomach, still moaning softly. Nellie didn’t know if she had tripped on one of the objects she had displaced or if she had fallen from exhaustion, and she didn’t care. “Guys, help me!” Devi and West rushed in and immediately assisted Nellie in righting the woman, who staggered briefly before supporting herself against the doorframe. Nellie guessed the woman was in her sixties, but her eyes looked much older. Frightened. Tired. “Who are you?” Devi asked. The woman glared at her like the question was impolite. “You need to get out of here,” West said gently. “The building isn’t safe. Come with us.” The woman’s eyes flicked past him then settled on Nellie before widening. No, not Nellie. The woman was looking at the diary in her hand. She snatched it, flipping through the pages before impatiently opening the book towards the floor and shaking it. But whatever had been hidden inside was gone, lost somewhere in the Upper Observatory. The woman looked at them with fury. “You fools,” she seethed, her voice paper dry and crackling with fury. She stepped out of the room and Nellie watched with horror as she grabbed the door, sure the old woman would slam it shut and send the ceiling, the walls, maybe the whole house crashing down on them. And then she froze. If she was furious before, Nellie did not have a word for what she was now. The woman pointed a long finger at Nellie. “That’s MINE.” Nellie was confused until she followed the woman’s gaze down to her jeans, where a white ribbon had come unravelled and trailed out of her pocket. Before the woman could say anything else, West rushed forward and bodychecked her, slamming her to the ground. “What the HELL West?” Devi screamed. “We do not have time for crazy old women who live in haunted mansions!” West screamed back. Nellie agreed with West. She grabbed Devi’s hand, pulling her through the hallway, following her cameraman who she just realized was not filming any of this. They fled the mansion and jumped into the car, speeding away from their crime. “Um, guys?” Nellie asked after several minutes had passed. “Did anything like… actually haunted happen? Or did we just attack and old woman and leave her in a structurally unsound building?” Neither of her crewmembers answered. Nellie turned on the radio and a familiar song began to play. [[End of Track]] “Hello?” a voice called out. “Have you come back for me?” “You all heard that, right?” asked West. Nellie stared at the open wardrobe door, leading down into a darkness that did not seem so dark. “Is someone down there?” Devi asked, shocked. Nellie started forward, shaking off West’s attempt to hold her back. “We can’t go down to the basement if the house is collapsing!” he shouted. “We can’t leave someone in the basement if the house is collapsing!” Nellie shouted back. “I’m with Nellie on this one,” said Devi. “It might just be a ghost,” West insisted. “West, on any of our investigations, when has a ghost actually talked to us in a full, easily understandable sentence?” Nellie asked. West opened his mouth, snapped it shut, and followed Nellie and Devi down the stairs into the basement, where they found a man sitting cross-legged on the altar. “Tara?” the man asked, his voice cool and smooth. He was handsome, in an unusual way. His skin was a little too pale, the color of someone naturally pale who has not seen sunlight in a very long time. His eyes were dark, either gray, brown, or blue, Nellie could not tell. He blinked slowly at them, and Nellie had the impression that he could not see them very well, if at all. At least, that was her impression until his eyes locked on her. His black hair was thick, pushed back from his forehead. It looked too long to Nellie, but it reminded her of the rockstars in the photos, stylish for another time. His black t-shirt and jeans were tight on his skinny frame, his studded thick boots looking too heavy for his body. He smiled at the crewmembers and Nellie wished she could look away, it was too bright, not with an actual light, but something worse that teased at the edges of her sight like the beginning of an aura migraine. “You’ve done something to your spirit, Tara, you clever witch,” the man said, his voice lilting with mockery. “Totally unrecognizable. But if you really wanted to hide, you would have left your precious diary behind. So you must think you have something to offer me that’s more enticing than what I’m due…” Nellie looked down at the diary she held. It did not look so distinctive to her. She immediately regretted taking it. This man was not human and by coming down here with this book she seemed to have invited his undivided attention. “Have you reached out to me for a trade?” the man asked, leaning forward without moving from his seated position. “A couple of lives for a couple of lifetimes? I didn’t think you took an interest in that side of the occult.” Nellie hesitated. As long as this man assumed she was Tara, he would assume she had magic powers, apparently. Enough to trick him. Enough to earn a compliment. She might as well lean into the illusion. She pulled the white ribbon out of her pocket, the one she recognized on Tara in the family portrait, tying it around her hair. “What if I was looking to trade?” Nellie asked softly, hoping her voice wouldn’t give her away. “What would I need to do.” “Littlest One, you’ve already done it,” the man laughed. His eyes became completely dark and for a split second Nellie heard West and Devi scream. There was a sound like a rushing of air, and Nellie watched her crewmembers’ clothes whipping around them in a wind she could not feel, before they collapsed on the floor. Before Nellie could say anything, she felt something sour rising in her stomach, like bile, like vomit, but it refused to bubble up completely, leaving her full and sick and… drunk? She stumbled to the side, catching herself before she fell, and the man on the altar laughed. “Sleep it off, Tara,” the man said. “You’ll feel better in the morning. Much better. You know, if you’re willing to continue the family tradition and keep bringing me little gifts, maybe we can continue to delay our eventual, mutual gratification.” Nellie could barely pay attention to his lilting words. She somehow had the wherewithal to remember to grab the keys of Devi’s dead body before lurching up the steps, through the house, and out the front door. She didn’t know how far she drove before she crashed, but it hardly left a scratch. The sickness was starting to fade, and she felt invincible. She felt like she would live forever. Or at least, for two extra lifetimes. [[End of Track]] “So, let’s go left, but avoid the Séance Pit,” Devi said, leading the crew forward. “The door to the pit is really fragile so just… don’t touch it. West.” “If anyone is touching things she shouldn’t, it’s Nellie!” West protested. “Wow, just because of that accusation, I’m going to touch *everything*,” Nellie said, glaring at West. “Guys, stop. Avoid the Séance door. If you’re really interested in that, we can get a view from the Upper Séance room, as long as you promise to be careful.” “Careful?” West asked. “You’ll see,” Devi said. She waited for Nellie to ask her what she meant, but she had been distracted by the photographs lining the hallway’s walls. Devi signalled for West to film while she also explored the photos. The people in them looked familiar, and she assumed she must have seen them in the guidebook, or in the news, or in one of those faded tabloid magazines her mother would pull out to add visuals to an especially gruesome Bennington story, rife with human sacrifice and taboo sex. But while she did recognize an especially youthful looking Tara, her familiar curls held back in French braids, and a picture of Mark looking uncharacteristically happy, relaxed on a curved sofa between three men in ripped shirts strumming on guitars, she did not think the other people in the phots were particularly Bennington related. She paused at a photograph of Dawn, showing off her big-blue eyes under an impressively fluffy fringe, ignoring the man in extensive makeup who had tossed his arm over her shoulder in a misguided flirtatious move. The man… she had definitely seen him before… “Is that David Bowie?” Devi finally asked. Nellie startled next to her, as if she had not been looking at the same exact picture of the same exact famous popstar. “Oh shit, it is!” said West. “Holy shit, Mick Jagger’s in this pic!” Devi realized that all those semi-familiar faces were rock, pop, and folk stars who reached their heights in the 70s. Some she knew continued to perform today, and some reached fates as tragic as any of the Bennington children. Nellie’s eyes were wide as she soaked them in, and Devi wondered if she was imagining her own potential success, her own news-worthy demise.
