Devi gently touched her shoulder and Nellie seemed to come out of her trance. “Where to next, boss?” West asked. “It looks like we have options.” [[Groove Room – Devi's Tour]] [[Girls’ Bathroom – Devi’s Tour]] [[Séance Pit - Devi's Tour]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour]] Devi stepped into the Groove Room, and though its green shaggy carpet was torn up, the wallpaper was peeling and damp, and the lazily turning disco ball didn’t reflect as much as it used to, in her mind, Devi was transported back in time. She had told the other crew members that her mother told her stories about the Bennington Mansion, nothing more than the urban legends anyone might know, but it was more than that. Her mother had been here. She had danced in this room, she had walked down the wide steps that led to the deeply indented dance floor. She had swung her hips next to Dawn and Mark and learned the vices and desires of the rock stars of their time. She had run through dark rooms with Tara, the only partier who had guessed she had lied about her age and was just as much a child as the youngest Bennington, and had learned about real darkness, more than shadows. The darkness of stars that had burnt out. The way you could hold their ash in your hand. Or else, that was how her mother described it. Devi always assumed there were drugs involved that her mother did not want to disclose that made the sparkling universe of a disco ball seem like constellations. Even now, the disco ball had lost most of its sparkle, content to reflect the poor light of the moon. West passed by her, filming the disco ball, then closing in on the carpeted green stairs that led to the Upper Séance Room, before turning back to film Nellie who danced dreamily with an invisible partner on the dance floor. “Oh, I’ll be waiting here My lover, my lover The world is far away But I feel the soft skin of your hand…” Devi listened intently to her headphones, ignored by her crew members. She could have been picking up a stray radio station, but she did not think so. “Oh I’ll be waiting here, My killer, my wonder Your soul is far away How much darkness can you stand?” “What’s going on?” asked West, setting his camera on his shoulder. “I might be picking something up.” “Something spooky?” It sounded more sad than spooky, but Devi nodded her head anyway. She thought it could be ghostly. Or she could make it sound ghostly in post. The sound faded away and Devi huffed. “It’s gone now,” she said. “West, did you film me dancing?” Nellie asked. “Yes, of course,” West said, rolling his eyes. “Anything the guidebook wants us to know about this room?” “This is the Groove Room,” Devi said, reading from the guidebook. “It was built at the request of Bennington’s children and used during all of their parties. It had the best acoustics and was sometimes rented out as a studio space, but since this business venture was informal, we do not know what celebrities might have recorded here. While the ground floor was popular with disco dancers and musicians, the upper floor was reserved for the children’s more intimate activities. However, an earthquake caused extensive damage to the upper floor, and it is not open for tours.” “There’s nothing blocking the stairs now,” said West. “We have to up, Devi,” said Nellie. “We just started exploring!” [[Upper Séance Room - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GR)]]The salmon pink of the tiles, toilet, and tub were aggressively girly, in a way that hurt Devi’s eyes, the same sort of pang she got in her teeth when she ate equally pink icing on cupcakes. Devi’s mother told her stories about how Tara hated the girliness Bradford’s lovers pushed on her in some misguided attempt to keep her under their influence, away from Bradford’s occult concerns. As if enforced sweetness would equal compliance. No girl could ever live up to the sweetness of this pink. It was a mocking color, condescending and oppressive. “Looks like a bathroom,” said West, nodding officially to himself. Devi opened the guidebook, happy to look away from the walls, while West filmed Nellie looking pensively at the tile. “This is the Girls’ Bathroom,” said Devi. “While it was open to the public during parties, guests for the more private occult viewings, and eventually customers on tours, while this mansion was strictly a private residence it was shared by the five female Benningtons: Bradford’s three lovers as well as his two daughters. The men had their own private bathrooms, and this forced sharing created tension in an already tense household. The women in Bradford’s life did not get along. Dawn generally avoided the company of the lovers, including her own mother, and Tara was closest with Bradford even in her childhood. The lovers resented their daughters’ dismissal, and there were several incidents of fights breaking out over time spent in the shower, fights that reached such heights that the police were called for de-escalation on at least five separate occasions. Eventually, Tara would share a bathroom with her father and Dawn would use Mark’s bathroom during his frequent forays away from the mansion and his family. But officially, this bathroom would always be known as the Girls’ Bathroom.” “I bet he called his lovers his ‘girls,’” Nellie said, adjusting her sharp bangs in the cracked mirror. “He seems like the kind of misogynist who would do that.” “Free love isn’t necessarily misogynistic,” West said, but he did not argue further after Nellie snorted a derisive laugh. “If you want bathroom footage, you’ll have to film here,” Devi said, mostly to stop the fight before it began. “There was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and Bradford and Mark’s private bathrooms got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. We’ll see the doors in their bedrooms, but that’s it. I’m not picking anything up on the mics, but if any of this looks particularly compelling to you, we can have a closer look.” [[Explore the Tub - Devi's Tour]] [[Explore the Toilet - Devi's Tour]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Devi's Tour]] [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] Satisfied that they had enough footage from the first few rooms, Devi led the crew deeper into the Bennington mansion. They wandered away from the photographs of the rock stars. Devi wondered if her mother had met any of them during her secret trips to the Bennington Mansion. Maybe it was best that she didn’t know any of those stories. They would probably be hard to pass off as cautionary tales or urban legends that she had no personal connection to. Plus, she didn’t like to think of her mother partying with rock stars, and what that might have entailed. “You alright, Devi?” West asked. “Yeah,” Devi said, shrugging. “Is anyone else chilly?” Nellie asked and Devi relaxed as the star drew West’s attention away from her. “Nope,” said West. “Maybe it’s a ghost?” “West. Film,” Nellie demanded, before turning to the red light and smirking. “I think we have company, viewers. Does anyone want to make contact? It’s safe here. We’re listening.” Despite the silliness of its name, Spooktacular Investigations didn’t use EVP, radio channels, any of the tricks popular on other streaming shows because as far as Nellie was concerned, they were just tricks. And Devi didn’t mind. Fewer recordings to make sense of later, and none of that terrible static some of those machines made while the hapless investigators pretended they could hear sentences formed between the white noise. All three of the crew members had a history of paranormal connection, and none of them had needed tricks or special gear. Well, Devi had kind of lied about her history. It was her mother’s history, right here, at the mansion. Maybe it wasn’t as personal as West’s experience with his grandmother or Nellie’s - “Guess they’re shy,” Nellie said, shrugging at the camera. “We’ve got some chilly, shy ghosts or demons in the mansion.” “Maybe I should play ‘Running With the Devil,’” Devi suggested. “Only if we’re desperate for contact,” Nellie said. “Okay Devi, I’ve had enough of this popcorn ceiling for a lifetime. What does the guidebook say?” Devi flipped open the book. “These three bedrooms belonged to Bradford’s children,” Devi said. “They moved in during their adulthood, except for Tara, who was teenager when construction was completed. Their rooms are marked with their initials above their doors…” The crew members all looked up at the molding mantels above each door, where pieces of metal twisted into the shape of a letter were still securely nailed: M, T, D. “What’s the plan, Devi?” asked West. “We probably have time to explore two of the rooms.” [[Tara's Room - Devi's Tour]] [[Dawn's Room - Devi's Tour]] [[Mark's Room - Devi's Tour]]“Nobody touch the tub!” Devi said, pulling the loose sleeve of her hoodie over her nose. “Nellie, do not touch the tub!” Devi had ignored her nose’s warning, that putrid scent like rotting meat, and had leaned over to look inside, hoping for something a little haunted. But the thick layer of sludge covering the bottom of the pink clawed monstrosity was too much, even for viewers looking for the ghastly. “I wasn’t going to touch it!” Nellie said, covering her own mouth and nose. “I… I probably wouldn’t have touched it,” West said, filming the sludge intently. “No one wants to see that West,” said Devi. “I’ll film a bit for safety,” West grinned as his crew members backed away from the filth and stench. [[Girls' Bathroom 1 - Devi's Tour from Tub]] [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]]The owner had assured her the plumbing would work if they needed it, but Devi did not trust the look of the toilet. Its pink hue had taken on some sickly greenish undertones. “Step back, Devi,” said Nellie with fake seriousness. “It might eat you. I saw that in a 70s horror movie.” “Did you know Psycho was the first time a film showed a toilet flushing?” West asked, filming as Nellie replaced Devi by the edge of the moldy toilet bowl. “Fascinating,” said Nellie, dryly. “Can we finish up here?” [[Girls' Bathroom 1 - Devi's Tour from Toilet]] [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] “Maybe someone left something interesting behind,” Devi murmured, opening the cabinet. “Yeah, let’s get high on 70s Valium that’s thirty years past its due date,” laughed Nellie. “I mean… I feel like that would have been cleared out by now,” West said. “You’re right,” Devi said, pulling out a white ribbon that was carefully wound up in a tight ball. “Just some hair supplies left behind.” “Anything creepy about it?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said Devi. She tucked the ribbon back in place and closed the cabinet. [[Girls' Bathroom 1 - Devi's Tour from Cabinet]] [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]]Nellie peered at the guidebook over Devi’s shoulder. “Do we keep going, or do you want to check out the Groove Room?” she asked. [[Groove Room - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] [[Séance Pit - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour]] “West, are you getting good footage?” Devi asked. “It is a bathroom,” West said. “I am getting the opposite of good footage.” [[Explore the Tub - Devi's Tour from Toilet]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Devi's Tour from Toilet]] “Nobody touch the tub!” Devi said, pulling the loose sleeve of her hoodie over her nose. “Nellie, do not touch the tub!” Devi had ignored her nose’s warning, that putrid scent like rotting meat, and had leaned over to look inside, hoping for something a little haunted. But the thick layer of sludge covering the bottom of the pink clawed monstrosity was too much, even for viewers looking for the ghastly. “I wasn’t going to touch it!” Nellie said, covering her own mouth and nose. “I… I probably wouldn’t have touched it,” West said, filming the sludge intently. “No one wants to see that West,” said Devi. “I’ll film a bit for safety,” West grinned as his crew members backed away from the filth and stench. [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] “Maybe someone left something interesting behind,” Devi murmured, opening the cabinet. “Yeah, let’s get high on 70s Valium that’s thirty years past its due date,” laughed Nellie. “I mean… I feel like that would have been cleared out by now,” West said. “You’re right,” Devi said, pulling out a white ribbon that was carefully wound up in a tight ball. “Just some hair supplies left behind.” “Anything creepy about it?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said Devi. She tucked the ribbon back in place and closed the cabinet. [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] “West, are you getting good footage?” Devi asked. “It is a bathroom,” West said. “I am getting the opposite of good footage.” [[Explore the Tub - Devi's Tour from Cabinet]] [[Explore the Toilet - Devi's Tour from Cabinet]]“Nobody touch the tub!” Devi said, pulling the loose sleeve of her hoodie over her nose. “Nellie, do not touch the tub!” Devi had ignored her nose’s warning, that putrid scent like rotting meat, and had leaned over to look inside, hoping for something a little haunted. But the thick layer of sludge covering the bottom of the pink clawed monstrosity was too much, even for viewers looking for the ghastly. “I wasn’t going to touch it!” Nellie said, covering her own mouth and nose. “I… I probably wouldn’t have touched it,” West said, filming the sludge intently. “No one wants to see that West,” said Devi. “I’ll film a bit for safety,” West grinned as his crew members backed away from the filth and stench. [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] The owner had assured her the plumbing would work if they needed it, but Devi did not trust the look of the toilet. Its pink hue had taken on some sickly greenish undertones. “Step back, Devi,” said Nellie with fake seriousness. “It might eat you. I saw that in a 70s horror movie.” “Did you know Psycho was the first time a film showed a toilet flushing?” West asked, filming as Nellie replaced Devi by the edge of the moldy toilet bowl. “Fascinating,” said Nellie, dryly. “Can we finish up here?” [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]]“West, are you getting good footage?” Devi asked. “It is a bathroom,” West said. “I am getting the opposite of good footage.” [[Explore the Toilet - Devi's Tour from Tub]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Devi's Tour from Tub]]The owner had assured her the plumbing would work if they needed it, but Devi did not trust the look of the toilet. Its pink hue had taken on some sickly greenish undertones. “Step back, Devi,” said Nellie with fake seriousness. “It might eat you. I saw that in a 70s horror movie.” “Did you know Psycho was the first time a film showed a toilet flushing?” West asked, filming as Nellie replaced Devi by the edge of the moldy toilet bowl. “Fascinating,” said Nellie, dryly. “Can we finish up here?” [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]]“Maybe someone left something interesting behind,” Devi murmured, opening the cabinet. “Yeah, let’s get high on 70s Valium that’s thirty years past its due date,” laughed Nellie. “I mean… I feel like that would have been cleared out by now,” West said. “You’re right,” Devi said, pulling out a white ribbon that was carefully wound up in a tight ball. “Just some hair supplies left behind.” “Anything creepy about it?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said Devi. She tucked the ribbon back in place and closed the cabinet. [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] Devi stepped into the Groove Room, and though its green shaggy carpet was torn up, the wallpaper was peeling and damp, and the lazily turning disco ball didn’t reflect as much as it used to, in her mind, Devi was transported back in time. She had told the other crew members that her mother told her stories about the Bennington Mansion, nothing more than the urban legends anyone might know, but it was more than that. Her mother had been here. She had danced in this room, she had walked down the wide steps that led to the deeply indented dance floor. She had swung her hips next to Dawn and Mark and learned the vices and desires of the rock stars of their time. She had run through dark rooms with Tara, the only partier who had guessed she had lied about her age and was just as much a child as the youngest Bennington, and had learned about real darkness, more than shadows. The darkness of stars that had burnt out. The way you could hold their ash in your hand. Or else, that was how her mother described it. Devi always assumed there were drugs involved that her mother did not want to disclose that made the sparkling universe of a disco ball seem like constellations. Even now, the disco ball had lost most of its sparkle, content to reflect the poor light of the moon. West passed by her, filming the disco ball, then closing in on the carpeted green stairs that led to the Upper Séance Room, before turning back to film Nellie who danced dreamily with an invisible partner on the dance floor. “Oh, I’ll be waiting here My lover, my lover The world is far away But I feel the soft skin of your hand…” Devi listened intently to her headphones, ignored by her crew members. She could have been picking up a stray radio station, but she did not think so. “Oh I’ll be waiting here, My killer, my wonder Your soul is far away How much darkness can you stand?” “What’s going on?” asked West, setting his camera on his shoulder. “I might be picking something up.” “Something spooky?” It sounded more sad than spooky, but Devi nodded her head anyway. She thought it could be ghostly. Or she could make it sound ghostly in post. The sound faded away and Devi huffed. “It’s gone now,” she said. “West, did you film me dancing?” Nellie asked. “Yes, of course,” West said, rolling his eyes. “Anything the guidebook wants us to know about this room?” “This is the Groove Room,” Devi said, reading from the guidebook. “It was built at the request of Bennington’s children and used during all of their parties. It had the best acoustics and was sometimes rented out as a studio space, but since this business venture was informal, we do not know what celebrities might have recorded here. While the ground floor was popular with disco dancers and musicians, the upper floor was reserved for the children’s more intimate activities. However, an earthquake caused extensive damage to the upper floor, and it is not open for tours.” “There’s nothing blocking the stairs now,” said West. “It’s up to you, Devi,” said Nellie. “We can go up or keep exploring on the not damaged level.” [[Upper Séance Room - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour]] “West, I told you not to touch the door to the Séance Pit,” Devi scolded. “I didn’t know this was the door to the Pit,” West protested as he stepped back. “It looks like all the other doors. But, yeah, way more rotted. I bet I could kick it down.” “It’s so rotted I could kick it down,” Nellie said, squaring up like she was about to try. Devi grabbed her hand, blushed, and let it go. “No one’s kicking down any doors,” she said, quietly, but firmly. “We were just joking, Devi,” West grinned. “Lead the way.” [[Groove Room - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour]] Devi immediately regretted encouraging her crew members to explore the upper floor when they saw the large hole in the floor leading down to the even bigger hole of the séance pit and chose to lean over it as far as they could manage. “Please step away from the edge of the Pit,” Devi said, not surprised when neither Nellie or West moved. “I need to get the best footage,” West said. “The best footage involves me looking like I’m in imminent danger,” Nellie agreed. “Looking like, not actually being in,” Devi protested, but they ignored her. She pulled out the guidebook and read from the room’s official entry, understanding why it was meant to be read from the safety of the Groove Room. “An earthquake at the time caused structural damage to a lot of the mansion and is said to have upset some poorly made support beams that collapsed, making the center of the floor collapse. But some people think there was an explosion of dark energy after a séance went wrong, and the explosion caused the hole. It was in the papers. And my mom remembered it.” Devi bit her tongue. Her mother remembered it because she was there. She and Tara had been in the Upper Séance Room, had looked down and seen… it could have been party guests, but her mother had always assumed the three women in the Séance Room were Bradford’s lovers. There was an object on the table, some kind of doll, and they were chanting something. Her mother said she wanted to leave, but Tara was mesmerized. And then… nothing. Her mother didn’t remember the explosion. She was just suddenly outside, and a fireman was wrapping a blanket over her shoulders. “Doesn’t look burnt…” Nellie murmured as she touched the edge of the green carpet, torn and drooping towards the darkness below. “Maybe dark energy doesn’t burn,” West said. “Most of the dark energy we’ve faced has been cold.” Devi’s mic began to pick something up again, and Devi listened for the music, but instead she heard… footsteps? It was hard to hear over West and Nellie arguing, but they were definitely footsteps. Coming from where? It was like they were coming from the wall, but there was no room on the other side of this wall. And then the sound stopped. Devi held her breath, but there were no more footsteps. It didn’t really matter. In post, footsteps were indistinguishable from old plumbing, or a branch knocked about by wind. The audience wouldn’t care. Devi decided it was a ghost, but it was not the first ghost she had encountered that never made the final cut. “Let’s go guys,” she said. “If we stay here any longer, one of you is going to fall in the Pit.” [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] Satisfied that they had enough footage of the house so far, Devi led the crew deeper into the Bennington mansion. They wandered away from the photographs of the rock stars in the hallway. Devi wondered if her mother had met any of them during her secret trips to the Bennington Mansion. Maybe it was best that she didn’t know any of those stories. They would probably be hard to pass off as cautionary tales or urban legends that she had no personal connection to. Plus, she didn’t like to think of her mother partying with rock stars, and what that might have entailed. “You alright, Devi?” West asked. “Yeah,” Devi said, shrugging. "It's just, my mic keeps picking up these sounds like footsteps coming from the walls." "Could be ghost steps," West said. "Or rats. Or support beams giving way." "Then let's hope for ghosts," Devi shuddered. “Is anyone else chilly?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said West. “Maybe it’s a ghost?” “West. Film,” Nellie demanded, before turning to the red light and smirking. “I think we have company, viewers. Does anyone want to make contact? It’s safe here. We’re listening.” Despite the silliness of its name, Spooktacular Investigations didn’t use EVP, radio channels, any of the tricks popular on other streaming shows because as far as Nellie was concerned, they were just tricks. And Devi didn’t mind. Fewer recordings to make sense of later, and none of that terrible static some of those machines made while the hapless investigators pretended they could hear sentences formed between the white noise. All three of the crew members had a history of paranormal connection, and none of them had needed tricks or special gear. Well, Devi had kind of lied about her history. It was her mother’s history, right here, at the mansion. Maybe it wasn’t as personal as West’s experience with his grandmother or Nellie’s - “Guess they’re shy,” Nellie said, shrugging at the camera. “We’ve got some chilly, shy ghosts or demons in the mansion.” “Maybe I should play ‘Running With the Devil,’” Devi suggested. “Only if we’re desperate for contact,” Nellie said. “Okay Devi, I’ve had enough of this popcorn ceiling for a lifetime. What does the guidebook say?” Devi flipped open the book. “These three bedrooms belonged to Bradford’s children,” Devi said. “They moved in during their adulthood, except for Tara, who was teenager when construction was completed. Their rooms are marked with their initials above their doors…” The crew members all looked up at the molding mantels above each door, where pieces of metal twisted into the shape of a letter were still securely nailed: M, T, D. “What’s the plan, Devi?” asked West. “We probably have time to explore two of the rooms.” [[Tara's Room - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Dawn's Room - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Mark's Room - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]Devi immediately regretted encouraging her crew members to explore the upper floor when they saw the large hole in the floor leading down to the even bigger hole of the séance pit and chose to lean over it as far as they could manage. “Please step away from the edge of the Pit,” Devi said, not surprised when neither Nellie or West moved. “I need to get the best footage,” West said. “The best footage involves me looking like I’m in imminent danger,” Nellie agreed. “Looking like, not actually being in,” Devi protested, but they ignored her. She pulled out the guidebook and read from the room’s official entry, understanding why it was meant to be read from the safety of the Groove Room. “An earthquake at the time caused structural damage to a lot of the mansion and is said to have upset some poorly made support beams that collapsed, making the center of the floor collapse. But some people think there was an explosion of dark energy after a séance went wrong, and the explosion caused the hole. It was in the papers. And my mom remembered it.” Devi bit her tongue. Her mother remembered it because she was there. She and Tara had been in the Upper Séance Room, had looked down and seen… it could have been party guests, but her mother had always assumed the three women in the Séance Room were Bradford’s lovers. There was an object on the table, some kind of doll, and they were chanting something. Her mother said she wanted to leave, but Tara was mesmerized. And then… nothing. Her mother didn’t remember the explosion. She was just suddenly outside, and a fireman was wrapping a blanket over her shoulders. “Doesn’t look burnt…” Nellie murmured as she touched the edge of the green carpet, torn and drooping towards the darkness below. “Maybe dark energy doesn’t burn,” West said. “Most of the dark energy we’ve faced has been cold.” Devi’s mic began to pick something up again, and Devi listened for the music, but instead she heard… footsteps? It was hard to hear over West and Nellie arguing, but they were definitely footsteps. Coming from where? It was like they were coming from the wall, but there was no room on the other side of this wall. And then the sound stopped. Devi held her breath, but there were no more footsteps. It didn’t really matter. In post, footsteps were indistinguishable from old plumbing, or a branch knocked about by wind. The audience wouldn’t care. Devi decided it was a ghost, but it was not the first ghost she had encountered that never made the final cut. “Let’s go guys,” she said. “If we stay here any longer, one of you is going to fall in the Pit.” [[Hallway 1 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]Nellie peered at the guidebook over Devi’s shoulder. “Do we keep going, or do you want to check out the Girls' Bathroom?” she asked. [[Girls' Bathroom - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Séance Pit – Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] The salmon pink of the tiles, toilet, and tub were aggressively girly, in a way that hurt Devi’s eyes, the same sort of pang she got in her teeth when she ate equally pink icing on cupcakes. Devi’s mother told her stories about how Tara hated the girliness Bradford’s lovers pushed on her in some misguided attempt to keep her under their influence, away from Bradford’s occult concerns. As if enforced sweetness would equal compliance. No girl could ever live up to the sweetness of this pink. It was a mocking color, condescending and oppressive. “Looks like a bathroom,” said West, nodding officially to himself. Devi opened the guidebook, happy to look away from the walls, while West filmed Nellie looking pensively at the tile. “This is the Girls’ Bathroom,” said Devi. “While it was open to the public during parties, guests for the more private occult viewings, and eventually customers on tours, while this mansion was strictly a private residence it was shared by the five female Benningtons: Bradford’s three lovers as well as his two daughters. The men had their own private bathrooms, and this forced sharing created tension in an already tense household. The women in Bradford’s life did not get along. Dawn generally avoided the company of the lovers, including her own mother, and Tara was closest with Bradford even in her childhood. The lovers resented their daughters’ dismissal, and there were several incidents of fights breaking out over time spent in the shower, fights that reached such heights that the police were called for de-escalation on at least five separate occasions. Eventually, Tara would share a bathroom with her father and Dawn would use Mark’s bathroom during his frequent forays away from the mansion and his family. But officially, this bathroom would always be known as the Girls’ Bathroom.” “I bet he called his lovers his ‘girls,’” Nellie said, adjusting her sharp bangs in the cracked mirror. “He seems like the kind of misogynist who would do that.” “Free love isn’t necessarily misogynistic,” West said, but he did not argue further after Nellie snorted a derisive laugh. “If you want bathroom footage, you’ll have to film here,” Devi said, mostly to stop the fight before it began. “There was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and Bradford and Mark’s private bathrooms got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. We’ll see the doors in their bedrooms, but that’s it. I’m not picking anything up on the mics, but if any of this looks particularly compelling to you, we can have a closer look.” [[Explore the Tub - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Explore the Toilet - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] “West, I told you not to touch the door to the Séance Pit,” Devi scolded. “I didn’t know this was the door to the Pit,” West protested as he stepped back. “It looks like all the other doors. But, yeah, way more rotted. I bet I could kick it down.” “It’s so rotted I could kick it down,” Nellie said, squaring up like she was about to try. Devi grabbed her hand, blushed, and let it go. “No one’s kicking down any doors,” she said, quietly, but firmly. “We were just joking, Devi,” West grinned. “Lead the way.” [[Girls' Bathroom - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]“Nobody touch the tub!” Devi said, pulling the loose sleeve of her hoodie over her nose. “Nellie, do not touch the tub!” Devi had ignored her nose’s warning, that putrid scent like rotting meat, and had leaned over to look inside, hoping for something a little haunted. But the thick layer of sludge covering the bottom of the pink clawed monstrosity was too much, even for viewers looking for the ghastly. “I wasn’t going to touch it!” Nellie said, covering her own mouth and nose. “I… I probably wouldn’t have touched it,” West said, filming the sludge intently. “No one wants to see that West,” said Devi. “I’ll film a bit for safety,” West grinned as his crew members backed away from the filth and stench. [[Girls' Bathroom 1 - Devi's Tour from Tub (Cont. from USR)]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]The owner had assured her the plumbing would work if they needed it, but Devi did not trust the look of the toilet. Its pink hue had taken on some sickly greenish undertones. “Step back, Devi,” said Nellie with fake seriousness. “It might eat you. I saw that in a 70s horror movie.” “Did you know Psycho was the first time a film showed a toilet flushing?” West asked, filming as Nellie replaced Devi by the edge of the moldy toilet bowl. “Fascinating,” said Nellie, dryly. “Can we finish up here?” [[Girls' Bathroom 1 - Devi's Tour from Toilet (Cont. from USR)]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]“Maybe someone left something interesting behind,” Devi murmured, opening the cabinet. “Yeah, let’s get high on 70s Valium that’s thirty years past its due date,” laughed Nellie. “I mean… I feel like that would have been cleared out by now,” West said. “You’re right,” Devi said, pulling out a white ribbon that was carefully wound up in a tight ball. “Just some hair supplies left behind.” “Anything creepy about it?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said Devi. She tucked the ribbon back in place and closed the cabinet. [[Girls' Bathroom 1 - Devi's Tour from Cabinet (Cont. from USR)]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]“West, are you getting good footage?” Devi asked. “It is a bathroom,” West said. “I am getting the opposite of good footage.” [[Explore the Tub - Devi's Tour from Cabinet (Cont. from USR)]] [[Explore the Toilet - Devi's Tour from Cabinet (Cont. from USR)]]“Nobody touch the tub!” Devi said, pulling the loose sleeve of her hoodie over her nose. “Nellie, do not touch the tub!” Devi had ignored her nose’s warning, that putrid scent like rotting meat, and had leaned over to look inside, hoping for something a little haunted. But the thick layer of sludge covering the bottom of the pink clawed monstrosity was too much, even for viewers looking for the ghastly. “I wasn’t going to touch it!” Nellie said, covering her own mouth and nose. “I… I probably wouldn’t have touched it,” West said, filming the sludge intently. “No one wants to see that West,” said Devi. “I’ll film a bit for safety,” West grinned as his crew members backed away from the filth and stench. [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]The owner had assured her the plumbing would work if they needed it, but Devi did not trust the look of the toilet. Its pink hue had taken on some sickly greenish undertones. “Step back, Devi,” said Nellie with fake seriousness. “It might eat you. I saw that in a 70s horror movie.” “Did you know Psycho was the first time a film showed a toilet flushing?” West asked, filming as Nellie replaced Devi by the edge of the moldy toilet bowl. “Fascinating,” said Nellie, dryly. “Can we finish up here?” [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]“West, I told you not to touch the door to the Séance Pit,” Devi scolded. “I didn’t know this was the door to the Pit,” West protested as he stepped back. “It looks like all the other doors. But, yeah, way more rotted. I bet I could kick it down.” “It’s so rotted I could kick it down,” Nellie said, squaring up like she was about to try. Devi grabbed her hand, blushed, and let it go. “No one’s kicking down any doors,” she said, quietly, but firmly. “We were just joking, Devi,” West grinned. “Lead the way.” "Okay, but we're going to be quick here," Devi said. "Choose the bathroom or the Groove Room. I don't trust either of you this close to this door for very long." [[Groove Room - Devi's Tour (Cont. from GBR)]] [[Girls' Bathroom - Devi's Tour (Cont. from SP)]]“West, are you getting good footage?” Devi asked. “It is a bathroom,” West said. “I am getting the opposite of good footage.” [[Explore the Toilet - Devi's Tour from Tub (Cont. from USR)]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Devi's Tour from Tub (Cont. from USR)]]The owner had assured her the plumbing would work if they needed it, but Devi did not trust the look of the toilet. Its pink hue had taken on some sickly greenish undertones. “Step back, Devi,” said Nellie with fake seriousness. “It might eat you. I saw that in a 70s horror movie.” “Did you know Psycho was the first time a film showed a toilet flushing?” West asked, filming as Nellie replaced Devi by the edge of the moldy toilet bowl. “Fascinating,” said Nellie, dryly. “Can we finish up here?” [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]“Maybe someone left something interesting behind,” Devi murmured, opening the cabinet. “Yeah, let’s get high on 70s Valium that’s thirty years past its due date,” laughed Nellie. “I mean… I feel like that would have been cleared out by now,” West said. “You’re right,” Devi said, pulling out a white ribbon that was carefully wound up in a tight ball. “Just some hair supplies left behind.” “Anything creepy about it?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said Devi. She tucked the ribbon back in place and closed the cabinet. [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]“West, are you getting good footage?” Devi asked. “It is a bathroom,” West said. “I am getting the opposite of good footage.” [[Explore the Tub - Devi's Tour from Toilet (Cont. from USR)]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Devi's Tour from Toilet (Cont. from USR)]]“Nobody touch the tub!” Devi said, pulling the loose sleeve of her hoodie over her nose. “Nellie, do not touch the tub!” Devi had ignored her nose’s warning, that putrid scent like rotting meat, and had leaned over to look inside, hoping for something a little haunted. But the thick layer of sludge covering the bottom of the pink clawed monstrosity was too much, even for viewers looking for the ghastly. “I wasn’t going to touch it!” Nellie said, covering her own mouth and nose. “I… I probably wouldn’t have touched it,” West said, filming the sludge intently. “No one wants to see that West,” said Devi. “I’ll film a bit for safety,” West grinned as his crew members backed away from the filth and stench. [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]“Maybe someone left something interesting behind,” Devi murmured, opening the cabinet. “Yeah, let’s get high on 70s Valium that’s thirty years past its due date,” laughed Nellie. “I mean… I feel like that would have been cleared out by now,” West said. “You’re right,” Devi said, pulling out a white ribbon that was carefully wound up in a tight ball. “Just some hair supplies left behind.” “Anything creepy about it?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said Devi. She tucked the ribbon back in place and closed the cabinet. [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]The salmon pink of the tiles, toilet, and tub were aggressively girly, in a way that hurt Devi’s eyes, the same sort of pang she got in her teeth when she ate equally pink icing on cupcakes. Devi’s mother told her stories about how Tara hated the girliness Bradford’s lovers pushed on her in some misguided attempt to keep her under their influence, away from Bradford’s occult concerns. As if enforced sweetness would equal compliance. No girl could ever live up to the sweetness of this pink. It was a mocking color, condescending and oppressive. “Looks like a bathroom,” said West, nodding officially to himself. Devi opened the guidebook, happy to look away from the walls, while West filmed Nellie looking pensively at the tile. “This is the Girls’ Bathroom,” said Devi. “While it was open to the public during parties, guests for the more private occult viewings, and eventually customers on tours, while this mansion was strictly a private residence it was shared by the five female Benningtons: Bradford’s three lovers as well as his two daughters. The men had their own private bathrooms, and this forced sharing created tension in an already tense household. The women in Bradford’s life did not get along. Dawn generally avoided the company of the lovers, including her own mother, and Tara was closest with Bradford even in her childhood. The lovers resented their daughters’ dismissal, and there were several incidents of fights breaking out over time spent in the shower, fights that reached such heights that the police were called for de-escalation on at least five separate occasions. Eventually, Tara would share a bathroom with her father and Dawn would use Mark’s bathroom during his frequent forays away from the mansion and his family. But officially, this bathroom would always be known as the Girls’ Bathroom.” “I bet he called his lovers his ‘girls,’” Nellie said, adjusting her sharp bangs in the cracked mirror. “He seems like the kind of misogynist who would do that.” “Free love isn’t necessarily misogynistic,” West said, but he did not argue further after Nellie snorted a derisive laugh. “If you want bathroom footage, you’ll have to film here,” Devi said, mostly to stop the fight before it began. “There was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and Bradford and Mark’s private bathrooms got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. We’ll see the doors in their bedrooms, but that’s it. I’m not picking anything up on the mics, but if any of this looks particularly compelling to you, we can have a closer look.” [[Explore the Tub - Devi's Tour (Cont. from SP)]] [[Explore the Toilet - Devi's Tour (Cont. from SP)]] [[Explore the Cabinet - Devi's Tour (Cont. from SP)]] [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour]] “Nobody touch the tub!” Devi said, pulling the loose sleeve of her hoodie over her nose. “Nellie, do not touch the tub!” Devi had ignored her nose’s warning, that putrid scent like rotting meat, and had leaned over to look inside, hoping for something a little haunted. But the thick layer of sludge covering the bottom of the pink clawed monstrosity was too much, even for viewers looking for the ghastly. “I wasn’t going to touch it!” Nellie said, covering her own mouth and nose. “I… I probably wouldn’t have touched it,” West said, filming the sludge intently. “No one wants to see that West,” said Devi. “I’ll film a bit for safety,” West grinned as his crew members backed away from the filth and stench.
