I saw that in a 70s horror movie.” “Did you know Psycho was the first time a film showed a toilet flushing?” West asked, filming as Nellie replaced Devi by the edge of the moldy toilet bowl. “Fascinating,” said Nellie, dryly. “Can we finish up here?” [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour]]The owner had assured her the plumbing would work if they needed it, but Devi did not trust the look of the toilet. Its pink hue had taken on some sickly greenish undertones. “Step back, Devi,” said Nellie with fake seriousness. “It might eat you. I saw that in a 70s horror movie.” “Did you know Psycho was the first time a film showed a toilet flushing?” West asked, filming as Nellie replaced Devi by the edge of the moldy toilet bowl. “Fascinating,” said Nellie, dryly. “Can we finish up here?” [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour]]“Maybe someone left something interesting behind,” Devi murmured, opening the cabinet. “Yeah, let’s get high on 70s Valium that’s thirty years past its due date,” laughed Nellie. “I mean… I feel like that would have been cleared out by now,” West said. “You’re right,” Devi said, pulling out a white ribbon that was carefully wound up in a tight ball. “Just some hair supplies left behind.” “Anything creepy about it?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said Devi. She tucked the ribbon back in place and closed the cabinet. [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour]]“Nobody touch the tub!” Devi said, pulling the loose sleeve of her hoodie over her nose. “Nellie, do not touch the tub!” Devi had ignored her nose’s warning, that putrid scent like rotting meat, and had leaned over to look inside, hoping for something a little haunted. But the thick layer of sludge covering the bottom of the pink clawed monstrosity was too much, even for viewers looking for the ghastly. “I wasn’t going to touch it!” Nellie said, covering her own mouth and nose. “I… I probably wouldn’t have touched it,” West said, filming the sludge intently. “No one wants to see that West,” said Devi. “I’ll film a bit for safety,” West grinned as his crew members backed away from the filth and stench. [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour]]“Maybe someone left something interesting behind,” Devi murmured, opening the cabinet. “Yeah, let’s get high on 70s Valium that’s thirty years past its due date,” laughed Nellie. “I mean… I feel like that would have been cleared out by now,” West said. “You’re right,” Devi said, pulling out a white ribbon that was carefully wound up in a tight ball. “Just some hair supplies left behind.” “Anything creepy about it?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said Devi. She tucked the ribbon back in place and closed the cabinet. [[Hallway 2 - Devi's Tour]]“Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow. Edward. That was what Tara named him. She still slept with him well into her teen years. When Devi’s mother snuck into the Bennington parties, she always hoped Tara would find her, take her exploring through those mysterious hallways that only she could navigate, toting Edward along with her. Her mother made it sound like Tara conjured the halls out of thin air, but Devi assumed there were enough substances filling the air on those cool desert nights to make any trip on a back stairway seem like a miraculous journey to the stars. She was not sure what to make of her mother’s other stories, the ones where she and Tara hid behind cracked doors and watched as the Benningtons spoke to… something. Someone terrible, a man her mother never fully described. She never said what he did to Bradford, to his lovers, to Mark. She just said Dawn made sure to stay away from him, and Tara could never resist sneaking closer and closer until the day she was fully brought into the fold, leaving her mother on the other side of a firmly shut door. Her mother said the terrible creature was not a man. Not a ghost. Not a demon. Something else. Devi had been chasing him for years, a face to put to her mother’s memory. She did not know why she couldn’t dismiss the man in the same way she dismissed the magical hallways. “You should get in the bed,” West whispered to Nellie. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie. Devi flipped to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “This room belonged to Tara, Bradford’s youngest child. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, sometimes days in his secret study, communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mother who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died…” Devi paused. The rest of the entry implied that Tara had killed him for her own dark purposes, to take revenge or gain power. It was a good story for a ghostly investigation. But she felt Edward’s button eyes on her, the same ones that watched her mother as the girls ran through magical hallways. She closed the book, smiling at West and Nellie like there was nothing else on the page. [[Dawn's Room - Devi's Tour (from Tara's/Mark's Room)]] [[Mark's Room - Devi's Tour (from Dawn's/Tara's Room)]] Devi had heard stories from her mother about Dawn’s temper. Usually Dawn would play it cool during the parties that Devi’s mother attended, but every so often something would happen to set her off. The something was usually Mark. And once Dawn was screaming, she was throwing things, and breaking chairs, and shattering glasses. So, though the room could have been wrecked recently by vandals, Devi suspected that the gouged walls, scratched bedposts, and crushed sparkling jewels on the ground were the remains of Dawn’s final tantrum. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Devi flipped through the guidebook as West casually filmed Nellie who was piecing through the jewellery on the floor, not with the intent to steal it. Devi didn’t know what her intent was. But the meticulous way she seemed to be searching through the jewellery was unsettling. She read quickly. “Dawn was Bradford’s oldest daughter. She grew up in Mississippi with her mother, one of Bradford’s lovers. It was this lover who had encouraged him to build the Bennington Mansion for the whole family. The press described Dawn as a Southern Belle, or a Peach Flower forced to live as a Cactus. She was sweet to her friends and family but downright prickly to anyone who came courting. However, rumor has it that she did fall in love, and not with one of those rich Hollywood types that were always shmoozing with Bradford on the estate or cozying up to her brother with their wild lives. She met a folksinger named Emma who snuck into one of their parties because she heard that Janis Ian was there. Emma didn’t meet Janis, but she did meet Dawn. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react to this poor prospect, an unknown outsider with no ties to the family through wealth, celebrity, or even occult interests. When Mark discovered their romance, he told her father, and Bradford forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again. Some say he arranged for Emma to be murdered or sacrificed her to a dark spirit in order to ensure the continued wealth of the family. Whatever her fate, she disappeared in the summer of 1978. Mere weeks later, her sister Tara would tell the police that she thought she heard Dawn come into her room in the middle of the night and felt her gently kiss her on the forehead before she took the sheets from her bed, went to the Upper Séance room, and hanged herself.” “Nel, did you need a sec? Or a tissue?” West asked, surprisingly genuine. “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty.” Devi’s mother told her that she had never seen a person in real life or on film who was as beautiful as Dawn Bennington. She also said that the papers had it wrong. They thought that Emma’s death caused Dawn’s depression. But Dawn had always carried that sadness in her, along with her rage and her joy, every emotion at full throttle all the time. It was Emma who cooled her woes and her temper, her rages and her joys. Without Emma to carry her, what else could Dawn do but fall? Before they moved on, Nellie picked up the jewellery and set it on the remains of a vanity, a neat line of broken memories in front of a mirror with only a few smashed pieces left in its frame. [[Tara's Room - Devi's Tour (from Dawn's/Mark's Room)]] [[Mark's Room - Devi's Tour (from Dawn's/Tara's Room)]] Devi’s mother didn’t have many stories about Mark from those days when she would party at the Bennington Mansion, and she definitely hadn’t gone into Mark’s bedroom, but even if she did not have first-person witness testimony, Devi doubted it had looked like this in its heyday. The purple paisley wallpaper wet and peeling, oozing a brown sludge seemed to have seeped into everything it touched. The walls, the bed, the carpet, and the few personal items left in the room had all gone soft, like a half-chewed meal spat out by a cranky child. The ooze was at its thickest by a door at the far end of the room. Devi was not tempted to look behind it, and even if her more adventurous crew members wanted to, it was nailed shut with large pieces of wood. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, trying not to look too disgusted as she peered thoughtfully at the sogging decay. Devi flipped through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. However, Mark chose to bring the rock star crowd that welcomed him back to the mansion, finding less independence than his family might have hoped. Mark was a songwriter, and his guitar is still preserved in his bedroom, in the corner it rarely left once the Bennington son found more excitement in the lifestyle of musicians than in his own music. He often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, spreading rumors in the press that most reporters believed were greatly exaggerated, though their suspicions never stopped them from printing Mark’s tall tales of human sacrifice and portals to Hell. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, demanding that he make his own way in the world, but his more sympathetic family members always welcomed this prodigal son’s frequent returns. Police reported that one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other, though whether they fought in Bradford’s bedroom or the kitchen was uncertain. This uncertainty would prove a boon to the elder Bradford, casting doubt on his daughters’ memories and therefore doubt on his possible involvement in his son’s disappearance. Bradford was screaming at Mark to leave their house for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. Immediate landscaping on the Bennington garden led to speculation that Bradford had killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive.” “Devi, I can’t take anymore,” said Nellie gagging. “Wait, does anyone see that guitar?” West asked. The crew members looked at the misshapen piles of sludge around the room. Devi supposed any of those piles could have been a guitar at one point. Nellie shrugged at West and they followed her hurried retreat from the room. Devi’s mother did tell her that Mark once screamed at Tara for touching his guitar. She wondered what he would have thought about the state of his beloved instrument now. [[Dawn's Room - Devi's Tour (from Tara's/Mark's Room)]] [[Tara's Room - Devi's Tour (from Dawn's/Mark's Room)]] Devi had heard stories from her mother about Dawn’s temper. Usually Dawn would play it cool during the parties that Devi’s mother attended, but every so often something would happen to set her off. The something was usually Mark. And once Dawn was screaming, she was throwing things, and breaking chairs, and shattering glasses. So, though the room could have been wrecked recently by vandals, Devi suspected that the gouged walls, scratched bedposts, and crushed sparkling jewels on the ground were the remains of Dawn’s final tantrum. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Devi flipped through the guidebook as West casually filmed Nellie who was piecing through the jewellery on the floor, not with the intent to steal it. Devi didn’t know what her intent was. But the meticulous way she seemed to be searching through the jewellery was unsettling. She read quickly. “Dawn was Bradford’s oldest daughter. She grew up in Mississippi with her mother, one of Bradford’s lovers. It was this lover who had encouraged him to build the Bennington Mansion for the whole family. The press described Dawn as a Southern Belle, or a Peach Flower forced to live as a Cactus. She was sweet to her friends and family but downright prickly to anyone who came courting. However, rumor has it that she did fall in love, and not with one of those rich Hollywood types that were always shmoozing with Bradford on the estate or cozying up to her brother with their wild lives. She met a folksinger named Emma who snuck into one of their parties because she heard that Janis Ian was there. Emma didn’t meet Janis, but she did meet Dawn. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react to this poor prospect, an unknown outsider with no ties to the family through wealth, celebrity, or even occult interests. When Mark discovered their romance, he told her father, and Bradford forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again. Some say he arranged for Emma to be murdered or sacrificed her to a dark spirit in order to ensure the continued wealth of the family. Whatever her fate, she disappeared in the summer of 1978. Mere weeks later, her sister Tara would tell the police that she thought she heard Dawn come into her room in the middle of the night and felt her gently kiss her on the forehead before she took the sheets from her bed, went to the Upper Séance room, and hanged herself.” “Nel, did you need a sec? Or a tissue?” West asked, surprisingly genuine. “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty.” Devi’s mother told her that she had never seen a person in real life or on film who was as beautiful as Dawn Bennington. She also said that the papers had it wrong. They thought that Emma’s death caused Dawn’s depression. But Dawn had always carried that sadness in her, along with her rage and her joy, every emotion at full throttle all the time. It was Emma who cooled her woes and her temper, her rages and her joys. Without Emma to carry her, what else could Dawn do but fall? Before they moved on, Nellie picked up the jewellery and set it on the remains of a vanity, a neat line of broken memories in front of a mirror with only a few smashed pieces left in its frame. Nellie paused. There was something sticking out of the vanity’s top drawer. She tugged it free, reading the faded lines. “Hey, guys, I think I found a poem.” “Give a dead woman some privacy, Nellie,” said West. “We should go on.” [[Dawn's Poem - Devi's Tour]] [[Library - Devi's Tour]]Devi’s mother didn’t have many stories about Mark from those days when she would party at the Bennington Mansion, and she definitely hadn’t gone into Mark’s bedroom, but even if she did not have first-person witness testimony, Devi doubted it had looked like this in its heyday. The purple paisley wallpaper wet and peeling, oozing a brown sludge seemed to have seeped into everything it touched. The walls, the bed, the carpet, and the few personal items left in the room had all gone soft, like a half-chewed meal spat out by a cranky child. The ooze was at its thickest by a door at the far end of the room. Devi was not tempted to look behind it, and even if her more adventurous crew members wanted to, it was nailed shut with large pieces of wood. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, trying not to look too disgusted as she peered thoughtfully at the sogging decay. Devi flipped through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. However, Mark chose to bring the rock star crowd that welcomed him back to the mansion, finding less independence than his family might have hoped. Mark was a songwriter, and his guitar is still preserved in his bedroom, in the corner it rarely left once the Bennington son found more excitement in the lifestyle of musicians than in his own music. He often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, spreading rumors in the press that most reporters believed were greatly exaggerated, though their suspicions never stopped them from printing Mark’s tall tales of human sacrifice and portals to Hell. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, demanding that he make his own way in the world, but his more sympathetic family members always welcomed this prodigal son’s frequent returns. Police reported that one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other, though whether they fought in Bradford’s bedroom or the kitchen was uncertain. This uncertainty would prove a boon to the elder Bradford, casting doubt on his daughters’ memories and therefore doubt on his possible involvement in his son’s disappearance. Bradford was screaming at Mark to leave their house for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. Immediate landscaping on the Bennington garden led to speculation that Bradford had killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive.” “Devi, I can’t take anymore,” said Nellie gagging. “Wait, does anyone see that guitar?” West asked. The crew members looked at the misshapen piles of sludge around the room. Devi supposed any of those piles could have been a guitar at one point. Devi’s mother did tell her that Mark once screamed at Tara for touching his guitar. She wondered what he would have thought about the state of his beloved instrument now. West frowned as he stared at piece of the bedframe that had not completely rotted. “There’s some kind of message scratched on here,” West said, leaning down to read it more closely. “West, do not touch the rotten wood,” Devi chided. “Let’s go.” [[Mark's Message - Devi's Tour]] [[Library - Devi's Tour]]“Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow. Edward. That was what Tara named him. She still slept with him well into her teen years. When Devi’s mother snuck into the Bennington parties, she always hoped Tara would find her, take her exploring through those mysterious hallways that only she could navigate, toting Edward along with her. Her mother made it sound like Tara conjured the halls out of thin air, but Devi assumed there were enough substances filling the air on those cool desert nights to make any trip on a back stairway seem like a miraculous journey to the stars. She was not sure what to make of her mother’s other stories, the ones where she and Tara hid behind cracked doors and watched as the Benningtons spoke to… something. Someone terrible, a man her mother never fully described. She never said what he did to Bradford, to his lovers, to Mark. She just said Dawn made sure to stay away from him, and Tara could never resist sneaking closer and closer until the day she was fully brought into the fold, leaving her mother on the other side of a firmly shut door. Her mother said the terrible creature was not a man. Not a ghost. Not a demon. Something else. Devi had been chasing him for years, a face to put to her mother’s memory. She did not know why she couldn’t dismiss the man in the same way she dismissed the magical hallways. “You should get in the bed,” West whispered to Nellie. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie. Devi flipped to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “This room belonged to Tara, Bradford’s youngest child. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, sometimes days in his secret study, communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mother who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died…” Devi paused. The rest of the entry implied that Tara had killed him for her own dark purposes, to take revenge or gain power. It was a good story for a ghostly investigation. But she felt Edward’s button eyes on her, the same ones that watched her mother as the girls ran through magical hallways. She closed the book, smiling at West and Nellie like there was nothing else on the page. West and Nellie shared a shrug and turned to leave. “Wait,” said Devi, crouching to look at a little box on the ground, no bigger than a box for a ring, with nine sliding tiles on the top. “There’s some kind of puzzle here.” “No, I see numbers, that counts as math,” Nellie protested. “We’re going to the next room.” [[Tara's Puzzle - Devi's Tour]] [[Library - Devi's Tour]]Devi walked through an ornate archway into a library that was exactly how her mother had described it to her. A part of her had always expected that memory, fear of trespassing where she did not belong when she tagged along after Tara into the more private quarters of the mansion, had colored her mother’s descriptions with darkness and dread. But the Bennington Mansion library was as cold and unwelcoming as her stories had always made it seem, made worse by the ravages of time and rot. “Is that sludge or a choice?” West asked at Devi’s shoulder. She followed his camera up. The ceiling came to a point, painted all the same black or dark brown, and while it did look wet, fresh, it wasn’t dripping. It was the same style as the entry room ceiling, designed by Bradford, but if he wanted the entry hall to welcome people in with light, the smoky glass above them screamed at these visitors to leave or be swallowed by darkness. There weren’t any of the mansion’s signature porthole windows in this room, the only light dimly edging in from the hallway. Devi pulled a flashlight from her bag, frustrated that she had to use it so early in their exploration. “Probably could have used this earlier, but I wanted to save the battery,” said Devi, letting a beam of light disrupt the darkness. Her light panned across the uninviting room, illuminating bookshelves still filled with books that would have been priceless if they weren’t so decrepit. The black leather sofas filled the room with a musky smell like animals that had come in from the damp. They sat low to the ground, like fungal growths, creating a kind of fairy path across the sprawling room. Devi could imagine walking through them and disappearing forever. Maybe this was the room where her mother had disappeared. “The floor is lava,” Nellie whispered. Devi had not heard what inspired this statement, but West chuckled politely, and Devi offered a meek smile to pretend she had been paying attention. There was a blinding moment as the light caught on a large globe with a golden-hued frame and what looked like hand-painted countries, but Devi noticed with unease that they were not countries from any earth she recognized. It tilted at an odd, unearthly angle, and its elegance contrasted with the sensation of wrongness that it emanated. Devi’s eyes were transfixed for a moment, and she was not sure if she wanted to read the neat inky print naming each of those unfamiliar shapes cascading across the smooth surface or if she wanted give it a strong kick to send it smashing to the floor. Devi stopped the light at the far end of the room, where a similar archway led further into the mansion, bringing them closer to their final destination. Next to it, a solid black winding staircase, its artificial smoothness making the sogging shelves behind it look even more forlorn, led to an upper floor. “Well,” said Nellie. “There’s a lot going on here. I feel like libraries are made to be haunted. Keep that camera on me, West.” West did as he was told, but waited for Devi to take the lead. [[Upper Floor Observatory - Devi's Tour]] [[Globe - Devi's Tour]] [[Bookshelves - Devi's Tour]]“Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow. Edward. That was what Tara named him. She still slept with him well into her teen years. When Devi’s mother snuck into the Bennington parties, she always hoped Tara would find her, take her exploring through those mysterious hallways that only she could navigate, toting Edward along with her. Her mother made it sound like Tara conjured the halls out of thin air, but Devi assumed there were enough substances filling the air on those cool desert nights to make any trip on a back stairway seem like a miraculous journey to the stars. She was not sure what to make of her mother’s other stories, the ones where she and Tara hid behind cracked doors and watched as the Benningtons spoke to… something. Someone terrible, a man her mother never fully described. She never said what he did to Bradford, to his lovers, to Mark. She just said Dawn made sure to stay away from him, and Tara could never resist sneaking closer and closer until the day she was fully brought into the fold, leaving her mother on the other side of a firmly shut door. Her mother said the terrible creature was not a man. Not a ghost. Not a demon. Something else. Devi had been chasing him for years, a face to put to her mother’s memory. She did not know why she couldn’t dismiss the man in the same way she dismissed the magical hallways. “You should get in the bed,” West whispered to Nellie. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie. Devi flipped to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “This room belonged to Tara, Bradford’s youngest child. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, sometimes days in his secret study, communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mother who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died…” Devi paused. The rest of the entry implied that Tara had killed him for her own dark purposes, to take revenge or gain power. It was a good story for a ghostly investigation. But she felt Edward’s button eyes on her, the same ones that watched her mother as the girls ran through magical hallways. She closed the book, smiling at West and Nellie like there was nothing else on the page. [[Dawn's Room - Devi's Tour (from Tara's/Mark's Room Cont. from USR)]] [[Mark's Room - Devi's Tour (from Dawn's/Tara's Room Cont. from USR)]] Devi had heard stories from her mother about Dawn’s temper. Usually Dawn would play it cool during the parties that Devi’s mother attended, but every so often something would happen to set her off. The something was usually Mark. And once Dawn was screaming, she was throwing things, and breaking chairs, and shattering glasses. So, though the room could have been wrecked recently by vandals, Devi suspected that the gouged walls, scratched bedposts, and crushed sparkling jewels on the ground were the remains of Dawn’s final tantrum. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Devi flipped through the guidebook as West casually filmed Nellie who was piecing through the jewellery on the floor, not with the intent to steal it. Devi didn’t know what her intent was. But the meticulous way she seemed to be searching through the jewellery was unsettling. She read quickly. “Dawn was Bradford’s oldest daughter. She grew up in Mississippi with her mother, one of Bradford’s lovers. It was this lover who had encouraged him to build the Bennington Mansion for the whole family. The press described Dawn as a Southern Belle, or a Peach Flower forced to live as a Cactus. She was sweet to her friends and family but downright prickly to anyone who came courting. However, rumor has it that she did fall in love, and not with one of those rich Hollywood types that were always shmoozing with Bradford on the estate or cozying up to her brother with their wild lives. She met a folksinger named Emma who snuck into one of their parties because she heard that Janis Ian was there. Emma didn’t meet Janis, but she did meet Dawn. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react to this poor prospect, an unknown outsider with no ties to the family through wealth, celebrity, or even occult interests. When Mark discovered their romance, he told her father, and Bradford forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again. Some say he arranged for Emma to be murdered or sacrificed her to a dark spirit in order to ensure the continued wealth of the family. Whatever her fate, she disappeared in the summer of 1978. Mere weeks later, her sister Tara would tell the police that she thought she heard Dawn come into her room in the middle of the night and felt her gently kiss her on the forehead before she took the sheets from her bed, went to the Upper Séance room, and hanged herself.” “Nel, did you need a sec? Or a tissue?” West asked, surprisingly genuine. “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty.” Devi’s mother told her that she had never seen a person in real life or on film who was as beautiful as Dawn Bennington. She also said that the papers had it wrong. They thought that Emma’s death caused Dawn’s depression. But Dawn had always carried that sadness in her, along with her rage and her joy, every emotion at full throttle all the time. It was Emma who cooled her woes and her temper, her rages and her joys. Without Emma to carry her, what else could Dawn do but fall? Before they moved on, Nellie picked up the jewellery and set it on the remains of a vanity, a neat line of broken memories in front of a mirror with only a few smashed pieces left in its frame. [[Tara's Room - Devi's Tour (from Dawn's/Mark's Room Cont. from USR)]] [[Mark's Room - Devi's Tour (from Dawn's/Tara's Room Cont. from USR)]] Devi’s mother didn’t have many stories about Mark from those days when she would party at the Bennington Mansion, and she definitely hadn’t gone into Mark’s bedroom, but even if she did not have first-person witness testimony, Devi doubted it had looked like this in its heyday. The purple paisley wallpaper wet and peeling, oozing a brown sludge seemed to have seeped into everything it touched. The walls, the bed, the carpet, and the few personal items left in the room had all gone soft, like a half-chewed meal spat out by a cranky child. The ooze was at its thickest by a door at the far end of the room. Devi was not tempted to look behind it, and even if her more adventurous crew members wanted to, it was nailed shut with large pieces of wood. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, trying not to look too disgusted as she peered thoughtfully at the sogging decay. Devi flipped through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. However, Mark chose to bring the rock star crowd that welcomed him back to the mansion, finding less independence than his family might have hoped. Mark was a songwriter, and his guitar is still preserved in his bedroom, in the corner it rarely left once the Bennington son found more excitement in the lifestyle of musicians than in his own music. He often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, spreading rumors in the press that most reporters believed were greatly exaggerated, though their suspicions never stopped them from printing Mark’s tall tales of human sacrifice and portals to Hell. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, demanding that he make his own way in the world, but his more sympathetic family members always welcomed this prodigal son’s frequent returns. Police reported that one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other, though whether they fought in Bradford’s bedroom or the kitchen was uncertain. This uncertainty would prove a boon to the elder Bradford, casting doubt on his daughters’ memories and therefore doubt on his possible involvement in his son’s disappearance. Bradford was screaming at Mark to leave their house for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. Immediate landscaping on the Bennington garden led to speculation that Bradford had killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive.” “Devi, I can’t take anymore,” said Nellie gagging. “Wait, does anyone see that guitar?” West asked. The crew members looked at the misshapen piles of sludge around the room. Devi supposed any of those piles could have been a guitar at one point. Nellie shrugged at West and they followed her hurried retreat from the room. Devi’s mother did tell her that Mark once screamed at Tara for touching his guitar. She wondered what he would have thought about the state of his beloved instrument now. [[Dawn's Room - Devi's Tour (from Tara's/Mark's Room Cont. from USR)]] [[Tara's Room - Devi's Tour (from Dawn's/Mark's Room Cont. from USR)]] Devi had heard stories from her mother about Dawn’s temper. Usually Dawn would play it cool during the parties that Devi’s mother attended, but every so often something would happen to set her off. The something was usually Mark. And once Dawn was screaming, she was throwing things, and breaking chairs, and shattering glasses. So, though the room could have been wrecked recently by vandals, Devi suspected that the gouged walls, scratched bedposts, and crushed sparkling jewels on the ground were the remains of Dawn’s final tantrum. “Do you think someone stole the sheets?” West asked. “Oh, you don’t know the legend about Dawn!” Devi gasped. “We have established that, no, I don’t know the legend,” West said before mumbling. “Don’t think I want to, but I’m sure I’ll learn it soon enough.” Devi flipped through the guidebook as West casually filmed Nellie who was piecing through the jewellery on the floor, not with the intent to steal it. Devi didn’t know what her intent was. But the meticulous way she seemed to be searching through the jewellery was unsettling. She read quickly. “Dawn was Bradford’s oldest daughter. She grew up in Mississippi with her mother, one of Bradford’s lovers. It was this lover who had encouraged him to build the Bennington Mansion for the whole family. The press described Dawn as a Southern Belle, or a Peach Flower forced to live as a Cactus. She was sweet to her friends and family but downright prickly to anyone who came courting. However, rumor has it that she did fall in love, and not with one of those rich Hollywood types that were always shmoozing with Bradford on the estate or cozying up to her brother with their wild lives. She met a folksinger named Emma who snuck into one of their parties because she heard that Janis Ian was there. Emma didn’t meet Janis, but she did meet Dawn. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react to this poor prospect, an unknown outsider with no ties to the family through wealth, celebrity, or even occult interests. When Mark discovered their romance, he told her father, and Bradford forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again. Some say he arranged for Emma to be murdered or sacrificed her to a dark spirit in order to ensure the continued wealth of the family. Whatever her fate, she disappeared in the summer of 1978. Mere weeks later, her sister Tara would tell the police that she thought she heard Dawn come into her room in the middle of the night and felt her gently kiss her on the forehead before she took the sheets from her bed, went to the Upper Séance room, and hanged herself.” “Nel, did you need a sec? Or a tissue?” West asked, surprisingly genuine. “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty.” Devi’s mother told her that she had never seen a person in real life or on film who was as beautiful as Dawn Bennington. She also said that the papers had it wrong. They thought that Emma’s death caused Dawn’s depression. But Dawn had always carried that sadness in her, along with her rage and her joy, every emotion at full throttle all the time. It was Emma who cooled her woes and her temper, her rages and her joys. Without Emma to carry her, what else could Dawn do but fall? Before they moved on, Nellie picked up the jewellery and set it on the remains of a vanity, a neat line of broken memories in front of a mirror with only a few smashed pieces left in its frame. Nellie paused. There was something sticking out of the vanity’s top drawer. She tugged it free, reading the faded lines. “Hey, guys, I think I found a poem.” “Give a dead woman some privacy, Nellie,” said West. “We should go on.” [[Dawn's Poem - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Library - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] Devi’s mother didn’t have many stories about Mark from those days when she would party at the Bennington Mansion, and she definitely hadn’t gone into Mark’s bedroom, but even if she did not have first-person witness testimony, Devi doubted it had looked like this in its heyday. The purple paisley wallpaper wet and peeling, oozing a brown sludge seemed to have seeped into everything it touched. The walls, the bed, the carpet, and the few personal items left in the room had all gone soft, like a half-chewed meal spat out by a cranky child. The ooze was at its thickest by a door at the far end of the room. Devi was not tempted to look behind it, and even if her more adventurous crew members wanted to, it was nailed shut with large pieces of wood. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said, trying not to look too disgusted as she peered thoughtfully at the sogging decay. Devi flipped through the guidebook until she found the page for Mark. “Mark was the second son and biggest disappointment of Bradford’s three children. He had little interest in his father’s occult activities and Bradford’s lovers encouraged him to find a life outside of their strange home. However, Mark chose to bring the rock star crowd that welcomed him back to the mansion, finding less independence than his family might have hoped. Mark was a songwriter, and his guitar is still preserved in his bedroom, in the corner it rarely left once the Bennington son found more excitement in the lifestyle of musicians than in his own music. He often mocked his father for his beliefs in spirits and demonic forces, spreading rumors in the press that most reporters believed were greatly exaggerated, though their suspicions never stopped them from printing Mark’s tall tales of human sacrifice and portals to Hell. Several times Bradford tried to cut him off, demanding that he make his own way in the world, but his more sympathetic family members always welcomed this prodigal son’s frequent returns. Police reported that one night his sisters both heard their father and brother yelling at each other, though whether they fought in Bradford’s bedroom or the kitchen was uncertain. This uncertainty would prove a boon to the elder Bradford, casting doubt on his daughters’ memories and therefore doubt on his possible involvement in his son’s disappearance. Bradford was screaming at Mark to leave their house for good, and the next morning Mark was gone. But not left, vanished. Immediate landscaping on the Bennington garden led to speculation that Bradford had killed him and buried him on the property. Some investigators claim they can hear sounds like muffled screams when they walk through the garden, pounding like it’s coming from beneath their feet. It’s been suggested he was buried alive.” “Devi, I can’t take anymore,” said Nellie gagging. “Wait, does anyone see that guitar?” West asked. The crew members looked at the misshapen piles of sludge around the room. Devi supposed any of those piles could have been a guitar at one point. Devi’s mother did tell her that Mark once screamed at Tara for touching his guitar. She wondered what he would have thought about the state of his beloved instrument now. West frowned as he stared at piece of the bedframe that had not completely rotted. “There’s some kind of message scratched on here,” West said, leaning down to read it more closely. “West, do not touch the rotten wood,” Devi chided. “Let’s go.” [[Mark's Message - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Library - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] “Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow. Edward. That was what Tara named him. She still slept with him well into her teen years. When Devi’s mother snuck into the Bennington parties, she always hoped Tara would find her, take her exploring through those mysterious hallways that only she could navigate, toting Edward along with her. Her mother made it sound like Tara conjured the halls out of thin air, but Devi assumed there were enough substances filling the air on those cool desert nights to make any trip on a back stairway seem like a miraculous journey to the stars. She was not sure what to make of her mother’s other stories, the ones where she and Tara hid behind cracked doors and watched as the Benningtons spoke to… something. Someone terrible, a man her mother never fully described. She never said what he did to Bradford, to his lovers, to Mark. She just said Dawn made sure to stay away from him, and Tara could never resist sneaking closer and closer until the day she was fully brought into the fold, leaving her mother on the other side of a firmly shut door. Her mother said the terrible creature was not a man. Not a ghost. Not a demon. Something else. Devi had been chasing him for years, a face to put to her mother’s memory. She did not know why she couldn’t dismiss the man in the same way she dismissed the magical hallways. “You should get in the bed,” West whispered to Nellie. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” “Sorry, Devi,” said Nellie. Devi flipped to Tara’s page in the guidebook. “This room belonged to Tara, Bradford’s youngest child. She moved into the house when she was thirteen, and though her mother tried to keep them separate, Bradford immediately inducted her into the world of dark arts. They would spend hours, sometimes days in his secret study, communing with dark forces. She was known to have fits of demonic possession during public get togethers, though her siblings insisted she performed these tricks because she was incredibly shy and it was an easy way to get back to her room or the library or to hide with her mother who also hated social events. After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, taking care of her father well into his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died…” Devi paused. The rest of the entry implied that Tara had killed him for her own dark purposes, to take revenge or gain power. It was a good story for a ghostly investigation. But she felt Edward’s button eyes on her, the same ones that watched her mother as the girls ran through magical hallways. She closed the book, smiling at West and Nellie like there was nothing else on the page. West and Nellie shared a shrug and turned to leave. “Wait,” said Devi, crouching to look at a little box on the ground, no bigger than a box for a ring, with nine sliding tiles on the top. “There’s some kind of puzzle here.” “No, I see numbers, that counts as math,” Nellie protested. “We’re going to the next room.” [[Tara's Puzzle - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Library - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] Devi walked through an ornate archway into a library that was exactly how her mother had described it to her. A part of her had always expected that memory, fear of trespassing where she did not belong when she tagged along after Tara into the more private quarters of the mansion, had colored her mother’s descriptions with darkness and dread. But the Bennington Mansion library was as cold and unwelcoming as her stories had always made it seem, made worse by the ravages of time and rot. “Is that sludge or a choice?” West asked at Devi’s shoulder. She followed his camera up. The ceiling came to a point, painted all the same black or dark brown, and while it did look wet, fresh, it wasn’t dripping. It was the same style as the entry room ceiling, designed by Bradford, but if he wanted the entry hall to welcome people in with light, the smoky glass above them screamed at these visitors to leave or be swallowed by darkness. There weren’t any of the mansion’s signature porthole windows in this room, the only light dimly edging in from the hallway. Devi pulled a flashlight from her bag, frustrated that she had to use it so early in their exploration. “Probably could have used this earlier, but I wanted to save the battery,” said Devi, letting a beam of light disrupt the darkness. Her light panned across the uninviting room, illuminating bookshelves still filled with books that would have been priceless if they weren’t so decrepit. The black leather sofas filled the room with a musky smell like animals that had come in from the damp. They sat low to the ground, like fungal growths, creating a kind of fairy path across the sprawling room. Devi could imagine walking through them and disappearing forever. Maybe this was the room where her mother had disappeared. “The floor is lava,” Nellie whispered. Devi had not heard what inspired this statement, but West chuckled politely, and Devi offered a meek smile to pretend she had been paying attention. There was a blinding moment as the light caught on a large globe with a golden-hued frame and what looked like hand-painted countries, but Devi noticed with unease that they were not countries from any earth she recognized. It tilted at an odd, unearthly angle, and its elegance contrasted with the sensation of wrongness that it emanated. Devi’s eyes were transfixed for a moment, and she was not sure if she wanted to read the neat inky print naming each of those unfamiliar shapes cascading across the smooth surface or if she wanted give it a strong kick to send it smashing to the floor. Devi stopped the light at the far end of the room, where a similar archway led further into the mansion, bringing them closer to their final destination. Next to it, a solid black winding staircase, its artificial smoothness making the sogging shelves behind it look even more forlorn, led to an upper floor. “Well,” said Nellie. “There’s a lot going on here. I feel like libraries are made to be haunted. Keep that camera on me, West.” West did as he was told, but waited for Devi to take the lead. [[Upper Floor Observatory - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Globe - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Bookshelves - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]“You okay, Devi?” West asked. While West and Nellie had already wandered well into the room. West had paused his filming of the glass ceiling that must have continued above the house from the entry room while Nellie was playing with a telescope in the corner. But Devi could hear her mother’s voice in her head: “Guests were never allowed in observatory. It belonged to Bradford’s lovers. And they could not tolerate Bradford’s occult guests.” Devi guessed that a crew of ghost hunters counted as occult guests of the house. She reminded herself that Tara would invade the privacy of the observatory all the time, even if she could never convince Devi’s mother to play along with her. Even years later, the little boxy black beds with their little boxy black side tables seemed so neat and perfect they defied anyone to mess with their perfect parallel angles. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. Devi shook off her unease and stepped inside, giving the beds and wide berth, accidentally bumping into Nellie who seemed equally distracted. “What does the guidebook say?” West prompted. Devi opened the book but the words seemed to swim. They didn’t want to be read. She wasn’t supposed to be here. It was dangerous in the observatory. That was what her mother had said. That was why Bradford’s lovers told her to stay away. “You guys are… giving off bad vibes that I should definitely be filming,” said West. [[Telescope - Devi's Tour]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour]] As West followed Nellie’s movements, Devi found herself forced closer to the decorative globe. She tried to pay attention to Nellie’s improvisation, tried to listen for any suspicious sounds picket up by the mics, but the globe kept drawing her attention. It was not even an approximation of real continents and oceans. It was beautiful though. The black ink shimmered under the glow of her flashlight and she reached out to press her hand against the smooth wood. The slight pressure was met with a loud cracking sound as the globe split across its equator. “Devi broke the globe!” Nellie laughed. “No, she didn’t,” said West. For a moment, Devi thought that West was just trying to make her feel better, but then she saw he was right. She had not broken the globe. It was meant to be opened, and disuse had just left the hinges loud and rusty. She opened the top of the globe further, revealing a collection of glass bottles inside half-filled with suspicious brown liquid. “Scotch?” West asked. “Devi, you should try it,” Nellie grinned. Devi was about to protest but was interrupted by West. “Don’t tease her, Nellie,” he said. “Devi’s not as brave as us.” Devi felt her cheeks burn. Before she could think about it enough to decide it was a terrible idea, Devi pulled out the crystal topper on one of the bottles and took three deep swigs of the mystery liquid inside. Which was, as West had suggested, scotch. The first two swigs tasted pretty good too, as smooth as any bourbon Devi had tried. She did not drink often, at all, but even she could tell this was high quality stuff. Still, the last swig left her coughing at a belated burn. “Chug, chug, chug!” West chanted. “I said try it, Devi, not drink the whole thing,” Nellie laughed. The alcohol pooled warm in Devi’s stomach, and she smiled sheepishly under Nellie and West’s approval. She could already feel the hint of dizziness that warned she would be quite tipsy once the alcohol kicked into her system, but she decided that was a problem for future Devi. It was refreshing to be a little rebellious. [[Bookshelves - Devi's Tour (from Globe)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Devi's Tour (from Globe)]] “Nellie, we should get some footage of you by the bookshelves,” Devi said. “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West agreed. Nellie stepped over to the books, frowned as she examined the spines, and then her jaw dropped. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” West gave Devi a look that seemed to say, “you’re in charge, get our star to stop reading.” Devi sighed and walked up to Nellie, gently plucking the book from her hands, ignoring Nellie’s pout. But when Devi tried to put the book back into place, it no longer seemed to fit. She shined her flashlight at the space they had made and saw something tucked into the shelf, glinting in the light. Devi reached in and pulled out a locket. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and Devi hopped deftly away. “Absolutely not,” said Devi. “We’re putting it back. It probably belonged to one of the Benningtons and costs more than West’s camera.” “It’s costume jewellery,” Nellie insisted, though her eyes looked hungry for the fake gold. “Then… it probably was left by another ghost crew, or tourists, who might be looking for it,” Devi said, slipping the locket into her briefcase. “I’ll let the owner know that we found it tomorrow. It might have sentimental value.” Nellie glared at Devi, but then she shrugged, wandering over to the sofas. “You should be filming me, West!” she shouted. “You should put that in the hotel safe when we get back,” West whispered. “She’s totally going to try to steal it.” Devi bit back her instinct to defend Nellie because West was most likely correct. [[Globe - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (from Telescope)]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Telescope)]] West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “And microplastics,” Devi added. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Observatory Bed)]] [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (from Observatory Bed)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “And microplastics,” Devi added. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Telescope)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] Devi tried to act like she was completely fine, like this wasn’t the room of the man who built the house her mother just couldn’t resist returning to. Even after Tara abandoned her to the occult secrets that consumed her father, even after she snuck into the last party that almost killed her in the mysterious Bennington explosion, even after she had years of nightmares about the monster she had glimpsed… She had to come back one more time. One last time. Leaving her only daughter behind to mourn for her, to wonder how she had met her end in the Bennington Mansion. No, there was never a body found on the grounds. But the police never found Mark’s body, either. Devi’s eyes darted from the abandoned hospital bed, to the fraying pictures on the walls, to the intricately carved wardrobe at the far end of the room. One object boring and normal, some appropriately spooky, and one almost absurdly sinister. “Any guidebook info?” Mark asked. “No,” Devi said. “Bradford was still living here during the heyday of the tours and this room was always private.” “Is that normal?” West asked. “To have tours in a place where someone is actively living?” “I think there are some castle tours in Scotland like that,” said Devi. “Haunted ones?” West asked, perking up. “We should do a trip. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said, nodding at the door on the far side of the room. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” She was surprised at how well she was able to keep her voice from trembling. “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Nellie wandered over to the pictures, touching them, messing with the frayed pieces and Devi wondered if it was worth the wasted energy to tell her to stop. “Does anyone see a knife?” asked Nellie. West and Devi shook their heads. West was filming a engraved wardrobe in the corner. Devi sat on the edge of the hospital bed. “That would have been too exciting, I guess,” Nellie sighed, letting the pieces of the picture fall back into disarray. “Does anyone see anything interesting?” [[Hospital Bed - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Observatory Bed)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] “Nellie, we should get some footage of you by the bookshelves,” Devi said. “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West agreed. Nellie stepped over to the books, frowned as she examined the spines, and then her jaw dropped. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” West gave Devi a look that seemed to say, “you’re in charge, get our star to stop reading.” Devi sighed and walked up to Nellie, gently plucking the book from her hands, ignoring Nellie’s pout. But when Devi tried to put the book back into place, it no longer seemed to fit. She shined her flashlight at the space they had made and saw something tucked into the shelf, glinting in the light. Devi reached in and pulled out a locket. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and Devi hopped deftly away. “Absolutely not,” said Devi. “We’re putting it back. It probably belonged to one of the Benningtons and costs more than West’s camera.” “It’s costume jewellery,” Nellie insisted, though her eyes looked hungry for the fake gold. “Then… it probably was left by another ghost crew, or tourists, who might be looking for it,” Devi said, slipping the locket into her briefcase. “I’ll let the owner know that we found it tomorrow. It might have sentimental value.” Nellie glared at Devi, but then she shrugged, wandering over to the sofas. “You should be filming me, West!” she shouted. “You should put that in the hotel safe when we get back,” West whispered. “She’s totally going to try to steal it.” Devi bit back her instinct to defend Nellie because West was most likely correct. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Devi's Tour (from Globe with Locket)]] “You okay, Devi?” West asked. While West and Nellie had already wandered well into the room. West had paused his filming of the glass ceiling that must have continued above the house from the entry room while Nellie was playing with a telescope in the corner. But Devi could hear her mother’s voice in her head: “Guests were never allowed in observatory. It belonged to Bradford’s lovers. And they could not tolerate Bradford’s occult guests.” Devi guessed that a crew of ghost hunters counted as occult guests of the house. She reminded herself that Tara would invade the privacy of the observatory all the time, even if she could never convince Devi’s mother to play along with her. Even years later, the little boxy black beds with their little boxy black side tables seemed so neat and perfect they defied anyone to mess with their perfect parallel angles. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. “We probably have enough time to check out a couple things in here.” Devi shook off her unease and stepped inside, giving the beds and wide berth, accidentally bumping into Nellie who seemed equally distracted. “What does the guidebook say?” West prompted. Devi opened the book but the words seemed to swim. She didn’t think she had drunk that much. It couldn’t have been the Scotch. It had to have been the book. The words. They didn’t want to be read. She wasn’t supposed to be here. It was dangerous in the observatory. That was what her mother had said. That was why Bradford’s lovers told her to stay away. “You guys are… giving off bad vibes that I should definitely be filming,” said West. [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (from Globe)]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (from Globe)]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Globe)]]Devi tried to act like she was completely fine, like this wasn’t the room of the man who built the house her mother just couldn’t resist returning to. Even after Tara abandoned her to the occult secrets that consumed her father, even after she snuck into the last party that almost killed her in the mysterious Bennington explosion, even after she had years of nightmares about the monster she had glimpsed… She had to come back one more time. One last time. Leaving her only daughter behind to mourn for her, to wonder how she had met her end in the Bennington Mansion. No, there was never a body found on the grounds. But the police never found Mark’s body, either. Devi’s eyes darted from the abandoned hospital bed, to the fraying pictures on the walls, to the intricately carved wardrobe at the far end of the room.
