Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said, nodding at the door on the far side of the room. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” She was surprised at how well she was able to keep her voice from trembling. “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Nellie wandered over to the pictures, touching them, messing with the frayed pieces and Devi wondered if it was worth the wasted energy to tell her to stop. “Does anyone see a knife?” asked Nellie. West and Devi shook their heads. West was filming a engraved wardrobe in the corner. Devi sat on the edge of the hospital bed. “That would have been too exciting, I guess,” Nellie sighed, letting the pieces of the picture fall back into disarray. “Does anyone see anything interesting?” [[Hospital Bed - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]]“You okay, Devi?” West asked. While West and Nellie had already wandered well into the room. West had paused his filming of the glass ceiling that must have continued above the house from the entry room while Nellie was playing with a telescope in the corner. But Devi could hear her mother’s voice in her head: “Guests were never allowed in observatory. It belonged to Bradford’s lovers. And they could not tolerate Bradford’s occult guests.” Devi guessed that a crew of ghost hunters counted as occult guests of the house. She reminded herself that Tara would invade the privacy of the observatory all the time, even if she could never convince Devi’s mother to play along with her. Even years later, the little boxy black beds with their little boxy black side tables seemed so neat and perfect they defied anyone to mess with their perfect parallel angles. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. “We probably have enough time to check out one of the things in here.” Devi shook off her unease and stepped inside, giving the beds and wide berth, accidentally bumping into Nellie who seemed equally distracted. “What does the guidebook say?” West prompted. Devi opened the book but the words seemed to swim. She didn’t think she had drunk that much. It couldn’t have been the Scotch. It had to have been the book. The words. They didn’t want to be read. She wasn’t supposed to be here. It was dangerous in the observatory. That was what her mother had said. That was why Bradford’s lovers told her to stay away. “You guys are… giving off bad vibes that I should definitely be filming,” said West. [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (from Globe with Locket)]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (from Globe with Locket)]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Globe with Locket)]] Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” “Did our little drunk-y forget to take off the lens cap?” West laughed. “Don’t patronize me,” Devi said, throwing West a mock glare. She made sure he didn’t see her slight of hand as she checked that there wasn’t a lens cap on the telescope, relieved when she felt solid glass. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “And microplastics,” Devi added. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but her head was getting fuzzy from the alcohol, so she just nodded and slipped the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] Devi tried to act like she was completely fine, like this wasn’t the room of the man who built the house her mother just couldn’t resist returning to. Even after Tara abandoned her to the occult secrets that consumed her father, even after she snuck into the last party that almost killed her in the mysterious Bennington explosion, even after she had years of nightmares about the monster she had glimpsed… She had to come back one more time. One last time. Leaving her only daughter behind to mourn for her, to wonder how she had met her end in the Bennington Mansion. No, there was never a body found on the grounds. But the police never found Mark’s body, either. Devi felt nauseous. The Scotch had settled like a hot lump of iron in her stomach. She knew she was a lightweight, but she had never gotten this sick this quickly after drinking. It was stronger stuff than she was used to, and she had quite a bit. She set a hand against the doorframe for balance, wondering if her crew members noticed, if they suspected that for their sound engineer the sparsely decorated room was spinning. Devi’s eyes darted from the abandoned hospital bed, to the fraying pictures on the walls, to the intricately carved wardrobe at the far end of the room. One object boring and normal, some appropriately spooky, and one almost absurdly sinister. “Any guidebook info?” Mark asked. “No,” Devi said. “Bradford was still living here during the heyday of the tours and this room was always private.” She was glad she did not need to try to read. If the room was spinning, she couldn’t imagine what letters would look like. “Is that normal?” West asked. “To have tours in a place where someone is actively living?” “I think there are some castle tours in Scotland like that,” said Devi. “Haunted ones?” West asked, perking up. “We should do a trip. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said, nodding at the door on the far side of the room. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” She was surprised at how well she was able to keep her voice from trembling. “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Nellie wandered over to the pictures, touching them, messing with the frayed pieces and Devi wondered if it was worth the wasted energy to tell her to stop. “Does anyone see a knife?” asked Nellie. West and Devi shook their heads. West was filming a engraved wardrobe in the corner. Devi sat on the edge of the hospital bed, hoping the room might go still if she got off her feet, but the change did little to settle her roiling stomach. “That would have been too exciting, I guess,” Nellie sighed, letting the pieces of the picture fall back into disarray. “Does anyone see anything interesting?” [[Hospital Bed - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” “Did our little drunk-y forget to take off the lens cap?” West laughed. “Don’t patronize me,” Devi said, throwing West a mock glare. She made sure he didn’t see her slight of hand as she checked that there wasn’t a lens cap on the telescope, relieved when she felt solid glass. [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Globe and Telescope)]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (from Globe and Telescope)]]West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “And microplastics,” Devi added. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Observatory Bed and Globe)]] [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (from Observatory Bed and Globe)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but her head was getting fuzzy from the alcohol, so she just nodded and slipped the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]]Devi tried to act like she was completely fine, like this wasn’t the room of the man who built the house her mother just couldn’t resist returning to. Even after Tara abandoned her to the occult secrets that consumed her father, even after she snuck into the last party that almost killed her in the mysterious Bennington explosion, even after she had years of nightmares about the monster she had glimpsed… She had to come back one more time. One last time. Leaving her only daughter behind to mourn for her, to wonder how she had met her end in the Bennington Mansion. No, there was never a body found on the grounds. But the police never found Mark’s body, either. Devi felt nauseous. The Scotch had settled like a hot lump of iron in her stomach. She knew she was a lightweight, but she had never gotten this sick this quickly after drinking. It was stronger stuff than she was used to, and she had quite a bit. She set a hand against the doorframe for balance, wondering if her crew members noticed, if they suspected that for their sound engineer the sparsely decorated room was spinning. Devi’s eyes darted from the abandoned hospital bed, to the fraying pictures on the walls, to the intricately carved wardrobe at the far end of the room. One object boring and normal, some appropriately spooky, and one almost absurdly sinister. “Any guidebook info?” Mark asked. “No,” Devi said. “Bradford was still living here during the heyday of the tours and this room was always private.” She was glad she did not need to try to read. If the room was spinning, she couldn’t imagine what letters would look like. “Is that normal?” West asked. “To have tours in a place where someone is actively living?” “I think there are some castle tours in Scotland like that,” said Devi. “Haunted ones?” West asked, perking up. “We should do a trip. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said, nodding at the door on the far side of the room. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” She was surprised at how well she was able to keep her voice from trembling. “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Nellie wandered over to the pictures, touching them, messing with the frayed pieces and Devi wondered if it was worth the wasted energy to tell her to stop. “Does anyone see a knife?” asked Nellie. West and Devi shook their heads. West was filming a engraved wardrobe in the corner. Devi sat on the edge of the hospital bed, hoping the room might go still if she got off her feet, but the change did little to settle her roiling stomach. “That would have been too exciting, I guess,” Nellie sighed, letting the pieces of the picture fall back into disarray. “Does anyone see anything interesting?” [[Hospital Bed - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]] [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but her head was getting fuzzy from the alcohol, so she just nodded and slipped the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]]West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “And microplastics,” Devi added. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s go back downstairs." [[Bookshelves - Devi's Tour (from Globe and Upper Observatory)]]“Nellie, we should get some footage of you by the bookshelves,” Devi said. “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West agreed. Nellie stepped over to the books, frowned as she examined the spines, and then her jaw dropped. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” West gave Devi a look that seemed to say, “you’re in charge, get our star to stop reading.” Devi sighed and walked up to Nellie, gently plucking the book from her hands, ignoring Nellie’s pout. But when Devi tried to put the book back into place, it no longer seemed to fit. She shined her flashlight at the space they had made and saw something tucked into the shelf, glinting in the light. Devi reached in and pulled out a locket. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and Devi hopped deftly away. “Absolutely not,” said Devi. “We’re putting it back. It probably belonged to one of the Benningtons and costs more than West’s camera.” “It’s costume jewellery,” Nellie insisted, though her eyes looked hungry for the fake gold. “Then… it probably was left by another ghost crew, or tourists, who might be looking for it,” Devi said, slipping the locket into her briefcase. “I’ll let the owner know that we found it tomorrow. It might have sentimental value.” Nellie glared at Devi, but then she shrugged, wandering over to the sofas. “You should be filming me, West!” she shouted. “You should put that in the hotel safe when we get back,” West whispered. “She’s totally going to try to steal it.” Devi bit back her instinct to defend Nellie because West was most likely correct. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but her head was getting fuzzy from the alcohol, so she just nodded and slipped the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]] Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” “Did our little drunk-y forget to take off the lens cap?” West laughed. “Don’t patronize me,” Devi said, throwing West a mock glare. "Let's get back to the library." She made sure he didn’t see her slight of hand as she checked that there wasn’t a lens cap on the telescope, relieved when she felt solid glass. [[Bookshelves - Devi's Tour (from Globe and Upper Observatory)]] As West followed Nellie’s movements, Devi found herself forced closer to the decorative globe. She tried to pay attention to Nellie’s improvisation, tried to listen for any suspicious sounds picket up by the mics, but the globe kept drawing her attention. It was not even an approximation of real continents and oceans. It was beautiful though. The black ink shimmered under the glow of her flashlight and she reached out to press her hand against the smooth wood. The slight pressure was met with a loud cracking sound as the globe split across its equator. “Devi broke the globe!” Nellie laughed. “No, she didn’t,” said West. For a moment, Devi thought that West was just trying to make her feel better, but then she saw he was right. She had not broken the globe. It was meant to be opened, and disuse had just left the hinges loud and rusty. She opened the top of the globe further, revealing a collection of glass bottles inside half-filled with suspicious brown liquid. “Scotch?” West asked. “Devi, you should try it,” Nellie grinned. Devi was about to protest but was interrupted by West. “Don’t tease her, Nellie,” he said. “Devi’s not as brave as us.” Devi felt her cheeks burn. Before she could think about it enough to decide it was a terrible idea, Devi pulled out the crystal topper on one of the bottles and took three deep swigs of the mystery liquid inside. Which was, as West had suggested, scotch. The first two swigs tasted pretty good too, as smooth as any bourbon Devi had tried. She did not drink often, at all, but even she could tell this was high quality stuff. Still, the last swig left her coughing at a belated burn. “Chug, chug, chug!” West chanted. “I said try it, Devi, not drink the whole thing,” Nellie laughed. The alcohol pooled warm in Devi’s stomach, and she smiled sheepishly under Nellie and West’s approval. She could already feel the hint of dizziness that warned she would be quite tipsy once the alcohol kicked into her system, but she decided that was a problem for future Devi. It was refreshing to be a little rebellious. [[Upper Floor Observatory - Devi's Tour (from Globe with Locket)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]“You okay, Devi?” West asked. While West and Nellie had already wandered well into the room. West had paused his filming of the glass ceiling that must have continued above the house from the entry room while Nellie was playing with a telescope in the corner. But Devi could hear her mother’s voice in her head: “Guests were never allowed in observatory. It belonged to Bradford’s lovers. And they could not tolerate Bradford’s occult guests.” Devi guessed that a crew of ghost hunters counted as occult guests of the house. She reminded herself that Tara would invade the privacy of the observatory all the time, even if she could never convince Devi’s mother to play along with her. Even years later, the little boxy black beds with their little boxy black side tables seemed so neat and perfect they defied anyone to mess with their perfect parallel angles. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. “We probably have enough time to check out a couple things in here.” Devi shook off her unease and stepped inside, giving the beds and wide berth, accidentally bumping into Nellie who seemed equally distracted. “What does the guidebook say?” West prompted. Devi opened the book but the words seemed to swim. They didn’t want to be read. She wasn’t supposed to be here. It was dangerous in the observatory. That was what her mother had said. That was why Bradford’s lovers told her to stay away. “You guys are… giving off bad vibes that I should definitely be filming,” said West. [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Telescope with Locket)]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (from Telescope with Locket)]]West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “And microplastics,” Devi added. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Observatory Bed with Locket)]] [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (from Observatory Bed with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “And microplastics,” Devi added. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Globe - Devi's Tour (from Upper Observatory with Locket)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]]As West followed Nellie’s movements, Devi found herself forced closer to the decorative globe. She tried to pay attention to Nellie’s improvisation, tried to listen for any suspicious sounds picket up by the mics, but the globe kept drawing her attention. It was not even an approximation of real continents and oceans. It was beautiful though. The black ink shimmered under the glow of her flashlight and she reached out to press her hand against the smooth wood. The slight pressure was met with a loud cracking sound as the globe split across its equator. “Devi broke the globe!” Nellie laughed. “No, she didn’t,” said West. For a moment, Devi thought that West was just trying to make her feel better, but then she saw he was right. She had not broken the globe. It was meant to be opened, and disuse had just left the hinges loud and rusty. She opened the top of the globe further, revealing a collection of glass bottles inside half-filled with suspicious brown liquid. “Scotch?” West asked. “Devi, you should try it,” Nellie grinned. Devi was about to protest but was interrupted by West. “Don’t tease her, Nellie,” he said. “Devi’s not as brave as us.” Devi felt her cheeks burn. Before she could think about it enough to decide it was a terrible idea, Devi pulled out the crystal topper on one of the bottles and took three deep swigs of the mystery liquid inside. Which was, as West had suggested, scotch. The first two swigs tasted pretty good too, as smooth as any bourbon Devi had tried. She did not drink often, at all, but even she could tell this was high quality stuff. Still, the last swig left her coughing at a belated burn. “Chug, chug, chug!” West chanted. “I said try it, Devi, not drink the whole thing,” Nellie laughed. The alcohol pooled warm in Devi’s stomach, and she smiled sheepishly under Nellie and West’s approval. She could already feel the hint of dizziness that warned she would be quite tipsy once the alcohol kicked into her system, but she decided that was a problem for future Devi. It was refreshing to be a little rebellious. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” [[Globe - Devi's Tour (from Upper Observatory with Locket)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]]“You okay, Devi?” West asked. While West and Nellie had already wandered well into the room. West had paused his filming of the glass ceiling that must have continued above the house from the entry room while Nellie was playing with a telescope in the corner. But Devi could hear her mother’s voice in her head: “Guests were never allowed in observatory. It belonged to Bradford’s lovers. And they could not tolerate Bradford’s occult guests.” Devi guessed that a crew of ghost hunters counted as occult guests of the house. She reminded herself that Tara would invade the privacy of the observatory all the time, even if she could never convince Devi’s mother to play along with her. Even years later, the little boxy black beds with their little boxy black side tables seemed so neat and perfect they defied anyone to mess with their perfect parallel angles. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. Devi shook off her unease and stepped inside, giving the beds and wide berth, accidentally bumping into Nellie who seemed equally distracted. “What does the guidebook say?” West prompted. Devi opened the book but the words seemed to swim. They didn’t want to be read. She wasn’t supposed to be here. It was dangerous in the observatory. That was what her mother had said. That was why Bradford’s lovers told her to stay away. “You guys are… giving off bad vibes that I should definitely be filming,” said West. [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] As West followed Nellie’s movements, Devi found herself forced closer to the decorative globe. She tried to pay attention to Nellie’s improvisation, tried to listen for any suspicious sounds picket up by the mics, but the globe kept drawing her attention. It was not even an approximation of real continents and oceans. It was beautiful though. The black ink shimmered under the glow of her flashlight and she reached out to press her hand against the smooth wood. The slight pressure was met with a loud cracking sound as the globe split across its equator. “Devi broke the globe!” Nellie laughed. “No, she didn’t,” said West. For a moment, Devi thought that West was just trying to make her feel better, but then she saw he was right. She had not broken the globe. It was meant to be opened, and disuse had just left the hinges loud and rusty. She opened the top of the globe further, revealing a collection of glass bottles inside half-filled with suspicious brown liquid. “Scotch?” West asked. “Devi, you should try it,” Nellie grinned. Devi was about to protest but was interrupted by West. “Don’t tease her, Nellie,” he said. “Devi’s not as brave as us.” Devi felt her cheeks burn. Before she could think about it enough to decide it was a terrible idea, Devi pulled out the crystal topper on one of the bottles and took three deep swigs of the mystery liquid inside. Which was, as West had suggested, scotch. The first two swigs tasted pretty good too, as smooth as any bourbon Devi had tried. She did not drink often, at all, but even she could tell this was high quality stuff. Still, the last swig left her coughing at a belated burn. “Chug, chug, chug!” West chanted. “I said try it, Devi, not drink the whole thing,” Nellie laughed. The alcohol pooled warm in Devi’s stomach, and she smiled sheepishly under Nellie and West’s approval. She could already feel the hint of dizziness that warned she would be quite tipsy once the alcohol kicked into her system, but she decided that was a problem for future Devi. It was refreshing to be a little rebellious. [[Bookshelves - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe)]]“Nellie, we should get some footage of you by the bookshelves,” Devi said. “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West agreed. Nellie stepped over to the books, frowned as she examined the spines, and then her jaw dropped. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” West gave Devi a look that seemed to say, “you’re in charge, get our star to stop reading.” Devi sighed and walked up to Nellie, gently plucking the book from her hands, ignoring Nellie’s pout. But when Devi tried to put the book back into place, it no longer seemed to fit. She shined her flashlight at the space they had made and saw something tucked into the shelf, glinting in the light. Devi reached in and pulled out a locket. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and Devi hopped deftly away. “Absolutely not,” said Devi. “We’re putting it back. It probably belonged to one of the Benningtons and costs more than West’s camera.” “It’s costume jewellery,” Nellie insisted, though her eyes looked hungry for the fake gold. “Then… it probably was left by another ghost crew, or tourists, who might be looking for it,” Devi said, slipping the locket into her briefcase. “I’ll let the owner know that we found it tomorrow. It might have sentimental value.” Nellie glared at Devi, but then she shrugged, wandering over to the sofas. “You should be filming me, West!” she shouted. “You should put that in the hotel safe when we get back,” West whispered. “She’s totally going to try to steal it.” Devi bit back her instinct to defend Nellie because West was most likely correct. [[Globe - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR)]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR))]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (from Telescope Cont. from USR)]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Telescope Cont. from USR)]] West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. Devi thought of the footsteps she heard earlier and had an unsettling moment… No. That was ridiculous. This wasn’t an Oscar-winning South Korean film. There was no one hiding out of sight, eating hidden stashes of chocolate. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Observatory Bed Cont. from USR)]] [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (from Observatory Bed Cont. from USR)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] Devi tried to act like she was completely fine, like this wasn’t the room of the man who built the house her mother just couldn’t resist returning to. Even after Tara abandoned her to the occult secrets that consumed her father, even after she snuck into the last party that almost killed her in the mysterious Bennington explosion, even after she had years of nightmares about the monster she had glimpsed… She had to come back one more time. One last time. Leaving her only daughter behind to mourn for her, to wonder how she had met her end in the Bennington Mansion. No, there was never a body found on the grounds. But the police never found Mark’s body, either. Devi’s eyes darted from the abandoned hospital bed, to the fraying pictures on the walls, to the intricately carved wardrobe at the far end of the room. One object boring and normal, some appropriately spooky, and one almost absurdly sinister. “Any guidebook info?” Mark asked. “No,” Devi said. “Bradford was still living here during the heyday of the tours and this room was always private.” “Is that normal?” West asked. “To have tours in a place where someone is actively living?” “I think there are some castle tours in Scotland like that,” said Devi. “Haunted ones?” West asked, perking up. “We should do a trip. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said, nodding at the door on the far side of the room. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” She was surprised at how well she was able to keep her voice from trembling. “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Nellie wandered over to the pictures, touching them, messing with the frayed pieces and Devi wondered if it was worth the wasted energy to tell her to stop. “Does anyone see a knife?” asked Nellie. West and Devi shook their heads. West was filming a engraved wardrobe in the corner. Devi sat on the edge of the hospital bed. “That would have been too exciting, I guess,” Nellie sighed, letting the pieces of the picture fall back into disarray. “Does anyone see anything interesting?” [[Hospital Bed - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]]West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. Devi thought of the footsteps she heard earlier and had an unsettling moment… No. That was ridiculous. This wasn’t an Oscar-winning South Korean film. There was no one hiding out of sight, eating hidden stashes of chocolate. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Telescope Cont. from USR)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Telescope Cont. from USR)]]As West followed Nellie’s movements, Devi found herself forced closer to the decorative globe. The black ink shimmered under the glow of her flashlight and she reached out to press her hand against the smooth wood. The slight pressure was met with a loud cracking sound as the globe split across its equator. “Devi broke the globe!” Nellie laughed. “No, she didn’t,” said West. For a moment, Devi thought that West was just trying to make her feel better, but then she saw he was right. She had not broken the globe. It was meant to be opened, and disuse had just left the hinges loud and rusty. She opened the top of the globe further, revealing a collection of glass bottles inside half-filled with suspicious brown liquid. “Scotch?” West asked. “Devi, you should try it,” Nellie grinned. Devi was about to protest but was interrupted by West. “Don’t tease her, Nellie,” he said. “Devi’s not as brave as us.” Devi felt her cheeks burn. Which was, as West had suggested, scotch. The first two swigs tasted pretty good too, as smooth as any bourbon Devi had tried. She did not drink often, at all, but even she could tell this was high quality stuff. Still, the last swig left her coughing at a belated burn. “Chug, chug, chug!” West chanted. “I said try it, Devi, not drink the whole thing,” Nellie laughed. The alcohol pooled warm in Devi’s stomach, and she smiled sheepishly under Nellie and West’s approval.
