It was refreshing to be a little rebellious. [[Upper Floor Observatory - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe with Locket)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]“You okay, Devi?” West asked. While West and Nellie had already wandered well into the room. West had paused his filming of the glass ceiling that must have continued above the house from the entry room while Nellie was playing with a telescope in the corner. But Devi could hear her mother’s voice in her head: “Guests were never allowed in observatory. It belonged to Bradford’s lovers. And they could not tolerate Bradford’s occult guests.” Devi guessed that a crew of ghost hunters counted as occult guests of the house. She reminded herself that Tara would invade the privacy of the observatory all the time, even if she could never convince Devi’s mother to play along with her. Even years later, the little boxy black beds with their little boxy black side tables seemed so neat and perfect they defied anyone to mess with their perfect parallel angles. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. “We probably have enough time to check out a couple things in here.” Devi shook off her unease and stepped inside, giving the beds and wide berth, accidentally bumping into Nellie who seemed equally distracted. “What does the guidebook say?” West prompted. Devi opened the book but the words seemed to swim. They didn’t want to be read. She wasn’t supposed to be here. It was dangerous in the observatory. That was what her mother had said. That was why Bradford’s lovers told her to stay away. “You guys are… giving off bad vibes that I should definitely be filming,” said West. [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR)]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR)]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR)]]“You okay, Devi?” West asked. While West and Nellie had already wandered well into the room. West had paused his filming of the glass ceiling that must have continued above the house from the entry room while Nellie was playing with a telescope in the corner. But Devi could hear her mother’s voice in her head: “Guests were never allowed in observatory. It belonged to Bradford’s lovers. And they could not tolerate Bradford’s occult guests.” Devi guessed that a crew of ghost hunters counted as occult guests of the house. She reminded herself that Tara would invade the privacy of the observatory all the time, even if she could never convince Devi’s mother to play along with her. Even years later, the little boxy black beds with their little boxy black side tables seemed so neat and perfect they defied anyone to mess with their perfect parallel angles. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. “We probably have enough time to check out one of the things in here.” Devi shook off her unease and stepped inside, giving the beds and wide berth, accidentally bumping into Nellie who seemed equally distracted. “What does the guidebook say?” West prompted. Devi opened the book but the words seemed to swim. She didn’t think she had drunk that much. It couldn’t have been the Scotch. It had to have been the book. The words. They didn’t want to be read. She wasn’t supposed to be here. It was dangerous in the observatory. That was what her mother had said. That was why Bradford’s lovers told her to stay away. “You guys are… giving off bad vibes that I should definitely be filming,” said West. [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (from Globe with Locket Cont. from USR)]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (from Globe with Locket Cont. from USR)]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (from Globe with Locket Cont. from USR)]] Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” “Did our little drunk-y forget to take off the lens cap?” West laughed. “Don’t patronize me,” Devi said, throwing West a mock glare. She made sure he didn’t see her slight of hand as she checked that there wasn’t a lens cap on the telescope, relieved when she felt solid glass. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. Devi thought of the footsteps she heard earlier and had an unsettling moment… No. That was ridiculous. This wasn’t an Oscar-winning South Korean film. There was no one hiding out of sight, eating hidden stashes of chocolate. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but her head was getting fuzzy from the alcohol, so she just nodded and slipped the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]]Devi tried to act like she was completely fine, like this wasn’t the room of the man who built the house her mother just couldn’t resist returning to. Even after Tara abandoned her to the occult secrets that consumed her father, even after she snuck into the last party that almost killed her in the mysterious Bennington explosion, even after she had years of nightmares about the monster she had glimpsed… She had to come back one more time. One last time. Leaving her only daughter behind to mourn for her, to wonder how she had met her end in the Bennington Mansion. No, there was never a body found on the grounds. But the police never found Mark’s body, either. Devi felt nauseous. The Scotch had settled like a hot lump of iron in her stomach. She knew she was a lightweight, but she had never gotten this sick this quickly after drinking. It was stronger stuff than she was used to, and she had quite a bit. She set a hand against the doorframe for balance, wondering if her crew members noticed, if they suspected that for their sound engineer the sparsely decorated room was spinning. Devi’s eyes darted from the abandoned hospital bed, to the fraying pictures on the walls, to the intricately carved wardrobe at the far end of the room. One object boring and normal, some appropriately spooky, and one almost absurdly sinister. “Any guidebook info?” Mark asked. “No,” Devi said. “Bradford was still living here during the heyday of the tours and this room was always private.” She was glad she did not need to try to read. If the room was spinning, she couldn’t imagine what letters would look like. “Is that normal?” West asked. “To have tours in a place where someone is actively living?” “I think there are some castle tours in Scotland like that,” said Devi. “Haunted ones?” West asked, perking up. “We should do a trip. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said, nodding at the door on the far side of the room. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” She was surprised at how well she was able to keep her voice from trembling. “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Nellie wandered over to the pictures, touching them, messing with the frayed pieces and Devi wondered if it was worth the wasted energy to tell her to stop. “Does anyone see a knife?” asked Nellie. West and Devi shook their heads. West was filming a engraved wardrobe in the corner. Devi sat on the edge of the hospital bed, hoping the room might go still if she got off her feet, but the change did little to settle her roiling stomach. “That would have been too exciting, I guess,” Nellie sighed, letting the pieces of the picture fall back into disarray. “Does anyone see anything interesting?” [[Hospital Bed - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]] [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR and Telescope)]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR and Telescope)]]West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. Devi thought of the footsteps she heard earlier and had an unsettling moment… No. That was ridiculous. This wasn’t an Oscar-winning South Korean film. There was no one hiding out of sight, eating hidden stashes of chocolate. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR and Observatory Bed)]] [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR and Observatory Bed)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” [[Globe - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR and Upper Observatory)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR with Locket)]]As West followed Nellie’s movements, Devi found herself forced closer to the decorative globe. She tried to pay attention to Nellie’s improvisation, tried to listen for any suspicious sounds picket up by the mics, but the globe kept drawing her attention. It was not even an approximation of real continents and oceans. It was beautiful though. The black ink shimmered under the glow of her flashlight and she reached out to press her hand against the smooth wood. The slight pressure was met with a loud cracking sound as the globe split across its equator. “Devi broke the globe!” Nellie laughed. “No, she didn’t,” said West. For a moment, Devi thought that West was just trying to make her feel better, but then she saw he was right. She had not broken the globe. It was meant to be opened, and disuse had just left the hinges loud and rusty. She opened the top of the globe further, revealing a collection of glass bottles inside half-filled with suspicious brown liquid. “Scotch?” West asked. “Devi, you should try it,” Nellie grinned. Devi was about to protest but was interrupted by West. “Don’t tease her, Nellie,” he said. “Devi’s not as brave as us.” Devi felt her cheeks burn. Before she could think about it enough to decide it was a terrible idea, Devi pulled out the crystal topper on one of the bottles and took three deep swigs of the mystery liquid inside. Which was, as West had suggested, scotch. The first two swigs tasted pretty good too, as smooth as any bourbon Devi had tried. She did not drink often, at all, but even she could tell this was high quality stuff. Still, the last swig left her coughing at a belated burn. “Chug, chug, chug!” West chanted. “I said try it, Devi, not drink the whole thing,” Nellie laughed. The alcohol pooled warm in Devi’s stomach, and she smiled sheepishly under Nellie and West’s approval. She could already feel the hint of dizziness that warned she would be quite tipsy once the alcohol kicked into her system, but she decided that was a problem for future Devi. It was refreshing to be a little rebellious. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Locket)]]Devi tried to act like she was completely fine, like this wasn’t the room of the man who built the house her mother just couldn’t resist returning to. Even after Tara abandoned her to the occult secrets that consumed her father, even after she snuck into the last party that almost killed her in the mysterious Bennington explosion, even after she had years of nightmares about the monster she had glimpsed… She had to come back one more time. One last time. Leaving her only daughter behind to mourn for her, to wonder how she had met her end in the Bennington Mansion. No, there was never a body found on the grounds. But the police never found Mark’s body, either. Devi’s eyes darted from the abandoned hospital bed, to the fraying pictures on the walls, to the intricately carved wardrobe at the far end of the room. One object boring and normal, some appropriately spooky, and one almost absurdly sinister. “Any guidebook info?” Mark asked. “No,” Devi said. “Bradford was still living here during the heyday of the tours and this room was always private.” “Is that normal?” West asked. “To have tours in a place where someone is actively living?” “I think there are some castle tours in Scotland like that,” said Devi. “Haunted ones?” West asked, perking up. “We should do a trip. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said, nodding at the door on the far side of the room. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” She was surprised at how well she was able to keep her voice from trembling. “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Nellie wandered over to the pictures, touching them, messing with the frayed pieces and Devi wondered if it was worth the wasted energy to tell her to stop. “Does anyone see a knife?” asked Nellie. West and Devi shook their heads. West was filming a engraved wardrobe in the corner. Devi sat on the edge of the hospital bed. “That would have been too exciting, I guess,” Nellie sighed, letting the pieces of the picture fall back into disarray. “Does anyone see anything interesting?” [[Hospital Bed - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]]Devi tried to act like she was completely fine, like this wasn’t the room of the man who built the house her mother just couldn’t resist returning to. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said, nodding at the door on the far side of the room. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” She was surprised at how well she was able to keep her voice from trembling. “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Nellie wandered over to the pictures, touching them, messing with the frayed pieces and Devi wondered if it was worth the wasted energy to tell her to stop. “Does anyone see a knife?” asked Nellie. West and Devi shook their heads. West was filming a engraved wardrobe in the corner. Devi sat on the edge of the hospital bed, hoping the room might go still if she got off her feet, but the change did little to settle her roiling stomach. “That would have been too exciting, I guess,” Nellie sighed, letting the pieces of the picture fall back into disarray. “Does anyone see anything interesting?” [[Hospital Bed - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. There was no one hiding out of sight, eating hidden stashes of chocolate. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Globe - Devi's Tour (with Locket Cont. from USR and Upper Observatory)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but nodded anyway, slipping the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]]“Nellie, we should get some footage of you by the bookshelves,” Devi said. “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West agreed. Nellie stepped over to the books, frowned as she examined the spines, and then her jaw dropped. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” West gave Devi a look that seemed to say, “you’re in charge, get our star to stop reading.” Devi sighed and walked up to Nellie, gently plucking the book from her hands, ignoring Nellie’s pout. But when Devi tried to put the book back into place, it no longer seemed to fit. She shined her flashlight at the space they had made and saw something tucked into the shelf, glinting in the light. Devi reached in and pulled out a locket. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and Devi hopped deftly away. “Absolutely not,” said Devi. “We’re putting it back. It probably belonged to one of the Benningtons and costs more than West’s camera.” “It’s costume jewellery,” Nellie insisted, though her eyes looked hungry for the fake gold. “Then… it probably was left by another ghost crew, or tourists, who might be looking for it,” Devi said, slipping the locket into her briefcase. “I’ll let the owner know that we found it tomorrow. It might have sentimental value.” Nellie glared at Devi, but then she shrugged, wandering over to the sofas. “You should be filming me, West!” she shouted. “You should put that in the hotel safe when we get back,” West whispered. “She’s totally going to try to steal it.” Devi bit back her instinct to defend Nellie because West was most likely correct. [[Upper Floor Observatory - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe with Locket)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Locket)]]“You okay, Devi?” West asked. While West and Nellie had already wandered well into the room. West had paused his filming of the glass ceiling that must have continued above the house from the entry room while Nellie was playing with a telescope in the corner. But Devi could hear her mother’s voice in her head: “Guests were never allowed in observatory. It belonged to Bradford’s lovers. And they could not tolerate Bradford’s occult guests.” Devi guessed that a crew of ghost hunters counted as occult guests of the house. She reminded herself that Tara would invade the privacy of the observatory all the time, even if she could never convince Devi’s mother to play along with her. Even years later, the little boxy black beds with their little boxy black side tables seemed so neat and perfect they defied anyone to mess with their perfect parallel angles. “I mean, I’m happy to just shoot footage of this sky, but should we look around a bit?” asked West. “We probably have enough time to check out a couple of the things in here.” Devi shook off her unease and stepped inside, giving the beds and wide berth, accidentally bumping into Nellie who seemed equally distracted. “What does the guidebook say?” West prompted. Devi opened the book but the words seemed to swim. She didn’t think she had drunk that much. It couldn’t have been the Scotch. It had to have been the book. The words. They didn’t want to be read. She wasn’t supposed to be here. It was dangerous in the observatory. That was what her mother had said. That was why Bradford’s lovers told her to stay away. “You guys are… giving off bad vibes that I should definitely be filming,” said West. [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe)]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe)]] [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” “Did our little drunk-y forget to take off the lens cap?” West laughed. “Don’t patronize me,” Devi said, throwing West a mock glare. She made sure he didn’t see her slight of hand as she checked that there wasn’t a lens cap on the telescope, relieved when she felt solid glass. [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe from Telescope)]] [[Observatory Bed - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe from Telescope)]]West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. Devi thought of the footsteps she heard earlier and had an unsettling moment… No. That was ridiculous. This wasn’t an Oscar-winning South Korean film. There was no one hiding out of sight, eating hidden stashes of chocolate. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe and Observatory Bed)]] [[Telescope - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe and Observatory Bed)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but her head was getting fuzzy from the alcohol, so she just nodded and slipped the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but her head was getting fuzzy from the alcohol, so she just nodded and slipped the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]]West squished one of the pillows. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. “Looking to take a nap?” she asked. “It looked weird,” said West, still squished the pillow. “Feels weird too.” “It’s probably rotten,” shrugged Nellie. “No,” said West. “There’s something…” He shook the pillow and something small and square fell from its hiding place in the pillowcase. “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, triumphant. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. “Huh,” said West, picking out one of the chocolates. “They don’t look all that old.” “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. Devi thought of the footsteps she heard earlier and had an unsettling moment… No. That was ridiculous. This wasn’t an Oscar-winning South Korean film. There was no one hiding out of sight, eating hidden stashes of chocolate. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Bookshelves - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe and Upper Floor Observatory)]]“Nellie, we should get some footage of you by the bookshelves,” Devi said. “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West agreed. Nellie stepped over to the books, frowned as she examined the spines, and then her jaw dropped. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” West gave Devi a look that seemed to say, “you’re in charge, get our star to stop reading.” Devi sighed and walked up to Nellie, gently plucking the book from her hands, ignoring Nellie’s pout. But when Devi tried to put the book back into place, it no longer seemed to fit. She shined her flashlight at the space they had made and saw something tucked into the shelf, glinting in the light. Devi reached in and pulled out a locket. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and Devi hopped deftly away. “Absolutely not,” said Devi. “We’re putting it back. It probably belonged to one of the Benningtons and costs more than West’s camera.” “It’s costume jewellery,” Nellie insisted, though her eyes looked hungry for the fake gold. “Then… it probably was left by another ghost crew, or tourists, who might be looking for it,” Devi said, slipping the locket into her briefcase. “I’ll let the owner know that we found it tomorrow. It might have sentimental value.” Nellie glared at Devi, but then she shrugged, wandering over to the sofas. “You should be filming me, West!” she shouted. “You should put that in the hotel safe when we get back,” West whispered. “She’s totally going to try to steal it.” Devi bit back her instinct to defend Nellie because West was most likely correct. [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” She thought that was what her mother had said. She had some memory that Bradford’s lover had been featured in fashion magazines and home magazines, something between style icons and domestic goddesses. But she couldn’t remember the names of the magazines, so she let her crew members ignore her as they argued. It gave her the freedom to pick up the small object that she had caught in the flashlight’s glow, hidden or fallen behind the side table. It was simple, delicate, a spiral journal with “TARA” printed in neat letters on the cover. Her diary. “Ooo, a diary, open it!” said Nellie. Devi clutched the diary to her chest. “No,” she said. “This is private. It’s inappropriate. We should return it to the owner.” “A secret Bennington diary is good TV,” said West. Devi shook her head. Nellie sighed and laid a hand on Devi’s arm. She could barely feel the touch under her thick hoodie, but Devi flushed warm anyway. “At least hold onto it,” said Nellie. “You can look through it when we get back to the hotel and censor anything too sensitive. And if there is anything particularly compelling, we can scan the pages in the lobby. And then we can give the diary back tomorrow.” Devi knew Nellie’s logic was off, but her head was getting fuzzy from the alcohol, so she just nodded and slipped the diary into her briefcase. “Fine,” said Devi. “But there’s too much nice stuff in this library that I can’t trust either of you not to steal, and it’s too big for me to keep an eye on both of you. Let’s go to Bradford’s room.” “You don’t think they’ll be nice stuff to steal there?” Nellie asked, all innocent big eyes. “It’s one little room,” said Devi. “I can keep you both in check.” [[Bradford's Bedroom - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? Devi shivered, but she still looked. Her mother said that the Bennington ladies loves astronomy, and for years Devi thought she meant astrology, it made more sense to her for the pseudo-sensationalists. But the women would draw star charts like they were oracles from some ancient civilization, the only ones marking the stories to the constellations. But however they observed the stars, Devi doubted it was through this telescope. “Something’s wrong with it,” Devi sighed. “I’m just seeing black. Moving on.” “Did our little drunk-y forget to take off the lens cap?” West laughed. “Don’t patronize me,” Devi said, throwing West a mock glare. She made sure he didn’t see her slight of hand as she checked that there wasn’t a lens cap on the telescope, relieved when she felt solid glass. [[Bookshelves - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR and Globe and Upper Floor Observatory)]]Something crinkled under the sheet. Devi lifted it, finding a small, crumpled piece of paper covered in neat handwriting. “There’s a letter on this bed,” she said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. Devi tried to read the letter, but time had done some damage to its legibility. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, Nellie, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. “Careful with that!” Nellie said. “West, film me. He apologizes to Tara, tells her she has responsibilities, and says… this is hard to make out, it’s so dark in here… He says Mark was a threat to the family, he did what he had to do…” “Is he confessing to killing him?” asked West. “He might just be confessing to kicking him out,” Nellie said, shaking her head. “There aren’t any specifics. Okay, then he says his daughter Dawn never understood, she was a danger… she was in danger? Well, there’s a paragraph about Dawn and danger and… Emma?” “Emma was Dawn’s girlfriend,” Devi said, then shook her head. “Well, her tragically dead girlfriend.” “The writing isn’t clear there,” said Nellie. “He says he’s trapped, he just wants to be free, maybe it’s a final gift he can give Tara… ugh. Oh no.” “What?” asked Devi. “He’s asking her to sacrifice him. For her own freedom.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. “We should hold on to that letter!” Devi said, too loudly, and West and Nellie stared blankly at her. “I mean… it could be useful. For the show. And I’m in charge. So.” She grabbed the letter, sticking it into her bag. Maybe Tara wasn’t exactly responsible for her mother’s disappearance. But if she was responsible for Bradford’s death, maybe this letter could be used to make her pay. As much as any dead or missing woman could pay for anything. [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] “If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe appeared to be a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “What do you say, Devi? Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. My flashlight’s batteries are dead.” She was surprised that neither of her crew members questioned her statement, beyond looking mildly disappointed. She doubted the batteries were dead, but it was as good an excuse as any to avoid that looming darkness. Unfortunately, it meant that she would now have to commit to the lie, and the night was only going to get darker. “Well, what else are we going to show our viewers?” asked West, grinning at Devi, but his good cheer felt like more like a challenge than a joke. [[Basement - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] The cacti of the garden loomed like gargoyles, filling up as much space as they could beside the circling stone path. Devi thought the flowers that bloomed from them, ranging from pale pink to red, were lovely, if perhaps a little too “fleshy” to be called beautiful. Maybe it was because the cacti themselves were as tall as people, Devi found herself imagining the loose petals as flopping tongues. Her mother had never mentioned the garden. Perhaps she never made it this far into the house. The thought made Devi want to turn around, but she could not leave Nellie and West alone to wreak havoc. Even if the encircling high fence that enclosed the garden kept their havoc contained. “Hold that position,” West said to Nellie, who was gently caressing a petal. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. She pointed out the swirl of the path that guided them inward before looping back out again and onward, towards the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. It looked solid, but the windows had been covered by planks of wood, hinting at some kind of damage. She was surprised the owner left priceless art in such a shabby part of the mansion, but then supposed the pieces were too large to be moved, built as they were for the building that housed them. //Why… come back…// Devi paused, listening to the crackling voice through her headphones. West and Nellie were saying something, she could see their mouths moving, but her mic was picking up static. She was sure she had heard a voice, though, not the illusion of words. She turned slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. //Why did… come back…// A tune played, unfamiliar, and Devi could not tell if it was harmonizing with the voice or competing with it. “Anything good?” Nellie asked, her voice muffled. “Actually, there might be,” Devi said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” She did not know why she did not mention the voice. Maybe because it sounded so familiar. Maybe because she wished it was familiar. //Why did you come back?// No. That was not her mother. That was… this voice sounded angry. Cruel. Inhuman. The kind of voice that would be perfect for a teaser trailer. The static stopped abruptly. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said, feeling a little less anxious now that she was sure this was a generic spirit and not… well, not her mother. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry this time? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, plucking the guidebook from Devi’s hand. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. Devi led the way into the gallery, followed by West, as Nellie trailed behind them. They kept the door open, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like spirits escaping from the stone. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped.” So had the voice. In the shadowy darkness of the gallery, Devi wasn’t sure if that was a good or bad thing. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie, to Devi’s dismay. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] Something crinkled under the sheet. Devi lifted it, finding a small, crumpled piece of paper covered in neat handwriting. “There’s a letter on this bed,” she said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. Devi tried to read the letter, but time had done some damage to its legibility. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, Nellie, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. “Careful with that!” Nellie said. “West, film me. He apologizes to Tara, tells her she has responsibilities, and says… this is hard to make out, it’s so dark in here… He says Mark was a threat to the family, he did what he had to do…” “Is he confessing to killing him?” asked West. “He might just be confessing to kicking him out,” Nellie said, shaking her head. “There aren’t any specifics. Okay, then he says his daughter Dawn never understood, she was a danger… she was in danger? Well, there’s a paragraph about Dawn and danger and… Emma?” “Emma was Dawn’s girlfriend,” Devi said, then shook her head. “Well, her tragically dead girlfriend.” “The writing isn’t clear there,” said Nellie. “He says he’s trapped, he just wants to be free, maybe it’s a final gift he can give Tara… ugh. Oh no.” “What?” asked Devi. “He’s asking her to sacrifice him. For her own freedom.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. “We should hold on to that letter!” Devi said, too loudly, and West and Nellie stared blankly at her. “I mean… it could be useful. For the show. And I’m in charge. So.” She grabbed the letter, sticking it into her bag. Maybe Tara wasn’t exactly responsible for her mother’s disappearance. But if she was responsible for Bradford’s death, maybe this letter could be used to make her pay. As much as any dead or missing woman could pay for anything. [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] “If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe appeared to be a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “What do you say, Devi? Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. My flashlight’s batteries are dead.” She was surprised that neither of her crew members questioned her statement, beyond looking mildly disappointed. She doubted the batteries were dead, but it was as good an excuse as any to avoid that looming darkness. Unfortunately, it meant that she would now have to commit to the lie, and the night was only going to get darker. “Well, what else are we going to show our viewers?” asked West, grinning at Devi, but his good cheer felt like more like a challenge than a joke. [[Basement - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] Something crinkled under the sheet. Devi lifted it, finding a small, crumpled piece of paper covered in neat handwriting. “There’s a letter on this bed,” she said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. Devi tried to read the letter, but as she had feared, the words bled together on the page. She squinted, willing the letters to stay still, wishing she had never brought attention to it. “Devi? Having some troubles?” West chuckled. She couldn’t read any full sentences, but certain words jumped out at her. //Responsibility//. //Lonely//. //Emma//, and then… //Amitava//? Amitava. That was her mother’s name. It could have been a coincidence. It wasn’t. She was sure. “Are you too… um… unwell to keep going?” Nellie asked, actually sounding concerned. “I’m fine,” said Devi, shoving the paper into her briefcase. “It was nothing. A grocery list.” “Which is why you’re keeping it with you,” West said, fake nodding in agreement. “I said it’s nothing!” Devi snapped and her stomach flipped. She swallowed down hot bile. “Let’s just keeping looking around.” [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] “If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe appeared to be a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “What do you say, Devi? Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. My flashlight’s batteries are dead.” She was surprised that neither of her crew members questioned her statement, beyond looking mildly disappointed. She doubted the batteries were dead, but it was as good an excuse as any to avoid that looming darkness. Unfortunately, it meant that she would now have to commit to the lie, and the night was only going to get darker. “Well, what else are we going to show our viewers?” asked West, grinning at Devi, but his good cheer felt like more like a challenge than a joke. [[Basement - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] Something crinkled under the sheet. Devi lifted it, finding a small, crumpled piece of paper covered in neat handwriting. “There’s a letter on this bed,” she said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. She was sure. “Are you too… um… unwell to keep going?” Nellie asked, actually sounding concerned. “I’m fine,” said Devi, shoving the paper into her briefcase. “It was nothing. A grocery list.” “Which is why you’re keeping it with you,” West said, fake nodding in agreement. “I said it’s nothing!” Devi snapped and her stomach flipped. Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. Devi lifted it, finding a small, crumpled piece of paper covered in neat handwriting. “There’s a letter on this bed,” she said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, Nellie, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. “Careful with that!” Nellie said. “West, film me. He apologizes to Tara, tells her she has responsibilities, and says… this is hard to make out, it’s so dark in here… He says Mark was a threat to the family, he did what he had to do…” “Is he confessing to killing him?” asked West. “He might just be confessing to kicking him out,” Nellie said, shaking her head. “There aren’t any specifics. Okay, then he says his daughter Dawn never understood, she was a danger… she was in danger? Well, there’s a paragraph about Dawn and danger and… Emma?” “Emma was Dawn’s girlfriend,” Devi said, then shook her head. “Well, her tragically dead girlfriend.” “The writing isn’t clear there,” said Nellie. “He says he’s trapped, he just wants to be free, maybe it’s a final gift he can give Tara… ugh. Oh no.” “What?” asked Devi. “He’s asking her to sacrifice him. For her own freedom.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. “We should hold on to that letter!” Devi said, too loudly, and West and Nellie stared blankly at her. “I mean… it could be useful. For the show. And I’m in charge. So.” She grabbed the letter, sticking it into her bag. Maybe Tara wasn’t exactly responsible for her mother’s disappearance. But if she was responsible for Bradford’s death, maybe this letter could be used to make her pay. As much as any dead or missing woman could pay for anything. [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] “If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe appeared to be a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “What do you say, Devi? Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. My flashlight’s batteries are dead.” She was surprised that neither of her crew members questioned her statement, beyond looking mildly disappointed. She doubted the batteries were dead, but it was as good an excuse as any to avoid that looming darkness. Unfortunately, it meant that she would now have to commit to the lie, and the night was only going to get darker. “Well, what else are we going to show our viewers?” asked West, grinning at Devi, but his good cheer felt like more like a challenge than a joke. [[Basement - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] “If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe appeared to be a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “What do you say, Devi? Should we go down?” “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway. My flashlight’s batteries are dead.” She was surprised that neither of her crew members questioned her statement, beyond looking mildly disappointed. She doubted the batteries were dead, but it was as good an excuse as any to avoid that looming darkness. Unfortunately, it meant that she would now have to commit to the lie, and the night was only going to get darker. “Well, what else are we going to show our viewers?” asked West, grinning at Devi, but his good cheer felt like more like a challenge than a joke. [[Basement - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]] [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]] The cacti of the garden loomed like gargoyles, filling up as much space as they could beside the circling stone path. Devi thought the flowers that bloomed from them, ranging from pale pink to red, were lovely, if perhaps a little too “fleshy” to be called beautiful. Maybe it was because the cacti themselves were as tall as people, Devi found herself imagining the loose petals as flopping tongues. Her mother had never mentioned the garden. Perhaps she never made it this far into the house. The thought made Devi want to turn around, but she could not leave Nellie and West alone to wreak havoc. Even if the encircling high fence that enclosed the garden kept their havoc contained. “Hold that position,” West said to Nellie, who was gently caressing a petal. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. She pointed out the swirl of the path that guided them inward before looping back out again and onward, towards the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. It looked solid, but the windows had been covered by planks of wood, hinting at some kind of damage. She was surprised the owner left priceless art in such a shabby part of the mansion, but then supposed the pieces were too large to be moved, built as they were for the building that housed them. //Why… come back…// Devi paused, listening to the crackling voice through her headphones. West and Nellie were saying something, she could see their mouths moving, but her mic was picking up static. She was sure she had heard a voice, though, not the illusion of words. She turned slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. //Why did… come back…// A tune played, unfamiliar, and Devi could not tell if it was harmonizing with the voice or competing with it. “Anything good?” Nellie asked, her voice muffled. “Actually, there might be,” Devi said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” She did not know why she did not mention the voice. Maybe because it sounded so familiar. Maybe because she wished it was familiar. //Why did you come back?// No. That was not her mother. That was… this voice sounded angry. Cruel. Inhuman. The kind of voice that would be perfect for a teaser trailer. The static stopped abruptly. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said, feeling a little less anxious now that she was sure this was a generic spirit and not… well, not her mother. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry this time? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, plucking the guidebook from Devi’s hand. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. Devi led the way into the gallery, followed by West, as Nellie trailed behind them. They kept the door open, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like spirits escaping from the stone. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped.” So had the voice. In the shadowy darkness of the gallery, Devi wasn’t sure if that was a good or bad thing. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie, to Devi’s dismay. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (with Locket)]]Something crinkled under the sheet. Devi lifted it, finding a small, crumpled piece of paper covered in neat handwriting. “There’s a letter on this bed,” she said. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. Devi tried to read the letter, but as she had feared, the words bled together on the page. She squinted, willing the letters to stay still, wishing she had never brought attention to it. “Devi? Having some troubles?” West chuckled. She couldn’t read any full sentences, but certain words jumped out at her. //Responsibility//. //Lonely//. //Emma//, and then… //Amitava//? Amitava. That was her mother’s name. It could have been a coincidence. It wasn’t. She was sure. “Are you too… um… unwell to keep going?” Nellie asked, actually sounding concerned. “I’m fine,” said Devi, shoving the paper into her briefcase. “It was nothing. A grocery list.” “Which is why you’re keeping it with you,” West said, fake nodding in agreement. “I said it’s nothing!” Devi snapped and her stomach flipped. She swallowed down hot bile. “Let’s just keeping looking around.” [[Wardrobe - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]] [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]]There were gargoyles in the garden! No, wait. Those were just very big cacti. Devi giggled and told herself she was just tipsy. Definitely not drunk. Devi thought the flowers that bloomed from the cacti, ranging from pale pink to red, were lovely, if perhaps a “fleshy.” Like tongues. At least they looked soft… “Ow!” Devi pulled back her bleeding hand. "Devi, those spikes are huge," West chided. "How could you not see them?" “Do you have any first aid stuff in your briefcase?” Nellie asked. Devi nodded. Of course. She was prepared. She was professional. She was just a little bit bloody. A little bloody tipsy. Nellie reached into her briefcase and found the makeup bag she had marked with a first aid cross, unzipped it, and pulled out a roll of self-adhesive bandage. “This will do,” she murmured, taking Devi’s hand, wrapping it so gently. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” Devi said, and Nellie nodded kindly, so she must have been slurring a little bit. Devi tried to point out the swirl of the path that guided them inward before looping back out again and onward, towards the hexagon-shaped building in front of them, but couldn’t free her hand from Nellie’s insistent help. //Why… come back…// Devi paused, listening to the crackling voice through her headphones. West and Nellie were saying something, she could see their mouths moving, but her mic was picking up static. She was sure she had heard a voice, though, not the illusion of words, not something imagined by a groggy mind. She freed herself from Nellie and turned slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. //Why did… come back…// A tune played, unfamiliar, and Devi could not tell if it was harmonizing with the voice or competing with it. “I think she heard something good,” Nellie said, her voice muffled, and Devi nodded. “Coming from the gallery,” she said, slowly, so every word was clear. Though maybe a little too loudly, based on her crewmates’ expressions. “It’s like… a song. Or not. It’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” //Why did you come back?// “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi shrugged. Probably. It would be easier to tell later if it was something good. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said, letting the cool air hit her skin and bring her back to the moment. But still, reading was out of the question. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry this time? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, plucking the guidebook from Devi’s hand. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. Devi led the way into the gallery, followed by West, as Nellie trailed behind them. They kept the door open, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like spirits escaping from the stone. She was sure it was just her swimming vision that made it look like the shadows were dancing, but it was a mesmerizing sight nonetheless. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped.” So had the voice. Oh well. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]There were gargoyles in the garden! No, wait. Those were just very big cacti. Devi giggled and told herself she was just tipsy. Definitely not drunk. Devi thought the flowers that bloomed from the cacti, ranging from pale pink to red, were lovely, if perhaps a “fleshy.” Like tongues. At least they looked soft… “Ow!” Devi pulled back her bleeding hand. "Devi, those spikes are huge," West chided. "How could you not see them?" “Do you have any first aid stuff in your briefcase?” Nellie asked. Devi nodded. Of course. She was prepared. She was professional. She was just a little bit bloody. A little bloody tipsy. Nellie reached into her briefcase and found the makeup bag she had marked with a first aid cross, unzipped it, and pulled out a roll of self-adhesive bandage. “This will do,” she murmured, taking Devi’s hand, wrapping it so gently. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” Devi said, and Nellie nodded kindly, so she must have been slurring a little bit. Devi tried to point out the swirl of the path that guided them inward before looping back out again and onward, towards the hexagon-shaped building in front of them, but couldn’t free her hand from Nellie’s insistent help. //Why… come back…// Devi paused, listening to the crackling voice through her headphones. West and Nellie were saying something, she could see their mouths moving, but her mic was picking up static. She was sure she had heard a voice, though, not the illusion of words, not something imagined by a groggy mind. She freed herself from Nellie and turned slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. //Why did… come back…// A tune played, unfamiliar, and Devi could not tell if it was harmonizing with the voice or competing with it. “I think she heard something good,” Nellie said, her voice muffled, and Devi nodded. “Coming from the gallery,” she said, slowly, so every word was clear. Though maybe a little too loudly, based on her crewmates’ expressions. “It’s like… a song. Or not. It’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” //Why did you come back?// “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi shrugged. Probably.
