It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, plucking the guidebook from Devi’s hand. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. Devi led the way into the gallery, followed by West, as Nellie trailed behind them. They kept the door open, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like spirits escaping from the stone. She was sure it was just her swimming vision that made it look like the shadows were dancing, but it was a mesmerizing sight nonetheless. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped.” So had the voice. Oh well. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]] [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]]There were gargoyles in the garden! No, wait. Those were just very big cacti. Devi giggled and told herself she was just tipsy. Definitely not drunk. Devi thought the flowers that bloomed from the cacti, ranging from pale pink to red, were lovely, if perhaps a “fleshy.” Like tongues. At least they looked soft… “Ow!” Devi pulled back her bleeding hand. "Devi, those spikes are huge," West chided. "How could you not see them?" “Do you have any first aid stuff in your briefcase?” Nellie asked. Devi nodded. Of course. She was prepared. She was professional. She was just a little bit bloody. A little bloody tipsy. Nellie reached into her briefcase and found the makeup bag she had marked with a first aid cross, unzipped it, and pulled out a roll of self-adhesive bandage. “This will do,” she murmured, taking Devi’s hand, wrapping it so gently. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” Devi said, and Nellie nodded kindly, so she must have been slurring a little bit. Devi tried to point out the swirl of the path that guided them inward before looping back out again and onward, towards the hexagon-shaped building in front of them, but couldn’t free her hand from Nellie’s insistent help. //Why… come back…// Devi paused, listening to the crackling voice through her headphones. West and Nellie were saying something, she could see their mouths moving, but her mic was picking up static. She was sure she had heard a voice, though, not the illusion of words, not something imagined by a groggy mind. She freed herself from Nellie and turned slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. //Why did… come back…// A tune played, unfamiliar, and Devi could not tell if it was harmonizing with the voice or competing with it. “I think she heard something good,” Nellie said, her voice muffled, and Devi nodded. “Coming from the gallery,” she said, slowly, so every word was clear. Though maybe a little too loudly, based on her crewmates’ expressions. “It’s like… a song. Or not. It’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” //Why did you come back?// “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi shrugged. Probably. It would be easier to tell later if it was something good. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said, letting the cool air hit her skin and bring her back to the moment. But still, reading was out of the question. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry this time? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, plucking the guidebook from Devi’s hand. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. Devi led the way into the gallery, followed by West, as Nellie trailed behind them. They kept the door open, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like spirits escaping from the stone. She was sure it was just her swimming vision that made it look like the shadows were dancing, but it was a mesmerizing sight nonetheless. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped.” So had the voice. Oh well. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]] [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]] “Devi, if it’s too scary for you, we can skip…” West’s voice trailed off as Devi pushed past him, leading the way down the stairs. “Someone’s found her backbone!” Nellie laughed. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity,” Devi grumbled, glad the darkness hid her blush. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down, but Devi walked with false confidence. She could almost hear her mother’s voice warning her that this was a terrible idea, this was the dark underbelly of the Bennington Mansion that called her back, that swallowed her whole. But if Devi held her breath, willed it to be so, she could imagine that her mother’s voice was coming from somewhere in front of her. Deeper into the darkness. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Devi could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid underground. A glow, gentle as misty moonlight, was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi. Why was she in this basement? Why was she pretending to be brave? Why was she back in the Bennington Mansion? Before she could voice her concerns, at least the ones she was willing to share, Nellie walked towards the altar. She set a hand on the flat, round surface tracing a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. West approached Nellie’s shoulder, and though Devi wanted to run back upstairs, her gut told her it would be a terrible idea to split up. She stared at the image Nellie traced with an almost loving caress. “A ‘V,’” murmured Devi. “Horns,” said West. “We should leave the house,” said Nellie. “We don’t have enough footage yet for the show,” West protested before Devi could agree. “This is cool, but it’s not like we can just be done because we found something good.” He was right. She was overreacting. It was creepy, yes, but occult house basements were bound to be creepy. This would be good for the show. For their careers. “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi said when she found her voice. “We can’t lose this opportunity. Unless… unless you’re really not feeling well or something like that?” Nellie shrugged off Devi’s comforting hand on her shoulder and it felt like the last bit of hope for everything to be okay slipping away. “You’re right,” Nellie said. “Both of you. I’m fine. I’ll be fine. Let’s just get to the gallery… Did you get that West?” “Damn it, Nellie, was that a performance?” Nellie grinned and Devi bit back an aggravated groan. “Back up to reality we go,” Nellie said, and Devi was only too happy to lead the way. [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] “Devi, if it’s too scary for you, we can skip…” West’s voice trailed off as Devi pushed past him, leading the way down the stairs. “Someone’s found her backbone!” Nellie laughed. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity,” Devi grumbled, glad the darkness hid her blush. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down, but Devi walked with false confidence. She could almost hear her mother’s voice warning her that this was a terrible idea, this was the dark underbelly of the Bennington Mansion that called her back, that swallowed her whole. But if Devi held her breath, willed it to be so, she could imagine that her mother’s voice was coming from somewhere in front of her. Deeper into the darkness. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Devi could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid underground. A glow, gentle as misty moonlight, was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi. Why was she in this basement? Why was she pretending to be brave? Why was she back in the Bennington Mansion? Before she could voice her concerns, at least the ones she was willing to share, Nellie walked towards the altar. She set a hand on the flat, round surface tracing a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. West approached Nellie’s shoulder, and though Devi wanted to run back upstairs, her gut told her it would be a terrible idea to split up. She stared at the image Nellie traced with an almost loving caress. “A ‘V,’” murmured Devi. “Horns,” said West. “We should leave the house,” said Nellie. “We don’t have enough footage yet for the show,” West protested before Devi could agree. “This is cool, but it’s not like we can just be done because we found something good.” He was right. She was overreacting. It was creepy, yes, but occult house basements were bound to be creepy. This would be good for the show. For their careers. “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi said when she found her voice. “We can’t lose this opportunity. Unless… unless you’re really not feeling well or something like that?” Nellie shrugged off Devi’s comforting hand on her shoulder and it felt like the last bit of hope for everything to be okay slipping away. “You’re right,” Nellie said. “Both of you. I’m fine. I’ll be fine. Let’s just get to the gallery… Did you get that West?” “Damn it, Nellie, was that a performance?” Nellie grinned and Devi bit back an aggravated groan. “Back up to reality we go,” Nellie said, and Devi was only too happy to lead the way. [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (Basement with Locket)]] “Devi, if it’s too scary for you, we can skip…” West’s voice trailed off as Devi pushed past him unsteadily, leading the way down the stairs. “Someone’s found her backbone!” Nellie laughed. “Nope, just Bradford’s scotch!” Devi grinned. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down, and Devi managed to trip over her stumbling feet a couple times anyway despite the light. She could almost hear her mother’s voice whispering a vague warning, but to Devi’s addled perception it almost sounded like the whispering voice was coming from somewhere in front of her. Deeper into the darkness. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Devi could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid enough, though her balance insisted she was on a rocking boat. A glow, gentle as misty moonlight, was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi. It was beautiful, and for a moment she understood her mother. The lure of this place, despite the danger, as addictive as the sharpest taste of confidence. Devi walked towards the altar, passing Nellie who huffed something under the breath that Devi did not bother to try to decipher. She set a hand on the flat, round surface tracing a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. She didn’t hear West and Nellie approach until the spoke, making her jump, which in turn made her stomach flip. “A ‘V?’” asked Nellie, examining the altar’s surface. “Horns,” said West. “Creepy. But at least it makes for good footage. Makes you wonder if we even need to see more.” “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi protested, noticing how her voice was starting to slur. “I was just joking, Devi,” said West, and he and Nellie exchanged a glance. Devi didn’t bother deciphering it. At least they were getting along. Kind of. They didn’t even make biting comments about each other as they let Devi lead them back up the stairs. [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket)]] “Devi, if it’s too scary for you, we can skip…” West’s voice trailed off as Devi pushed past him unsteadily, leading the way down the stairs. “Someone’s found her backbone!” Nellie laughed. “Nope, just Bradford’s scotch!” Devi grinned. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down, and Devi managed to trip over her stumbling feet a couple times anyway despite the light. She could almost hear her mother’s voice whispering a vague warning, but to Devi’s addled perception it almost sounded like the whispering voice was coming from somewhere in front of her. Deeper into the darkness. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Devi could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid enough, though her balance insisted she was on a rocking boat. A glow, gentle as misty moonlight, was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi. It was beautiful, and for a moment she understood her mother. The lure of this place, despite the danger, as addictive as the sharpest taste of confidence. Devi walked towards the altar, passing Nellie who huffed something under the breath that Devi did not bother to try to decipher. She set a hand on the flat, round surface tracing a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. She didn’t hear West and Nellie approach until the spoke, making her jump, which in turn made her stomach flip. “A ‘V?’” asked Nellie, examining the altar’s surface. “Horns,” said West. “Creepy. But at least it makes for good footage. Makes you wonder if we even need to see more.” “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi protested, noticing how her voice was starting to slur. “I was just joking, Devi,” said West, and he and Nellie exchanged a glance. Devi didn’t bother deciphering it. At least they were getting along. Kind of. They didn’t even make biting comments about each other as they let Devi lead them back up the stairs. [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary)]]“Devi, if it’s too scary for you, we can skip…” West’s voice trailed off as Devi pushed past him, leading the way down the stairs. “Someone’s found her backbone!” Nellie laughed. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity,” Devi grumbled, glad the darkness hid her blush. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down, but Devi walked with false confidence. She could almost hear her mother’s voice warning her that this was a terrible idea, this was the dark underbelly of the Bennington Mansion that called her back, that swallowed her whole. But if Devi held her breath, willed it to be so, she could imagine that her mother’s voice was coming from somewhere in front of her. Deeper into the darkness. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Devi could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid underground. A glow, gentle as misty moonlight, was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi. Why was she in this basement? Why was she pretending to be brave? Why was she back in the Bennington Mansion? Before she could voice her concerns, at least the ones she was willing to share, Nellie walked towards the altar. She set a hand on the flat, round surface tracing a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. West approached Nellie’s shoulder, and though Devi wanted to run back upstairs, her gut told her it would be a terrible idea to split up. She stared at the image Nellie traced with an almost loving caress. “A ‘V,’” murmured Devi. “Horns,” said West. “We should leave the house,” said Nellie. “We don’t have enough footage yet for the show,” West protested before Devi could agree. “This is cool, but it’s not like we can just be done because we found something good.” He was right. She was overreacting. It was creepy, yes, but occult house basements were bound to be creepy. This would be good for the show. For their careers. “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi said when she found her voice. “We can’t lose this opportunity. Unless… unless you’re really not feeling well or something like that?” Nellie shrugged off Devi’s comforting hand on her shoulder and it felt like the last bit of hope for everything to be okay slipping away. “You’re right,” Nellie said. “Both of you. I’m fine. I’ll be fine. Let’s just get to the gallery… Did you get that West?” “Damn it, Nellie, was that a performance?” Nellie grinned and Devi bit back an aggravated groan. “Back up to reality we go,” Nellie said, and Devi was only too happy to lead the way. [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] The cacti of the garden loomed like gargoyles, filling up as much space as they could beside the circling stone path. Devi thought the flowers that bloomed from them, ranging from pale pink to red, were lovely, if perhaps a little too “fleshy” to be called beautiful. Maybe it was because the cacti themselves were as tall as people, Devi found herself imagining the loose petals as flopping tongues. Her mother had never mentioned the garden. Perhaps she never made it this far into the house. The thought made Devi want to turn around, but she could not leave Nellie and West alone to wreak havoc. Even if the encircling high fence that enclosed the garden kept their havoc contained. “Hold that position,” West said to Nellie, who was gently caressing a petal. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. She pointed out the swirl of the path that guided them inward before looping back out again and onward, towards the hexagon-shaped building in front of them. It looked solid, but the windows had been covered by planks of wood, hinting at some kind of damage. She was surprised the owner left priceless art in such a shabby part of the mansion, but then supposed the pieces were too large to be moved, built as they were for the building that housed them. //Why… come back…// Devi paused, listening to the crackling voice through her headphones. West and Nellie were saying something, she could see their mouths moving, but her mic was picking up static. She was sure she had heard a voice, though, not the illusion of words. She turned slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room. //Why did… come back…// A tune played, unfamiliar, and Devi could not tell if it was harmonizing with the voice or competing with it. “Anything good?” Nellie asked, her voice muffled. “Actually, there might be,” Devi said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” She did not know why she did not mention the voice. Maybe because it sounded so familiar. Maybe because she wished it was familiar. //Why did you come back?// No. That was not her mother. That was… this voice sounded angry. Cruel. Inhuman. The kind of voice that would be perfect for a teaser trailer. The static stopped abruptly. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said, feeling a little less anxious now that she was sure this was a generic spirit and not… well, not her mother. “Nellie, maybe you could read the guidebook entry this time? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” “Let me enlighten you,” Nellie said, plucking the guidebook from Devi’s hand. “The Gallery was renowned for housing some of the most expensive commissioned art pieces of the mid-twentieth century, some completed by world-renowned masters and others by either anonymous or unknown creatives. While some have attempted to make reproductions based on the photographs of the works, the originals have never left the property, despite numerous bids from museums and private collectors alike. Though art critics often disparaged Bradford’s taste on principle due to his children’s inclinations towards Rock n Roll, considered distinctly unclassy at the time, his manner of hoarding the pieces and their uniqueness has leant the collection considerable value. Even during the height of his life, before the deaths of any of his children, no one except a member of the Bennington family was allowed to visit the gallery. His wishes for the space to remain a sacred family space have been respected to this day.” “That is an outdated guidebook,” West laughed. Devi led the way into the gallery, followed by West, as Nellie trailed behind them. They kept the door open, letting the starlight illuminate the spacious room, and cast deep shadows the stretched from the larger art pieces like spirits escaping from the stone. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped.” So had the voice. In the shadowy darkness of the gallery, Devi wasn’t sure if that was a good or bad thing. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends, perhaps, who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. There was no response. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West. “Good idea,” said Nellie, to Devi’s dismay. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary)]]“Devi, if it’s too scary for you, we can skip…” West’s voice trailed off as Devi pushed past him unsteadily, leading the way down the stairs. “Someone’s found her backbone!” Nellie laughed. “Nope, just Bradford’s scotch!” Devi grinned. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down, and Devi managed to trip over her stumbling feet a couple times anyway despite the light. She could almost hear her mother’s voice whispering a vague warning, but to Devi’s addled perception it almost sounded like the whispering voice was coming from somewhere in front of her. Deeper into the darkness. They walked down for a while without speaking. The only sounds for Devi to record were their heavy breaths and shoes scraping against dusty stone. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. Devi could just see the steps in front of her, enough to notice when they reached solid ground. Solid enough, though her balance insisted she was on a rocking boat. A glow, gentle as misty moonlight, was coming from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi. It was beautiful, and for a moment she understood her mother. The lure of this place, despite the danger, as addictive as the sharpest taste of confidence. Devi walked towards the altar, passing Nellie who huffed something under the breath that Devi did not bother to try to decipher. She set a hand on the flat, round surface tracing a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. She didn’t hear West and Nellie approach until the spoke, making her jump, which in turn made her stomach flip. “A ‘V?’” asked Nellie, examining the altar’s surface. “Horns,” said West. “Creepy. But at least it makes for good footage. Makes you wonder if we even need to see more.” “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi protested, noticing how her voice was starting to slur. “I was just joking, Devi,” said West, and he and Nellie exchanged a glance. Devi didn’t bother deciphering it. At least they were getting along. Kind of. They didn’t even make biting comments about each other as they let Devi lead them back up the stairs. [[Gallery - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]]Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. She was getting tired, and if West and Nellie didn’t agree, she didn’t have the energy to argue. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi. “No,” West laughed. “That’s the other-” “Shut up, West,” Nellie huffed, smiling at Devi. “What do you mean?” Devi pointed to the indents. “On the one woman’s shoulder,” she said. “They’re not dots, they’re diamonds, like the sculptures in A Constellation. They’re even spaced out the same way.” West filmed the indents, the panned across the gallery. “Great catch, Devi!” Nellie grinned and Devi blushed. [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (with Diary from The Triad)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, smiling, playing along. If she pointed out Bradford’s lovers’ interest in astrology, the fact that the mansion had an observatory, that the lovers were known to chart the stars, it would just sound like she was lecturing them. It didn’t matter, anyway. West was still filming it. She could have Nellie record a statement about it later for a voice over in post. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (with Diary from A Constellation))]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] Devi stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. She recognized them all from her mother’s stories, but they were easy enough to identify, even if she didn’t have her mother’s descriptions to prompt her. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Devi knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders. It reminded her of Nellie’s cut, but a little more pampered. Self-conscious. Dawn lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Devi could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. The artist apparently chose to capture him in a precarious moment. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro almost reminded her of Sly Stone. Someone playing at being as cool as Sly. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt and bore a cruel sneer. He bullied Tara, her mother said. They would avoid him at the parties. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls that looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. Devi knew that she was much more comfortable in jeans, was always the most under-dressed at the parties, but Bradford’s lovers must have picked this look for her. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, uneasy… Afraid? The looked caught, trapped, desperate. Devi wondered what she was looking at, and then wondered why the artist would want to capture such an uncomfortable image. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But there was something off about him. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but only if the artist wasn’t very good at capturing likenesses. But if it wasn’t him, who could it be? “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Not a man. Not a ghost. Not a demon. A spectre from her mother’s stories, glimpsed through a door two girls should never have been peeking through. Her mother never could describe him, just the way he made her feel. Terrified. She stepped closer to the painting, gazing at his faded eyes, and she could almost hear something. Chanting. No. Lyrics. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. As she reached for her equipment, a bit of the faded paint flecked off of the portrait, onto her sleeve. Not paint, at least not oil paint, but something else. Devi looked closer at the painting of the man, and saw that it had been smeared with something to purposefully cover his features. But if it was coming off, maybe it could be wiped away? She knew she shouldn’t touch the painting, but it had already been vandalized, and she needed to see him. She needed to see the monster her mother had seen. The touched the man’s face, where his jaw should have been, and was surprised that the paint was warm. Like skin. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members covered their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Devi heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, and Devi thought she might puke and found herself actually focusing on the sound for some kind of constant in the chaos. She picked up noises that sounded familiar, snatches of family melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Devi to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Landslide]]Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. She was getting tired, and if West and Nellie didn’t agree, she didn’t have the energy to argue. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi. “No,” West laughed. “That’s the other-” “Shut up, West,” Nellie huffed, smiling at Devi. “What do you mean?” Devi pointed to the indents. “On the one woman’s shoulder,” she said. “They’re not dots, they’re diamonds, like the sculptures in A Constellation. They’re even spaced out the same way.” West filmed the indents, the panned across the gallery. “Great catch, Devi!” Nellie grinned and Devi blushed. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, smiling, playing along. If she pointed out Bradford’s lovers’ interest in astrology, the fact that the mansion had an observatory, that the lovers were known to chart the stars, it would just sound like she was lecturing them. It didn’t matter, anyway. West was still filming it. She could have Nellie record a statement about it later for a voice over in post. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (with Locket from A Constellation)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] Devi stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. She recognized them all from her mother’s stories, but they were easy enough to identify, even if she didn’t have her mother’s descriptions to prompt her. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Devi knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders. It reminded her of Nellie’s cut, but a little more pampered. Self-conscious. Dawn lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Devi could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. The artist apparently chose to capture him in a precarious moment. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro almost reminded her of Sly Stone. Someone playing at being as cool as Sly. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt and bore a cruel sneer. He bullied Tara, her mother said. They would avoid him at the parties. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls that looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. Devi knew that she was much more comfortable in jeans, was always the most under-dressed at the parties, but Bradford’s lovers must have picked this look for her. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, uneasy… Afraid? The looked caught, trapped, desperate. Devi wondered what she was looking at, and then wondered why the artist would want to capture such an uncomfortable image. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But there was something off about him. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but only if the artist wasn’t very good at capturing likenesses. But if it wasn’t him, who could it be? “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Devi’s eyes caught on the locket at Dawn’s neck. She stepped closer to the painting, checking that, yes, it was the locket in her briefcase! She pulled it out to be sure, grasping the warm jewellery in her hand, and she heard a tune whispering in her headphones. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. She reached for her equipment and nearly lost her grip on the necklace. The chain swung loose and the locket struck the painting, chipping the color from Dawn's chest. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members covered their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones, and the locket was hot against her cheek. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Devi heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, and Devi thought she might puke and found herself actually focusing on the sound for some kind of constant in the chaos. She picked up noises that sounded familiar, snatches of family melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Devi to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Barracuda]]Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. She was getting tired, and if West and Nellie didn’t agree, she didn’t have the energy to argue. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi. “No,” West laughed. “That’s the other-” “Shut up, West,” Nellie huffed, smiling at Devi. “What do you mean?” Devi pointed to the indents. “On the one woman’s shoulder,” she said. “They’re not dots, they’re diamonds, like the sculptures in A Constellation. They’re even spaced out the same way.” West filmed the indents, the panned across the gallery. “Great catch, Devi!” Nellie grinned and Devi blushed. [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary from The Triad)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi said, smiling, playing along. If she pointed out Bradford’s lovers’ interest in astrology, the fact that the mansion had an observatory, that the lovers were known to chart the stars, it would just sound like she was lecturing them. It didn’t matter, anyway. West was still filming it. She could have Nellie record a statement about it later for a voice over in post. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary from A Constellation)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (USR with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]]Devi stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. She recognized them all from her mother’s stories, but they were easy enough to identify, even if she didn’t have her mother’s descriptions to prompt her. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Devi knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders. It reminded her of Nellie’s cut, but a little more pampered. Self-conscious. Dawn lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Devi could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. The artist apparently chose to capture him in a precarious moment. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro almost reminded her of Sly Stone. Someone playing at being as cool as Sly. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt and bore a cruel sneer. He bullied Tara, her mother said. They would avoid him at the parties. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls that looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. Devi knew that she was much more comfortable in jeans, was always the most under-dressed at the parties, but Bradford’s lovers must have picked this look for her. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, uneasy… Afraid? The looked caught, trapped, desperate. Devi wondered what she was looking at, and then wondered why the artist would want to capture such an uncomfortable image. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But there was something off about him. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but only if the artist wasn’t very good at capturing likenesses. But if it wasn’t him, who could it be? “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? We never checked out the rooms to the right of the entryway. We could make time to squeeze in a few quick shots.” Not a man. Not a ghost. Not a demon. A spectre from her mother’s stories, glimpsed through a door two girls should never have been peeking through. Her mother never could describe him, just the way he made her feel. Terrified. She stepped closer to the painting, gazing at his faded eyes, and she could almost hear something. Chanting. No. Lyrics. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. As she reached for her equipment, a bit of the faded paint flecked off of the portrait, onto her sleeve. Not paint, at least not oil paint, but something else. Devi looked closer at the painting of the man, and saw that it had been smeared with something to purposefully cover his features. But if it was coming off, maybe it could be wiped away? She knew she shouldn’t touch the painting, but it had already been vandalized, and she needed to see him. She needed to see the monster her mother had seen. The touched the man’s face, where his jaw should have been, and was surprised that the paint was warm. Like skin. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members covered their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Devi heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, and Devi thought she might puke and found herself actually focusing on the sound for some kind of constant in the chaos. She picked up noises that sounded familiar, snatches of family melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Devi to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Someone Saved My Life Tonight]]“Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. She wasn’t sure what she had been expecting. That was a lie. Some sign of her mother. But the tour was almost over and there was nothing. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]] “Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. She wasn’t sure what she had been expecting. That was a lie. Some sign of her mother. But the tour was almost over and there was nothing. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (with Diary from The Fountain of Life and A Constellation)]] Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” Devi heard Nellie huff as she scuffed the tile with the toe of her shoe. Probably wondering why West was whispering with her instead of filming the star of the show. Devi shook her head. “Guys!” Nellie called to them. “We have more work to do.” [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (with Diary from The Fountain of Life and The Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (with Diary)]]Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” Devi heard Nellie huff as she scuffed the tile with the toe of her shoe.
