Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. She was getting tired, and if West and Nellie didn’t agree, she didn’t have the energy to argue. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi. “No,” West laughed. “That’s the other-” “Shut up, West,” Nellie huffed, smiling at Devi. “What do you mean?” Devi pointed to the indents. “On the one woman’s shoulder,” she said. “They’re not dots, they’re diamonds, like the sculptures in A Constellation. They’re even spaced out the same way.” West filmed the indents, the panned across the gallery. “Great catch, Devi!” Nellie grinned and Devi blushed. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement with Locket)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement with Locket)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. She giggled and was dismayed that she burped, tasting the burn of the scotch. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. The indents were diamonds, spread out like the sculptures in A Constellation. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Triad)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from A Constellation)]]Devi stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. She recognized them all from her mother’s stories, but they were easy enough to identify, even if she didn’t have her mother’s descriptions to prompt her. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Devi knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders. It reminded her of Nellie’s cut, but a little more pampered. Self-conscious. Dawn lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Devi could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. The artist apparently chose to capture him in a precarious moment. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro almost reminded her of Sly Stone. Someone playing at being as cool as Sly. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt and bore a cruel sneer. He bullied Tara, her mother said. They would avoid him at the parties. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls that looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. Devi knew that she was much more comfortable in jeans, was always the most under-dressed at the parties, but Bradford’s lovers must have picked this look for her. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, uneasy… Afraid? The looked caught, trapped, desperate. Devi wondered what she was looking at, and then wondered why the artist would want to capture such an uncomfortable image. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But there was something off about him. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but only if the artist wasn’t very good at capturing likenesses. But if it wasn’t him, who could it be? “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? I think we need to get Devi to bed.” Devi’s eyes caught on the locket at Dawn’s neck. She stepped closer to the painting, checking that, yes, it was the locket in her briefcase! She pulled it out to be sure, grasping the warm jewellery in her hand, and she heard a tune whispering in her headphones. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. She reached for her equipment and nearly lost her grip on the necklace. The chain swung loose and the locket struck the painting, chipping the color from Dawn's chest. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members covered their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones, and the locket was hot against her cheek. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Devi heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, and Devi thought she might puke and found herself actually focusing on the sound for some kind of constant in the chaos. She picked up noises that sounded familiar, snatches of family melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Devi to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Born to Run.]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. She giggled and was dismayed that she burped, tasting the burn of the scotch. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. The indents were diamonds, spread out like the sculptures in A Constellation. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Triad)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from A Constellation)]]Devi stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. She recognized them all from her mother’s stories, but they were easy enough to identify, even if she didn’t have her mother’s descriptions to prompt her. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Devi knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders. It reminded her of Nellie’s cut, but a little more pampered. Self-conscious. Dawn lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Devi could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. The artist apparently chose to capture him in a precarious moment. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro almost reminded her of Sly Stone. Someone playing at being as cool as Sly. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt and bore a cruel sneer. He bullied Tara, her mother said. They would avoid him at the parties. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls that looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. Devi knew that she was much more comfortable in jeans, was always the most under-dressed at the parties, but Bradford’s lovers must have picked this look for her. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, uneasy… Afraid? The looked caught, trapped, desperate. Devi wondered what she was looking at, and then wondered why the artist would want to capture such an uncomfortable image. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But there was something off about him. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but only if the artist wasn’t very good at capturing likenesses. But if it wasn’t him, who could it be? “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? I think we need to get Devi to bed.” Devi’s eyes caught on the locket at Dawn’s neck. She stepped closer to the painting, checking that, yes, it was the locket in her briefcase! She pulled it out to be sure, grasping the warm jewellery in her hand, and she heard a tune whispering in her headphones. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. She reached for her equipment and nearly lost her grip on the necklace. The chain swung loose and the locket struck the painting, chipping the color from Dawn's chest. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members covered their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones, and the locket was hot against her cheek. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Devi heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, and Devi thought she might puke and found herself actually focusing on the sound for some kind of constant in the chaos. She picked up noises that sounded familiar, snatches of family melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Devi to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Born to Run]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. She giggled and was dismayed that she burped, tasting the burn of the scotch. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. The indents were diamonds, spread out like the sculptures in A Constellation. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary from The Triad)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary from A Constellation)]]Devi stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. She recognized them all from her mother’s stories, but they were easy enough to identify, even if she didn’t have her mother’s descriptions to prompt her. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Devi knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders. It reminded her of Nellie’s cut, but a little more pampered. Self-conscious. Dawn lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Devi could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. The artist apparently chose to capture him in a precarious moment. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro almost reminded her of Sly Stone. Someone playing at being as cool as Sly. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt and bore a cruel sneer. He bullied Tara, her mother said. They would avoid him at the parties. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls that looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. Devi knew that she was much more comfortable in jeans, was always the most under-dressed at the parties, but Bradford’s lovers must have picked this look for her. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, uneasy… Afraid? The looked caught, trapped, desperate. Devi wondered what she was looking at, and then wondered why the artist would want to capture such an uncomfortable image. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But there was something off about him. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but only if the artist wasn’t very good at capturing likenesses. But if it wasn’t him, who could it be? “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? I think we need to get Devi to bed.” Not a man. Not a ghost. Not a demon. A spectre from her mother’s stories, glimpsed through a door two girls should never have been peeking through. Her mother never could describe him, just the way he made her feel. Terrified. She stepped closer to the painting, gazing at his faded eyes, and she could almost hear something. Chanting. No. Lyrics. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. As she reached for her equipment, a bit of the faded paint flecked off of the portrait, onto her sleeve. Not paint, at least not oil paint, but something else. Devi looked closer at the painting of the man, and saw that it had been smeared with something to purposefully cover his features. But if it was coming off, maybe it could be wiped away? She knew she shouldn’t touch the painting, but it had already been vandalized, and she needed to see him. She needed to see the monster her mother had seen. She touched the man’s face, where his jaw should have been, and was surprised that the paint was warm. Like skin. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members covered their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Devi heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, and Devi thought she might puke and found herself actually focusing on the sound for some kind of constant in the chaos. She picked up noises that sounded familiar, snatches of family melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Devi to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Down Down]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. She giggled and was dismayed that she burped, tasting the burn of the scotch. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. The indents were diamonds, spread out like the sculptures in A Constellation. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Triad)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 1 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from A Constellation)]]Devi stepped up to the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but the colors were flat and dull, the already dark picture faded further from neglect and exposure. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West mused, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. She recognized them all from her mother’s stories, but they were easy enough to identify, even if she didn’t have her mother’s descriptions to prompt her. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were still so bright blue under her fringe, bright enough that they could have been glistening with tears. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that Devi knew were popular in the peasant-dress fashion of the time. It was cut low in a deep sweep over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair was just a shade darker than her honey-tanned skin and fell in loose curls down her shoulders. It reminded her of Nellie’s cut, but a little more pampered. Self-conscious. Dawn lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, but Devi could just see a hint of ballet-slipper style shoes peeking out from under her, the same pale blue as her dress. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood beside Dawn, side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise. The artist apparently chose to capture him in a precarious moment. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves that put Dawn’s billowing dress to shame and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro almost reminded her of Sly Stone. Someone playing at being as cool as Sly. He rested one hand against the ruffles of his shirt and bore a cruel sneer. He bullied Tara, her mother said. They would avoid him at the parties. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls that looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. Devi knew that she was much more comfortable in jeans, was always the most under-dressed at the parties, but Bradford’s lovers must have picked this look for her. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, uneasy… Afraid? The looked caught, trapped, desperate. Devi wondered what she was looking at, and then wondered why the artist would want to capture such an uncomfortable image. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But there was something off about him. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but only if the artist wasn’t very good at capturing likenesses. But if it wasn’t him, who could it be? “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? I think we need to get Devi to bed.” Not a man. Not a ghost. Not a demon. A spectre from her mother’s stories, glimpsed through a door two girls should never have been peeking through. Her mother never could describe him, just the way he made her feel. Terrified. She stepped closer to the painting, gazing at his faded eyes, and she could almost hear something. Chanting. No. Lyrics. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. As she reached for her equipment, a bit of the faded paint flecked off of the portrait, onto her sleeve. Not paint, at least not oil paint, but something else. Devi looked closer at the painting of the man, and saw that it had been smeared with something to purposefully cover his features. But if it was coming off, maybe it could be wiped away? She knew she shouldn’t touch the painting, but it had already been vandalized, and she needed to see him. She needed to see the monster her mother had seen. She touched the man’s face, where his jaw should have been, and was surprised that the paint was warm. Like skin. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members covered their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Devi heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, and Devi thought she might puke and found herself actually focusing on the sound for some kind of constant in the chaos. She picked up noises that sounded familiar, snatches of family melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Devi to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Down Down.]]“Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her hazy thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. He frowned like he didn’t quite believe her. She didn’t quite believe herself. She tried to swallow down the choking feeling in her throat that told her she had failed. The tour was almost over and there was no sign of her mother. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket)]] “Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her hazy thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. He frowned like he didn’t quite believe her. She didn’t quite believe herself. She tried to swallow down the choking feeling in her throat that told her she had failed. The tour was almost over and there was no sign of her mother. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Triad)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket)]] “Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her hazy thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. He frowned like he didn’t quite believe her. She didn’t quite believe herself. She tried to swallow down the choking feeling in her throat that told her she had failed. The tour was almost over and there was no sign of her mother. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from A Constellation)]] [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket)]] Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. She giggled and was dismayed that she burped, tasting the burn of the scotch. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. The indents were diamonds, spread out like the sculptures in A Constellation. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and The Triad)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and A Constellation)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and The Triad)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Triad and A Constellation)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and A Constellation)]]Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Triad and A Constellation)]]Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” “I thought I would find her,” Devi hiccupped. “Find who?” West asked. “My mother,” Devi whispered, and West’s eyebrows shot up. “She disappeared here. I wanted her to… reappear. A magic trick. Bradford was all about magic, right?” West shook his head slowly. “Devi, you should have told us.” “Guys!” Nellie called to them. “We have more work to do.” West hesitated. “We’ll talk about this when you’re… feeling better.” [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket)]] Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” “I thought I would find her,” Devi hiccupped. “Find who?” West asked. “My mother,” Devi whispered, and West’s eyebrows shot up. “She disappeared here. I wanted her to… reappear. A magic trick. Bradford was all about magic, right?” West shook his head slowly. “Devi, you should have told us.” “Guys!” Nellie called to them. “We have more work to do.” West hesitated. “We’ll talk about this when you’re… feeling better.” [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket from The Triad and A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Locket)]]Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” “I thought I would find her,” Devi hiccupped. “Find who?” West asked. “My mother,” Devi whispered, and West’s eyebrows shot up. “She disappeared here. I wanted her to… reappear. A magic trick. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls that looked unruly even in a carefully manicured portrait. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn, her deep brown eyes gazing not at the viewer but off to the side somewhere, uneasy… Afraid? The looked caught, trapped, desperate. Devi wondered what she was looking at, and then wondered why the artist would want to capture such an uncomfortable image. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded worse than any of the other figures. He was clearly a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting one hand on Tara’s shoulder. But there was something off about him. “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but only if the artist wasn’t very good at capturing likenesses. But if it wasn’t him, who could it be? “Right,” said West. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go? I think we need to get Devi to bed.” Not a man. Not a ghost. Not a demon. A spectre from her mother’s stories, glimpsed through a door two girls should never have been peeking through. Her mother never could describe him, just the way he made her feel. Terrified. She stepped closer to the painting, gazing at his faded eyes, and she could almost hear something. Chanting. No. Lyrics. “Hey, guys,” said Devi. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” “Then turn it up!” West laughed. As she reached for her equipment, a bit of the faded paint flecked off of the portrait, onto her sleeve. Not paint, at least not oil paint, but something else. Devi looked closer at the painting of the man, and saw that it had been smeared with something to purposefully cover his features. But if it was coming off, maybe it could be wiped away? She knew she shouldn’t touch the painting, but it had already been vandalized, and she needed to see him. She needed to see the monster her mother had seen. She touched the man’s face, where his jaw should have been, and was surprised that the paint was warm. Like skin. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members covered their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and Devi heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building, and Devi thought she might puke and found herself actually focusing on the sound for some kind of constant in the chaos. She picked up noises that sounded familiar, snatches of family melodies and lyrics, and she realized it was not senseless, but songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for Devi to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Evil Woman]]“Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her hazy thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. He frowned like he didn’t quite believe her. She didn’t quite believe herself. She tried to swallow down the choking feeling in her throat that told her she had failed. The tour was almost over and there was no sign of her mother. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]“Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her hazy thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. He frowned like he didn’t quite believe her. She didn’t quite believe herself. She tried to swallow down the choking feeling in her throat that told her she had failed. The tour was almost over and there was no sign of her mother. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Triad)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]“Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her hazy thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. He frowned like he didn’t quite believe her. She didn’t quite believe herself. She tried to swallow down the choking feeling in her throat that told her she had failed. The tour was almost over and there was no sign of her mother. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from A Constellation)]] [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. She giggled and was dismayed that she burped, tasting the burn of the scotch. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. The indents were diamonds, spread out like the sculptures in A Constellation. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and The Triad)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and A Constellation)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and The Triad)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Triad and A Constellation)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and A Constellation)]]Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. She giggled and was dismayed that she burped, tasting the burn of the scotch. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. The indents were diamonds, spread out like the sculptures in A Constellation. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Triad and A Constellation)]] Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” “I thought I would find her,” Devi hiccupped. “Find who?” West asked. “My mother,” Devi whispered, and West’s eyebrows shot up. “She disappeared here. I wanted her to… reappear. A magic trick. Bradford was all about magic, right?” West shook his head slowly. “Devi, you should have told us.” “Guys!” Nellie called to them. “We have more work to do.” West hesitated. “We’ll talk about this when you’re… feeling better.” [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and The Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” “I thought I would find her,” Devi hiccupped. “Find who?” West asked. “My mother,” Devi whispered, and West’s eyebrows shot up. “She disappeared here. I wanted her to… reappear. A magic trick. Bradford was all about magic, right?” West shook his head slowly. “Devi, you should have told us.” “Guys!” Nellie called to them. “We have more work to do.” West hesitated. “We’ll talk about this when you’re… feeling better.” [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Triad and A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]]Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” “I thought I would find her,” Devi hiccupped. “Find who?” West asked. “My mother,” Devi whispered, and West’s eyebrows shot up. “She disappeared here. I wanted her to… reappear. A magic trick. Bradford was all about magic, right?” West shook his head slowly. “Devi, you should have told us.” “Guys!” Nellie called to them. “We have more work to do.” West hesitated. “We’ll talk about this when you’re… feeling better.” [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket from The Fountain of Life and A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Locket)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room.
