But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Tipsy with Diary)]]“Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her hazy thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. He frowned like he didn’t quite believe her. She didn’t quite believe herself. She tried to swallow down the choking feeling in her throat that told her she had failed. The tour was almost over and there was no sign of her mother. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary)]]“Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her hazy thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. He frowned like he didn’t quite believe her. She didn’t quite believe herself. She tried to swallow down the choking feeling in her throat that told her she had failed. The tour was almost over and there was no sign of her mother. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Triad)]] [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary)]]“Still with us, Devi?” West asked. Devi shook herself from her hazy thoughts and gave West a thumbs up. He frowned like he didn’t quite believe her. She didn’t quite believe herself. She tried to swallow down the choking feeling in her throat that told her she had failed. The tour was almost over and there was no sign of her mother. She was just one guest of many, one more memory haunting the Bennington mansion. [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary)]]Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. She giggled and was dismayed that she burped, tasting the burn of the scotch. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. The indents were diamonds, spread out like the sculptures in A Constellation. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Fountain of Life and The Triad)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Fountain of Life and A Constellation)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Fountain of Life and The Triad)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Triad and A Constellation)]]Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. She giggled and was dismayed that she burped, tasting the burn of the scotch. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. The indents were diamonds, spread out like the sculptures in A Constellation. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Triad and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “Feels like a sad lesson at the end of a dark fairy tale.” “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “And, yeah, that basically covers the point it was going for.” “Get a drink in her and suddenly she’s the queen of sass,” Nellie said, playfully raising her eyebrow. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip. The only design in the fountain was a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. “Do you think we shouldn’t touch the bowl?” West asked. “I think we shouldn’t have climbed on the bench, but here we are,” said Nellie. Devi watched as Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. She didn’t stop her. The fountain was meant to be interactive. Maybe her mother had done the same thing, run her hand on that same deep curve. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Fountain of Life and A Constellation)]]Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” “I thought I would find her,” Devi hiccupped. “Find who?” West asked. “My mother,” Devi whispered, and West’s eyebrows shot up. “She disappeared here. I wanted her to… reappear. A magic trick. Bradford was all about magic, right?” West shook his head slowly. “Devi, you should have told us.” “Guys!” Nellie called to them. “We have more work to do.” West hesitated. “We’ll talk about this when you’re… feeling better.” [[A Constellation - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Fountain of Life and The Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary)]]Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” “I thought I would find her,” Devi hiccupped. “Find who?” West asked. “My mother,” Devi whispered, and West’s eyebrows shot up. “She disappeared here. I wanted her to… reappear. A magic trick. Bradford was all about magic, right?” West shook his head slowly. “Devi, you should have told us.” “Guys!” Nellie called to them. “We have more work to do.” West hesitated. “We’ll talk about this when you’re… feeling better.” [[The Triad - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Fountain of Life and A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary)]] Devi felt West’s hand on her shoulder. “We can leave now,” he whispered. “We have enough footage.” “I thought I would find her,” Devi hiccupped. “Find who?” West asked. “My mother,” Devi whispered, and West’s eyebrows shot up. “She disappeared here. I wanted her to… reappear. A magic trick. Bradford was all about magic, right?” West shook his head slowly. “Devi, you should have told us.” “Guys!” Nellie called to them. “We have more work to do.” West hesitated. “We’ll talk about this when you’re… feeling better.” [[The Fountain of Life - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary from The Triad and A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. From a bird’s eye view they would look like six diamonds, stretching towards the sky. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked. “I’ve never understood modern art,” Nellie sighed, staring at the largest block. “It’s very square. Rectangular.” “It makes me feel… angular,” West nodded. “Stop making fun of the art!” Devi giggled. “At least this block’s big,” Nellie said. “Took some expense to make it. I appreciate the effort.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (Basement Tipsy with Diary)]]Devi’s mother had not told her much about Bradfords’ lovers, so she could not guess if they had commissioned the sculpture of themselves or if it was Bradford’s decision. A statement to his devotion, to all three of them? Or a version of them he could possess and preserve? The smooth marble figures were dancing, in theory, but Devi was struck by their stillness. A mockery of moving on. She giggled and was dismayed that she burped, tasting the burn of the scotch. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. Devi understood why he had guessed that, but she was sure her instinct was right. Even if she had no proof. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. Bradford wouldn’t honor any other goddesses here but the ones he had worshipped. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi said, keeping her theory to herself. If West and Nellie didn’t agree, she was too tipsy to argue her point. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. The women’s faces were mostly smooth moon-round planes with the faintest indents for eyes. All three had long hair, one in loose illusions of curls, one two long braids, and one done in an intricate updo. One statue’s delicate fingers held up her skirt. Another statue’s dress appeared to be falling from her shoulder, revealing impressions as faint as the eye indents, six distinct pressure points like a smattering of stars. “It’s A Constellation,” said Devi, but the words slurred together. The indents were diamonds, spread out like the sculptures in A Constellation. But she could see Nellie and West share a judgmental look, so she just clenched her jaw and didn’t try to explain the connection between the art pieces. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - Devi's Tour (USR Tipsy with Diary)]]“Absolutely not,” said Nellie. She pulled a pencil out of her bag. “You are not going to write on a dead woman’s poem!” West protested. “Some of the words are faded,” Nellie insisted. “I’m just going to write them in so they show up on camera.” “How will you know what the right words are?” Devi asked. “Well, the verses are haikus,” said Nellie. “And you can kind of see what the words should be. We’ll just make it fit the pattern. Here’s the first verse.” //Did I die that night? All the stars went out at once I saw the moon _____// [[winking - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[warping - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] [[weep - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]] “Absolutely not,” said Nellie. She pulled a pencil out of her bag. “You are not going to write on a dead woman’s poem!” West protested. “Some of the words are faded,” Nellie insisted. “I’m just going to write them in so they show up on camera.” “How will you know what the right words are?” Devi asked. “Well, the verses are haikus,” said Nellie. “And you can kind of see what the words should be. We’ll just make it fit the pattern. Here’s the first verse.” //Did I die that night? Nellie brushed the ash off her hands, sure that Dawn’s poem just concluded in a supernatural way that neither of her crewmates bothered to notice, and followed. [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]]“Almost…” said Devi. 123 45□ 786 [[slide 6 up - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]] [[slide 3 down - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room)]]After Devi slid the last tile into place, she heard a gentle click and the top of the box popped open. “Ew, oh my god, oh my god,” said Nellie, peering over Devi’s shoulder. “What is that?” asked West. “Teeth,” said Devi. There were two teeth, darkened with age, tapping together in the tiny box. “My mom used to keep my baby teeth,” West said. “These aren’t baby teeth,” said Devi. They looked like adult molars. Why was there a puzzle box with two adult molars in Tara’s bedroom? “This is why you don’t do math!” said Nellie, stomping out of the room. Devi closed the lid shut, leaving the teeth and the mystery behind her as she and West followed Nellie. Nellie's Tour (Cont. with Ribbon)]]“Okay,” said Nellie. “I don’t get it either,” said Devi. “Guys,” said West. “Shh.” £^: -|[:_ “+: £+\~_> £| .~<< [: THE WOMEN ARE TRYING [[TO SAVE ME - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]] [[TO KILL ME - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - Devi's Tour]]“What do you think it means?” Devi asked. “THE WOMEN ARE TRYING TO KILL ME,” Nellie said. “I mean… is that vague?” “Yes,” Devi huffed. “Is he talking about his sisters? Bradford’s lovers? Some other women completely?” “Pretty cool, though,” said West. “We have different definitions of cool,” Devi laughed. “Let’s get out of here. That message is freaking me out.” [[Library - Devi's Tour]] “I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - Devi's Tour]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - Devi's Tour (Cont. from USR)]]“What do you think it means?” Devi asked. “THE WOMEN ARE TRYING TO KILL ME,” Nellie said. “I mean… is that vague?” “Yes,” Devi huffed. “Is he talking about his sisters?
