That message is freaking me out.” [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. with Ribbon)]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. with Ribbon)]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]]“What do you think it means?” Devi asked. “THE WOMEN ARE TRYING TO KILL ME,” Nellie said. “I mean… is that vague?” “Yes,” Devi huffed. “Is he talking about his sisters? Bradford’s lovers? Some other women completely?” “Pretty cool, though,” said West. “We have different definitions of cool,” Devi laughed. “Let’s get out of here. That message is freaking me out.” [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - Nellie's Tour (Cont. from Groove Room with Ribbon)]]“The locket is hot,” Devi gasped, holding it by the chain away from her face. “Why is the locket hot?” “We are in a fragile building and just experienced an earthquake, we can investigate a hot locket after we get out of this mansion!” West said, grabbing Devi’s hand. Nellie chased after them as they ran through the garden, the swirling stones of the path a mess from the recent upheaval. They were leaving. Devi had no more answers about her mother’s disappearance than when she had arrived. She squeezed her eyes shut trying to hold in tears and heard something strange, coming from… “Wait!” she said, digging her heels into the loose stones, skidding for a moment before West stopped dragging her forward, and Nellie collided into his back with a soft huff. Devi pulled on her headphones, and sure enough, her mic was picking up static, sprinkled with words. //Help Her Where// Devi turned slowly, frustrated as she could not locate the source, more frustrated by the impatient murmurings of her crewmates that the headphones couldn’t quite block out completely. And then she realized she could not pinpoint the sound because it was not coming from around her, not from the gallery or gardens of mansion, but from the burning locket still dangling in her grasp. “The locket is talking to me,” Devi said slowly, pulling off her headphones. West and Nellie stared at her. And then Nellie grinned. “Amazing!” she squealed, sweeping Devi into a hug, hissing when the locket nicked her hand. “Let’s go! We can run all sorts of tests back at the studio-” “No.” West's jaw opened then snapped shut. “What are you talking about, Devi?” Nellie asked, still smiling, but it was a nervous smile now. “I came here to find one specific ghost,” she said, teeth clenched against the truth still. “And I’m not leaving until I make contact.” The ground began to rumble again. “Okay,” West said, stuttering. “Okay…” “Not okay!” Nellie shouted, bracing herself. “Devi, we have to go. We have to take the ghost we have and go!” [[Contact Mother in Séance Room]] “The Séance Room is right by the entrance,” Devi insisted, already starting to run, followed by West and Nellie. “If you’re trying to reach a specific ghost, that’s the place to do it. I’ll just try to make contact for a second…” “Isn’t the Séance Room a Séance Pit now?” West asked, keeping up with her as they took shaky strides through Bradford’s room, into the hallway. “I… yes!” Devi said, gasping for breath as they ran on the ground that trembled more violently the deeper they went into the house. “But I have to try something.” She could hear Nellie arguing with West, but she could not concentrate on them. She kept one of her headphones over her ear, listening to the static words getting picked up from the locket, listening for any other voice that might be caught by the mic or just in the halls. Her mother said she was coming here. If she had left, she would have come back to Devi, so she must still be here. She must be trying to reach out, if only Devi knew how to reach back. Devi skidded to a halt in front of the Séance Room door. She tried the handle but it was stuck, locked, even as the old wood rattled in its frame. It was fragile, though. She could break it. She could ask West, but what if he said no, tried to convince her this was a bad idea, because it was a bad idea, but she was already backing up for a running start… And she was suddenly airborne. It took her a moment to realize that West had picked her up and thrown her over his shoulder. She was too shocked to move until they were already out the door. “Sorry, Devi,” he said, tossing her into the backseat. “But I think you’ve lost it a little bit.” “No!” Devi yelled as he slammed the door shut. She heard the lock click in place before she could grab the handle. West hopped into the driver’s seat, Nellie jumping in beside him. “Sorry, Devi,” Nellie said, though she didn’t sound it. “We couldn’t let you fall to your death and take..” //And take the locket with you.// The car tires screeched on the pavement as West drove them away. Devi held the locket tight in her palm, the heat almost unbearable against her skin. But the pain was nothing compared to the ache in her chest as she watched her mother’s final resting place shrink smaller and smaller into the distance behind them. [[End of Track]] “The locket is hot,” Devi gasped, holding it by the chain away from her face. “Why is the locket hot?” “We are in a fragile building and just experienced an earthquake, we can investigate a hot locket after we get out of this mansion!” West said, grabbing Devi’s hand. Nellie chased after them as they ran through the garden, the swirling stones of the path a mess from the recent upheaval. They were leaving. Devi had no more answers about her mother’s disappearance than when she had arrived. She squeezed her eyes shut trying to hold in tears and heard something strange, coming from… “Wait!” she said, digging her heels into the loose stones, skidding for a moment before West stopped dragging her forward, and Nellie collided into his back with a soft huff. Devi pulled on her headphones, and sure enough, her mic was picking up static, sprinkled with words. //Help Her Where// Devi turned slowly, frustrated as she could not locate the source, more frustrated by the impatient murmurings of her crewmates that the headphones couldn’t quite block out completely. And then she realized she could not pinpoint the sound because it was not coming from around her, not from the gallery or gardens of mansion, but from the burning locket still dangling in her grasp. “The locket is talking to me,” Devi said slowly, pulling off her headphones. West and Nellie stared at her. And then Nellie grinned. “Amazing!” she squealed, sweeping Devi into a hug, hissing when the locket nicked her hand. “Let’s go! We can run all sorts of tests back at the studio-” “No.” West's jaw opened then snapped shut. “What are you talking about, Devi?” Nellie asked, still smiling, but it was a nervous smile now. “I came here to find one specific ghost,” she said, teeth clenched against the truth still. “And I’m not leaving until I make contact.” The ground began to rumble again. “Okay,” West said, stuttering. “Okay…” “Not okay!” Nellie shouted, bracing herself. “Devi, we have to go. We have to take the ghost we have and go!” [[Contact Mother in Séance Room]] [[Contact Mother in Basement]]“The basement is right inside,” Devi insisted, already starting to run, followed by West and Nellie. “We all saw that weird altar. I’m betting the Benningtons used it to contact spirits.” “Yeah, contact them in a way that involves a //sacrificial altar//,” Nellie protested as they ran into Bradford’s room. “Devi, you might be right, but there is no way we’re going down into a basement during an earthquake,” West said, grabbing Devi’s arm after she threw open the wardrobe door. “You guys don’t have to go anywhere,” Devi said, wrenching herself free. “We’re not waiting for you during a natural disaster,” West said, and Devi shrugged, pulled the keys out of her briefcase and tossed them to him. “You can’t just take…” Nellie’s voice trailed off and her face was tense with worry. For a moment Devi faltered, until she realized Nellie was not looking at her, but at the locket in her hand. “Whatever,” Devi grimaced, shoving the locket into West’s hands. “Good to know your priorities.” She still hoped she would hear their footsteps following her as she ran down the steps with bleary eyes, but there was only silence behind her. She was too focused on her disappointment to notice at first how bright the stairway was now, or how the ground down here did not seem to be shaking at all. But the biggest surprise was the man who appeared to have been waiting for her, sitting cross-legged on the altar. Devi gasped, and his head tilted slightly in her direction, a smile fluttering on his lips as she stepped closer, slowly. The man was handsome, Devi supposed, to those gothic girls who lusted after vampires. His skin was a little too pale, the color of someone naturally pale who has not seen sunlight in a very long time. His eyes were dark, a cloudy hazel that shifted between colors. He blinked slowly and Devi realized he could not see her, only hear her, reacting slightly to each soft breath, each footfall. His black hair was thick, pushed back from his forehead. He looked like a rockstar, or pseudo-punk, but too neatly put together for his rebellion to be anything but a performance. His black t-shirt and jeans were tight on his skinny frame, his studded thick boots looking too heavy for his body. Devi noted six distinct freckles that crossed his cheeks. He sat, waiting, with just a slight impatience. Waiting on the altar… to be sacrificed? No. For a sacrifice. Devi’s blood ran cold. “I don’t know you,” the man said. “Are you a gift from Tara? Is she here?” A gift? A sacrifice. At once, every story of her mother’s was tinged in red. People coming to the Bennington parties, unsuspecting people like her mother, joining in Bradford’s exploration of the occult, perhaps descending to his secret room once they were fully initiated, and then… Why would her mother come back if she had managed to get away? “Not very talkative, are you?” the man asked. “Did Tara give you… Did Tara sacrifice my mother to you?” Devi asked. “Her name was Amitava.” The man cocked his head. The man's grin stretched the stars on her cheek. “Do you want to see her again?” Longing like a fist gripped Devi’s throat. “Can you show her to me?” “Oh yes,” said the man. “Just stay right there. I know exactly where all of them go.” Devi held still. The man’s eyes went completely black. There was the rush of air, like a vacuum opening into pure space. She gasped, trying to plant herself firmly on the ground, to stay still, but the vacuum did not pull at her bodies. It was tugging at something inside of her. She felt dizzy, and fell to her knees, her vision tripling until it looked like there were three figures looming over her, grinning. “Where…” Devi whispered, her voice sounding so far away. “My mother…” “Oh, you sad little girl,” said the man with the night sky for eyes. “I lied.” The last thing Devi ever heard was laughter like a song made of static. [[End of Track]] “The locket’s hot,” Devi slurred, holding it by the chain away from her face. “Why is the locket hot?” “We are in a fragile building and just experienced an earthquake, we can investigate a hot locket after we get out of this mansion!” West said, grabbing Devi’s hand. Nellie chased after them as they ran through the garden, the swirling stones creating intricate patterns under Devi’s unsteady attention. They were leaving. Devi had no more answers about her mother’s disappearance than when she had arrived. She squeezed her eyes shut trying to hold in tears and heard something strange, coming from… “Wait!” she said, digging her heels into the loose stones, skidding for a moment before West stopped dragging her forward, and Nellie collided into his back with a soft huff. Devi pulled on her headphones, and sure enough, her mic was picking up static, sprinkled with words. //Help Her Where// Devi turned slowly, frustrated as she could not locate the source, more frustrated by the impatient murmurings of her crewmates that the headphones couldn’t quite block out completely. And then she realized she could not pinpoint the sound because it was not coming from around her, not from the gallery or gardens of mansion, but from the burning locket still dangling in her grasp. “The locket’s talking,” Devi said slowly, pulling off her headphones. West and Nellie stared at her. “Devi, it’s not that I don’t believe you,” said Nellie. “It’s just that you’re… drunk. And I don’t believe a locket’s talking to you.” “Nellie,” West started, but didn’t seem to have anything else to say. “Locket’s talking!” Devi insisted, then shook her head. “Doesn’t matter. Wrong ghost. Not my mom.” “What?” Nellie gasped. “Oh shit,” said West. “My mom’s here, somewhere,” Devi mumbled. “Her ghost. I’m not leaving ‘til I talk to her.” “Okay,” West said, stuttering. “Okay…” “Not okay!” Nellie shouted, bracing herself. “Devi, we have to go! Let me help you.” [[Let Nellie Help You]] “The locket’s hot,” Devi slurred, holding it by the chain away from her face. “Why is the locket hot?” “We are in a fragile building and just experienced an earthquake, we can investigate a hot locket after we get out of this mansion!” West said, grabbing Devi’s hand. Nellie chased after them as they ran through the garden, the swirling stones creating intricate patterns under Devi’s unsteady attention. They were leaving. Devi had no more answers about her mother’s disappearance than when she had arrived. She squeezed her eyes shut trying to hold in tears and heard something strange, coming from… “Wait!” she said, digging her heels into the loose stones, skidding for a moment before West stopped dragging her forward, and Nellie collided into his back with a soft huff. Devi pulled on her headphones, and sure enough, her mic was picking up static, sprinkled with words. //Help Her Where// Devi turned slowly, frustrated as she could not locate the source, more frustrated by the impatient murmurings of her crewmates that the headphones couldn’t quite block out completely. And then she realized she could not pinpoint the sound because it was not coming from around her, not from the gallery or gardens of mansion, but from the burning locket still dangling in her grasp. “The locket’s talking,” Devi said slowly, pulling off her headphones. West and Nellie stared at her. “Devi, it’s not that I don’t believe you,” said Nellie. “It’s just that you’re… drunk. And I don’t believe a locket’s talking to you.” “Nellie,” West started, but didn’t seem to have anything else to say. “Locket’s talking!” Devi insisted, then shook her head. “Doesn’t matter. Wrong ghost. Not my mom.” “What?” Nellie gasped. “Oh shit,” said West. “My mom’s here, somewhere,” Devi mumbled. “Her ghost. I’m not leaving ‘til I talk to her.” “Okay,” West said, stuttering. “Okay…” “Not okay!” Nellie shouted, bracing herself. “Devi, we have to go! Let me help you.” [[Let Nellie Help You]] [[Refuse Nellie's Help]] “Fine…” Devi sighed. She was resigned to letting Nellie take her hand. But instead of reaching for her, Nellie reached for the locket. Devi pulled it away from her, holding it close to her chest. “Help me?” she laughed, hearing the hysterical edge to her voice. “Or help yourself to the locket?” “What is wrong with you, Nellie?” West asked. Before Nellie could explain herself, the ground started shaking. “Whatever!” Nellie shouted. “It doesn’t matter. Let’s just leave.” “If it doesn’t matter, I’m putting it back,” Devi hissed. “This ghost doesn’t belong to us.” Before West or Nellie could protest, Devi was already sprinting towards the library. The unsteady ground made her feel nauseous, that and the fact that she didn’t find her mom, and Nellie didn’t give a shit about her. She skidded into the library. The globe had fallen on its side, and bottles now rattles against the low sofas. The cloth-bound books were shaking on the shelves. Devi could see the space where the locket belonged. Devi lurched towards it and had a moment of confusion that she was not moving, until she realized Nellie was holding her shoulder. But while she glared at Nellie’s face, Nellie’s eyes were stuck on the locket. Devi pulled herself forward, dragging Nellie with her. “Guys!” West screamed. Devi couldn’t think, so she didn’t try. She just jumped back, tripped over one of the sofas and fell deep into the soft, sinking material. Nellie had more wits about her, so she did take a moment to look at West, to clarify, so she didn’t have time to move before the large, heavy bookshelf crashed down on top of her. “Nellie!” Devi tried to scream, but her voice came out as a whisper. “Maybe she’s okay,” West said. The floor crumpled under the weight of the bookcase, taking it, and whatever was left of Nellie’s body, into the darkness below. A new pit for the Bennington Mansion. “Not okay, not okay,” said West, refusing to come deeper into the deteriorating room, but still holding his arms out to Devi. Devi leapt to him, and somehow he stayed on his feet, pulled her arm over his shoulder, and guided her out of the house. The locket was still in Devi’s hand, even hotter after they burst out into the cool desert air. As West fished the car keys out of Devi’s briefcase, she tried to put together what had just happened. Where there was once Nellie, there was no Nellie anymore. She couldn’t do it, so she stopped trying. As West careened out of the driveway, she told herself she was drunk. She had probably imagined the voice on the static. Maybe she had imagined what had happened to Nellie, too, and she would wake up tomorrow to Nellie’s grumpy morning scowl. Maybe if she could believe it, she would make it so, and West would stop crying as he drove them to safety. [[End of Track]] “No!” Devi shouted. “The basement is right inside. We all saw that weird altar. I’m betting the Benningtons used it to contact spirits.” “Yeah, contact them in a way that involves a //sacrificial altar//,” Nellie protested, but she and West still ran after Devi as she lurched towards Bradford’s room. “Devi, you might be right, but there is no way we’re going down into a basement during an earthquake,” West said, grabbing Devi’s arm after she threw open the wardrobe door. “You guys don’t have to go anywhere,” Devi grumbled, wrenching herself free. The ground shuddered beneath their feet. “Well we can’t let you go down into a basement during an earthquake all by yourself when you’re drunk!” West groaned. “We can’t?” Nellie scoffed, but she followed West who followed Devi down. Devi was sure it wasn’t her state that made the stairway look so bright now, stop the ground from shaking. And when Nellie gasped with her, she was positive that she was not hallucinating the man who appeared to have been waiting for her, sitting cross-legged on the altar. His head tilted slightly in her direction, a smile fluttering on his lips as she tried to step closer, before West put a warning hand on her shoulder. The man was handsome, Devi supposed, to those gothic girls who lusted after vampires. His skin was a little too pale, the color of someone naturally pale who has not seen sunlight in a very long time. His eyes were dark, a cloudy hazel that shifted between colors. His black hair was thick, pushed back from his forehead. He looked like a rockstar, or pseudo-punk, but too neatly put together for his rebellion to be anything but a performance. His black t-shirt and jeans were tight on his skinny frame, his studded thick boots looking too heavy for his body. The freckles on his cheeks swirled gently, but Devi was pretty sure that was her vision doubling. “Dawn, it’s been so long,” the man said. Devi frowned as the man blinked slowly, his eyes as unfocused as hers probably looked. He couldn’t see her. So why would he think she was Dawn? “You’ve got the wrong girl, buddy,” said West, almost puffing up in a pathetic attempt to looking intimidating. “I never forget a soul that was promised to me,” the man sneered, but he seemed a little less certain now. A soul that was promised to him. Devi held the locket out in front of her, and it burned so bright it was practically screaming. Or maybe Devi was hearing those screams in her headphones. West put the pieces together at the same time she did but came up with a plan much faster. He grabbed the locket and tossed it at the man who fumbled to grab it from his seat. Was there something wrong with his legs? Was he stuck? What was he going to do with Dawn’s soul? Devi didn’t have time to answer these questions. West and Nellie had taken her hands and she did her best to keep up with them as they ran up the stairs, the man’s laughter echoing behind them. The ground no longer trembled, but they ran all the way to the car, and West sped them away from whatever creature they had met in the basement. Only when they could not longer see the Bennington Mansion in the rearview mirror did Devi relax, and promptly throw up in her lap. [[End of Track]] “We have to get out of here!” West said, but as Devi started to run with him, she heard something tapping, hard, against her equipment in her briefcase. Her keys? She thought they were safe in one of the pockets. But if they scratched the equipment… yes, they needed to get out of the mansion, and had just experienced an earthquake, but she had spent a lot of money on her gear and she was not going to let it get scratched up. “Hold on!” she said right as they reached the looming cacti, crouching to unzip her bag. “Devi, you better be reacting to the coolest ghost shit you’ve ever heard or I swear to god,” Nellie began, but Devi waved her silent. Her keys were not loose. There was something sticking out of the diary they had found in the Upper Observatory. A piece of glass? She pulled out the diary, opening it up, revealing a round, smooth piece of glass. It looked clear, but as she turned it, even with almost no light to reflect, she saw a full spectrum of colors go bright then fade away. “A compact?” Nellie asked. “It looks like a lens,” said West, pushing up his glasses. A lens. For a telescope? Devi opened the diary to the page where the lens had been hidden. The writing was looping, scrawled, like it had been written by a child. //When the sacrifice to the starless sky is complete, set the key in its place to lock the door to return Him to the void.// Under the scrawled words was a shaky drawing of a large curving V. “Well, that’s ominous,” said Nellie, reading over Devi’s shoulder. “What //key// is it talking about?” West asked, reading over Devi’s other shoulder. She fought the urge to shrug them both off. “I’m more concerned about the //sacrifice//, or the //void//, or //Him//,” Devi said. “But sure, let’s focus on the key thing.” [[The Diary is the Key]] [[The Lens is the Key]] “We have to put the diary back,” said Devi. “Why?” Nellie asked. “That looks like the diary of a crazy person. It’s probably nothing. There’s no sacrifice. Nothing to worry about.” But Devi could still feel the warmth of the paint under her fingers, warm like skin on the cheek of a man who was not a man. Him. The monster from her mother’s stories, the one she had spied on as the Benningtons performed their occult rituals. Instead of finding her mother’s ghost, she had a literal brush with something so much worse. And if the diary was the key, and they had the diary, then it was their job to lock awaywhat they had awakened. What //she// had awakened. “We need to go to the observatory,” said Devi. “Right, because going upstairs in an unstable house during an earthquake is a good idea,” said Nellie. Nellie continued her protests as she followed Devi, but West was silent for once. A part of her was glad to have his support. A bigger part of her wondered how he could be so convinced when he didn’t feel the painting come to life under his hand. When they reached the observatory, Devi paused for a moment before sliding the lens back into its place in the pages of the diary. She tucked it where she found it, behind the side table. “Is that it?” asked Nellie. “Door closed and all? You really think that was the key? I didn’t feel anything change, and I’m really sensitive to these things.” Instead of arguing with her, Devi just snatched the diary back, pulled out the lens, and put it over the telescope. “Happy now?” she asked. “Yes,” said West. Both of the girls stared at him. Devi hadn’t noticed how tense he was until she saw him relax. “West?” asked Devi. “What are you-” “We should get out of here before there are any aftershocks,” West said, cutting her off. Devi nodded, saying nothing, and followed him down the stairs. Nellie tried to catch her eye, but she refused to look at her. Disappointment flooded her. She hadn’t made contact with her mother. And she had a feeling that they had missed out on something fantastic and life-changing, even if it was terrible. Then she felt Nellie’s lips near her ear, heard her whisper: “He’s so moody, I'd rather kill myself and haunt the Bennington Mansion than spend the next three hours in the car with him.” Devi giggled, and in a moment of unearned confidence, slid her hand into Nellie’s, and Nellie did not pull away. Maybe she hadn’t missed out on something fantastic and life-changing after all. [[End of Track]] “We have to put the lens on the telescope,” said Devi. “Why?” Nellie asked. “That looks like the diary of a crazy person. It’s probably nothing. There’s no sacrifice. Nothing to worry about.” But Devi could still feel the warmth of the paint under her fingers, warm like skin on the cheek of a man who was not a man. Him. The monster from her mother’s stories, the one she had spied on as the Benningtons performed their occult rituals. Instead of finding her mother’s ghost, she had a literal brush with something so much worse. And if the lens was the key, and they had the lens, then it was their job to lock awaywhat they had awakened. What she had awakened. “We need to go to the observatory,” said Devi. “Right, because going upstairs in an unstable house during an earthquake is a good idea,” said Nellie. Nellie continued her protests as she followed Devi, but West was silent for once. A part of her was glad to have his support. A bigger part of her wondered how he could be so convinced when he didn’t feel the painting come to life under his hand. “Wait,” said Nellie as Devi approached the telescope. “I’m… I’m getting a weird feeling.” “Me too,” said Devi. “But it’ll be over soon.” She fished the lens out of the diary as Nellie wandered to the telescope, frowning up at the clear glass ceiling. “Does anyone else see that constellation?” Nellie asked. “I’ve never seen it before.” Nellie bent down to look through the telescope, maybe to see the stars more clearly, but Devi didn’t get a chance to ask her what she was looking for. There was a rushing sound, like air through a vacuum, and Nellie disappeared. Devi didn’t even feel the lens slipping through her fingers, but West must have seen it falling, because he lunged and caught it, then covered the end of the telescope. “No!” said Devi, rushing at him, but he held her back, away from the key and the locked door to the void. “She’s… she went somewhere! Open it up, bring her back!” Devi pushed past him, took off the lens, but Nellie didn’t reappear. If this was a door, it only went one way. West still let her try, let the tears roll down her cheeks, before he grabbed her shoulders and gently led her down the stairs. He didn’t try to explain what happened. Devi wasn’t sure if he understood any more than she did. All she knew was that Nellie was gone. And if she had just let the door stay open, if she had not made a mistake she felt a need to fix, if she had not requested they investigate the Bennington Mansion so she could hunt for a ghost she never found, Nellie would still be here. [[End of Track]] “We have to get out of here!” West said, but as Devi started to run with him, she heard something tapping, hard, against her equipment in her briefcase. Her keys? She thought they were safe in one of the pockets. But if they scratched the equipment… yes, they needed to get out of the mansion, and had just experienced an earthquake, but she had spent a lot of money on her gear and she was not going to let it get scratched up. “Hold on!” she said right as they reached the looming cacti, crouching to unzip her bag. “Devi, you get your drunk ass up or I swear to god,” Nellie began, but Devi waved her silent. Her keys were not loose. There was something sticking out of the diary they had found in the Upper Observatory. She pulled out the diary, opening it up, revealing a round, smooth piece of glass. It looked clear, but as she turned it, even with almost no light to reflect, she saw a full spectrum of colors go bright then fade away. “A compact?” Nellie asked. “It looks like a lens,” said West, pushing up his glasses. Devi opened the diary to the page where the lens had been hidden. The writing was looping, scrawled, like it had been written by a child. // When the sacrifice to the starless sky is complete, set the key in its place to lock the door to return Him to the void.// Under the scrawled words was a shaky drawing of a large curving V. “Well, that’s ominous,” said Nellie, reading over Devi’s shoulder. “What key is it talking about?” West asked, reading over Devi’s other shoulder. She fought the urge to shrug them both off. “Guys… no. Shut up,” Devi mumbled. “The sacrifice… The void...” [[Contact Mother Tipsy in Séance Room]] “We have to get out of here!” West said, but as Devi started to run with him, she heard something tapping, hard, against her equipment in her briefcase. Her keys? She thought they were safe in one of the pockets. But if they scratched the equipment… yes, they needed to get out of the mansion, and had just experienced an earthquake, but she had spent a lot of money on her gear and she was not going to let it get scratched up. “Hold on!” she said right as they reached the looming cacti, crouching to unzip her bag. “Devi, you get your drunk ass up or I swear to god,” Nellie began, but Devi waved her silent. Her keys were not loose. There was something sticking out of the diary they had found in the Upper Observatory. She pulled out the diary, opening it up, revealing a round, smooth piece of glass. It looked clear, but as she turned it, even with almost no light to reflect, she saw a full spectrum of colors go bright then fade away. “A compact?” Nellie asked. “It looks like a lens,” said West, pushing up his glasses. Devi opened the diary to the page where the lens had been hidden. The writing was looping, scrawled, like it had been written by a child. // When the sacrifice to the starless sky is complete, set the key in its place to lock the door to return Him to the void.// Under the scrawled words was a shaky drawing of a large curving V. “Well, that’s ominous,” said Nellie, reading over Devi’s shoulder. “What key is it talking about?” West asked, reading over Devi’s other shoulder. She fought the urge to shrug them both off. “Guys… no. Shut up,” Devi mumbled. “The sacrifice… The void...” [[Contact Mother Tipsy in Séance Room]] [[Contact Mother Tipsy in Basement]]“We need to go to the Séance Room,” Devi said, lurching to her feet. “We need to get out of here!” said West as the ground rumbled under their feet. “No!” Devi protested, pulling against him when he grabbed her arm. “My mom… my mom came here. Disappeared here. I thought she died but what if…” The sacrifice… “Why didn’t you tell us?” Nellie asked. “Shit,” said West. Devi sobbed, and Nellie bit her lip, looking pleadingly at West. “Why don’t we give it a shot, West?” Nellie said. “We’ve a ghost investigating team. Something weird is happening. Maybe… Maybe it is Devi’s mom, trying to make contact, and it would suck to leave without any ghostly proof. And something strange happened in the séance room to make it, um, a pit.” “The ground is shaking!” West protested, but Devi was already running as she wiped away her tears, Nellie close behind her. They ran through the mansion, reaching the fragile séance door. West huffed heavily next to her, eyeing her like he wished he could just toss her over his shoulder and carry her into the car, but Nellie warned him off with a glare. “How do we open it?” Devi asked, her voice shaking. West kicked the door and it flew backward, falling into the dark pit behind it. “That works,” said Nellie. “Ok Devi, do you hear anything?” Devi concentrated on the sound coming from her headphones. No static. No music. She got closer to the edge of the pit and peered into the darkness. She could see a faint light below her. And then suddenly a gently sound, like a rushing wind far away. Then voices, crying out, some angry, some singing, and one voice, no louder than the others but so clear to Devi. //Devi, my girl, my darling girl…// “Mom?” Devi asked, softly, and she felt Nellie’s hand on her shoulder, holding her back from the edge of the pit. //My darling girl…// “Mom, what is it?” Devi asked, watching the lights dance on her equipment as she picked up her mother’s voice. //Devi. Run!// The ground shook and then all the voices from that distant wind were covered by that laughter she had heard in the gallery, that terrible inhuman sound. Nellie gasped, pulled Devi back, as the ground where she had stood crumbled into the growing pit. She let her crewmates pull her away, out of the house, but only because her mother had told her to run. Her mother had spoken to her. She did it. She found her. “Holy shit,” said Nellie as they jumped in the car, and West sped them away. “Holy shit!” The world was spinning around Devi, but it wasn’t the alcohol that had made her dizzy. She stared down at her equipment. Her mother’s voice. The mansion was getting smaller and smaller in the rearview and Devi let out a breath of relief. Of triumph. She could decide what she would do with this information when her head was clearer. For now, she would just be happy with what she had accomplished. [[End of Track]] “We need to go to the basement,” Devi said, lurching to her feet. “We need to get out of here!” said West as the ground rumbled under their feet. “No!” Devi protested, pulling against him when he grabbed her arm. “My mom… my mom came here. Disappeared here. I thought she died but what if…” //The sacrifice…// “Why didn’t you tell us?” Nellie asked. “Shit,” said West. Devi sobbed, and Nellie bit her lip, looking pleadingly at West. “Why don’t we give it a shot, West?” Nellie said. “We’ve a ghost investigating team. Something weird is happening. Maybe… Maybe it is Devi’s mom, trying to make contact, and it would suck to leave without any ghostly proof. And that basement was super weird.” “The ground is shaking!” West protested, but Devi was already running as she brushed away her tears, Nellie close behind her. When they got to the wardrobe, West tried to argue again, but Nellie took Devi’s hand and West followed them down. Devi was sure it wasn’t her state that made the stairway look so bright now, stop the ground from shaking. And when Nellie gasped with her, she was positive that she was not hallucinating the man who appeared to have been waiting for her, sitting cross-legged on the altar. His head tilted slightly in her direction, a smile fluttering on his lips as she tried to step closer, before West put a warning hand on her shoulder. The man was handsome, Devi supposed, to those gothic girls who lusted after vampires. His skin was a little too pale, the color of someone naturally pale who has not seen sunlight in a very long time. His eyes were dark, a cloudy hazel that shifted between colors. His black hair was thick, pushed back from his forehead. He looked like a rockstar, or pseudo-punk, but too neatly put together for his rebellion to be anything but a performance. His black t-shirt and jeans were tight on his skinny frame, his studded thick boots looking too heavy for his body. The freckles on his cheeks swirled gently, but Devi was pretty sure that was her vision doubling. “Is that you Tara?” the man asked, his eyes catching the lens in Devi’s hand that was shifting color again. “What trick is this?” “You’ve got the wrong girl, buddy,” said West, almost puffing up in a pathetic attempt to looking intimidating. “My apologies,” said the man, but his eyes never even flicked to West, all of his attention of that little circle of glass. “Be careful, girl. You don’t know what you have there.” Devi’s tongue felt thick and heavy. Nellie spoke for her. “Why don’t you enlighten us, then?” she asked. “What do we have?” “A key,” the man smiled. “Locking the door to everything you could ever want. Break the key, open the door. Wouldn’t that be lovely?” Devi thought she could hear voices whispering in her headphones, but when West and Nellie gasped, she realized they could hear it, too. Some voices were arguing. Some singing. But one… //Devi, my girl, my darling girl…// “Mom?” Devi asked, softly, and the man’s smile grew, distorting his freckles even more. //My darling girl…// “All you have to do is break the key.” It didn’t make sense. Break a key to open a door? It didn’t make sense, but that was her mother’s voice. She wouldn’t lose this opportunity. Devi held the glass above her, reading to send it crashing to the ground, but then West was holding her wrist, pulling the lens from her grasp. “Devi, you’re drunk but you’re not stupid,” West hissed. “Don’t listen to him!” the man screamed. “Don’t you want to see your mother?” His voice hurt her ears now, like the pricks of needles, and she felt her injured hand begin to bleed again. //Devi. Run!// Her mother’s voice was louder than the man’s frustrated growl. She didn’t fight West and Nellie as they pushed and pulled her up the stairs and through the Bennington Mansion. “Holy shit,” said Nellie as they jumped in the car, and West sped them away. “Holy shit!” The world was spinning around Devi, but it wasn’t the alcohol that had made her dizzy. She stared down at the diary in her hands, flipping through the scrawled warnings. Instructions. Maybe the man had lied, but not about everything. And West still held the key. She was suddenly glad that Nellie convinced her to take the diary. She had so much to learn. To find. Maybe, just maybe, there was a door that she could open, and her mother would be there, waiting on the other side. [[End of Track]] “We have to get out of here!” West said, but as Devi started to run with him, she heard something tapping, hard, against her equipment in her briefcase. Her keys? She thought they were safe in one of the pockets. But if they scratched the equipment… yes, they needed to get out of the mansion, and had just experienced an earthquake, but she had spent a lot of money on her gear and she was not going to let it get scratched up. “Hold on!” she said right as they reached the looming cacti, crouching to unzip her bag. “Devi, you better be reacting to the coolest ghost shit you’ve ever heard or I swear to god,” Nellie began, but Devi waved her silent. Her keys were not loose. There was something sticking out of the diary they had found in the Upper Observatory. A piece of glass? She pulled out the diary, opening it up, revealing a round, smooth piece of glass. It looked clear, but as she turned it, even with almost no light to reflect, she saw a full spectrum of colors go bright then fade away. “A compact?” Nellie asked. “It looks like a lens,” said West, pushing up his glasses. A lens. For a telescope? Devi opened the diary to the page where the lens had been hidden. The writing was looping, scrawled, like it had been written by a child. //When the sacrifice to the starless sky is complete, set the key in its place to lock the door to return Him to the void.// Under the scrawled words was a shaky drawing of a large curving V. “Well, that’s ominous,” said Nellie, reading over Devi’s shoulder. “What key is it talking about?” West asked, reading over Devi’s other shoulder. She fought the urge to shrug them both off. “I’m more concerned about the sacrifice, or the void, or Him,” Devi said. “But sure, let’s focus on the key thing. Come on.” “Where?” asked West. “We need to put the lens on the telescope.” “Why?” Nellie asked. “That looks like the diary of a crazy person. It’s probably nothing. There’s no sacrifice. Nothing to worry about.” But Devi could still feel the warmth of the paint under her fingers, warm like skin on the cheek of a man who was not a man. Him. The monster from her mother’s stories, the one she had spied on as the Benningtons performed their occult rituals. Instead of finding her mother’s ghost, she had a literal brush with something so much worse. And if the lens was the key, and they had the lens, then it was their job to lock awaywhat they had awakened. What she had awakened. Nellie continued her protests as she followed Devi into the house, to the observatory, but West was silent for once. A part of her was glad to have his support. A bigger part of her wondered how he could be so convinced when he didn’t feel the painting come to life under his hand. “Wait,” said Nellie as Devi approached the telescope. “I’m… I’m getting a weird feeling.” “Me too,” said Devi. Her mic was picking up that strange sound again, like footsteps. And it was getting louder. She rushed to fish the lens out of the diary as Nellie wandered to the telescope, frowning up at the clear glass ceiling. “Does anyone else see that constellation?” Nellie asked. “I’ve never seen it before.” As Nellie bent down to look through the telescope, something shifted in the wall next to Devi, and a figure came barrelling out of a door that appeared out of nowhere. It was an old woman with long, curly gray hair, apparently surprisingly strong for her age because she managed to wrest Nellie away from the telescope. “What are you doing?” Nellie screamed as she freed herself from the woman’s grip. “Saving your life!” the woman shouted at her. “You have no idea…” The woman bit her tongue, shaking her head, then she turned to Devi and her eyes grew wide. “Amitava?” she asked. Devi shook her head slowly, shocked. “I’m… I’m her daughter.” Tara. This was Tara. She was alive. She was here. Didn't her mother claim that Tara had conjured the halls out of thin air? It sounded familiar. Devi thought it was magic, or drug related, but she must have been talking about secret passages. And Tara had been using them to hide in the house, all these years. Tara reached for the lens in Devi’s hand. “Give that to me.” [[Give Tara the Lens]] [[Refuse to Give Tara the Lens]] “We have to get out of here!” West said, but as Devi started to run with him, she heard something tapping, hard, against her equipment in her briefcase. Her keys? She thought they were safe in one of the pockets. But if they scratched the equipment… yes, they needed to get out of the mansion, and had just experienced an earthquake, but she had spent a lot of money on her gear and she was not going to let it get scratched up. “Hold on!” she said right as they reached the looming cacti, crouching to unzip her bag. “Devi, you get your drunk ass up or I swear to god,” Nellie began, but Devi waved her silent. Her keys were not loose. There was something sticking out of the diary they had found in the Upper Observatory. A piece of glass? She pulled out the diary, opening it up, revealing a round, smooth piece of glass. It looked clear, but as she turned it, even with almost no light to reflect, she saw a full spectrum of colors go bright then fade away. “A compact?” Nellie asked. “It looks like a lens,” said West, pushing up his glasses. A lens. For a telescope? Devi opened the diary to the page where the lens had been hidden. The writing was looping, scrawled, like it had been written by a child. //When the sacrifice to the starless sky is complete, set the key in its place to lock the door to return Him to the void.// Under the scrawled words was a shaky drawing of a large curving V. “Well, that’s ominous,” said Nellie, reading over Devi’s shoulder. “What key is it talking about?” West asked, reading over Devi’s other shoulder. She fought the urge to shrug them both off. “The telescope..." Devi mumbled. “Telescope?” Nellie asked. “That looks like the diary of a crazy person. It’s probably nothing. There’s no sacrifice. Nothing to worry about.” But Devi could still feel the warmth of the paint under her fingers, warm like skin on the cheek of a man who was not a man. Him. The monster from her mother’s stories, the one she had spied on as the Benningtons performed their occult rituals. Instead of finding her mother’s ghost, she had a literal brush with something so much worse. And if the lens was the key, and they had the lens, then it was their job to lock awaywhat they had awakened. What she had awakened. Nellie continued her protests as she followed Devi into the house, to the observatory, but West was silent for once. A part of her was glad to have his support. A bigger part of her wondered how he could be so convinced when he didn’t feel the painting come to life under his hand. “Wait,” said Nellie as Devi approached the telescope. “I’m… I’m getting a weird feeling.” “Me too,” said Devi, the word slurring. Her mic was picking up that strange sound again, like footsteps. And it was getting louder. She clumsily fished the lens out of the diary as Nellie wandered to the telescope, frowning up at the clear glass ceiling. “Does anyone else see that constellation?” Nellie asked. “I’ve never seen it before.” As Nellie bent down to look through the telescope, something shifted in the wall next to Devi, and a figure came barrelling out of a door that appeared out of nowhere. It was an old woman with long, curly gray hair, apparently surprisingly strong for her age because she managed to wrest Nellie away from the telescope. “What are you doing?” Nellie screamed as she freed herself from the woman’s grip. “Saving your life!” the woman shouted at her. “You have no idea…” The woman bit her tongue, shaking her head, then she turned to Devi and her eyes grew wide. “Amitava?” she asked. Devi shook her head slowly, shocked. Was she hallucinating? Did she pass out? Was she dreaming? “I’m… I’m her daughter.” Tara. This was Tara. She was alive. She was here. Didn't her mother claim that Tara had conjured the halls out of thin air? It sounded familiar. Devi thought it was magic, or drug related, but she must have been talking about secret passages. And Tara had been using them to hide in the house, all these years. Tara reached for the lens in Devi’s hand. “Give that to me.” [[Drunkenly Give Tara the Lens]] [[Drunkenly Refuse to Give Tara the Lens]]“Alright,” said Devi, holding out the lens. Tara snatched it from her, fitting it on the telescope. Devi saw her body sag in relief. “How did you three get in here?” Tara asked, her voice harsh but exhausted. “We asked the owner for permission,” Nellie huffed. “How are you not the owner?” Devi asked. “Who is this?” West asked. “My mother,” Tara murmured. “I bound the other two but… you must have spoken to my mother. I didn’t think she would be so reckless.” “It’s Tara!” Nellie gasped. “I need the two of you to figure this out faster!” Devi snapped before turning her attention back to Tara. “What did your mother do that was so reckless?” Tara smiled, but her lips were tight and sad. “She opened a door. A door that could swallow the world. You three need to leave.” Devi wanted to protest. She expected Nellie or West to protest, but instead they grabbed her hands, pulling her down the stairs, through the mansion, to the car. “Holy shit,” said Nellie as they jumped in the car, and West sped them away. “Holy shit! West, you got that right? You were filming?” West grinned at them through the rearview mirror. “You bet your ass I got it!” Nellie turned to look at Devi. “You’ve still got the diary, right Devi?” Shit. She did still have the diary. She pulled it out of her bag. “This is going to be the Best. Episode. EVER!” Nellie whooped. [[End of Track]] Devi held the lens close to her chest. “I’m not giving you anything until you tell me what happened to my mother.” Tara’s face fell. “I told her not to come back. It’s not my fault she put herself in danger.” “Is she dead?” Tara hesitated. “Probably.” “What do you mean probably?” “What the actual HELL are we talking about?” asked Nellie. “Who is this?” asked West. “She went through a door,” said Tara. “It only goes one way. If she is alive, it isn’t in any sense that we would understand it. She’s gone. She’s never coming back.” “Why would she do that?” Devi asked, her voice cracking, and Tara would not meet her eyes. Devi’s flesh went cold. “Why would you do that to her?” Tara’s eyes flashed. “I didn’t do anything,” she snapped. “I tried to help her. I’m trying to help you.” She lunged at Devi, but West rushed between them, pushing her back. Tara stumbled a few steps, then tripped. Her head hit the edge of the squat side table with a sharp crack. “Oh my god,” said Nellie. “Oh my god!” Tara slid to the floor, a pool of blood forming beneath her. Her eyes were wide, her lips moving. Devi ducked under West’s arm as he attempted to restrain her, getting close enough to hear Tara whisper. “Lock the door… responsibility…” Devi felt sick. She ran to the telescope, fitting on the lens on it. Nothing seemed to change, but she turned to Tara from approval anyway. The woman’s eyes were empty, cold. Somewhere, far away, Devi thought she could hear the sound of laughter being picked up by her mic. “We need to call an ambulance,” said West. “Come on! My phone is in the car.” They ran out the mansion, and Devi tried to fight the urge to vomit as West called the police. What were they going to do? What had they done? [[End of Track]] “Fine,” mumbled Devi. She held out the lens. She tried to hold onto it, but one moment it felt secure, the next it was slipping through her fingers. It felt to the floor, and Devi braced for the sound of shattering, but instead heard nothing. “It slipped through the floor,” Nellie gasped. The floor was half-rotted, and there were many inaccessible pockets it could have fallen into. Tara fell to her knees, almost scratching at the wood before realizing the futility. She glared at Devi, baring her teeth like an animal. “You idiot!” she hissed, then smiled a terrible smile. “Fine. There’s more than one way to send him home satisfied.” Suddenly, Tara’s arm was around her throat, and she was pulling Devi into the corridor she had opened behind her. Devi had a moment to see Nellie and West’s horrified faces before the secret door shut in front of her, sealing her off from rescue. She did not know if she was particularly drunk or if Tara was particularly strong, but she had no luck trying to pull free as Tara led her down uneven steps. It took all her concentration not to fall and break her neck, and even that effort was almost fruitless when Tara pushed her forward down the last few steps. Devi did not know where she was. Somewhere underground. And yet, there was light, coming from a round altar in front of her where a man sat cross-legged on the altar, as if he had been waiting for them. The man was handsome, Devi supposed, to those gothic girls who lusted after vampires. His skin was a little too pale, the color of someone naturally pale who has not seen sunlight in a very long time. His eyes were dark, a cloudy hazel that shifted between colors. His black hair was thick, pushed back from his forehead. He looked like a rockstar, or pseudo-punk, but too neatly put together for his rebellion to be anything but a performance. His black t-shirt and jeans were tight on his skinny frame, his studded thick boots looking too heavy for his body. The freckles on his cheeks swirled gently, but Devi was pretty sure that was her vision doubling. Maybe this was all a hallucination. Maybe she had passed out. Maybe she was dreaming. “Tara, what a delicious gift you have brought me,” the man drawled. The man’s eyes went completely black. There was the rush of air, like a vacuum opening into pure space. Devi tried to scream but couldn’t find her breath as she felt the vacuum tugging at something inside of her. She fell to her knees, her vision tripling until it looked like there were three figures looming over her, grinning. The last thing Devi ever heard was laughter like a song made of static. [[End of Track]] Devi held the lens close to her chest. “No!" she said, too loudly. "I’m not giving... tell me wha... bout my mother.” "What?" asked Tara. "Devi, you are slurring like crazy," said Nellie. “Who is this?” asked West. Tara’s eyes flashed. “I don't have time for this,” she snapped. She lunged at Devi, but West rushed between them, pushing her back. Tara stumbled a few steps, then tripped. Her head hit the edge of the squat side table with a sharp crack. “Oh my god,” said Nellie. “Oh my god!” Tara slid to the floor, a pool of blood forming beneath her. Her eyes were wide, her lips moving. Devi tried to get to her, to listen to what she was saying, but West restrained her, pulling her away from the old woman whose lips had already gone still. “We need to call an ambulance,” said West. “Come on! My phone is in the car.” They ran out the mansion, and Devi tried to fight the urge to vomit as West called the police. She had a terrible feeling, not just about the dead woman. Like they had forgotten to do something important. Like the worst was yet to come. Somewhere, far away, Devi thought she could hear the sound of laughter being picked up by her mic. [[End of Track]] “Left, to the Séance Pit!” West announced. “Please avoid the Séance Pit,” Devi said, stumbling after West and Nellie. “The door to the pit is really fragile so just… don’t touch it. West.” West realized he was leaning towards the Séance Pit door, but it was only because of the sudden appearance of ghost who looked as shocked to see him as he was to see her. She had deep black almond eyes and a messy cropped haircut. Her fringe vest gave her a friendly 70s folksy vibe that was negated by the angry energy she focused on West before disappearing through the door into the Groove Room. “If anyone is touching things she shouldn’t, it’s Nellie!” West protested, pulling himself away from the door now that the ghost had left them more room in the hallway. “Wow, just because of that accusation, I’m going to touch *everything*,” Nellie said, glaring at West. “I’m in charge, and therefore, I will decide who touches what,” West argued. “Typical man,” said Nellie, but she wandered away to examine the photos on the wall before West could defend himself. Devi signalled for West to film while she also explored the photos. West had trouble focusing on the pictures that flashed between their faded state and the bright images they once were. Some of the people’s eyes shifted, like they were watching him back. He would probably pick up those flickers on camera. Which would be great for their ghost show. Flickering footage had gotten West fired from plenty of previous gigs. The worst photos were the ones of the Bennington children. He had a better idea of what the kids looked like from the dancing color-block illustrations in the guide book than by looking at actual photos of them that were humming with spectral energy. It was a little easier to focus on the other faces in the photos, which were surprisingly familiar… “Is that David Bowie?” Devi finally asked. Nellie startled next to her, as if she had not been looking at the same exact picture of the same exact famous popstar. “Oh shit, it is!” said West. “Holy shit, Mick Jagger’s in this pic!” West realized that the photos were studded with rock, pop, and folk stars who reached their heights in the 70s. If he didn’t pull his starstruck crewmates away from the photos they would be admiring them for hours. And he didn’t think the leftover energy the Bennington children had left in their particular photos were appreciating the scrutiny. Or else they were always in a bad mood. Either way. “Time to move on,” West announced. [[Séance Pit - West's Tour]] [[Girls’ Bathroom - West's Tour]] [[Groove Room - West's Tour]] “West, I told you not to touch the door to the Séance Pit,” Devi scolded. “There is a pit behind it. If you try to enter it, you will fall and die.” West stepped back, mumbling some kind of protest. He couldn’t recognize at first that he was drawn to the door, and when he realized why, his blood ran cold. There was no spectral energy coming from the door. There was no energy at all, not even lingering memories. Not even the usual negative haunted energies of fear or sadness. It really was a pit. Devi was looking at him funny, or maybe just judgementally, but West felt the need to shake off his sudden discomfort. “The door is pretty rotted,” West said. “Not much protection from such a dangerous pit. Hell, I bet I could kick it down.” “It’s so rotted I could kick it down,” Nellie said, squaring up like she was about to try. “No one’s kicking down any doors,” Devi groaned. West wasn’t worried about the pit for the same reasons as Devi, but it did worry him. He had a bad feeling about the feelingless pit. He had a bad feeling about this mansion. “We were just joking, Devi,” West said, forcing a grin. “And now we’re just wasting time we don’t have, and I need to keep us on schedule." [[Groove Room - West's Tour from Séance Pit]] [[Girls' Bathroom - West's Tour from Séance Pit]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]] The bathroom was a little girly. Very pink. West was distracted by the images in loop of women getting ready, the faded memory projected across the weirdly moist tiles, but he still got some good footage of Nellie staring pensively into the bathroom mirror. He pulled out the guidebook, clanking at an illustration that looked like a more solid version of the image he was glimpsing, three women in elegant pink house robes delicately powdering their face, brushing their hair, putting on lipstick. “All the girls shared this bathroom,” said Devi. “Both the daughters had to share in a mansion?” Nellie asked, incredulous. “Both the daughters and Bradfords’ three lovers,” Devi clarified. “I forgot about the three lovers, all living together,” Nellie shuddered. “Bradford was such a misogynist.” “Free love isn’t inherently misogynistic,” West protested. “If you want bathroom footage, you’ll have to film here,” Devi interrupted before Nellie could really wind up West. “There was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and Bradford and Mark’s private bathrooms got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. We’ll see the doors in their bedrooms, but that’s it. I’m not picking anything up on the mics, but if any of this looks particularly compelling to you, we can have a closer look.” [[Explore the Tub - West's Tour]] [[Explore the Toilet - West's Tour]] [[Explore the Cabinet - West's Tour]]West looked around the room, and he could almost see the grimy shag rug, the cracking paint on the walls, but this room was… active. West knew it wasn’t real, but he was dazzled by the brightly lit disco ball lazily spinning designs across the ghostly partiers still grooving, illuminated by a memory stronger than tonight’s gentle moonlight he could barely see through the small porthole windows. Short steps led down to an indented dance floor filled with shimmering dancers with flared trousers, scarf shirts, drooping necklaces, and voluminous hair. West filmed the dancers under the disco ball, realized no one else would see them on the film, and turned his camera to the stairs leading up to a second floor as if he had just been panning across the room. “This place is…” West began. “I know,” said Nellie, her voice full of awe, and he wondered if she was getting some kind of ghostly after-image too, if she could feel the welcoming presence of the Groove Room. Well, from the first floor of the Groove Room. The upper floor had strange vibes. Dark. Devi was listening intently to her headphones. “What’s going on?” asked West, setting his camera on his shoulder. “I might be picking something up.” “Something spooky?” Devi nodded. “A song. Kind of.” She didn’t elaborate. Nellie had moved to the center of the dance floor, and West filmed her as she grooved among the apparitions, swaying her hips along with the beat that he could almost hear. “Doing okay, Nellie?” West asked with a chuckle. She gave a few extra turns just for the camera. “Anything ghostly going on?” she asked them when she was done. “Devi thought she heard a song,” West said. “A disco song?” Nellie asked. “It was quiet,” said Devi. “Hard to make out. I’ll play it back when we get home.” “I bet it was contact,” Nellie grinned, making Devi blush, before she turned to West. “Anything good in the guidebook?” The color-block pictures looked pathetic compared to the real thing. He stared at each figure, looking for a girl with shaggy black hair, but whoever the ghost was who had disappeared into this room, she wasn’t important enough for the artist to draw. West didn’t see her in the crowd. He wondered if she was upstairs, if she was that dark presence he felt, but she didn’t think they were the same spirit. She just seemed pissed. The spirit upstairs was malevolent. The stairs to the upper floor were depicted in the picture, and three women in flowing gowns were on their way up the steps, beckoning at the reader, inviting them to follow. “I wonder what’s upstairs,” said West. “You could read the guidebook and find out,” said Nellie. “It’s the Upper Séance Room,” Devi interrupted. “It was damaged in the same explosion as the Séance Pit. Probably too dangerous to check it out. But I guess it’s up to you, West.” [[Hallway 1 - West's Tour from Groove Room]] [[Upper Séance Room - West's Tour]] West looked around the room, and he could almost see the grimy shag rug, the cracking paint on the walls, but this room was… active. West knew it wasn’t real, but he was dazzled by the brightly lit disco ball lazily spinning designs across the ghostly partiers still grooving, illuminated by a memory stronger than tonight’s gentle moonlight he could barely see through the small porthole windows. Short steps led down to an indented dance floor filled with shimmering dancers with flared trousers, scarf shirts, drooping necklaces, and voluminous hair. West filmed the dancers under the disco ball, realized no one else would see them on the film, and turned his camera to the stairs leading up to a second floor as if he had just been panning across the room. “This place is…” West began. “I know,” said Nellie, her voice full of awe, and he wondered if she was getting some kind of ghostly after-image too, if she could feel the welcoming presence of the Groove Room. Well, from the first floor of the Groove Room. The upper floor had strange vibes. Dark. Devi was listening intently to her headphones. “What’s going on?” asked West, setting his camera on his shoulder. “I might be picking something up.” “Something spooky?” Devi nodded. “A song. Kind of.” She didn’t elaborate. Nellie had moved to the center of the dance floor, and West filmed her as she grooved among the apparitions, swaying her hips along with the beat that he could almost hear. “Doing okay, Nellie?” West asked with a chuckle. She gave a few extra turns just for the camera. “Anything ghostly going on?” she asked them when she was done. “Devi thought she heard a song,” West said. “A disco song?” Nellie asked. “It was quiet,” said Devi. “Hard to make out. I’ll play it back when we get home.” “I bet it was contact,” Nellie grinned, making Devi blush, before she turned to West. “Anything good in the guidebook?” The color-block pictures looked pathetic compared to the real thing. He stared at each figure, looking for a girl with shaggy black hair, but whoever the ghost was who had disappeared into this room, she wasn’t important enough for the artist to draw. West didn’t see her in the crowd. He wondered if she was upstairs, if she was that dark presence he felt, but she didn’t think they were the same spirit. She just seemed pissed. The spirit upstairs was malevolent. The stairs to the upper floor were depicted in the picture, and three women in flowing gowns were on their way up the steps, beckoning at the reader, inviting them to follow. “I wonder what’s upstairs,” said West. “You could read the guidebook and find out,” said Nellie. “It’s the Upper Séance Room,” Devi interrupted. “It was damaged in the same explosion as the Séance Pit. Probably too dangerous to check it out. But I guess it’s up to you, West.” [[Hallway 1 - West's Tour from Groove Room and Séance Pit]] [[Upper Séance Room - West's Tour from Séance Pit]] The bathroom was a little girly. Very pink. West was distracted by the images in loop of women getting ready, the faded memory projected across the weirdly moist tiles, but he still got some good footage of Nellie staring pensively into the bathroom mirror. He pulled out the guidebook, clanking at an illustration that looked like a more solid version of the image he was glimpsing, three women in elegant pink house robes delicately powdering their face, brushing their hair, putting on lipstick. “All the girls shared this bathroom,” said Devi. “Both the daughters had to share in a mansion?” Nellie asked, incredulous. “Both the daughters and Bradfords’ three lovers,” Devi clarified. “I forgot about the three lovers, all living together,” Nellie shuddered. “Bradford was such a misogynist.” “Free love isn’t inherently misogynistic,” West protested. “If you want bathroom footage, you’ll have to film here,” Devi interrupted before Nellie could really wind up West. “There was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and Bradford and Mark’s private bathrooms got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. We’ll see the doors in their bedrooms, but that’s it. I’m not picking anything up on the mics, but if any of this looks particularly compelling to you, we can have a closer look.” [[Explore the Tub - West's Tour from Séance Pit]] [[Explore the Toilet - West's Tour from Séance Pit]] [[Explore the Cabinet - West's Tour from Séance Pit]] “Ew, there’s sludge in the tub!” said West, smearing his fingers through the thick muck. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked, horrified. “This is what happens when you let West explore first,” Nellie laughed, shaking her head. “It’s just mold,” West said, wiping the thick substance that was almost definitely not just mold off his hand, onto his jeans. “You girls are so squeamish.” He wiped until there wasn’t anything visibly left on his fingers, but he still felt that black-green muck coating his skin. If he focused too much on the feeling, it sort of felt like it was spreading, but that was probably something malicious messing with his senses. He fought the urge to glare at Nellie. She was supposedly the sensitive one. If a ghost was going to mess with anyone, it should have been her. He was almost positive that if Nellie had explored first, she also would have touched the sludge in the tub. [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from Tub and Séance Pit]] “Do you really want to film the toilet, West?” Nellie sneered. “Right,” said West. “Who do I think I am? Hitchcock?” “What?” asked Devi. “Psycho was the first film… Never mind,” said West. [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from Toilet and Séance Pit]] “Huh,” said West, pulling a white ribbon out of the medicine cabinet. “Pretty,” said Nellie. “Don’t let her have it!” Devi warned West. He held the ribbon over his head, far out of Nellie’s reach. “You guys aren’t any fun,” Nellie pouted. The looping image of the three women paused, and the flickering blank faces turned to all glare at West until he shoved the ribbon back into its hiding place. “No fun for you, Nellie,” West said, flashing her a fake smile. “Not while I’m in charge.” [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from Cabinet and Séance Pit]] “Ew, there’s sludge in the tub!” said West, smearing his fingers through the thick muck. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked, horrified. “This is what happens when you let West explore first,” Nellie laughed, shaking her head. “It’s just mold,” West said, wiping the thick substance that was almost definitely not just mold off his hand, onto his jeans. “You girls are so squeamish.” He wiped until there wasn’t anything visibly left on his fingers, but he still felt that black-green muck coating his skin. If he focused too much on the feeling, it sort of felt like it was spreading, but that was probably something malicious messing with his senses. He fought the urge to glare at Nellie. She was supposedly the sensitive one. If a ghost was going to mess with anyone, it should have been her. He was almost positive that if Nellie had explored first, she also would have touched the sludge in the tub. [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from Tub]] “Do you really want to film the toilet, West?” Nellie sneered. “Right,” said West. “Who do I think I am? Hitchcock?” “What?” asked Devi. “Psycho was the first film… Never mind,” said West. [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from Toilet]]“Huh,” said West, pulling a white ribbon out of the medicine cabinet. “Pretty,” said Nellie. “Don’t let her have it!” Devi warned West. He held the ribbon over his head, far out of Nellie’s reach. “You guys aren’t any fun,” Nellie pouted. The looping image of the three women paused, and the flickering blank faces turned to all glare at West until he shoved the ribbon back into its hiding place. “No fun for you, Nellie,” West said, flashing her a fake smile. “Not while I’m in charge.” [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from Cabinet]]“I guess bathrooms are a pretty popular horror setting,” West said as he filmed Nellie pretending to listen for ghosts. “But it’s only interesting if something scary happens,” Devi said. [[Explore the Toilet - West's Tour from Tub and Séance Pit]] [[Explore the Cabinet - West's Tour from Tub and Séance Pit]] “I guess bathrooms are a pretty popular horror setting,” West said as he filmed Nellie pretending to listen for ghosts. “But it’s only interesting if something scary happens,” Devi said. Hitchcock?” “What?” asked Devi. “Psycho was the first film… Never mind,” said West. [[Hallway 1 - West's Tour from GBR]]“Ew, there’s sludge in the tub!” said West, smearing his fingers through the thick muck. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked, horrified. “This is what happens when you let West explore first,” Nellie laughed, shaking her head. “It’s just mold,” West said, wiping the thick substance that was almost definitely not just mold off his hand, onto his jeans. “You girls are so squeamish.” He wiped until there wasn’t anything visibly left on his fingers, but he still felt that black-green muck coating his skin.
