She was supposedly the sensitive one. If a ghost was going to mess with anyone, it should have been her. He was almost positive that if Nellie had explored first, she also would have touched the sludge in the tub. [[Hallway 1 - West's Tour with Sludge]]West paused when they went back into the hallway. “Are we moving on?” asked Nellie. “What?” asked West, pulling his eyes from a photo of a sneering man lounging between two rockstars who was looking right at him. Terror shone through his eyes. Why was he scared? He was already dead. What did he have to be scared of? “West?” asked Devi. “Another room, or keep going?” “Right,” West said, shaking his head. “Sorry. Follow me.” [[Groove Room - West's Tour with Sludge from Séance Pit]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]] West paused when they went back into the hallway. “Are we moving on?” asked Nellie. “What?” asked West, pulling his eyes from a photo of a sneering man lounging between two rockstars who was looking right at him. Terror shone through his eyes. Why was he scared? He was already dead. What did he have to be scared of? “West?” asked Devi. “Another room, or keep going?” “Right,” West said, shaking his head. “Sorry. Follow me.” [[Groove Room - West's Tour from Séance Pit and GBR]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]West paused when they went back into the hallway. “Are we moving on?” asked Nellie. “What?” asked West, pulling his eyes from a photo of a sneering man lounging between two rockstars who was looking right at him. Terror shone through his eyes. Why was he scared? He was already dead. What did he have to be scared of? “West?” asked Devi. “Another room, or keep going?” “Right,” West said, shaking his head. “Sorry. Follow me.” [[Séance Pit - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Groove Room - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]]West paused when they went back into the hallway. “Are we moving on?” asked Nellie. “What?” asked West, pulling his eyes from a photo of a sneering man lounging between two rockstars who was looking right at him. Terror shone through his eyes. Why was he scared? He was already dead. What did he have to be scared of? “West?” asked Devi. “Another room, or keep going?” “Right,” West said, shaking his head. “Sorry. Follow me.” [[Séance Pit - West's Tour from GBR]] [[Groove Room - West's Tour from GBR]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]West looked around the room, and he could almost see the grimy shag rug, the cracking paint on the walls, but this room was… active. West knew it wasn’t real, but he was dazzled by the brightly lit disco ball lazily spinning designs across the ghostly partiers still grooving, illuminated by a memory stronger than tonight’s gentle moonlight he could barely see through the small porthole windows. Short steps led down to an indented dance floor filled with shimmering dancers with flared trousers, scarf shirts, drooping necklaces, and voluminous hair. West filmed the dancers under the disco ball, realized no one else would see them on the film, and turned his camera to the stairs leading up to a second floor as if he had just been panning across the room. “This place is…” West began. “I know,” said Nellie, her voice full of awe, and he wondered if she was getting some kind of ghostly after-image too, if she could feel the welcoming presence of the Groove Room. Well, from the first floor of the Groove Room. The upper floor had strange vibes. Dark. Devi was listening intently to her headphones. “What’s going on?” asked West, setting his camera on his shoulder. “I might be picking something up.” “Something spooky?” Devi nodded. “A song. Kind of.” She didn’t elaborate. Nellie had moved to the center of the dance floor, and West filmed her as she grooved among the apparitions, swaying her hips along with the beat that he could almost hear. “Doing okay, Nellie?” West asked with a chuckle. She gave a few extra turns just for the camera. “Anything ghostly going on?” she asked them when she was done. “Devi thought she heard a song,” West said. “A disco song?” Nellie asked. “It was quiet,” said Devi. “Hard to make out. I’ll play it back when we get home.” “I bet it was contact,” Nellie grinned, making Devi blush, before she turned to West. “Anything good in the guidebook?” The color-block pictures looked pathetic compared to the real thing. He stared at each figure, looking for a girl with shaggy black hair, but whoever the ghost was who had disappeared into this room, she wasn’t important enough for the artist to draw. West didn’t see her in the crowd. He wondered if she was upstairs, if she was that dark presence he felt, but she didn’t think they were the same spirit. She just seemed pissed. The spirit upstairs was malevolent. The stairs to the upper floor were depicted in the picture, and three women in flowing gowns were on their way up the steps, beckoning at the reader, inviting them to follow. “I wonder what’s upstairs,” said West. “You could read the guidebook and find out,” said Nellie. “It’s the Upper Séance Room,” Devi interrupted. “It was damaged in the same explosion as the Séance Pit. Probably too dangerous to check it out. But I guess it’s up to you, West.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Upper Séance Room - West's Tour with Sludge from Séance Pit]] West led the crew deeper into the mansion, leaving the haunted pictures of rockstars behind them. The pictures had gone inactive, but his camera had not. The image kept glitching, shifting colors, showing shadows that were not there. The kind of activity that got him fired from traditional sets. The results that Nellie lived for. West had tried to quit in the past, but it was hard to find people outside the paranormal field who were fine with haunted footage. It didn’t matter. On the last few haunts, he had felt less like a witness and more like a potential player. Like how Nellie described her own gift, which always sounded to him like a vulnerability more than a blessing. “Is anyone else chilly?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said West, truthfully, but that didn’t mean Nellie was lying. “Maybe it’s a ghost?” “West. Film,” Nellie demanded, before turning to the red light and smirking. “I think we have company, viewers. Does anyone want to make contact? It’s safe here. We’re listening.” Despite the silliness of its name, Spooktacular Investigations didn’t use EVP, radio channels, any of the tricks popular on other streaming shows because as far as their Nellie was concerned, they were just tricks. And she was right. And between the three of them, or even just with West’s influence, they didn’t need them. They waited a minute in silence. “Guess they’re shy,” Nellie said, shrugging at the camera. “We’ve got some chilly, shy ghosts or demons in the mansion.” “Maybe I should play ‘Running With the Devil,’” Devi suggested. “Only if we’re desperate for contact,” Nellie said. “Okay West, I’ve had enough of this popcorn ceiling for a lifetime. What does the guidebook say?” West flipped open the book to the entry for the Bradford children’s bedrooms. There were those dancing figures from the beginning of the guidebook again, each standing under a shadowed archway now. Not dancing. Leaning, tired. It was a weird pose for a guidebook. They didn’t look particularly welcoming, and West doubted their ghosts would be more welcoming to people invading the privacy of their bedrooms. The man with the afro stood under an arch with an M at the top, the blond woman under an arch labelled D, and the girl with dark ringlets under the arch labelled T. West looked up at the molding mantels above each bedroom door, where pieces of metal twisted into the shape of a letter were still securely nailed: M, T, D. He pointed it out to the crew. “Mark, Tara, Dawn,” he said. “The Bradford children. We probably have time to explore two of the rooms.” [[Mark's Room - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Tara's Room - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Dawn's Room - West's Tour with Sludge]]West looked around the room, and he could almost see the grimy shag rug, the cracking paint on the walls, but this room was… active. West knew it wasn’t real, but he was dazzled by the brightly lit disco ball lazily spinning designs across the ghostly partiers still grooving, illuminated by a memory stronger than tonight’s gentle moonlight he could barely see through the small porthole windows. Short steps led down to an indented dance floor filled with shimmering dancers with flared trousers, scarf shirts, drooping necklaces, and voluminous hair. West filmed the dancers under the disco ball, realized no one else would see them on the film, and turned his camera to the stairs leading up to a second floor as if he had just been panning across the room. “This place is…” West began. “I know,” said Nellie, her voice full of awe, and he wondered if she was getting some kind of ghostly after-image too, if she could feel the welcoming presence of the Groove Room. Well, from the first floor of the Groove Room. The upper floor had strange vibes. Dark. Devi was listening intently to her headphones. “What’s going on?” asked West, setting his camera on his shoulder. “I might be picking something up.” “Something spooky?” Devi nodded. “A song. Kind of.” She didn’t elaborate. Nellie had moved to the center of the dance floor, and West filmed her as she grooved among the apparitions, swaying her hips along with the beat that he could almost hear. “Doing okay, Nellie?” West asked with a chuckle. She gave a few extra turns just for the camera. “Anything ghostly going on?” she asked them when she was done. “Devi thought she heard a song,” West said. “A disco song?” Nellie asked. “It was quiet,” said Devi. “Hard to make out. I’ll play it back when we get home.” “I bet it was contact,” Nellie grinned, making Devi blush, before she turned to West. “Anything good in the guidebook?” The color-block pictures looked pathetic compared to the real thing. He stared at each figure, looking for a girl with shaggy black hair, but whoever the ghost was who had disappeared into this room, she wasn’t important enough for the artist to draw. West didn’t see her in the crowd. He wondered if she was upstairs, if she was that dark presence he felt, but she didn’t think they were the same spirit. She just seemed pissed. The spirit upstairs was malevolent. The stairs to the upper floor were depicted in the picture, and three women in flowing gowns were on their way up the steps, beckoning at the reader, inviting them to follow. “I wonder what’s upstairs,” said West. “You could read the guidebook and find out,” said Nellie. “It’s the Upper Séance Room,” Devi interrupted. “It was damaged in the same explosion as the Séance Pit. Probably too dangerous to check it out. But I guess it’s up to you, West.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]] [[Upper Séance Room - West's Tour from Séance Pit and GBR]]West led the crew deeper into the mansion, leaving the haunted pictures of rockstars behind them. The pictures had gone inactive, but his camera had not. The image kept glitching, shifting colors, showing shadows that were not there. The kind of activity that got him fired from traditional sets. The results that Nellie lived for. West had tried to quit in the past, but it was hard to find people outside the paranormal field who were fine with haunted footage. It didn’t matter. On the last few haunts, he had felt less like a witness and more like a potential player. Like how Nellie described her own gift, which always sounded to him like a vulnerability more than a blessing. “Is anyone else chilly?” Nellie asked. “Nope,” said West, truthfully, but that didn’t mean Nellie was lying. “Maybe it’s a ghost?” “West. Film,” Nellie demanded, before turning to the red light and smirking. “I think we have company, viewers. Does anyone want to make contact? It’s safe here. We’re listening.” Despite the silliness of its name, Spooktacular Investigations didn’t use EVP, radio channels, any of the tricks popular on other streaming shows because as far as their Nellie was concerned, they were just tricks. And she was right. And between the three of them, or even just with West’s influence, they didn’t need them. They waited a minute in silence. “Guess they’re shy,” Nellie said, shrugging at the camera. “We’ve got some chilly, shy ghosts or demons in the mansion.” “Maybe I should play ‘Running With the Devil,’” Devi suggested. “Only if we’re desperate for contact,” Nellie said. “Okay West, I’ve had enough of this popcorn ceiling for a lifetime. What does the guidebook say?” West flipped open the book to the entry for the Bradford children’s bedrooms. There were those dancing figures from the beginning of the guidebook again, each standing under a shadowed archway now. Not dancing. Leaning, tired. It was a weird pose for a guidebook. They didn’t look particularly welcoming, and West doubted their ghosts would be more welcoming to people invading the privacy of their bedrooms. The man with the afro stood under an arch with an M at the top, the blond woman under an arch labelled D, and the girl with dark ringlets under the arch labelled T. West looked up at the molding mantels above each bedroom door, where pieces of metal twisted into the shape of a letter were still securely nailed: M, T, D. He pointed it out to the crew. “Mark, Tara, Dawn,” he said. “The Bradford children. We probably have time to explore two of the rooms.” [[Mark's Room - West's Tour]] [[Tara's Room - West's Tour]] [[Dawn's Room - West's Tour]]“West, I told you not to touch the door to the Séance Pit,” Devi scolded. “There is a pit behind it. If you try to enter it, you will fall and die.” West stepped back, mumbling some kind of protest. He couldn’t recognize at first that he was drawn to the door, and when he realized why, his blood ran cold. There was no spectral energy coming from the door. There was no energy at all, not even lingering memories. Not even the usual negative haunted energies of fear or sadness. It really was a pit. Devi was looking at him funny, or maybe just judgementally, but West felt the need to shake off his sudden discomfort. “The door is pretty rotted,” West said. “Not much protection from such a dangerous pit. Hell, I bet I could kick it down.” “It’s so rotted I could kick it down,” Nellie said, squaring up like she was about to try. “No one’s kicking down any doors,” Devi groaned. West wasn’t worried about the pit for the same reasons as Devi, but it did worry him. He had a bad feeling about the feelingless pit. He had a bad feeling about this mansion. “We were just joking, Devi,” West said, forcing a grin. “And now we’re just wasting time we don’t have, and I need to keep us on schedule." [[Groove Room - West's Tour with Sludge from Séance Pit]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]]West looked around the room, and he could almost see the grimy shag rug, the cracking paint on the walls, but this room was… active. West knew it wasn’t real, but he was dazzled by the brightly lit disco ball lazily spinning designs across the ghostly partiers still grooving, illuminated by a memory stronger than tonight’s gentle moonlight he could barely see through the small porthole windows. Short steps led down to an indented dance floor filled with shimmering dancers with flared trousers, scarf shirts, drooping necklaces, and voluminous hair. West filmed the dancers under the disco ball, realized no one else would see them on the film, and turned his camera to the stairs leading up to a second floor as if he had just been panning across the room. “This place is…” West began. “I know,” said Nellie, her voice full of awe, and he wondered if she was getting some kind of ghostly after-image too, if she could feel the welcoming presence of the Groove Room. Well, from the first floor of the Groove Room. The upper floor had strange vibes. Dark. Devi was listening intently to her headphones. “What’s going on?” asked West, setting his camera on his shoulder. “I might be picking something up.” “Something spooky?” Devi nodded. “A song. Kind of.” She didn’t elaborate. Nellie had moved to the center of the dance floor, and West filmed her as she grooved among the apparitions, swaying her hips along with the beat that he could almost hear. “Doing okay, Nellie?” West asked with a chuckle. She gave a few extra turns just for the camera. “Anything ghostly going on?” she asked them when she was done. “Devi thought she heard a song,” West said. “A disco song?” Nellie asked. “It was quiet,” said Devi. “Hard to make out. I’ll play it back when we get home.” “I bet it was contact,” Nellie grinned, making Devi blush, before she turned to West. “Anything good in the guidebook?” The color-block pictures looked pathetic compared to the real thing. He stared at each figure, looking for a girl with shaggy black hair, but whoever the ghost was who had disappeared into this room, she wasn’t important enough for the artist to draw. West didn’t see her in the crowd. He wondered if she was upstairs, if she was that dark presence he felt, but she didn’t think they were the same spirit. She just seemed pissed. The spirit upstairs was malevolent. The stairs to the upper floor were depicted in the picture, and three women in flowing gowns were on their way up the steps, beckoning at the reader, inviting them to follow. “I wonder what’s upstairs,” said West. “You could read the guidebook and find out,” said Nellie. “It’s the Upper Séance Room,” Devi interrupted. “It was damaged in the same explosion as the Séance Pit. Probably too dangerous to check it out. But I guess it’s up to you, West.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Upper Séance Room - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Séance Pit - West's Tour with Sludge from Groove Room]]“West, I told you not to touch the door to the Séance Pit,” Devi scolded. “There is a pit behind it. If you try to enter it, you will fall and die.” West stepped back, mumbling some kind of protest. He couldn’t recognize at first that he was drawn to the door, and when he realized why, his blood ran cold. There was no spectral energy coming from the door. There was no energy at all, not even lingering memories. Not even the usual negative haunted energies of fear or sadness. It really was a pit. Devi was looking at him funny, or maybe just judgementally, but West felt the need to shake off his sudden discomfort. “The door is pretty rotted,” West said. “Not much protection from such a dangerous pit. Hell, I bet I could kick it down.” “It’s so rotted I could kick it down,” Nellie said, squaring up like she was about to try. “No one’s kicking down any doors,” Devi groaned. West wasn’t worried about the pit for the same reasons as Devi, but it did worry him. He had a bad feeling about the feelingless pit. He had a bad feeling about this mansion. “We were just joking, Devi,” West said, forcing a grin. “And now we’re just wasting time we don’t have, and I need to keep us on schedule." [[Groove Room - West's Tour from Séance Pit and GBR]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]West looked around the room, and he could almost see the grimy shag rug, the cracking paint on the walls, but this room was… active. West knew it wasn’t real, but he was dazzled by the brightly lit disco ball lazily spinning designs across the ghostly partiers still grooving, illuminated by a memory stronger than tonight’s gentle moonlight he could barely see through the small porthole windows. Short steps led down to an indented dance floor filled with shimmering dancers with flared trousers, scarf shirts, drooping necklaces, and voluminous hair. West filmed the dancers under the disco ball, realized no one else would see them on the film, and turned his camera to the stairs leading up to a second floor as if he had just been panning across the room. “This place is…” West began. “I know,” said Nellie, her voice full of awe, and he wondered if she was getting some kind of ghostly after-image too, if she could feel the welcoming presence of the Groove Room. Well, from the first floor of the Groove Room. The upper floor had strange vibes. Dark. Devi was listening intently to her headphones. “What’s going on?” asked West, setting his camera on his shoulder. “I might be picking something up.” “Something spooky?” Devi nodded. “A song. Kind of.” She didn’t elaborate. Nellie had moved to the center of the dance floor, and West filmed her as she grooved among the apparitions, swaying her hips along with the beat that he could almost hear. “Doing okay, Nellie?” West asked with a chuckle. She gave a few extra turns just for the camera. “Anything ghostly going on?” she asked them when she was done. “Devi thought she heard a song,” West said. “A disco song?” Nellie asked. “It was quiet,” said Devi. “Hard to make out. I’ll play it back when we get home.” “I bet it was contact,” Nellie grinned, making Devi blush, before she turned to West. “Anything good in the guidebook?” The color-block pictures looked pathetic compared to the real thing. He stared at each figure, looking for a girl with shaggy black hair, but whoever the ghost was who had disappeared into this room, she wasn’t important enough for the artist to draw. West didn’t see her in the crowd. He wondered if she was upstairs, if she was that dark presence he felt, but she didn’t think they were the same spirit. She just seemed pissed. The spirit upstairs was malevolent. The stairs to the upper floor were depicted in the picture, and three women in flowing gowns were on their way up the steps, beckoning at the reader, inviting them to follow. “I wonder what’s upstairs,” said West. “You could read the guidebook and find out,” said Nellie. “It’s the Upper Séance Room,” Devi interrupted. “It was damaged in the same explosion as the Séance Pit. Probably too dangerous to check it out. But I guess it’s up to you, West.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]] [[Upper Séance Room - West's Tour from GBR]] [[Séance Pit - West's Tour from Groove Room and GBR]]West paused when they went back into the hallway. “Are we moving on?” asked Nellie. “What?” asked West, pulling his eyes from a photo of a sneering man lounging between two rockstars who was looking right at him. Terror shone through his eyes. Why was he scared? He was already dead. What did he have to be scared of? “West?” asked Devi. “Another room, or keep going?” “Right,” West said, shaking his head. “Sorry. Follow me.” [[Girls' Bathroom - West's Tour from Groove Room and Séance Pit]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]The ghost with the cropped haircut and fringe vest was sitting in the corner, strumming a silent guitar that she balanced in her lap. West’s eyes flicked to Devi, but if she had been picking up this singer’s song before, her mic wasn’t picking anything up right now. The ghost caught his gaze and stopped singing. She pointed back to the stairs, frowning, mouthing something angrily. West didn’t want to ignore her obvious warning, but she couldn’t come up just to immediately turn back around without having a real explanation. And he refused to let Nellie know. Nellie, who would exploit anything, even her own abilities or mental health issues, for a few hundred streaming views. But there were other ways to ensure a quick exit. “West, back away from the giant hole in the floor!” Devi begged. West leaned over further, filming into the pit, Nellie eagerly peering over at his side. He could hear something, faintly, from inside. Voices, ghostly and sorrowful. And every so often, a faint impossible breeze, an echo of a much more powerful gust of air from centuries ago. He was glad he hadn't tested the fragile door to the Séance Room downstairs. He could imagine breaking it, falling through, and then... well he didn't want to imagine that. “What happened here?” asked Nellie. “Does the guidebook say anything?” Devi spoke before West could check. “An earthquake at the time caused structural damage to a lot of the mansion and is said to have upset some poorly made support beams that collapsed, making the center of the floor collapse,” she said. “But some people think there was an explosion of dark energy after a séance went wrong, and the explosion caused the hole...” Devi was still speaking, but West did not hear her. An vision flashed in front of his eyes, three pairs of hands with elegant manicures holding up a burlap sack of a doll, just the suggestion of a head torso and limbs, that flopped in their hands. Flopped wetly, with a squelching sound that made West’s stomach flip. A man was screaming, like his heart was being torn out, and the seems of the doll began to split, and green-black sludge dripped from the openings, before… Darkness. A shrieking vacuum of darkness. Devi’s hand was on his shoulder, and he though she had noticed his distraction, but she was hardly paying attention to him, all her focus spent on frowning at her equipment. “If we stay here any longer one of you is falling into the pit,” she said. “Is that a warning or a threat?” Nellie laughed. “She’s right,” West said, and he noticed the guitar playing ghost was gone. “We’re done here.” [[Hallway 1 - West's Tour from Groove Room and Séance Pit]]West paused when they went back into the hallway. “Are we moving on?” asked Nellie. “What?” asked West, pulling his eyes from a photo of a sneering man lounging between two rockstars who was looking right at him. Terror shone through his eyes. Why was he scared? He was already dead. What did he have to be scared of? “West?” asked Devi. “Another room, or keep going?” “Right,” West said, shaking his head. “Sorry. Follow me.” [[Girls' Bathroom - West's Tour from Groove Room]] [[Séance Pit - West's Tour from Groove Room]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]The ghost with the cropped haircut and fringe vest was sitting in the corner, strumming a silent guitar that she balanced in her lap. West’s eyes flicked to Devi, but if she had been picking up this singer’s song before, her mic wasn’t picking anything up right now. The ghost caught his gaze and stopped singing. She pointed back to the stairs, frowning, mouthing something angrily. West didn’t want to ignore her obvious warning, but she couldn’t come up just to immediately turn back around without having a real explanation. And he refused to let Nellie know. Nellie, who would exploit anything, even her own abilities or mental health issues, for a few hundred streaming views. But there were other ways to ensure a quick exit. “West, back away from the giant hole in the floor!” Devi begged. West leaned over further, filming into the pit, Nellie eagerly peering over at his side. He could hear something, faintly, from inside. Voices, ghostly and sorrowful. And every so often, a faint impossible breeze, an echo of a much more powerful gust of air from centuries ago. He was glad he hadn't tested the fragile door to the Séance Room downstairs. He could imagine breaking it, falling through, and then... well he didn't want to imagine that. “What happened here?” asked Nellie. “Does the guidebook say anything?” Devi spoke before West could check. “An earthquake at the time caused structural damage to a lot of the mansion and is said to have upset some poorly made support beams that collapsed, making the center of the floor collapse,” she said. “But some people think there was an explosion of dark energy after a séance went wrong, and the explosion caused the hole...” Devi was still speaking, but West did not hear her. An vision flashed in front of his eyes, three pairs of hands with elegant manicures holding up a burlap sack of a doll, just the suggestion of a head torso and limbs, that flopped in their hands. Flopped wetly, with a squelching sound that made West’s stomach flip. A man was screaming, like his heart was being torn out, and the seems of the doll began to split, and green-black sludge dripped from the openings, before… Darkness. A shrieking vacuum of darkness. Devi’s hand was on his shoulder, and he though she had noticed his distraction, but she was hardly paying attention to him, all her focus spent on frowning at her equipment. “If we stay here any longer one of you is falling into the pit,” she said. “Is that a warning or a threat?” Nellie laughed. “She’s right,” West said, and he noticed the guitar playing ghost was gone. “We’re done here.” [[Hallway 1 - West's Tour from Groove Room]]The ghost with the cropped haircut and fringe vest was sitting in the corner, strumming a silent guitar that she balanced in her lap. West’s eyes flicked to Devi, but if she had been picking up this singer’s song before, her mic wasn’t picking anything up right now. The ghost caught his gaze and stopped singing. She pointed back to the stairs, frowning, mouthing something angrily. West didn’t want to ignore her obvious warning, but she couldn’t come up just to immediately turn back around without having a real explanation. And he refused to let Nellie know. Nellie, who would exploit anything, even her own abilities or mental health issues, for a few hundred streaming views. But there were other ways to ensure a quick exit. “West, back away from the giant hole in the floor!” Devi begged. West leaned over further, filming into the pit, Nellie eagerly peering over at his side. He could hear something, faintly, from inside. Voices, ghostly and sorrowful. And every so often, a faint impossible breeze, an echo of a much more powerful gust of air from centuries ago. He was glad he hadn't tested the fragile door to the Séance Room downstairs. He could imagine breaking it, falling through, and then... well he didn't want to imagine that. “What happened here?” asked Nellie. “Does the guidebook say anything?” Devi spoke before West could check. “An earthquake at the time caused structural damage to a lot of the mansion and is said to have upset some poorly made support beams that collapsed, making the center of the floor collapse,” she said. “But some people think there was an explosion of dark energy after a séance went wrong, and the explosion caused the hole...” Devi was still speaking, but West did not hear her. An vision flashed in front of his eyes, three pairs of hands with elegant manicures holding up a burlap sack of a doll, just the suggestion of a head torso and limbs, that flopped in their hands. Flopped wetly, with a squelching sound that made West’s stomach flip. A man was screaming, like his heart was being torn out, and the seems of the doll began to split, and green-black sludge dripped from the openings, before… Darkness. A shrieking vacuum of darkness. Devi’s hand was on his shoulder, and he though she had noticed his distraction, but she was hardly paying attention to him, all her focus spent on frowning at her equipment. “If we stay here any longer one of you is falling into the pit,” she said. “Is that a warning or a threat?” Nellie laughed. “She’s right,” West said, and he noticed the guitar playing ghost was gone. “We’re done here.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]]The ghost with the cropped haircut and fringe vest was sitting in the corner, strumming a silent guitar that she balanced in her lap. West’s eyes flicked to Devi, but if she had been picking up this singer’s song before, her mic wasn’t picking anything up right now. The ghost caught his gaze and stopped singing. She pointed back to the stairs, frowning, mouthing something angrily. West didn’t want to ignore her obvious warning, but she couldn’t come up just to immediately turn back around without having a real explanation. And he refused to let Nellie know. Nellie, who would exploit anything, even her own abilities or mental health issues, for a few hundred streaming views. But there were other ways to ensure a quick exit. “West, back away from the giant hole in the floor!” Devi begged. West leaned over further, filming into the pit, Nellie eagerly peering over at his side. He could hear something, faintly, from inside. Voices, ghostly and sorrowful. And every so often, a faint impossible breeze, an echo of a much more powerful gust of air from centuries ago. “What happened here?” asked Nellie. “Does the guidebook say anything?” Devi spoke before West could check. “An earthquake at the time caused structural damage to a lot of the mansion and is said to have upset some poorly made support beams that collapsed, making the center of the floor collapse,” she said. “But some people think there was an explosion of dark energy after a séance went wrong, and the explosion caused the hole...” Devi was still speaking, but West did not hear her. An vision flashed in front of his eyes, three pairs of hands with elegant manicures holding up a burlap sack of a doll, just the suggestion of a head torso and limbs, that flopped in their hands. Flopped wetly, with a squelching sound that made West’s stomach flip. A man was screaming, like his heart was being torn out, and the seems of the doll began to split, and green-black sludge dripped from the openings, before… Darkness. A shrieking vacuum of darkness. Devi’s hand was on his shoulder, and he though she had noticed his distraction, but she was hardly paying attention to him, all her focus spent on frowning at her equipment. “If we stay here any longer one of you is falling into the pit,” she said. “Is that a warning or a threat?” Nellie laughed. “She’s right,” West said, and he noticed the guitar playing ghost was gone. “We’re done here.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]“West, I told you not to touch the door to the Séance Pit,” Devi scolded. “There is a pit behind it. If you try to enter it, you will fall and die.” West stepped back, mumbling some kind of protest. He couldn’t recognize at first that he was drawn to the door, and when he realized why, his blood ran cold. There was no spectral energy coming from the door. There was no energy at all, not even lingering memories. Not even the usual negative haunted energies of fear or sadness. It really was a pit. Devi was looking at him funny, or maybe just judgementally, but West felt the need to shake off his sudden discomfort. “The door is pretty rotted,” West said. “Not much protection from such a dangerous pit. Hell, I bet I could kick it down.” “It’s so rotted I could kick it down,” Nellie said, squaring up like she was about to try. “No one’s kicking down any doors,” Devi groaned. West wasn’t worried about the pit for the same reasons as Devi, but it did worry him. He had a bad feeling about the feelingless pit. He had a bad feeling about this mansion. “We were just joking, Devi,” West said, forcing a grin. “And now we’re just wasting time we don’t have, and I need to keep us on schedule." [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]]The ghost with the cropped haircut and fringe vest was sitting in the corner, strumming a silent guitar that she balanced in her lap. West’s eyes flicked to Devi, but if she had been picking up this singer’s song before, her mic wasn’t picking anything up right now. The ghost caught his gaze and stopped singing. She pointed back to the stairs, frowning, mouthing something angrily. West didn’t want to ignore her obvious warning, but she couldn’t come up just to immediately turn back around without having a real explanation. And he refused to let Nellie know. Nellie, who would exploit anything, even her own abilities or mental health issues, for a few hundred streaming views. But there were other ways to ensure a quick exit. “West, back away from the giant hole in the floor!” Devi begged. West leaned over further, filming into the pit, Nellie eagerly peering over at his side. He could hear something, faintly, from inside. Voices, ghostly and sorrowful. And every so often, a faint impossible breeze, an echo of a much more powerful gust of air from centuries ago. He was glad he hadn't tested the fragile door to the Séance Room downstairs. He could imagine breaking it, falling through, and then... well he didn't want to imagine that. “What happened here?” asked Nellie. “Does the guidebook say anything?” Devi spoke before West could check. “An earthquake at the time caused structural damage to a lot of the mansion and is said to have upset some poorly made support beams that collapsed, making the center of the floor collapse,” she said. “But some people think there was an explosion of dark energy after a séance went wrong, and the explosion caused the hole...” Devi was still speaking, but West did not hear her. An vision flashed in front of his eyes, three pairs of hands with elegant manicures holding up a burlap sack of a doll, just the suggestion of a head torso and limbs, that flopped in their hands. Flopped wetly, with a squelching sound that made West’s stomach flip.
