Devi’s hand was on his shoulder, and he though she had noticed his distraction, but she was hardly paying attention to him, all her focus spent on frowning at her equipment. “If we stay here any longer one of you is falling into the pit,” she said. “Is that a warning or a threat?” Nellie laughed. “She’s right,” West said, and he noticed the guitar playing ghost was gone. “We’re done here.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]“West, I told you not to touch the door to the Séance Pit,” Devi scolded. “There is a pit behind it. If you try to enter it, you will fall and die.” West stepped back, mumbling some kind of protest. He couldn’t recognize at first that he was drawn to the door, and when he realized why, his blood ran cold. There was no spectral energy coming from the door. There was no energy at all, not even lingering memories. Not even the usual negative haunted energies of fear or sadness. It really was a pit. Devi was looking at him funny, or maybe just judgementally, but West felt the need to shake off his sudden discomfort. “The door is pretty rotted,” West said. “Not much protection from such a dangerous pit. Hell, I bet I could kick it down.” “It’s so rotted I could kick it down,” Nellie said, squaring up like she was about to try. “No one’s kicking down any doors,” Devi groaned. West wasn’t worried about the pit for the same reasons as Devi, but it did worry him. He had a bad feeling about the feelingless pit. He had a bad feeling about this mansion. “We were just joking, Devi,” West said, forcing a grin. “And now we’re just wasting time we don’t have, and I need to keep us on schedule." [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]The ghost with the cropped haircut and fringe vest was sitting in the corner, strumming a silent guitar that she balanced in her lap. West’s eyes flicked to Devi, but if she had been picking up this singer’s song before, her mic wasn’t picking anything up right now. The ghost caught his gaze and stopped singing. She pointed back to the stairs, frowning, mouthing something angrily. West didn’t want to ignore her obvious warning, but she couldn’t come up just to immediately turn back around without having a real explanation. And he refused to let Nellie know. Nellie, who would exploit anything, even her own abilities or mental health issues, for a few hundred streaming views. But there were other ways to ensure a quick exit. “West, back away from the giant hole in the floor!” Devi begged. West leaned over further, filming into the pit, Nellie eagerly peering over at his side. He could hear something, faintly, from inside. Voices, ghostly and sorrowful. And every so often, a faint impossible breeze, an echo of a much more powerful gust of air from centuries ago. “What happened here?” asked Nellie. “Does the guidebook say anything?” Devi spoke before West could check. “An earthquake at the time caused structural damage to a lot of the mansion and is said to have upset some poorly made support beams that collapsed, making the center of the floor collapse,” she said. “But some people think there was an explosion of dark energy after a séance went wrong, and the explosion caused the hole...” Devi was still speaking, but West did not hear her. An vision flashed in front of his eyes, three pairs of hands with elegant manicures holding up a burlap sack of a doll, just the suggestion of a head torso and limbs, that flopped in their hands. Flopped wetly, with a squelching sound that made West’s stomach flip. A man was screaming, like his heart was being torn out, and the seems of the doll began to split, and green-black sludge dripped from the openings, before… Darkness. A shrieking vacuum of darkness. Devi’s hand was on his shoulder, and he though she had noticed his distraction, but she was hardly paying attention to him, all her focus spent on frowning at her equipment. “If we stay here any longer one of you is falling into the pit,” she said. “Is that a warning or a threat?” Nellie laughed. “She’s right,” West said, and he noticed the guitar playing ghost was gone. “We’re done here.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]] The bathroom was a little girly. Very pink. West was distracted by the images in loop of women getting ready, the faded memory projected across the weirdly moist tiles, but he still got some good footage of Nellie staring pensively into the bathroom mirror. He pulled out the guidebook, clanking at an illustration that looked like a more solid version of the image he was glimpsing, three women in elegant pink house robes delicately powdering their face, brushing their hair, putting on lipstick. “All the girls shared this bathroom,” said Devi. “Both the daughters had to share in a mansion?” Nellie asked, incredulous. “Both the daughters and Bradfords’ three lovers,” Devi clarified. “I forgot about the three lovers, all living together,” Nellie shuddered. “Bradford was such a misogynist.” “Free love isn’t inherently misogynistic,” West protested. “If you want bathroom footage, you’ll have to film here,” Devi interrupted before Nellie could really wind up West. “There was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and Bradford and Mark’s private bathrooms got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. We’ll see the doors in their bedrooms, but that’s it. I’m not picking anything up on the mics, but if any of this looks particularly compelling to you, we can have a closer look.” [[Explore the Tub - West's Tour from Groove Room]] [[Explore the Toilet - West's Tour from Groove Room]] [[Explore the Cabinet - West's Tour from Groove Room]] “West, I told you not to touch the door to the Séance Pit,” Devi scolded. “There is a pit behind it. If you try to enter it, you will fall and die.” West stepped back, mumbling some kind of protest. He couldn’t recognize at first that he was drawn to the door, and when he realized why, his blood ran cold. There was no spectral energy coming from the door. There was no energy at all, not even lingering memories. Not even the usual negative haunted energies of fear or sadness. It really was a pit. Devi was looking at him funny, or maybe just judgementally, but West felt the need to shake off his sudden discomfort. “The door is pretty rotted,” West said. “Not much protection from such a dangerous pit. Hell, I bet I could kick it down.” “It’s so rotted I could kick it down,” Nellie said, squaring up like she was about to try. “No one’s kicking down any doors,” Devi groaned. West wasn’t worried about the pit for the same reasons as Devi, but it did worry him. He had a bad feeling about the feelingless pit. He had a bad feeling about this mansion. “We were just joking, Devi,” West said, forcing a grin. “And now we’re just wasting time we don’t have, and I need to keep us on schedule." [[Girls' Bathroom - West's Tour from Groove Room and Séance Pit]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]The bathroom was a little girly. Very pink. West was distracted by the images in loop of women getting ready, the faded memory projected across the weirdly moist tiles, but he still got some good footage of Nellie staring pensively into the bathroom mirror. He pulled out the guidebook, clanking at an illustration that looked like a more solid version of the image he was glimpsing, three women in elegant pink house robes delicately powdering their face, brushing their hair, putting on lipstick. “All the girls shared this bathroom,” said Devi. “Both the daughters had to share in a mansion?” Nellie asked, incredulous. “Both the daughters and Bradfords’ three lovers,” Devi clarified. “I forgot about the three lovers, all living together,” Nellie shuddered. “Bradford was such a misogynist.” “Free love isn’t inherently misogynistic,” West protested. “If you want bathroom footage, you’ll have to film here,” Devi interrupted before Nellie could really wind up West. “There was an issue with the plumbing about ten years ago and Bradford and Mark’s private bathrooms got wrecked. The owner sealed them shut. We’ll see the doors in their bedrooms, but that’s it. I’m not picking anything up on the mics, but if any of this looks particularly compelling to you, we can have a closer look.” [[Explore the Tub - West's Tour from Groove Room and Séance Pit]] [[Explore the Toilet - West's Tour from Groove Room and Séance Pit]] [[Explore the Cabinet - West's Tour from Groove Room and Séance Pit]]“Ew, there’s sludge in the tub!” said West, smearing his fingers through the thick muck. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked, horrified. “This is what happens when you let West explore first,” Nellie laughed, shaking her head. “It’s just mold,” West said, wiping the thick substance that was almost definitely not just mold off his hand, onto his jeans. “You girls are so squeamish.” He wiped until there wasn’t anything visibly left on his fingers, but he still felt that black-green muck coating his skin. If he focused too much on the feeling, it sort of felt like it was spreading, but that was probably something malicious messing with his senses. He fought the urge to glare at Nellie. She was supposedly the sensitive one. If a ghost was going to mess with anyone, it should have been her. He was almost positive that if Nellie had explored first, she also would have touched the sludge in the tub. [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from the Tub and Groove Room]] “Do you really want to film the toilet, West?” Nellie sneered. “Right,” said West. “Who do I think I am? Hitchcock?” “What?” asked Devi. “Psycho was the first film… Never mind,” said West. [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from the Toilet and Groove Room]] “Huh,” said West, pulling a white ribbon out of the medicine cabinet. “Pretty,” said Nellie. “Don’t let her have it!” Devi warned West. He held the ribbon over his head, far out of Nellie’s reach. “You guys aren’t any fun,” Nellie pouted. The looping image of the three women paused, and the flickering blank faces turned to all glare at West until he shoved the ribbon back into its hiding place. “No fun for you, Nellie,” West said, flashing her a fake smile. “Not while I’m in charge.” [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from the Cabinet and Groove Room]] “Ew, there’s sludge in the tub!” said West, smearing his fingers through the thick muck. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked, horrified. “This is what happens when you let West explore first,” Nellie laughed, shaking her head. “It’s just mold,” West said, wiping the thick substance that was almost definitely not just mold off his hand, onto his jeans. “You girls are so squeamish.” He wiped until there wasn’t anything visibly left on his fingers, but he still felt that black-green muck coating his skin. If he focused too much on the feeling, it sort of felt like it was spreading, but that was probably something malicious messing with his senses. He fought the urge to glare at Nellie. She was supposedly the sensitive one. If a ghost was going to mess with anyone, it should have been her. He was almost positive that if Nellie had explored first, she also would have touched the sludge in the tub. [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from the Tub and Groove Room and Séance Pit]]“Do you really want to film the toilet, West?” Nellie sneered. “Right,” said West. “Who do I think I am? Hitchcock?” “What?” asked Devi. “Psycho was the first film… Never mind,” said West. [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from the Toilet and Groove Room and Séance Pit]]“Huh,” said West, pulling a white ribbon out of the medicine cabinet. “Pretty,” said Nellie. “Don’t let her have it!” Devi warned West. He held the ribbon over his head, far out of Nellie’s reach. “You guys aren’t any fun,” Nellie pouted. The looping image of the three women paused, and the flickering blank faces turned to all glare at West until he shoved the ribbon back into its hiding place. “No fun for you, Nellie,” West said, flashing her a fake smile. “Not while I’m in charge.” [[Bathroom 1 - West's Tour from the Cabinet and Groove Room and Séance Pit]]“I guess bathrooms are a pretty popular horror setting,” West said as he filmed Nellie pretending to listen for ghosts. “But it’s only interesting if something scary happens,” Devi said. [[Explore the Toilet - West's Tour from the Cabinet/Tub and Groove Room]] [[Explore the Cabinet - West's Tour from the Tub/Toilet and Groove Room]]“I guess bathrooms are a pretty popular horror setting,” West said as he filmed Nellie pretending to listen for ghosts. “But it’s only interesting if something scary happens,” Devi said. [[Explore the Toilet - West's Tour from the Cabinet/Tub and Groove Room and Séance Pit]] [[Explore the Cabinet - West's Tour from the Tub/Toilet and Groove Room and Séance Pit]]“I guess bathrooms are a pretty popular horror setting,” West said as he filmed Nellie pretending to listen for ghosts. “But it’s only interesting if something scary happens,” Devi said. [[Explore the Tub - West's Tour from the Cabinet/Toilet and Groove Room]] [[Explore the Cabinet - West's Tour from the Toilet and Groove Room]]“I guess bathrooms are a pretty popular horror setting,” West said as he filmed Nellie pretending to listen for ghosts. “But it’s only interesting if something scary happens,” Devi said. [[Explore the Tub - West's Tour from the Cabinet/Toilet and Groove Room and Séance Pit]] [[Explore the Cabinet - West's Tour from the Toilet and Groove Room and Séance Pit]]“I guess bathrooms are a pretty popular horror setting,” West said as he filmed Nellie pretending to listen for ghosts. “But it’s only interesting if something scary happens,” Devi said. [[Explore the Toilet - West's Tour from the Cabinet and Groove Room]] [[Explore the Tub - West's Tour from the Cabinet/Toilet and Groove Room]]“I guess bathrooms are a pretty popular horror setting,” West said as he filmed Nellie pretending to listen for ghosts. “But it’s only interesting if something scary happens,” Devi said. [[Explore the Toilet - West's Tour from the Cabinet and Groove Room and Séance Pit]] [[Explore the Tub - West's Tour from the Cabinet/Toilet and Groove Room and Séance Pit]]“Do you really want to film the toilet, West?” Nellie sneered. “Right,” said West. “Who do I think I am? Hitchcock?” “What?” asked Devi. “Psycho was the first film… Never mind,” said West. [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Séance Pit - West's Tour with Sludge from Groove Room]]“Ew, there’s sludge in the tub!” said West, smearing his fingers through the thick muck. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked, horrified. “This is what happens when you let West explore first,” Nellie laughed, shaking her head. “It’s just mold,” West said, wiping the thick substance that was almost definitely not just mold off his hand, onto his jeans. “You girls are so squeamish.” He wiped until there wasn’t anything visibly left on his fingers, but he still felt that black-green muck coating his skin. If he focused too much on the feeling, it sort of felt like it was spreading, but that was probably something malicious messing with his senses. He fought the urge to glare at Nellie. She was supposedly the sensitive one. If a ghost was going to mess with anyone, it should have been her. He was almost positive that if Nellie had explored first, she also would have touched the sludge in the tub. [[Séance Pit - West's Tour with Sludge from Groove Room]] [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]]“Huh,” said West, pulling a white ribbon out of the medicine cabinet. “Pretty,” said Nellie. “Don’t let her have it!” Devi warned West. He held the ribbon over his head, far out of Nellie’s reach. “You guys aren’t any fun,” Nellie pouted. The looping image of the three women paused, and the flickering blank faces turned to all glare at West until he shoved the ribbon back into its hiding place. “No fun for you, Nellie,” West said, flashing her a fake smile. “Not while I’m in charge.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Séance Pit - West's Tour with Sludge from Groove Room]]“Do you really want to film the toilet, West?” Nellie sneered. “Right,” said West. “Who do I think I am? Hitchcock?” “What?” asked Devi. “Psycho was the first film… Never mind,” said West. [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]]“Huh,” said West, pulling a white ribbon out of the medicine cabinet. “Pretty,” said Nellie. “Don’t let her have it!” Devi warned West. He held the ribbon over his head, far out of Nellie’s reach. “You guys aren’t any fun,” Nellie pouted. The looping image of the three women paused, and the flickering blank faces turned to all glare at West until he shoved the ribbon back into its hiding place. “No fun for you, Nellie,” West said, flashing her a fake smile. “Not while I’m in charge.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]]“Ew, there’s sludge in the tub!” said West, smearing his fingers through the thick muck. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked, horrified. “This is what happens when you let West explore first,” Nellie laughed, shaking her head. “It’s just mold,” West said, wiping the thick substance that was almost definitely not just mold off his hand, onto his jeans. “You girls are so squeamish.” He wiped until there wasn’t anything visibly left on his fingers, but he still felt that black-green muck coating his skin. If he focused too much on the feeling, it sort of felt like it was spreading, but that was probably something malicious messing with his senses. He fought the urge to glare at Nellie. She was supposedly the sensitive one. If a ghost was going to mess with anyone, it should have been her. He was almost positive that if Nellie had explored first, she also would have touched the sludge in the tub. [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour with Sludge]]“Do you really want to film the toilet, West?” Nellie sneered. “Right,” said West. “Who do I think I am? Hitchcock?” “What?” asked Devi. “Psycho was the first film… Never mind,” said West. [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]] [[Séance Pit - West's Tour from Groove Room and GBR]]“Huh,” said West, pulling a white ribbon out of the medicine cabinet. “Pretty,” said Nellie. “Don’t let her have it!” Devi warned West. He held the ribbon over his head, far out of Nellie’s reach. “You guys aren’t any fun,” Nellie pouted. The looping image of the three women paused, and the flickering blank faces turned to all glare at West until he shoved the ribbon back into its hiding place. “No fun for you, Nellie,” West said, flashing her a fake smile. “Not while I’m in charge.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]] [[Séance Pit - West's Tour from Groove Room and GBR]]“Huh,” said West, pulling a white ribbon out of the medicine cabinet. “Pretty,” said Nellie. “Don’t let her have it!” Devi warned West. He held the ribbon over his head, far out of Nellie’s reach. “You guys aren’t any fun,” Nellie pouted. The looping image of the three women paused, and the flickering blank faces turned to all glare at West until he shoved the ribbon back into its hiding place. “No fun for you, Nellie,” West said, flashing her a fake smile. “Not while I’m in charge.” [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]“Do you really want to film the toilet, West?” Nellie sneered. “Right,” said West. “Who do I think I am? Hitchcock?” “What?” asked Devi. “Psycho was the first film… Never mind,” said West. [[Hallway 2 - West's Tour]]The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. It didn’t feel ghostly, but it didn’t seem normal either. “I can’t believe you touched that stuff,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. West wiped his hand against his pants again. There was no sign of the sludge on his skin, but when he looked at it pooling out from the door, he could feel it. Creeping along him. Seeping inside. “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said. West balanced the camera on his shoulder, clumsily flipped through the guidebook with his free hand. He found a picture of Mark, playing a guitar. “Does anyone see a guitar in all this?” West asked, looking at the lumpy shapes in the room. “Mark’s missing body could be rotting here and I wouldn’t be able to tell,” said Devi. “They say Bradford buried his body in the garden after they had a huge blow out, but maybe he just left it here.” “That would explain the smell,” Nellie gagged. West shoved the guidebook in his pocket, giving a final glance around the room for something almost appealing to film, and the dull light from his camera was briefly reflect back to him on the tiniest object in the corner of the room. He leaned down, reaching towards it. “Don’t touch the sludge!” Devi chided. “I’m not!” said West. He picked up a small bit of plastic. A guitar pick. “Good find,” said Nellie. “If it’s Mark’s, that is. If it was left by some tourist, it’s a stupid find and we’re wasting time in a disgusting room talking about it.” “The fumes are getting to me,” said Devi. “Let’s go, please.” [[Tara's Room - West's Tour with Sludge from Mark's Room]] [[Dawn's Room - West's Tour with Sludge from Mark's Room]] “Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow. But West could barely see any of this mundane backdrop beneath the layers of ghostly after images. Not spirits, there was no consciousness in these shades that lay as thick as the sludge that plagued the Bennington plumbing. They were barely memories. Just trauma that could not quite pass on, held in Tara’s bedroom by… what? Usually trauma echoes were hitched to this reality by guilt. But there was no one left in the Bennington mansion to feel guilty, nothing to hold on to this lingering despair. Nellie was practically wading through them in her effort to explore the room and possibly steal the teddy bear, completely unaware of the distressed broken shapes she left in her wake. “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” West flipped to Tara’s page in the guidebook, that showed an artistic picture of a girl who was more curls and ruffles than human being. “She looks pretty harmless,” West said, his eyes flicking to the shades that had congealed in the girl’s room. “Don’t trust appearances,” said Devi. “She was Bradford’s protégée in the dark arts. Apparently she was as skilled as him at communing with dark forces.” “I believe it,” West said under his breath. “I wonder if she wanted that magic,” Nellie asked, surprisingly thoughtful. “Or if she resented the pressure of being Bradford’s favourite.” West shared a look with Devi. They hadn’t said anything about favourites, but it felt true. “Well, maybe, maybe not,” said Devi. “After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, and took care of Bradford in his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and then she fled. Disappeared. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or because of the evil magic he made her do. Or because she wanted to absorb his power.” “Weird,” said West. Had the layer of shades gotten thicker as they spoke? Or wetter? Grosser? “We should go.” [[Mark's Room - West's Tour with Sludge from Dawn's/Tara's Room]] [[Dawn's Room - West's Tour with Sludge from Tara's Room]] The room looked particularly wrecked. West would have assumed a poltergeist had made its way through the eldest Bradford child’s room, but there was an almost disturbing lack of ghostly presence here. The jagged scratches on the walls, teeth marks on the bedposts, and crushed costume jewellery on the floor did not reflect a hint of a memory. As much as West was tired of ghosts in his life, the complete lack of ghosts in a clearly haunted mansion made the hair rise on the back of his neck. Where was Dawn? Did she actually move on? West didn’t think so. He opened up the guidebook and frowned at the illustration. The blond woman with the feathered fringe was clearly supposed to be Dawn. There was another figure, sitting by her feet. With a messy cropped haircut, strumming a guitar. “Who’s that?” West asked Devi as Nellie admired the broken costume jewellery. “If you read the entry, you would find out,” Devi huffed. “I know you know, just tell me,” West said, sharper than he intended. “Someone’s being bitchy, and it’s not me, which is weird,” Nellie muttered into her mic. The comment softened Devi’s glare and she shrugged, pointing to the mystery ghost. “That was Dawn’s girlfriend, Emma, a folksinger. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react, with Emma not being rich or connected or anything. But Mark found out and told Bradford, and Bradford forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again, and the singer disappeared. Some legends say he arranged for Emma to be murdered, or sacrificed her to a dark spirit. Which sounds insane, even for an occult family, but might actually be true because Dawn committed suicide not long after Emma disappeared. She hanged herself in the Upper Séance room with her own bedsheets...” Devi’s voice trailed off when they heard Nellie sniffle. She was holding a few of the broken jewellery pieces in her hands. West was not sure if he had ever seen her cry. Or show a genuine emotion. He filmed her, even though it made him feel like a dick. “Nel, do you need a sec?” West asked. “Or a tissue?” “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty. We can keep going.” [[Mark's Room - West's Tour with Sludge from Dawn's/Tara's Room]] [[Tara's Room - West's Tour with Sludge from Dawn's Room]] The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. It didn’t feel ghostly, but it didn’t seem normal either. “Don’t touch anything, even if you think it would be hilarious, this place looks toxic,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. “The owner said the men’s bathrooms were… well I was not prepared for this.” “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said. West balanced the camera on his shoulder, clumsily flipped through the guidebook with his free hand. He found a picture of Mark, playing a guitar. “Does anyone see a guitar in all this?” West asked, looking at the lumpy shapes in the room. “Mark’s missing body could be rotting here and I wouldn’t be able to tell,” said Devi. “They say Bradford buried his body in the garden after they had a huge blow out, but maybe he just left it here.” “That would explain the smell,” Nellie gagged. West shoved the guidebook in his pocket, giving a final glance around the room for something almost appealing to film, and the dull light from his camera was briefly reflect back to him on the tiniest object in the corner of the room. He leaned down, reaching towards it. “Don’t touch the sludge!” Devi chided. “I’m not!” said West. He picked up a small bit of plastic. A guitar pick. “Good find,” said Nellie. “If it’s Mark’s, that is. If it was left by some tourist, it’s a stupid find and we’re wasting time in a disgusting room talking about it.” “The fumes are getting to me,” said Devi. “Let’s go, please.” [[Dawn's Room - West's Tour from Mark's Room]] [[Tara's Room - West's Tour from Mark's Room]] “Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow. But West could barely see any of this mundane backdrop beneath the layers of ghostly after images. Not spirits, there was no consciousness in these shades that lay as thick as the sludge that plagued the Bennington plumbing. They were barely memories. Just trauma that could not quite pass on, held in Tara’s bedroom by… what? Usually trauma echoes were hitched to this reality by guilt. But there was no one left in the Bennington mansion to feel guilty, nothing to hold on to this lingering despair. Nellie was practically wading through them in her effort to explore the room and possibly steal the teddy bear, completely unaware of the distressed broken shapes she left in her wake. “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” West flipped to Tara’s page in the guidebook, that showed an artistic picture of a girl who was more curls and ruffles than human being. “She looks pretty harmless,” West said, his eyes flicking to the shades that had congealed in the girl’s room. “Don’t trust appearances,” said Devi. “She was Bradford’s protégée in the dark arts. Apparently she was as skilled as him at communing with dark forces.” “I believe it,” West said under his breath. “I wonder if she wanted that magic,” Nellie asked, surprisingly thoughtful. “Or if she resented the pressure of being Bradford’s favourite.” West shared a look with Devi. They hadn’t said anything about favourites, but it felt true. “Well, maybe, maybe not,” said Devi. “After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, and took care of Bradford in his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and then she fled. Disappeared. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or because of the evil magic he made her do. Or because she wanted to absorb his power.” “Weird,” said West. Had the layer of shades gotten thicker as they spoke? Or wetter? Grosser? “We should go.” [[Mark's Room - West's Tour from Dawn's/Tara's Room]] [[Dawn's Room - West's Tour from Tara's Room]] The room looked particularly wrecked. West would have assumed a poltergeist had made its way through the eldest Bradford child’s room, but there was an almost disturbing lack of ghostly presence here. The jagged scratches on the walls, teeth marks on the bedposts, and crushed costume jewellery on the floor did not reflect a hint of a memory. As much as West was tired of ghosts in his life, the complete lack of ghosts in a clearly haunted mansion made the hair rise on the back of his neck. Where was Dawn? Did she actually move on? West didn’t think so. He opened up the guidebook and frowned at the illustration. The blond woman with the feathered fringe was clearly supposed to be Dawn. There was another figure, sitting by her feet. With a messy cropped haircut, strumming a guitar. “Who’s that?” West asked Devi as Nellie admired the broken costume jewellery. “If you read the entry, you would find out,” Devi huffed. “I know you know, just tell me,” West said, sharper than he intended. “Someone’s being bitchy, and it’s not me, which is weird,” Nellie muttered into her mic. The comment softened Devi’s glare and she shrugged, pointing to the mystery ghost. “That was Dawn’s girlfriend, Emma, a folksinger. They kept their relationship a secret because they were worried how Dawn’s family would react, with Emma not being rich or connected or anything. But Mark found out and told Bradford, and Bradford forbade Dawn from ever seeing Emma again, and the singer disappeared. Some legends say he arranged for Emma to be murdered, or sacrificed her to a dark spirit. Which sounds insane, even for an occult family, but might actually be true because Dawn committed suicide not long after Emma disappeared. She hanged herself in the Upper Séance room with her own bedsheets...” Devi’s voice trailed off when they heard Nellie sniffle. She was holding a few of the broken jewellery pieces in her hands. West was not sure if he had ever seen her cry. Or show a genuine emotion. He filmed her, even though it made him feel like a dick. “Nel, do you need a sec?” West asked. “Or a tissue?” “No,” Nellie said. “It’s just… dusty. We can keep going.” [[Mark's Room - West's Tour from Dawn's/Tara's Room]] [[Tara's Room - West's Tour from Dawn's Room]] The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. It didn’t feel ghostly, but it didn’t seem normal either. “I can’t believe you touched that stuff,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. West wiped his hand against his pants again. There was no sign of the sludge on his skin, but when he looked at it pooling out from the door, he could feel it. Creeping along him. Seeping inside. “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said. West balanced the camera on his shoulder, clumsily flipped through the guidebook with his free hand. He found a picture of Mark, playing a guitar. “Does anyone see a guitar in all this?” West asked, looking at the lumpy shapes in the room. “Mark’s missing body could be rotting here and I wouldn’t be able to tell,” said Devi. “They say Bradford buried his body in the garden after they had a huge blow out, but maybe he just left it here.” “That would explain the smell,” Nellie gagged. West shoved the guidebook in his pocket, giving a final glance around the room for something almost appealing to film, and the dull light from his camera was briefly reflect back to him on the tiniest object in the corner of the room. He leaned down, reaching towards it. “Don’t touch the sludge!” Devi chided. “I’m not!” said West. He picked up a small bit of plastic. A guitar pick. “Good find,” said Nellie. “If it’s Mark’s, that is. If it was left by some tourist, it’s a stupid find and we’re wasting time in a disgusting room talking about it.” “The fumes are getting to me,” said Devi. West frowned as he stared at piece of the bedframe that had not completely rotted. “There’s some kind of message scratched on here,” West said, leaning down to read it more closely. “West, do not touch the rotten wood,” Devi chided. "Let's go." [[Mark's Message - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]“Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow. But West could barely see any of this mundane backdrop beneath the layers of ghostly after images. Not spirits, there was no consciousness in these shades that lay as thick as the sludge that plagued the Bennington plumbing. They were barely memories. Just trauma that could not quite pass on, held in Tara’s bedroom by… what? Usually trauma echoes were hitched to this reality by guilt. But there was no one left in the Bennington mansion to feel guilty, nothing to hold on to this lingering despair. Nellie was practically wading through them in her effort to explore the room and possibly steal the teddy bear, completely unaware of the distressed broken shapes she left in her wake. “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” West flipped to Tara’s page in the guidebook, that showed an artistic picture of a girl who was more curls and ruffles than human being. “She looks pretty harmless,” West said, his eyes flicking to the shades that had congealed in the girl’s room. “Don’t trust appearances,” said Devi. “She was Bradford’s protégée in the dark arts. Apparently she was as skilled as him at communing with dark forces.” “I believe it,” West said under his breath. “I wonder if she wanted that magic,” Nellie asked, surprisingly thoughtful. “Or if she resented the pressure of being Bradford’s favourite.” West shared a look with Devi. They hadn’t said anything about favourites, but it felt true. “Well, maybe, maybe not,” said Devi. “After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, and took care of Bradford in his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and then she fled. Disappeared. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or because of the evil magic he made her do. Or because she wanted to absorb his power.” “Weird,” said West. Had the layer of shades gotten thicker as they spoke? Or wetter? Grosser? “We should go.” “Wait,” said Devi, crouching to look at a little box on the ground, no bigger than a box for a ring, with nine sliding tiles on the top. “There’s some kind of puzzle here.” “No, I see numbers, that counts as math,” Nellie protested. “We’re going to the next room.” [[Tara's Puzzle Box - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge]] “Absolutely not,” said Nellie. She pulled a pencil out of her bag. “You are not going to write on a dead woman’s poem!” West protested. “Some of the words are faded,” Nellie insisted. “I’m just going to write them in so they show up on camera.” “How will you know what the right words are?” Devi asked. “Well, the verses are haikus,” said Nellie. “And you can kind of see what the words should be. We’ll just make it fit the pattern. Here’s the first verse.” //Did I die that night? All the stars went out at once I saw the moon _____// [[winking - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[warping - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[weep - West's Tour with Sludge]]“Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow. But West could barely see any of this mundane backdrop beneath the layers of ghostly after images. Not spirits, there was no consciousness in these shades that lay as thick as the sludge that plagued the Bennington plumbing. They were barely memories. Just trauma that could not quite pass on, held in Tara’s bedroom by… what? Usually trauma echoes were hitched to this reality by guilt. But there was no one left in the Bennington mansion to feel guilty, nothing to hold on to this lingering despair. Nellie was practically wading through them in her effort to explore the room and possibly steal the teddy bear, completely unaware of the distressed broken shapes she left in her wake. “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” West flipped to Tara’s page in the guidebook, that showed an artistic picture of a girl who was more curls and ruffles than human being. “She looks pretty harmless,” West said, his eyes flicking to the shades that had congealed in the girl’s room. “Don’t trust appearances,” said Devi. “She was Bradford’s protégée in the dark arts. Apparently she was as skilled as him at communing with dark forces.” “I believe it,” West said under his breath. “I wonder if she wanted that magic,” Nellie asked, surprisingly thoughtful. “Or if she resented the pressure of being Bradford’s favourite.” West shared a look with Devi. They hadn’t said anything about favourites, but it felt true. “Well, maybe, maybe not,” said Devi. “After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, and took care of Bradford in his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and then she fled. Disappeared. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or because of the evil magic he made her do. Or because she wanted to absorb his power.” “Weird,” said West. Had the layer of shades gotten thicker as they spoke? Or wetter? Grosser? “We should go.” “Wait,” said Devi, crouching to look at a little box on the ground, no bigger than a box for a ring, with nine sliding tiles on the top. “There’s some kind of puzzle here.” “No, I see numbers, that counts as math,” Nellie protested. “We’re going to the next room.” [[Tara's Puzzle Box - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] “Absolutely not,” said Nellie. She pulled a pencil out of her bag. “You are not going to write on a dead woman’s poem!” West protested. “Some of the words are faded,” Nellie insisted. “I’m just going to write them in so they show up on camera.” “How will you know what the right words are?” Devi asked. “Well, the verses are haikus,” said Nellie. “And you can kind of see what the words should be. We’ll just make it fit the pattern. Here’s the first verse.” //Did I die that night? All the stars went out at once I saw the moon _____// [[winking - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[warping - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[weep - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]“Absolutely not,” said Nellie. She pulled a pencil out of her bag. “You are not going to write on a dead woman’s poem!” West protested. “Some of the words are faded,” Nellie insisted. “I’m just going to write them in so they show up on camera.” “How will you know what the right words are?” Devi asked. “Well, the verses are haikus,” said Nellie. “And you can kind of see what the words should be. We’ll just make it fit the pattern. Here’s the first verse.” //Did I die that night? All the stars went out at once I saw the moon _____// [[winking - West's Tour with Pick]] [[warping - West's Tour with Pick]] [[weep - West's Tour with Pick]]“Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow. But West could barely see any of this mundane backdrop beneath the layers of ghostly after images. Not spirits, there was no consciousness in these shades that lay as thick as the sludge that plagued the Bennington plumbing. They were barely memories. Just trauma that could not quite pass on, held in Tara’s bedroom by… what? Usually trauma echoes were hitched to this reality by guilt. But there was no one left in the Bennington mansion to feel guilty, nothing to hold on to this lingering despair. Nellie was practically wading through them in her effort to explore the room and possibly steal the teddy bear, completely unaware of the distressed broken shapes she left in her wake. “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” West flipped to Tara’s page in the guidebook, that showed an artistic picture of a girl who was more curls and ruffles than human being. “She looks pretty harmless,” West said, his eyes flicking to the shades that had congealed in the girl’s room. “Don’t trust appearances,” said Devi. “She was Bradford’s protégée in the dark arts. Apparently she was as skilled as him at communing with dark forces.” “I believe it,” West said under his breath. “I wonder if she wanted that magic,” Nellie asked, surprisingly thoughtful. “Or if she resented the pressure of being Bradford’s favourite.” West shared a look with Devi. They hadn’t said anything about favourites, but it felt true. “Well, maybe, maybe not,” said Devi. “After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, and took care of Bradford in his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and then she fled. Disappeared. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or because of the evil magic he made her do. Or because she wanted to absorb his power.” “Weird,” said West. Had the layer of shades gotten thicker as they spoke? Or wetter? Grosser? “We should go.” “Wait,” said Devi, crouching to look at a little box on the ground, no bigger than a box for a ring, with nine sliding tiles on the top. “There’s some kind of puzzle here.” “No, I see numbers, that counts as math,” Nellie protested. “We’re going to the next room.” [[Tara's Puzzle Box - West's Tour with Pick]] [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]] The wallpaper might have been a purple paisley print a long time ago, but it had softened to general swirls with the funky-smelling rot that left it wet and peeling. The brown sludge seemed to originate from under a door at the far end of the room that was nailed shut with large pieces of wood, the freshest items in the room. Everything else, from the soggy remains of poster drooping from nails in the wall, to the marshy remains of a bedspread on the once proud and now rotting wooden frame, had been taken over by the sludge. It didn’t feel ghostly, but it didn’t seem normal either. “I can’t believe you touched that stuff,” Devi said, hand covering her nose and mouth. West wiped his hand against his pants again. There was no sign of the sludge on his skin, but when he looked at it pooling out from the door, he could feel it. Creeping along him. Seeping inside. “West, camera on me, we’re going to be quick about this,” Nellie said. West balanced the camera on his shoulder, clumsily flipped through the guidebook with his free hand. He found a picture of Mark, playing a guitar. “Does anyone see a guitar in all this?” West asked, looking at the lumpy shapes in the room. “Mark’s missing body could be rotting here and I wouldn’t be able to tell,” said Devi. “They say Bradford buried his body in the garden after they had a huge blow out, but maybe he just left it here.” “That would explain the smell,” Nellie gagged. West shoved the guidebook in his pocket, giving a final glance around the room for something almost appealing to film, and the dull light from his camera was briefly reflect back to him on the tiniest object in the corner of the room. He leaned down, reaching towards it. “Don’t touch the sludge!” Devi chided. “I’m not!” said West. He picked up a small bit of plastic. A guitar pick. “Good find,” said Nellie. “If it’s Mark’s, that is. If it was left by some tourist, it’s a stupid find and we’re wasting time in a disgusting room talking about it.” “The fumes are getting to me,” said Devi. West frowned as he stared at piece of the bedframe that had not completely rotted. “There’s some kind of message scratched on here,” West said, leaning down to read it more closely. “West, do not touch the rotten wood,” Devi chided. "Let's go." [[Mark's Message - West's Tour with Pick]] [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“Holy crap, West, you’re recording this, right?” “Yes, Nellie, obviously.” The room was very dark. It was sandwiched between the hall and Dawn’s room, so there were no porthole windows to let in the scant starlight that lit the rest of the house. But even in the dull glow of the camera’s light, it was clear that this room had been spared the years of rot and disrepair they had seen elsewhere in the mansion. The bed even looked freshly made, turned down, ready for an occupant to slip inside. There was a teddy bear on a pillow. But West could barely see any of this mundane backdrop beneath the layers of ghostly after images. Not spirits, there was no consciousness in these shades that lay as thick as the sludge that plagued the Bennington plumbing. They were barely memories. Just trauma that could not quite pass on, held in Tara’s bedroom by… what? Usually trauma echoes were hitched to this reality by guilt. But there was no one left in the Bennington mansion to feel guilty, nothing to hold on to this lingering despair. Nellie was practically wading through them in her effort to explore the room and possibly steal the teddy bear, completely unaware of the distressed broken shapes she left in her wake. “You should get in the bed,” West whispered. “I am not getting in the bed,” Nellie whispered back. “Guys, please don’t whisper,” Devi sighed. “The mics won’t pick you up if you keep whispering.” West flipped to Tara’s page in the guidebook, that showed an artistic picture of a girl who was more curls and ruffles than human being. “She looks pretty harmless,” West said, his eyes flicking to the shades that had congealed in the girl’s room. “Don’t trust appearances,” said Devi. “She was Bradford’s protégée in the dark arts. Apparently she was as skilled as him at communing with dark forces.” “I believe it,” West said under his breath. “I wonder if she wanted that magic,” Nellie asked, surprisingly thoughtful. “Or if she resented the pressure of being Bradford’s favourite.” West shared a look with Devi. They hadn’t said anything about favourites, but it felt true. “Well, maybe, maybe not,” said Devi. “After her siblings died and Bradford’s lovers abandoned him, Tara stayed, and took care of Bradford in his old age. She was supposedly at his side when he died, and then she fled. Disappeared. There were some rumors that she killed Bradford as revenge for her siblings’ misfortunes, or because of the evil magic he made her do. Or because she wanted to absorb his power.” “Weird,” said West. Had the layer of shades gotten thicker as they spoke? Or wetter? Grosser? “We should go.” “Wait,” said Devi, crouching to look at a little box on the ground, no bigger than a box for a ring, with nine sliding tiles on the top. “There’s some kind of puzzle here.” “No, I see numbers, that counts as math,” Nellie protested. “We’re going to the next room.” [[Tara's Puzzle Box - West's Tour]] [[Library - West's Tour]] “Absolutely not,” said Nellie. She pulled a pencil out of her bag. “You are not going to write on a dead woman’s poem!” West protested. “Some of the words are faded,” Nellie insisted. “I’m just going to write them in so they show up on camera.” “How will you know what the right words are?” Devi asked. “Well, the verses are haikus,” said Nellie. “And you can kind of see what the words should be. We’ll just make it fit the pattern. Here’s the first verse.” //Did I die that night? All the stars went out at once I saw the moon _____// [[winking - West's Tour]] [[warping - West's Tour]] [[weep - West's Tour]]“I’m not touching it,” West protested. “I’m filming it. Look. It’s in code. Seems like someone who had no issues scratching rotten wood already started decoding it.” £^: -|[:_ “+: £+\~_> £| .~<< [: THE “I get it,” said Nellie, cocking her head. “I take that back. I don’t get it. The… The what?” [[DEVIL - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[TOTEM - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[WOMEN - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] West guided Devi and Nellie through the hallway and under an ornate archway into the library. It was dark, but he caught a glimpse of a shadowy ghost. She didn’t seem malevolent, but she did seem surprisingly distressed by their arrival. She hurried through the far wall, out of the library, clutching some illusion of a book close to her chest, her curls bouncing behind her until they disappeared through the moldy plaster wall. West eyed the cracks in the walls that unnerved him much more than the singular spectral presence. Could the building fall down on them? The fact that the ceiling was made of a strangely stained glass didn’t help. “Is that sludge or a choice?” West asked Devi. Her eyes followed as he pointed his camera up, and she squinted at the shadowed material above them. West didn’t blame her. There weren’t any of the mansion’s signature porthole windows in this room, the only light dimly edging in from the hallway. He told himself he could see it better through the camera, but the hairs on the back of his neck knew that was a lie. The only ghost here might have left, but there was something paranormal about that glass, the sky it tried so hard to obscure… his fingertips tingled as he imagined the feel of that glass, how cool it would be, slick and foul. Devi pulled a flashlight from her bag and panned across the uninviting room, illuminating bookshelves still filled with books that looked like they would tumble to the ground with one good knock on the strained wood. The black leather sofas that filled looked like low gravestones being swallowed by the earth. Or in this case, the hardwood floor. It looked pretty, but based on the state of the bookshelves, West wasn’t feeling too confident about exploring with the extra weight of their gear. “The floor is lava,” Nellie whispered. West chuckled, barely listening, his eyes flicking between the floor and the ceiling, trying to guess which was the bigger danger. Devi’s light caught on a large globe with a golden-hued frame and what looked like hand-painted countries, something West expected to see in a Victorian museum, not a 1970s mansion. There was a tapestry hanging on the wall, one corner hanging loose so it folded on itself, and he wasn’t sure if Devi even noticed how she avoided it, but West marked that it hung right above where the ghost had been reading. The light stopped at the far end of the room, where a similar archway led further into the mansion, bringing them closer to their final destination. Next to it, a solid black winding staircase led to an upper floor, there artificial material marking them as the least deteriorated thing in the room. “Well,” said Nellie. “There’s a lot going on here. I feel like library’s are made to be haunted. Lead the way West. But keep that camera on me.” West did as he was told. [[Tapestry - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Upper Floor Observatory- West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]“I’m not touching it,” West protested. “I’m filming it. Look. It’s in code. Seems like someone who had no issues scratching rotten wood already started decoding it.” £^: -|[:_ “+: £+\~_> £| .~<< [: THE “I get it,” said Nellie, cocking her head. “I take that back. I don’t get it. Next to it, a solid black winding staircase led to an upper floor, there artificial material marking them as the least deteriorated thing in the room. “Well,” said Nellie. “There’s a lot going on here. I feel like library’s are made to be haunted. Lead the way West. But keep that camera on me.” West did as he was told. [[Tapestry - West's Tour with Pick]] [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Pick]] [[Upper Floor Observatory- West's Tour with Pick]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] “I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]“Okay…” said Nellie. “You still don’t get it, do you?” asked West. “Just… no. Keep going, if you’re so smart.” £^: -|[:_ “+: £+\~_> £| .~<< [: THE WOMEN [[ARE TRYING - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[RUN WILDLY - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[FED FATHER - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] “I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“Okay…” said Nellie. “You still don’t get it, do you?” asked West. “Just… no. West's Tour with Pick]] [[TO SELL ME - West's Tour with Pick]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]“What do you think it means?” Devi asked. “THE WOMEN ARE TRYING TO KILL ME,” Nellie said. “I mean… is that vague?” “Yes,” Devi huffed. “Is he talking about his sisters? Bradford’s lovers? Some other women completely?” “Pretty cool, though,” said West. “We have different definitions of cool,” Devi laughed. “Let’s get out of here. That message is freaking me out.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] “I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“What do you think it means?” Devi asked. “THE WOMEN ARE TRYING TO KILL ME,” Nellie said. “I mean… is that vague?” “Yes,” Devi huffed. “Is he talking about his sisters? Bradford’s lovers? Some other women completely?” “Pretty cool, though,” said West. “We have different definitions of cool,” Devi laughed. “Let’s get out of here. That message is freaking me out.” [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“I think I messed up the pattern,” West mumbled. “I think it might just be random, and we do not have the time to figure out if I’m wrong,” said Nellie. “She’s right, West,” said Devi. “Let’s go.” [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“It’s not math,” said Devi, picking up the box. “We just need to slide the tiles so it looks like 123 456 78□ I can’t open the lid, so I’m guessing this is like a key. If we solve it, we unlock it. And it’s mostly solved!” She showed Devi and West the tiles. 123 485 7□6 “If this takes more than three tries, we’re leaving,” said Nellie. [[slide 8 down - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[slide 6 left - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[slide 7 right - West's Tour with Sludge]] West guided Devi and Nellie through the hallway and under an ornate archway into the library. It was dark, but he caught a glimpse of a shadowy ghost. She didn’t seem malevolent, but she did seem surprisingly distressed by their arrival. She hurried through the far wall, out of the library, clutching some illusion of a book close to her chest, her curls bouncing behind her until they disappeared through the moldy plaster wall. West eyed the cracks in the walls that unnerved him much more than the singular spectral presence. Could the building fall down on them? The fact that the ceiling was made of a strangely stained glass didn’t help. “Is that sludge or a choice?” West asked Devi. Her eyes followed as he pointed his camera up, and she squinted at the shadowed material above them. West didn’t blame her. There weren’t any of the mansion’s signature porthole windows in this room, the only light dimly edging in from the hallway. He told himself he could see it better through the camera, but the hairs on the back of his neck knew that was a lie. The only ghost here might have left, but there was something paranormal about that glass, the sky it tried so hard to obscure… his fingertips tingled as he imagined the feel of that glass, how cool it would be, slick and foul. Devi pulled a flashlight from her bag and panned across the uninviting room, illuminating bookshelves still filled with books that looked like they would tumble to the ground with one good knock on the strained wood. The black leather sofas that filled looked like low gravestones being swallowed by the earth. Or in this case, the hardwood floor. It looked pretty, but based on the state of the bookshelves, West wasn’t feeling too confident about exploring with the extra weight of their gear. “The floor is lava,” Nellie whispered. West chuckled, barely listening, his eyes flicking between the floor and the ceiling, trying to guess which was the bigger danger. Devi’s light caught on a large globe with a golden-hued frame and what looked like hand-painted countries, something West expected to see in a Victorian museum, not a 1970s mansion. There was a tapestry hanging on the wall, one corner hanging loose so it folded on itself, and he wasn’t sure if Devi even noticed how she avoided it, but West marked that it hung right above where the ghost had been reading. The light stopped at the far end of the room, where a similar archway led further into the mansion, bringing them closer to their final destination. Next to it, a solid black winding staircase led to an upper floor, there artificial material marking them as the least deteriorated thing in the room. “Well,” said Nellie. “There’s a lot going on here. I feel like library’s are made to be haunted. Lead the way West. But keep that camera on me.” West did as he was told. [[Tapestry - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Upper Floor Observatory- West's Tour with Sludge]] “It’s not math,” said Devi, picking up the box. “We just need to slide the tiles so it looks like 123 456 78□ I can’t open the lid, so I’m guessing this is like a key. If we solve it, we unlock it. And it’s mostly solved!” She showed Devi and West the tiles. 123 485 7□6 “If this takes more than three tries, we’re leaving,” said Nellie. [[slide 8 down - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[slide 6 left - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[slide 7 right - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]“It’s not math,” said Devi, picking up the box. “We just need to slide the tiles so it looks like 123 456 78□ I can’t open the lid, so I’m guessing this is like a key. If we solve it, we unlock it. And it’s mostly solved!” She showed Devi and West the tiles. 123 485 7□6 “If this takes more than three tries, we’re leaving,” said Nellie. I feel like library’s are made to be haunted. Lead the way West. But keep that camera on me.” West did as he was told. [[Tapestry - West's Tour]] [[Bookshelves - West's Tour]] [[Upper Floor Observatory- West's Tour]]“It’s not math,” said Devi, picking up the box. “We just need to slide the tiles so it looks like 123 456 78□ I can’t open the lid, so I’m guessing this is like a key. If we solve it, we unlock it. And it’s mostly solved!” She showed Devi and West the tiles. 123 485 7□6 “If this takes more than three tries, we’re leaving,” said Nellie. [[slide 8 down - West's Tour with Pick]] [[slide 6 left - West's Tour with Pick]] [[slide 7 right - West's Tour with Pick]]“I hate this,” said Nellie. “Just give me a second,” Devi sighed. 123 4□5 786 [[slide 4 right - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[slide 2 down - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[slide 5 left - West's Tour with Sludge]] “Wait, I’m so close!” Devi groaned, sliding the tiles around at random now, but Nellie was already walking out the door. She had no choice but to drop the puzzle box and follow. She had no choice but to drop the puzzle box and follow. [[Library - West's Tour]]“Almost…” said Devi. 123 45□ 786 [[slide 6 up - West's Tour]] [[slide 3 down - West's Tour]]“Wait, I’m so close!” Devi groaned, sliding the tiles around at random now, but Nellie was already walking out the door. She had no choice but to drop the puzzle box and follow. [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“Wait, I’m so close!” Devi groaned, sliding the tiles around at random now, but Nellie was already walking out the door. She had no choice but to drop the puzzle box and follow. [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“Almost…” said Devi. 123 45□ 786 [[slide 6 up - West's Tour with Pick]] [[slide 3 down - West's Tour with Pick]]After Devi slid the last tile into place, she heard a gentle click and the top of the box popped open. “Ew, oh my god, oh my god,” said Nellie, peering over Devi’s shoulder. “What is that?” asked West. “Teeth,” said Devi. There were two teeth, darkened with age, tapping together in the tiny box. “My mom used to keep my baby teeth,” West said. “These aren’t baby teeth,” said Devi. They looked like adult molars. Why was there a puzzle box with two adult molars in Tara’s bedroom? “This is why you don’t do math!” said Nellie, stomping out of the room. Devi closed the lid shut, leaving the teeth and the mystery behind her as she and West followed Nellie. [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge]] “Wait, I’m so close!” Devi groaned, sliding the tiles around at random now, but Nellie was already walking out the door. She had no choice but to drop the puzzle box and follow. [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge]] “You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge]] “Don’t tear the paper,” Devi said. “I’m being careful!” Nellie sighed. “Second verse.” //Through a glass darkly I looked in my lover’s eyes And saw ____// [[her rage - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[a stranger -
