Or do you wait for me still? Love, _____// [[do not linger - West's Tour]] [[did you live longer? - West's Tour]] [[I die of longing - West's Tour]]“You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour]]The poem crumpled into ash in Nellie’s hand. “So much for being careful,” West laughed. “It’s not my fault!” said Nellie. “Sure, sure,” said West, walking out of the room, followed by Devi who seemed to be holding in a lecture. Nellie brushed the ash off her hands, sure that Dawn’s poem just concluded in a supernatural way that neither of her crewmates bothered to notice, and followed. [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge]]“You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge]]“You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge]]The poem crumpled into ash in Nellie’s hand. “So much for being careful,” West laughed. “It’s not my fault!” said Nellie. “Sure, sure,” said West, walking out of the room, followed by Devi who seemed to be holding in a lecture. Nellie brushed the ash off her hands, sure that Dawn’s poem just concluded in a supernatural way that neither of her crewmates bothered to notice, and followed. [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]“You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]“You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]The poem crumpled into ash in Nellie’s hand. “So much for being careful,” West laughed. “It’s not my fault!” said Nellie. “Sure, sure,” said West, walking out of the room, followed by Devi who seemed to be holding in a lecture. Nellie brushed the ash off her hands, sure that Dawn’s poem just concluded in a supernatural way that neither of her crewmates bothered to notice, and followed. [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]“You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour with Pick]]The poem crumpled into ash in Nellie’s hand. “So much for being careful,” West laughed. “It’s not my fault!” said Nellie. “Sure, sure,” said West, walking out of the room, followed by Devi who seemed to be holding in a lecture. Nellie brushed the ash off her hands, sure that Dawn’s poem just concluded in a supernatural way that neither of her crewmates bothered to notice, and followed. [[Library - West's Tour]]“You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour]]“You do not know how a haiku works,” Devi huffed. “Stop vandalizing a dead woman’s love letter.” “Maybe you should put it back so we can keep moving forward,” West suggested. “Fine,” Nellie said, dropping the poem on the vanity. “But I liked my choice better.” [[Library - West's Tour]]“Nel, could you do something about that?” West asked, gesturing towards the tapestry. Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, almost completely lost her balance as it undulated under her like a waterbed, but managed to stay upright until it settled. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. She stepped back, stumbling off the sofa, revealing the image on the tapestry. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. A Satanic image. A classic sign of evil. Thank god. Fake shit like this was clickbait, and unlike the actual hauntings in the house, didn’t bother West at all. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns, and West dutifully caught the whole shot, including Nellie’s compelling expression of barely suppressed fear. “Do any of the Bennington’s have a ‘V’ name?” “I can’t check the guidebook and film at the same time,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bookshelves - West's Tour]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - West's Tour (from Tapestry)]] “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West said. He filmed Nellie, trying to look pensive as she stepped over to the books, frowning as she examined the spines. He was surprised when her performance of interested fell away as her jaw dropped, her eyes flickering with actual delight. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” They wouldn’t be for long if Nellie went tearing through them. As much as they appeared to be firmly glued together, based on the rot and sludge and crumbling state of the house, West could imagine their star opening the pages only to have them dissolve in her hands. She had already plucked on book from the shelf, and though she handled it carefully, West cleared his throat. She scowled at him. “I’m being careful!” Nellie insisted. “I would never hurt Nancy.” As he walked over to come up with an argument that didn’t make Nellie sound dangerously clumsy, the light from the camera caught on something tucked into the shadows of the shelf where the Nancy Drew book had once sat. West reached for the glittering object and pulled out an old locket. Simple. Cheap. Pretty. But looking at it made West’s stomach drop. He felt nauseous. He glanced around the room. Only angry ghosts made him feel like this, like he was on the edge of a dangerous fall. But he did not see any new specters. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and West stepped back, holding it close to his chest. He had to protect Nellie. He did not know where that thought came from, or what he was protecting her from by keeping the locket away from her, but he was sure that if she had it, something terrible would happen. “I’ll hold on to it,” he said, slipping it into his pocket. “That’s stealing, West,” Devi scolded him. “I’m not going to keep it,” West said. “Then we should put it back,” Nellie said, holding out her hand, like she would do just that. But she wouldn’t. West stepped away again, pretending he was trying to get her in frame, but by the way her expression soured he knew she wasn’t buying it. “I’ll let the owner know that we found it tomorrow,” Devi said, her voice cutting through the tense silence. “Maybe it’s been lost for a while, or another crew left it here. It might have sentimental value.” Nellie glared at Devi, but then she shrugged, wandering over to the sofas. “You should be filming me, West!” she shouted. “You should put that in the hotel safe when we get back,” West whispered. “She’s totally going to try to steal it.” He was relieved when Devi nodded slowly. He would feel more relieved when the locket wasn’t in his pocket, strangely heavy, strangely warm. “It’s getting late guys,” he said, making his voice a little tired, a little bored. “We can check out like, two more things, at an absolute maximum, and then keeping moving.” Nellie shrugged, clearly only half-listening. West couldn’t read Devi’s expression but she didn’t fight him on it. [[Upper Floor Observatory - West's Tour (with Locket)]] He could have gotten some sweeping artistic shot of the library as he walked up the stairs, but West could not take his attention or lens off of the strange smoky ceiling. It was not a spectral kind of smokiness, or that sludge rot they had seen before, but something like… a veil. To protect or hide, he was not sure. The ceiling continued its arc over the Upper Observatory, and most likely continued over the house to the entryway where the had come in. He was so fixated on the strange design, ne nearly closed the door on Devi after he and Nellie entered the single long room that ran the length of the library, its elevated twin. The boxy black beds were a similar style to the sofas below, but far less decayed. Perhaps being far from the malfunctioning plumbing helped. The little black side tables next to them seemed more artistic than useful – they didn’t even have drawers. No drawers, no closets. Well, maybe there was storage or armoires up here a long time ago that had been sold off. Weird that they would be sold off and not the beautiful telescope at the end of the room, pointing up at the obscured glass of the ceiling. West flipped through the guidebook and saw a picture of that same telescope, the same arched glass ceiling, but the picture depicted a view of stars. Not real stars, a random spattering of six stars that weren’t even in the shape of a constellation. “Observatory,” he said, though both of his crewmates seemed lost in their thoughts, hardly listening. “Rather self-explanatory. Time to poke around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour]] [[Side Table - West's Tour]] “Nel, could you do something about that?” West asked, gesturing towards the tapestry. Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, almost completely lost her balance as it undulated under her like a waterbed, but managed to stay upright until it settled. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. She stepped back, stumbling off the sofa, revealing the image on the tapestry. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. A Satanic image. A classic sign of evil. Thank god. Fake shit like this was clickbait, and unlike the actual hauntings in the house, didn’t bother West at all. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns, and West dutifully caught the whole shot, including Nellie’s compelling expression of barely suppressed fear. “Do any of the Bennington’s have a ‘V’ name?” “I can’t check the guidebook and film at the same time,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - West's Tour with Sludge (from Tapestry)]]“No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West said. He filmed Nellie, trying to look pensive as she stepped over to the books, frowning as she examined the spines. He was surprised when her performance of interested fell away as her jaw dropped, her eyes flickering with actual delight. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” They wouldn’t be for long if Nellie went tearing through them. As much as they appeared to be firmly glued together, based on the rot and sludge and crumbling state of the house, West could imagine their star opening the pages only to have them dissolve in her hands. She had already plucked on book from the shelf, and though she handled it carefully, West cleared his throat. She scowled at him. “I’m being careful!” Nellie insisted. “I would never hurt Nancy.” As he walked over to come up with an argument that didn’t make Nellie sound dangerously clumsy, the light from the camera caught on something tucked into the shadows of the shelf where the Nancy Drew book had once sat. West reached for the glittering object and pulled out an old locket. Simple. Cheap. Pretty. But looking at it made West’s stomach drop. He felt nauseous. He glanced around the room. Only angry ghosts made him feel like this, like he was on the edge of a dangerous fall. But he did not see any new specters. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and West stepped back, holding it close to his chest. He had to protect Nellie. He did not know where that thought came from, or what he was protecting her from by keeping the locket away from her, but he was sure that if she had it, something terrible would happen. “I’ll hold on to it,” he said, slipping it into his pocket. “That’s stealing, West,” Devi scolded him. “I’m not going to keep it,” West said. “Then we should put it back,” Nellie said, holding out her hand, like she would do just that. But she wouldn’t. West stepped away again, pretending he was trying to get her in frame, but by the way her expression soured he knew she wasn’t buying it. “I’ll let the owner know that we found it tomorrow,” Devi said, her voice cutting through the tense silence. “Maybe it’s been lost for a while, or another crew left it here. It might have sentimental value.” Nellie glared at Devi, but then she shrugged, wandering over to the sofas. “You should be filming me, West!” she shouted. “You should put that in the hotel safe when we get back,” West whispered. “She’s totally going to try to steal it.” He was relieved when Devi nodded slowly. He would feel more relieved when the locket wasn’t in his pocket, strangely heavy, strangely warm. “It’s getting late guys,” he said, making his voice a little tired, a little bored. “We can check out like, two more things, at an absolute maximum, and then keeping moving.” Nellie shrugged, clearly only half-listening. West couldn’t read Devi’s expression but she didn’t fight him on it. [[Upper Floor Observatory - West's Tour with Sludge (and Locket)]]He could have gotten some sweeping artistic shot of the library as he walked up the stairs, but West could not take his attention or lens off of the strange smoky ceiling. It was not a spectral kind of smokiness, or that sludge rot they had seen before, but something like… a veil. To protect or hide, he was not sure. The ceiling continued its arc over the Upper Observatory, and most likely continued over the house to the entryway where the had come in. He was so fixated on the strange design, ne nearly closed the door on Devi after he and Nellie entered the single long room that ran the length of the library, its elevated twin. The boxy black beds were a similar style to the sofas below, but far less decayed. Perhaps being far from the malfunctioning plumbing helped. The little black side tables next to them seemed more artistic than useful – they didn’t even have drawers. No drawers, no closets. Well, maybe there was storage or armoires up here a long time ago that had been sold off. Weird that they would be sold off and not the beautiful telescope at the end of the room, pointing up at the obscured glass of the ceiling. West flipped through the guidebook and saw a picture of that same telescope, the same arched glass ceiling, but the picture depicted a view of stars. Not real stars, a random spattering of six stars that weren’t even in the shape of a constellation. “Observatory,” he said, though both of his crewmates seemed lost in their thoughts, hardly listening. “Rather self-explanatory. Time to poke around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge]] “Nel, could you do something about that?” West asked, gesturing towards the tapestry. Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, almost completely lost her balance as it undulated under her like a waterbed, but managed to stay upright until it settled. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. She stepped back, stumbling off the sofa, revealing the image on the tapestry. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. A Satanic image. A classic sign of evil. Thank god. Fake shit like this was clickbait, and unlike the actual hauntings in the house, didn’t bother West at all. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns, and West dutifully caught the whole shot, including Nellie’s compelling expression of barely suppressed fear. “Do any of the Bennington’s have a ‘V’ name?” “I can’t check the guidebook and film at the same time,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Pick]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - West's Tour with Pick (from Tapestry)]]“No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West said. He filmed Nellie, trying to look pensive as she stepped over to the books, frowning as she examined the spines. He was surprised when her performance of interested fell away as her jaw dropped, her eyes flickering with actual delight. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” They wouldn’t be for long if Nellie went tearing through them. As much as they appeared to be firmly glued together, based on the rot and sludge and crumbling state of the house, West could imagine their star opening the pages only to have them dissolve in her hands. She had already plucked on book from the shelf, and though she handled it carefully, West cleared his throat. She scowled at him. “I’m being careful!” Nellie insisted. “I would never hurt Nancy.” As he walked over to come up with an argument that didn’t make Nellie sound dangerously clumsy, the light from the camera caught on something tucked into the shadows of the shelf where the Nancy Drew book had once sat. West reached for the glittering object and pulled out an old locket. Simple. Cheap. Pretty. But looking at it made West’s stomach drop. He felt nauseous. He glanced around the room. Only angry ghosts made him feel like this, like he was on the edge of a dangerous fall. But he did not see any new specters. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and West stepped back, holding it close to his chest. He had to protect Nellie. He did not know where that thought came from, or what he was protecting her from by keeping the locket away from her, but he was sure that if she had it, something terrible would happen. “I’ll hold on to it,” he said, slipping it into his pocket. “That’s stealing, West,” Devi scolded him. “I’m not going to keep it,” West said. “Then we should put it back,” Nellie said, holding out her hand, like she would do just that. But she wouldn’t. West stepped away again, pretending he was trying to get her in frame, but by the way her expression soured he knew she wasn’t buying it. “I’ll let the owner know that we found it tomorrow,” Devi said, her voice cutting through the tense silence. “Maybe it’s been lost for a while, or another crew left it here. It might have sentimental value.” Nellie glared at Devi, but then she shrugged, wandering over to the sofas. “You should be filming me, West!” she shouted. “You should put that in the hotel safe when we get back,” West whispered. “She’s totally going to try to steal it.” He was relieved when Devi nodded slowly. He would feel more relieved when the locket wasn’t in his pocket, strangely heavy, strangely warm. “It’s getting late guys,” he said, making his voice a little tired, a little bored. “We can check out like, two more things, at an absolute maximum, and then keeping moving.” Nellie shrugged, clearly only half-listening. West couldn’t read Devi’s expression but she didn’t fight him on it. [[Upper Floor Observatory - West's Tour with Pick (and Locket)]]He could have gotten some sweeping artistic shot of the library as he walked up the stairs, but West could not take his attention or lens off of the strange smoky ceiling. It was not a spectral kind of smokiness, or that sludge rot they had seen before, but something like… a veil. To protect or hide, he was not sure. The ceiling continued its arc over the Upper Observatory, and most likely continued over the house to the entryway where the had come in. He was so fixated on the strange design, ne nearly closed the door on Devi after he and Nellie entered the single long room that ran the length of the library, its elevated twin. The boxy black beds were a similar style to the sofas below, but far less decayed. Perhaps being far from the malfunctioning plumbing helped. The little black side tables next to them seemed more artistic than useful – they didn’t even have drawers. No drawers, no closets. Well, maybe there was storage or armoires up here a long time ago that had been sold off. Weird that they would be sold off and not the beautiful telescope at the end of the room, pointing up at the obscured glass of the ceiling. West flipped through the guidebook and saw a picture of that same telescope, the same arched glass ceiling, but the picture depicted a view of stars. Not real stars, a random spattering of six stars that weren’t even in the shape of a constellation. “Observatory,” he said, though both of his crewmates seemed lost in their thoughts, hardly listening. “Rather self-explanatory. Time to poke around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Pick]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Pick]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Pick]] “Nel, could you do something about that?” West asked, gesturing towards the tapestry. Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, almost completely lost her balance as it undulated under her like a waterbed, but managed to stay upright until it settled. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. She stepped back, stumbling off the sofa, revealing the image on the tapestry. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. A Satanic image. A classic sign of evil. Thank god. Fake shit like this was clickbait, and unlike the actual hauntings in the house, didn’t bother West at all. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns, and West dutifully caught the whole shot, including Nellie’s compelling expression of barely suppressed fear. “Do any of the Bennington’s have a ‘V’ name?” “I can’t check the guidebook and film at the same time,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Upper Floor Observatory - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (from Tapestry)]]“No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West said. He filmed Nellie, trying to look pensive as she stepped over to the books, frowning as she examined the spines. He was surprised when her performance of interested fell away as her jaw dropped, her eyes flickering with actual delight. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” They wouldn’t be for long if Nellie went tearing through them. As much as they appeared to be firmly glued together, based on the rot and sludge and crumbling state of the house, West could imagine their star opening the pages only to have them dissolve in her hands. She had already plucked on book from the shelf, and though she handled it carefully, West cleared his throat. She scowled at him. “I’m being careful!” Nellie insisted. “I would never hurt Nancy.” As he walked over to come up with an argument that didn’t make Nellie sound dangerously clumsy, the light from the camera caught on something tucked into the shadows of the shelf where the Nancy Drew book had once sat. West reached for the glittering object and pulled out an old locket. Simple. Cheap. Pretty. But looking at it made West’s stomach drop. He felt nauseous. He glanced around the room. Only angry ghosts made him feel like this, like he was on the edge of a dangerous fall. But he did not see any new specters. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and West stepped back, holding it close to his chest. He had to protect Nellie. He did not know where that thought came from, or what he was protecting her from by keeping the locket away from her, but he was sure that if she had it, something terrible would happen. “I’ll hold on to it,” he said, slipping it into his pocket. “That’s stealing, West,” Devi scolded him. “I’m not going to keep it,” West said. “Then we should put it back,” Nellie said, holding out her hand, like she would do just that. But she wouldn’t. West stepped away again, pretending he was trying to get her in frame, but by the way her expression soured he knew she wasn’t buying it. “I’ll let the owner know that we found it tomorrow,” Devi said, her voice cutting through the tense silence. “Maybe it’s been lost for a while, or another crew left it here. It might have sentimental value.” Nellie glared at Devi, but then she shrugged, wandering over to the sofas. “You should be filming me, West!” she shouted. “You should put that in the hotel safe when we get back,” West whispered. “She’s totally going to try to steal it.” He was relieved when Devi nodded slowly. He would feel more relieved when the locket wasn’t in his pocket, strangely heavy, strangely warm. “It’s getting late guys,” he said, making his voice a little tired, a little bored. “We can check out like, two more things, at an absolute maximum, and then keeping moving.” Nellie shrugged, clearly only half-listening. West couldn’t read Devi’s expression but she didn’t fight him on it. [[Upper Floor Observatory - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (and Locket)]]He could have gotten some sweeping artistic shot of the library as he walked up the stairs, but West could not take his attention or lens off of the strange smoky ceiling. It was not a spectral kind of smokiness, or that sludge rot they had seen before, but something like… a veil. To protect or hide, he was not sure. The ceiling continued its arc over the Upper Observatory, and most likely continued over the house to the entryway where the had come in. He was so fixated on the strange design, ne nearly closed the door on Devi after he and Nellie entered the single long room that ran the length of the library, its elevated twin. The boxy black beds were a similar style to the sofas below, but far less decayed. Perhaps being far from the malfunctioning plumbing helped. The little black side tables next to them seemed more artistic than useful – they didn’t even have drawers. No drawers, no closets. Well, maybe there was storage or armoires up here a long time ago that had been sold off. Weird that they would be sold off and not the beautiful telescope at the end of the room, pointing up at the obscured glass of the ceiling. West flipped through the guidebook and saw a picture of that same telescope, the same arched glass ceiling, but the picture depicted a view of stars. Not real stars, a random spattering of six stars that weren’t even in the shape of a constellation. “Observatory,” he said, though both of his crewmates seemed lost in their thoughts, hardly listening. “Rather self-explanatory. Time to poke around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] He could have gotten some sweeping artistic shot of the library as he walked up the stairs, but West could not take his attention or lens off of the strange smoky ceiling. It was not a spectral kind of smokiness, or that sludge rot they had seen before, but something like… a veil. To protect or hide, he was not sure. The ceiling continued its arc over the Upper Observatory, and most likely continued over the house to the entryway where the had come in. Not real stars, a random spattering of six stars that weren’t even in the shape of a constellation. “Observatory,” he said, though both of his crewmates seemed lost in their thoughts, hardly listening. “Rather self-explanatory. Time to poke around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge (and Locket)]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge (and Locket)]]He could have gotten some sweeping artistic shot of the library as he walked up the stairs, but West could not take his attention or lens off of the strange smoky ceiling. It was not a spectral kind of smokiness, or that sludge rot they had seen before, but something like… a veil. To protect or hide, he was not sure. The ceiling continued its arc over the Upper Observatory, and most likely continued over the house to the entryway where the had come in. He was so fixated on the strange design, ne nearly closed the door on Devi after he and Nellie entered the single long room that ran the length of the library, its elevated twin. The boxy black beds were a similar style to the sofas below, but far less decayed. Perhaps being far from the malfunctioning plumbing helped. The little black side tables next to them seemed more artistic than useful – they didn’t even have drawers. No drawers, no closets. Well, maybe there was storage or armoires up here a long time ago that had been sold off. Weird that they would be sold off and not the beautiful telescope at the end of the room, pointing up at the obscured glass of the ceiling. Not real stars, a random spattering of six stars that weren’t even in the shape of a constellation. “Observatory,” he said, though both of his crewmates seemed lost in their thoughts, hardly listening. “Rather self-explanatory. Time to poke around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Pick (and Locket)]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Pick (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Pick (and Locket)]]He could have gotten some sweeping artistic shot of the library as he walked up the stairs, but West could not take his attention or lens off of the strange smoky ceiling. It was not a spectral kind of smokiness, or that sludge rot they had seen before, but something like… a veil. To protect or hide, he was not sure. The ceiling continued its arc over the Upper Observatory, and most likely continued over the house to the entryway where the had come in. He was so fixated on the strange design, ne nearly closed the door on Devi after he and Nellie entered the single long room that ran the length of the library, its elevated twin. The boxy black beds were a similar style to the sofas below, but far less decayed. Perhaps being far from the malfunctioning plumbing helped. The little black side tables next to them seemed more artistic than useful – they didn’t even have drawers. No drawers, no closets. Well, maybe there was storage or armoires up here a long time ago that had been sold off. Weird that they would be sold off and not the beautiful telescope at the end of the room, pointing up at the obscured glass of the ceiling. West flipped through the guidebook and saw a picture of that same telescope, the same arched glass ceiling, but the picture depicted a view of stars. Not real stars, a random spattering of six stars that weren’t even in the shape of a constellation. “Observatory,” he said, though both of his crewmates seemed lost in their thoughts, hardly listening. “Rather self-explanatory. Time to poke around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (and Locket)]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (and Locket)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope (and Locket)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge from Observatory Bed (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge from Observatory Bed (and Locket)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped down the stairs, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour with Sludge]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour from Telescope (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour from Telescope (and Locket)]] The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour from Observatory Bed (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour from Observatory Bed (and Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped down the stairs, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope (and Locket)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour from Observatory Bed with Pick (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour from Observatory Bed with Pick (and Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped down the stairs, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour with Pick]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour with Pick]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Telescope (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Telescope (and Locket)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Observatory Bed (and Locket)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Observatory Bed (and Locket)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped down the stairs, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” "That's all we have time for here," West reminded her. "Then lead us onwards, leader," Nellie grinned, gesturing to the door. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour (with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped down the stairs, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” "That's all we have time for here," West reminded her. "Then lead us onwards, leader," Nellie grinned, gesturing to the door. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” "That's all we have time for here," West reminded her. "Then lead us onwards, leader," Nellie grinned, gesturing to the door. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Sludge (with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped down the stairs, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]West fought the urge to throw up. There were ghosts here, more ghosts than he had seen anywhere else in the mansion, but not lazing about, retracing their steps, or trying to communicate like any normal spectres he had encountered. They were pressed together in a tight mass along a wall that was covered in mutilated pictures. West could not tell if the spirits were likewise mutilated, they melded together to deeply to distinguish actual features. Bile rose hot on his tongue as he watched Nellie saunter over and trace the cuts in the pictures with her fingertips, reaching through those spectral limbs, spider like in their writhing mass. Were they pressed there on purpose, or trapped? He could not tell. They did not look like they were trying to escape, though a few eyes roved over Nellie’s body, some free fingers caressed her cheek and she did not even flinch. “Does anyone see a knife?” asked Nellie. Devi was sitting on a hospital bed opposite the picture wall, not quite what West was expecting as mansion furniture, but it was probably necessary at the end of the Bradford’s life. He wondered if Bradford’s failing health had anything to do with the horror show Nellie kept gliding through. West wandered over to a wardrobe in the corner, intricate and gothic, as an excuse to get away from the spirits that were starting to reach for him too, all globular sinking eyes and interwoven limbs. He flipped through the guidebook as an excuse to ignore them, to deny their offer of contact. But there was no chapter for “Bradford’s Bedroom.” Not even a picture. “There’s nothing for this room,” West said. “Bradford was alive when the tours were happening, but he would stay shut in his room,” said Devi from her perch. “No one was allowed to see him or come here. Besides, this was his private space.” “Is that normal?” West asked. “To have tours in a place where someone is actively living?” “I think there are some castle tours in Scotland like that,” said Devi. “Haunted ones?” West asked, perking up. Yes, he was planning on leaving, but he wasn’t crazy about the idea of his final shift including the wall creature from another dimension. A big overseas blow-out would be a much better farewell. “We should do a trip. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said, gesturing to the door on the far wall that was luckily ghost-free. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Unless he was eaten by something else. Partially chewed up. Regurgitated back into the bedroom. West leaned against the wardrobe, wincing as he heard a snapping creak that, oddly enough, seemed to create an echo. Devi shifted nervously on the hospital bed, her hand clearly covering up something she found. “Anything interesting to explore or should we take this party outside?” Nellie asked, flashing a grin. [[Hospital Bed - West's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Wardrobe - West's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour (with Locket)]] West fought the urge to throw up. There were ghosts here, more ghosts than he had seen anywhere else in the mansion, but not lazing about, retracing their steps, or trying to communicate like any normal spectres he had encountered. They were pressed together in a tight mass along a wall that was covered in mutilated pictures. West could not tell if the spirits were likewise mutilated, they melded together to deeply to distinguish actual features. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Unless he was eaten by something else. Partially chewed up. Regurgitated back into the bedroom. West leaned against the wardrobe, wincing as he heard a snapping creak that, oddly enough, seemed to create an echo. Devi shifted nervously on the hospital bed, her hand clearly covering up something she found. “Anything interesting to explore or should we take this party outside?” Nellie asked, flashing a grin. [[Hospital Bed - West's Tour with Sludge (with Locket)]] [[Wardrobe - West's Tour with Sludge (with Locket)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour with Sludge (with Locket)]]West took the diary out of his pocket, leaving it out, visible, trusting the owner to put it back in its proper place. A mystery for another time. He hurried to follow his crewmates deeper into the mansion. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour (with Locket)]] West took the locket out of his pocket, leaving it out, visible, trusting the owner to put it back in its proper place. At least it was safe from being snatched by Nellie now. He hurried to follow his crewmates deeper into the mansion. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour (with Diary)]] West fought the urge to throw up. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]]West fought the urge to throw up. There were ghosts here, more ghosts than he had seen anywhere else in the mansion, but not lazing about, retracing their steps, or trying to communicate like any normal spectres he had encountered. They were pressed together in a tight mass along a wall that was covered in mutilated pictures. West could not tell if the spirits were likewise mutilated, they melded together to deeply to distinguish actual features. Were they pressed there on purpose, or trapped? He could not tell. They did not look like they were trying to escape, though a few eyes roved over Nellie’s body, some free fingers caressed her cheek and she did not even flinch. “Does anyone see a knife?” asked Nellie. Devi was sitting on a hospital bed opposite the picture wall, not quite what West was expecting as mansion furniture, but it was probably necessary at the end of the Bradford’s life. He wondered if Bradford’s failing health had anything to do with the horror show Nellie kept gliding through. West wandered over to a wardrobe in the corner, intricate and gothic, as an excuse to get away from the spirits that were starting to reach for him too, all globular sinking eyes and interwoven limbs. He flipped through the guidebook as an excuse to ignore them, to deny their offer of contact. But there was no chapter for “Bradford’s Bedroom.” Not even a picture. “There’s nothing for this room,” West said. “Bradford was alive when the tours were happening, but he would stay shut in his room,” said Devi from her perch. “No one was allowed to see him or come here. Besides, this was his private space.” “Is that normal?” West asked. “To have tours in a place where someone is actively living?” “I think there are some castle tours in Scotland like that,” said Devi. “Haunted ones?” West asked, perking up. Yes, he was planning on leaving, but he wasn’t crazy about the idea of his final shift including the wall creature from another dimension. A big overseas blow-out would be a much better farewell. “We should do a trip. Claim it as a business expense.” “Sure, West, I’ll bet the IRS will love that for us,” Nellie groaned. “We’ll go to the garden next,” Devi said, gesturing to the door on the far wall that was luckily ghost-free. “We have to cross it to get to the Gallery. And we might see the ghost of Bradford’s son, Mark. If Bradford killed him, amateur sleuths think that’s where he was probably buried. But no body was found so… probably not.” “It could have been eaten by worms,” Nellie suggested. “I don’t think worms work that fast,” West countered. “Unless they’re like, ‘Dune’ worms.” Unless he was eaten by something else. Partially chewed up. Regurgitated back into the bedroom. West leaned against the wardrobe, wincing as he heard a snapping creak that, oddly enough, seemed to create an echo. Devi shifted nervously on the hospital bed, her hand clearly covering up something she found. “Anything interesting to explore or should we take this party outside?” Nellie asked, flashing a grin. [[Hospital Bed - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] [[Wardrobe - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right? And we're out of time here, anyway.” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour (with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped down the stairs, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. And we're out of time here, anyway.” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said.
