He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped down the stairs, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour with Sludge]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right? And we're out of time here, anyway.” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour (with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped down the stairs, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour with Pick]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour with Pick]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right? And we're out of time here, anyway.” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Sludge (with Locket)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped down the stairs, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour from Telescope]] [[Side Table - West's Tour from Telescope]] The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour from Observatory Bed]] [[Side Table - West's Tour from Observatory Bed]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Telescope - West's Tour from Side Table]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour from Side Table]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - West's Tour from Telescope and Observatory Bed]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Library 2 - West's Tour (with Diary)]]“We can look at one more thing in here or keep going,” said West. [[Tapestry - West's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Bookshelves - West's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour (with Diary)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Library 2 - West's Tour (with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Side Table - West's Tour from Telescope and Observatory Bed]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Library 2 - West's Tour (with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour from Telescope and Side Table]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour from Observatory Bed and Side Table]]“Nel, could you do something about that?” West asked, gesturing towards the tapestry. Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, almost completely lost her balance as it undulated under her like a waterbed, but managed to stay upright until it settled. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. She stepped back, stumbling off the sofa, revealing the image on the tapestry. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. A Satanic image. A classic sign of evil. Thank god. Fake shit like this was clickbait, and unlike the actual hauntings in the house, didn’t bother West at all. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns, and West dutifully caught the whole shot, including Nellie’s compelling expression of barely suppressed fear. “Do any of the Bennington’s have a ‘V’ name?” “I can’t check the guidebook and film at the same time,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour (with Diary)]] “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West said. He filmed Nellie, trying to look pensive as she stepped over to the books, frowning as she examined the spines. He was surprised when her performance of interested fell away as her jaw dropped, her eyes flickering with actual delight. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” They wouldn’t be for long if Nellie went tearing through them. As much as they appeared to be firmly glued together, based on the rot and sludge and crumbling state of the house, West could imagine their star opening the pages only to have them dissolve in her hands. She had already plucked on book from the shelf, and though she handled it carefully, West cleared his throat. She scowled at him. “I’m being careful!” Nellie insisted. “I would never hurt Nancy.” As he walked over to come up with an argument that didn’t make Nellie sound dangerously clumsy, the light from the camera caught on something tucked into the shadows of the shelf where the Nancy Drew book had once sat. West reached for the glittering object and pulled out an old locket. Simple. Cheap. Pretty. But looking at it made West’s stomach drop. He felt nauseous. He glanced around the room. Only angry ghosts made him feel like this, like he was on the edge of a dangerous fall. But he did not see any new specters. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and West stepped back, holding it close to his chest. He had to protect Nellie. He did not know where that thought came from, or what he was protecting her from by keeping the locket away from her, but he was sure that if she had it, something terrible would happen. “I’ll hold on to it,” he said, slipping it into his pocket. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped away, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour]] Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge from Observatory Bed]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge from Observatory Bed]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge from Side Table]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge from Side Table]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope and Side Table]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge from Observatory Bed and Side Table]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope and Observatory Bed]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope and Side Table]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope and Observatory Bed]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge from Observatory Bed and Side Table]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]]“We can look at one more thing in here or keep going,” said West. [[Tapestry - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]]“Nel, could you do something about that?” West asked, gesturing towards the tapestry. Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, almost completely lost her balance as it undulated under her like a waterbed, but managed to stay upright until it settled. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. She stepped back, stumbling off the sofa, revealing the image on the tapestry. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. A Satanic image. A classic sign of evil. Thank god. Fake shit like this was clickbait, and unlike the actual hauntings in the house, didn’t bother West at all. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns, and West dutifully caught the whole shot, including Nellie’s compelling expression of barely suppressed fear. “Do any of the Bennington’s have a ‘V’ name?” “I can’t check the guidebook and film at the same time,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West said. He filmed Nellie, trying to look pensive as she stepped over to the books, frowning as she examined the spines. He was surprised when her performance of interested fell away as her jaw dropped, her eyes flickering with actual delight. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” They wouldn’t be for long if Nellie went tearing through them. As much as they appeared to be firmly glued together, based on the rot and sludge and crumbling state of the house, West could imagine their star opening the pages only to have them dissolve in her hands. She had already plucked on book from the shelf, and though she handled it carefully, West cleared his throat. She scowled at him. “I’m being careful!” Nellie insisted. “I would never hurt Nancy.” As he walked over to come up with an argument that didn’t make Nellie sound dangerously clumsy, the light from the camera caught on something tucked into the shadows of the shelf where the Nancy Drew book had once sat. West reached for the glittering object and pulled out an old locket. Simple. Cheap. Pretty. But looking at it made West’s stomach drop. He felt nauseous. He glanced around the room. Only angry ghosts made him feel like this, like he was on the edge of a dangerous fall. But he did not see any new specters. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and West stepped back, holding it close to his chest. He had to protect Nellie. He did not know where that thought came from, or what he was protecting her from by keeping the locket away from her, but he was sure that if she had it, something terrible would happen. “I’ll hold on to it,” he said, slipping it into his pocket. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped away, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour with Sludge]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour with Sludge]] Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Pick from Observatory Bed]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Pick from Observatory Bed]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope and Side Table]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Side Table - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope and Observatory Bed]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Telescope - West's Tour with Pick from Observatory Bed and Side Table]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Pick from Observatory Bed and Side Table]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope and Side Table]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]]“We can look at one more thing in here or keep going,” said West. [[Tapestry - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]] [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]]“Nel, could you do something about that?” West asked, gesturing towards the tapestry. Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, almost completely lost her balance as it undulated under her like a waterbed, but managed to stay upright until it settled. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. She stepped back, stumbling off the sofa, revealing the image on the tapestry. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. A Satanic image. A classic sign of evil. Thank god. Fake shit like this was clickbait, and unlike the actual hauntings in the house, didn’t bother West at all. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns, and West dutifully caught the whole shot, including Nellie’s compelling expression of barely suppressed fear. “Do any of the Bennington’s have a ‘V’ name?” “I can’t check the guidebook and film at the same time,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]] “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West said. He filmed Nellie, trying to look pensive as she stepped over to the books, frowning as she examined the spines. He was surprised when her performance of interested fell away as her jaw dropped, her eyes flickering with actual delight. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” They wouldn’t be for long if Nellie went tearing through them. As much as they appeared to be firmly glued together, based on the rot and sludge and crumbling state of the house, West could imagine their star opening the pages only to have them dissolve in her hands. She had already plucked on book from the shelf, and though she handled it carefully, West cleared his throat. She scowled at him. “I’m being careful!” Nellie insisted. “I would never hurt Nancy.” As he walked over to come up with an argument that didn’t make Nellie sound dangerously clumsy, the light from the camera caught on something tucked into the shadows of the shelf where the Nancy Drew book had once sat. West reached for the glittering object and pulled out an old locket. Simple. Cheap. Pretty. But looking at it made West’s stomach drop. He felt nauseous. He glanced around the room. Only angry ghosts made him feel like this, like he was on the edge of a dangerous fall. But he did not see any new specters. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and West stepped back, holding it close to his chest. He had to protect Nellie. He did not know where that thought came from, or what he was protecting her from by keeping the locket away from her, but he was sure that if she had it, something terrible would happen. “I’ll hold on to it,” he said, slipping it into his pocket. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped away, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour with Pick]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour with Pick]] Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Telescope]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Telescope]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Observatory Bed]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Observatory Bed]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Side Table]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Side Table]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed.
