I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]]“We can look at one more thing in here or keep going,” said West. [[Tapestry - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]]“Nel, could you do something about that?” West asked, gesturing towards the tapestry. Nellie hopped up onto one of the sofas, almost completely lost her balance as it undulated under her like a waterbed, but managed to stay upright until it settled. She grabbed the edge of the tapestry, pressed up onto her toes and secured the corner back onto a rusted nail. She stepped back, stumbling off the sofa, revealing the image on the tapestry. It was the head of a goat, not depicted artistically floating in some empty black space, but dripping bloody gore from its torn-up throat. Its two horns were too large, extending high over its head in a large V, curving gently at the top. A Satanic image. A classic sign of evil. Thank god. Fake shit like this was clickbait, and unlike the actual hauntings in the house, didn’t bother West at all. “Nice,” said West. “We needed some occult stuff.” “I could have done with just the spooky vibes,” said Devi. “I think it is a V…” Nellie whispered to herself. “No whispering!” shouted Devi. “I think the horns are supposed to depict a V,” Nellie repeated, gesturing up at the horns, and West dutifully caught the whole shot, including Nellie’s compelling expression of barely suppressed fear. “Do any of the Bennington’s have a ‘V’ name?” “I can’t check the guidebook and film at the same time,” said West. “They don’t,” said Devi. “I mean, we don’t know any of Bradford’s lovers’ names. So maybe, actually?” “Very helpful, Devi,” sighed Nellie. “Still a cool tapestry,” said West. [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] “No point of filming in a library if we don’t see books,” West said. He filmed Nellie, trying to look pensive as she stepped over to the books, frowning as she examined the spines. He was surprised when her performance of interested fell away as her jaw dropped, her eyes flickering with actual delight. “Oh. My. God.” “What is it?” asked Devi. “It’s a first edition collection of the Nancy Drew series!” Nellie squealed, running her fingers along the cloth binding. “They’re still in pretty good condition, too!” They wouldn’t be for long if Nellie went tearing through them. As much as they appeared to be firmly glued together, based on the rot and sludge and crumbling state of the house, West could imagine their star opening the pages only to have them dissolve in her hands. She had already plucked on book from the shelf, and though she handled it carefully, West cleared his throat. She scowled at him. “I’m being careful!” Nellie insisted. “I would never hurt Nancy.” As he walked over to come up with an argument that didn’t make Nellie sound dangerously clumsy, the light from the camera caught on something tucked into the shadows of the shelf where the Nancy Drew book had once sat. West reached for the glittering object and pulled out an old locket. Simple. Cheap. Pretty. But looking at it made West’s stomach drop. He felt nauseous. He glanced around the room. Only angry ghosts made him feel like this, like he was on the edge of a dangerous fall. But he did not see any new specters. “It’s beautiful,” Nellie whispered. She reached out for it and West stepped back, holding it close to his chest. He had to protect Nellie. He did not know where that thought came from, or what he was protecting her from by keeping the locket away from her, but he was sure that if she had it, something terrible would happen. “I’ll hold on to it,” he said, slipping it into his pocket. “What is wrong with both of you?” Devi shouted, making both West and Nellie jump. “We’re not investigating, we’re… we’re looting!” She stomped away, leaving West and Nellie to glance guiltily at each other. “Maybe you should just pick one of those to take with us,” she suggested before hastily following Devi. [[Choose Locket - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] [[Choose Diary - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick]] Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour from Telescope (from Tapestry)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour from Telescope (from Tapestry)]] The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour from Observatory Bed (from Tapestry)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour from Observatory Bed (from Tapestry)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Telescope - West's Tour from Side Table (from Tapestry)]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour from Side Table (from Tapestry)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope (from Tapestry)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope (from Tapestry)]] The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Library 2 - West's Tour (with Diary from Tapestry)]]“We can look at one more thing in here or keep going,” said West. [[Bookshelves - West's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour (with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope (from Tapestry)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope (from Tapestry)]] The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Pick from Observatory Bed (from Tapestry)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Pick from Observatory Bed (from Tapestry)]] “Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Telescope - West's Tour with Pick from Side Table (from Tapestry)]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Pick from Side Table (from Tapestry)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope and Side Table (from Tapestry)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Pick from Observatory Bed and Side Table (from Tapestry)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. “Blegh,” said West, putting the chocolate back in its box. He placed the pillow on the bed, couldn’t fit the box back in the pillowcase, and decided to set the box at the foot of the bed. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Side Table - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope and Observatory Bed (from Tapestry)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Pick from Telescope and Side Table (from Tapestry)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary from Tapestry)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge from Telescope and Side Table (from Tapestry)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge from Observatory Bed and Side Table (from Tapestry)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from Tapestry)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from Tapestry)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from Tapestry)]]“We can look at one more thing in here or keep going,” said West. [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Telescope (from Tapestry)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Telescope (from Tapestry)]] The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. They should have been. But they weren’t. West picked up one of the chocolates. Firm. Apparently fresh. “They don’t look all that old,” he said. “Chocolate is full of preservatives,” Nellie shrugged. But even as she spoke, the chocolate dissolved in his fingers, turning to mush. He gagged and dropped it, tossing the box on the bed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Observatory Bed (from Tapestry)]] [[Side Table - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Observatory Bed (from Tapestry)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Side Table (from Tapestry)]] [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Side Table (from Tapestry)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Observatory Bed - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Telescope and Side Table (from Tapestry)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. West hardly listened to their protests, didn’t really know what he mumbled in explanation, because there was something in there, something hidden. His hands began to sweat and he put down the camera so he could shake the pillow case, free the secret object, a small box that fell to the ground - “Chocolates!” West said, grabbing it, grinning at his recent fear. Nellie fake gagged as West pulled off the top of the box. Just chocolate. Sweet chocolate. Truffles that had the lovely dark brown shine. “Those chocolates are probably dust by now,” said Devi. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Telescope - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick from Observatory Bed and Side Table (from Tapestry)]]The beds looked hastily neatened, and West wondered if some other crew had slept here during an overnight shoot. Spooktacular Investigations had done that a few times, but they never slept on fragile furniture, just sleeping bags on the ground. There was a chance the beds were made up to look like this, but West couldn’t imagine why. The wrinkled blankets were one thing. But that pillow… Was something stuffed into it? He reached out and squished it. “West, don’t touch those!” Devi gasped as Nellie laughed. He could smell the awful scent of the rotten chocolate on his fingers, no matter how much he tried to wipe it off. “Real smooth, West,” said Nellie. “Let’s keeping looking around.” [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from Tapestry)]]“Oh great, a cube, how thrilling,” muttered West. “It’s a mod side table,” said Devi. “Mod?” “Modern?” Devi continued. “Like, mid-century, fashion. 60s-70s style. I might be making this up.” “Well, it doesn’t have a drawer or anything on it,” said West. He turned the camera back to the glass. It would be good B-roll. “There’s a book behind it,” Nellie said. West turned back to see Nellie holding a spiral notebook, the kind he used in middle school for his classwork. “You should put that back,” Devi said quietly. “It looks private.” “Oh yeah, it’s definitely someone’s diary,” Nellie agreed, opening it. “Oops.” Something slipped out of the diary. West knelt on the ground with a feeling of dread, searching for what had fallen, but the floor was in rougher shape than he realized, full of cracks and holes. He thought he saw a glint of something in one of the cracks, but just slightly too far down for him to pinch it and pull it out. “Seriously, Nellie?” Devi said, exasperated. “It’s not like anyone’s going to miss it, whatever it is,” Nellie shrugged. “And it was totally worth it.” She opened the book and showed it off for the camera: large, looping letters that were barely decipherable, except one deeply imprinted “I HATE THEM,” another that might have been a scrawled “cursed ground,” and a heavily stylized, horn-like V. “Well, that’s interesting,” said West, abandoning the lost object to the floor. “That’s one word for it,” Nellie laughed. She snapped the book shut. “We can get a better look at it late. Scan the pages at home.” “I’ll hold on to it,” said West. “You don’t even have a bag,” Nellie protested. “I have pockets,” West said. “Ugh, I always forget how big the pockets are in men’s clothes,” said Nellie, reluctantly handing it over. West saw Devi almost protest as he slipped the book into his pocket, then change her mind. [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from Tapestry)]]Nellie looked through the telescope that pointed high at the clear glass ceiling and frowned, pulling back suddenly. Her expression shuddered, and West caught it perfectly. Even if she was putting it on a bit heavy, she was putting it on beautifully. “What do you see?” asked Devi. “Nothing,” said Nellie. She turned away from the camera, scene complete. That was odd. Not like her to turn away from the spotlight. “What do you mean?” asked West. “I… I don’t like it here. Let’s go.” "We've barely started looking around," said West. "Plus, you look good all freaked out on camera like this." "Thanks for the worst compliment," said Nellie. West grimaced. Maybe he was a little harsh. “Let me see,” said Devi. She saw Nellie bite her lip, holding back… a warning? “Don’t, Devi,” said West. Both of his crewmates looked at him, confused for their own reasons. “It’s… old. Don’t want to break it, right?” “Right,” said Devi, quickly dropping her outstretched hand. Nellie threw West a grateful glance, and he shrugged. He didn’t need to know what Nellie saw. Maybe she was overreacting. But they might as well be safe. For Devi. [[Library 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from Tapestry)]]“We can look at one more thing in here or keep going,” said West. [[Bookshelves - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] [[Bradford's Bedroom - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]]“There’s a letter on this bed,” Devi said, sheepishly offering it to West. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West, squelching across the surprisingly wet carpet to her. The rot in this house was everywhere. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, West, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. West skimmed to the end, where Bradford’s handwriting became erratic. That’s where all the good stuff would be. He mumbled out loud as he read. “The weight we carry is a burden unasked for, unwanted, shackles to this world and others and I will not let anyone take blame from me for my part in it. If I could die in your stead, I would, and perhaps it would be enough. Just one. Just this once. A sacrifice, if you can make it. And then you can run far away from here, forget the shackles and the burden and be free. Be brave, Tara, and let me give you this. Be brave and take the gift.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment, the only sound West’s boots shifting on the wet carpet. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. Maybe she didn’t listen. Maybe she let him die of natural causes. Or maybe… “We don’t even know if this note is real,” said Nellie. West placed the crumpled note back on the bed. “Real or not, it’s not exactly Spooktacular Investigations material,” said West. “Let’s focus on stuff that’s more visual. For the audience.” “Like what?” asked Nellie. [[Wardrobe - West's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour (with Locket)]] “If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors, relief flooding him when he saw his hunch was correct. He could barely fathom the embarrassment of opening the wardrobe with that line only to reveal rotting mink coats. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe was a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway.” Devi was right, but the ghosts in the wall-mass had suddenly grown restless, their writhing taking on a frantic air as they pressed further into the pictures. Away from the wardrobe and whatever it led to. Which meant that, whatever was down there, it would most likely be devoid of spectral visitors. “I guess we could just ignore the big mystery and move on…” said West. [[Basement - West's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour (with Locket)]] A high thick fence enclosed either side of the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, creating a strange tunnel-like effect despite the open night sky above them. There were a few ghosts on the path, ignoring them, and West ignored them in turn, breathing in the salty air. Salt? A mineral taste, at least, not with the graininess of sand, but more a flavor of barbeque. The smell only intensified as the path and fence opened wide around the garden. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others clustered together, all emitting that salty scent. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red. “Hold that position,” said West to Nellie, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. There were large needles just on the other side of that pretty pink and he bit back a warning, worried Nellie would caress more heavily to spite her and split open her hand. A stupid thought. Surely the needles weren’t that sharp. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Instead of following her gesture, West followed the path of the lone ghost who shared the garden with them, a woman in a long lacey skirt and a messy braid down her back. She was intent as she followed the gravel swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the beige-pink hexagon-shaped building in front of them. Its boarded-up windows weren’t very inviting, but that wasn’t stopping the ghost’s progress towards the gallery, so it would not stop the crew’s progress either. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the ghost making its way along the path. Even if she did not show a mere flicker or orb on playback, it at least helped him keep a steady pace. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room, completely bypassing the ghost that frowned when she noticed her audience and disappeared. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “West, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” West flipped through the guidebook, finding the page for the garden and cacti first, and his stomach dropped. There was a picture of the flowers, the needles, and a hand cut nearly in half. Yes, it was highly stylized, and even the apparent gore that poured from the wound had been artistically rendered in a floral deep green. But it just made him sure that he had been right to worry. Those needles. That smell. Metallic. He flipped the page to the gallery. “Looks like there are a couple big ticket items still being stored here,” West said, sharing the illustrations of the art with Devi as Nellie impatiently shifted forward to where the actual art pieces were waiting for them. “The captions say these are the originals, commissioned by Bradford, and they’ve never left the property. Have to assume a lot of people would want to get their hands on them. For the clout, I mean. Some of them are… modern.” “Not a modern art fan?” asked Devi. “I prefer the Impressionists,” said West. His crew reacted with teasing //oooohs// as they followed West to the Gallery. “Keep the door open,” Nellie instructed West who nodded, happy to let in the small amount of starlight into the spacious room. The shadows made by the art pieces looked more malevolent than the cacti needles, but the room was thankfully ghost-free. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. Well. Some of the pieces were. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. The ghost-free room did not respond. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West, the image of that needle-slice art making him anxious once more to get this night over with. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Fountain of Life - West's Tour (with Locket)]] [[The Triad - West's Tour (with Locket)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour (with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Locket)]]“There’s a letter on this bed,” Devi said, sheepishly offering it to West. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West, squelching across the surprisingly wet carpet to her. The rot in this house was everywhere. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, West, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. West skimmed to the end, where Bradford’s handwriting became erratic. That’s where all the good stuff would be. He mumbled out loud as he read. “The weight we carry is a burden unasked for, unwanted, shackles to this world and others and I will not let anyone take blame from me for my part in it. If I could die in your stead, I would, and perhaps it would be enough. Just one. Just this once. A sacrifice, if you can make it. And then you can run far away from here, forget the shackles and the burden and be free. Be brave, Tara, and let me give you this. Be brave and take the gift.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment, the only sound West’s boots shifting on the wet carpet. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. Maybe she didn’t listen. Maybe she let him die of natural causes. Or maybe… “We don’t even know if this note is real,” said Nellie. West placed the crumpled note back on the bed. “Real or not, it’s not exactly Spooktacular Investigations material,” said West. “Let’s focus on stuff that’s more visual. For the audience.” “Like what?” asked Nellie. [[Wardrobe - West's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour (with Diary)]]“If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors, relief flooding him when he saw his hunch was correct. He could barely fathom the embarrassment of opening the wardrobe with that line only to reveal rotting mink coats. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe was a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway.” Devi was right, but the ghosts in the wall-mass had suddenly grown restless, their writhing taking on a frantic air as they pressed further into the pictures. Away from the wardrobe and whatever it led to. Which meant that, whatever was down there, it would most likely be devoid of spectral visitors. “I guess we could just ignore the big mystery and move on…” said West. [[Basement - West's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour (with Diary)]]A high thick fence enclosed either side of the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, creating a strange tunnel-like effect despite the open night sky above them. There were a few ghosts on the path, ignoring them, and West ignored them in turn, breathing in the salty air. Salt? A mineral taste, at least, not with the graininess of sand, but more a flavor of barbeque. The smell only intensified as the path and fence opened wide around the garden. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others clustered together, all emitting that salty scent. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red. “Hold that position,” said West to Nellie, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. There were large needles just on the other side of that pretty pink and he bit back a warning, worried Nellie would caress more heavily to spite her and split open her hand. A stupid thought. Surely the needles weren’t that sharp. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Instead of following her gesture, West followed the path of the lone ghost who shared the garden with them, a woman in a long lacey skirt and a messy braid down her back. She was intent as she followed the gravel swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the beige-pink hexagon-shaped building in front of them. Its boarded-up windows weren’t very inviting, but that wasn’t stopping the ghost’s progress towards the gallery, so it would not stop the crew’s progress either. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the ghost making its way along the path. Even if she did not show a mere flicker or orb on playback, it at least helped him keep a steady pace. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room, completely bypassing the ghost that frowned when she noticed her audience and disappeared. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “West, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” West flipped through the guidebook, finding the page for the garden and cacti first, and his stomach dropped. There was a picture of the flowers, the needles, and a hand cut nearly in half. Yes, it was highly stylized, and even the apparent gore that poured from the wound had been artistically rendered in a floral deep green. But it just made him sure that he had been right to worry. Those needles. That smell. Metallic. He flipped the page to the gallery. “Looks like there are a couple big ticket items still being stored here,” West said, sharing the illustrations of the art with Devi as Nellie impatiently shifted forward to where the actual art pieces were waiting for them. “The captions say these are the originals, commissioned by Bradford, and they’ve never left the property. Have to assume a lot of people would want to get their hands on them. For the clout, I mean. Some of them are… modern.” “Not a modern art fan?” asked Devi. “I prefer the Impressionists,” said West. His crew reacted with teasing //oooohs// as they followed West to the Gallery. “Keep the door open,” Nellie instructed West who nodded, happy to let in the small amount of starlight into the spacious room. The shadows made by the art pieces looked more malevolent than the cacti needles, but the room was thankfully ghost-free. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. Well. Some of the pieces were. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. The ghost-free room did not respond. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West, the image of that needle-slice art making him anxious once more to get this night over with. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Fountain of Life - West's Tour (with Diary)]] [[The Triad - West's Tour (with Diary)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Diary)]]“There’s a letter on this bed,” Devi said, sheepishly offering it to West. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West, squelching across the surprisingly wet carpet to her. The rot in this house was everywhere. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, West, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. West skimmed to the end, where Bradford’s handwriting became erratic. That’s where all the good stuff would be. He mumbled out loud as he read. “The weight we carry is a burden unasked for, unwanted, shackles to this world and others and I will not let anyone take blame from me for my part in it. If I could die in your stead, I would, and perhaps it would be enough. Just one. Just this once. A sacrifice, if you can make it. And then you can run far away from here, forget the shackles and the burden and be free. Be brave, Tara, and let me give you this. Be brave and take the gift.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment, the only sound West’s boots shifting on the wet carpet. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. Maybe she didn’t listen. Maybe she let him die of natural causes. Or maybe… “We don’t even know if this note is real,” said Nellie. West placed the crumpled note back on the bed. “Real or not, it’s not exactly Spooktacular Investigations material,” said West. “Let’s focus on stuff that’s more visual. For the audience.” “Like what?” asked Nellie. [[Wardrobe - West's Tour with Sludge (with Locket)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour with Sludge (with Locket)]]“If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors, relief flooding him when he saw his hunch was correct. He could barely fathom the embarrassment of opening the wardrobe with that line only to reveal rotting mink coats. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe was a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway.” Devi was right, but the ghosts in the wall-mass had suddenly grown restless, their writhing taking on a frantic air as they pressed further into the pictures. Away from the wardrobe and whatever it led to. Which meant that, whatever was down there, it would most likely be devoid of spectral visitors. “I guess we could just ignore the big mystery and move on…” said West. [[Basement - West's Tour with Sludge (with Locket)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour with Sludge (with Locket)]]A high thick fence enclosed either side of the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, creating a strange tunnel-like effect despite the open night sky above them. There were a few ghosts on the path, ignoring them, and West ignored them in turn, breathing in the salty air. Salt? A mineral taste, at least, not with the graininess of sand, but more a flavor of barbeque. The smell only intensified as the path and fence opened wide around the garden. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. Have to assume a lot of people would want to get their hands on them. For the clout, I mean. Some of them are… modern.” “Not a modern art fan?” asked Devi. “I prefer the Impressionists,” said West.
