She was intent as she followed the gravel swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the beige-pink hexagon-shaped building in front of them. Its boarded-up windows weren’t very inviting, but that wasn’t stopping the ghost’s progress towards the gallery, so it would not stop the crew’s progress either. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the ghost making its way along the path. Even if she did not show a mere flicker or orb on playback, it at least helped him keep a steady pace. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room, completely bypassing the ghost that frowned when she noticed her audience and disappeared. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “West, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” West flipped through the guidebook, finding the page for the garden and cacti first, and his stomach dropped. There was a picture of the flowers, the needles, and a hand cut nearly in half. Yes, it was highly stylized, and even the apparent gore that poured from the wound had been artistically rendered in a floral deep green. But it just made him sure that he had been right to worry. Those needles. That smell. Metallic. He flipped the page to the gallery. “Looks like there are a couple big ticket items still being stored here,” West said, sharing the illustrations of the art with Devi as Nellie impatiently shifted forward to where the actual art pieces were waiting for them. “The captions say these are the originals, commissioned by Bradford, and they’ve never left the property. Have to assume a lot of people would want to get their hands on them. For the clout, I mean. Some of them are… modern.” “Not a modern art fan?” asked Devi. “I prefer the Impressionists,” said West. His crew reacted with teasing //oooohs// as they followed West to the Gallery. “Keep the door open,” Nellie instructed West who nodded, happy to let in the small amount of starlight into the spacious room. The shadows made by the art pieces looked more malevolent than the cacti needles, but the room was thankfully ghost-free. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. Well. Some of the pieces were. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. The ghost-free room did not respond. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West, the image of that needle-slice art making him anxious once more to get this night over with. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Fountain of Life - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]] [[The Triad - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]]“There’s a letter on this bed,” Devi said, sheepishly offering it to West. “That is… shockingly convenient,” said West, squelching across the surprisingly wet carpet to her. The rot in this house was everywhere. “Maybe it’s a prop for ghost tours like us,” Nellie said. “It’s old, I think,” said Devi. “Some of the ink has bled, but it looks like a letter from Bradford to his daughter, Tara. He’s apologizing for… something. ‘You have responsibilities no one should have to bear, and I’m sorry I doomed you to this lonely existence.’ That’s sad, it’s not his fault he got sick.” “Tell that to the doctors’ warnings on cigar boxes,” Nellie snorted. “Here, West, you keep reading,” said Devi, shoving the letter into her hands. West skimmed to the end, where Bradford’s handwriting became erratic. That’s where all the good stuff would be. He mumbled out loud as he read. “The weight we carry is a burden unasked for, unwanted, shackles to this world and others and I will not let anyone take blame from me for my part in it. If I could die in your stead, I would, and perhaps it would be enough. Just one. Just this once. A sacrifice, if you can make it. And then you can run far away from here, forget the shackles and the burden and be free. Be brave, Tara, and let me give you this. Be brave and take the gift.” The three crewmembers were silent for a moment, the only sound West’s boots shifting on the wet carpet. “But we don’t know if she killed him,” said West. Maybe she didn’t listen. Maybe she let him die of natural causes. Or maybe… “We don’t even know if this note is real,” said Nellie. West placed the crumpled note back on the bed. “Real or not, it’s not exactly Spooktacular Investigations material,” said West. “Let’s focus on stuff that’s more visual. For the audience.” “Like what?” asked Nellie. [[Wardrobe - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]]“If a witch offers you Turkish Delight, run,” West said, grinning, as he opened the wardrobe doors, relief flooding him when he saw his hunch was correct. He could barely fathom the embarrassment of opening the wardrobe with that line only to reveal rotting mink coats. “What is that?” Nellie gasped. The wardrobe was a door, not a wardrobe, leading down into the ground, into darkness. “It is a creepy secret passageway,” West declared. “We are not going down into the scary secret passageway in the demonic occult building,” said Devi. “Besides, it’s too dark for us to really see what’s down there, anyway.” Devi was right, but the ghosts in the wall-mass had suddenly grown restless, their writhing taking on a frantic air as they pressed further into the pictures. Away from the wardrobe and whatever it led to. Which meant that, whatever was down there, it would most likely be devoid of spectral visitors. “I guess we could just ignore the big mystery and move on…” said West. [[Basement - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] [[Gallery - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]]A high thick fence enclosed either side of the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, creating a strange tunnel-like effect despite the open night sky above them. There were a few ghosts on the path, ignoring them, and West ignored them in turn, breathing in the salty air. Salt? A mineral taste, at least, not with the graininess of sand, but more a flavor of barbeque. The smell only intensified as the path and fence opened wide around the garden. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others clustered together, all emitting that salty scent. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red. “Hold that position,” said West to Nellie, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. There were large needles just on the other side of that pretty pink and he bit back a warning, worried Nellie would caress more heavily to spite her and split open her hand. A stupid thought. Surely the needles weren’t that sharp. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Instead of following her gesture, West followed the path of the lone ghost who shared the garden with them, a woman in a long lacey skirt and a messy braid down her back. She was intent as she followed the gravel swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the beige-pink hexagon-shaped building in front of them. Its boarded-up windows weren’t very inviting, but that wasn’t stopping the ghost’s progress towards the gallery, so it would not stop the crew’s progress either. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the ghost making its way along the path. Even if she did not show a mere flicker or orb on playback, it at least helped him keep a steady pace. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room, completely bypassing the ghost that frowned when she noticed her audience and disappeared. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “West, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” West flipped through the guidebook, finding the page for the garden and cacti first, and his stomach dropped. There was a picture of the flowers, the needles, and a hand cut nearly in half. Yes, it was highly stylized, and even the apparent gore that poured from the wound had been artistically rendered in a floral deep green. But it just made him sure that he had been right to worry. Those needles. That smell. Metallic. He flipped the page to the gallery. “Looks like there are a couple big ticket items still being stored here,” West said, sharing the illustrations of the art with Devi as Nellie impatiently shifted forward to where the actual art pieces were waiting for them. “The captions say these are the originals, commissioned by Bradford, and they’ve never left the property. Have to assume a lot of people would want to get their hands on them. For the clout, I mean. Some of them are… modern.” “Not a modern art fan?” asked Devi. “I prefer the Impressionists,” said West. His crew reacted with teasing //oooohs// as they followed West to the Gallery. “Keep the door open,” Nellie instructed West who nodded, happy to let in the small amount of starlight into the spacious room. The shadows made by the art pieces looked more malevolent than the cacti needles, but the room was thankfully ghost-free. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. Well. Some of the pieces were. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. The ghost-free room did not respond. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West, the image of that needle-slice art making him anxious once more to get this night over with. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Fountain of Life - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]]“Okay, West, let’s do this. But if I die here, I am coming back to haunt you,” said Nellie. “I completely understand, and you have my full permission,” said West. “Devi, if it’s too scary for you-” “I’m coming,” Devi grumbled. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity.” West led the way down the stairs. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down. But West felt a calm settle over him as he descended, a warmth he would not have expected to feel going underground. He turned out Nellie and Devi’s semi-flirtatious bickering, enjoying the sound of his own quiet breaths, undisturbed by flashes in the corner of his eye or the weight of another presence pressing down on him. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He was right. The steps became more visible, the descent safer, until they reached solid ground. The light was gentle, a faint starlight kind of illumination, emenating from an object in the middle of the room. “Is that… it looks like an altar,” said Devi, her voice quavering slightly. Nellie walked towards it, and West followed at her shoulder, the two leaving Devi behind them in the shadows. West knew, logically, that this was the kind of dangerous thing he should pull Nellie away from, but he could not help how much he liked it down here. The quiet. The feeling that as long as he stayed here, those spirits that plagued him would leave him alone. If the gentle, warm light kept the ghosts away, he was in no rush to leave. Nellie set a hand on the flat, round surface of the altar, and it was perfectly smooth except for a deep engraving that ran in two elegant lines. “A ‘V,’” murmured Devi. “Horns,” said West. And to his surprise, he shivered. “We should leave the house,” said Nellie. “We don’t have enough footage yet for the show,” West protested. He wiped his hand across his brow, suddenly breaking into a cold sweat. Was he scared? Was he terrified? Did Nellie or Devi notice? “The owner doesn’t usually let investigators see the gallery, everything’s super fragile in there,” Devi said. “We can’t lose this opportunity. Unless… unless you’re really not feeling well or something like that?” Nellie shrugged. “Okay, let’s go,” said West. If he sounded any pushier than usual, Nellie didn’t give him crap about it. He wondered if she felt as sick as he did. Even feeling ill, he felt a pang of regret as they walked back up the stairs. It was peaceful in the basement. Wrong. Disturbing. But peaceful nonetheless. [[Gallery - West's Tour (Basement with Locket)]] “Okay, West, let’s do this. But if I die here, I am coming back to haunt you,” said Nellie. “I completely understand, and you have my full permission,” said West. “Devi, if it’s too scary for you-” “I’m coming,” Devi grumbled. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity.” West led the way down the stairs. The red light from the camera, and the assorted lights from Devi’s recorder offered barely enough light for them to not trip over their feet on the way down. But West felt a calm settle over him as he descended, a warmth he would not have expected to feel going underground. He turned out Nellie and Devi’s semi-flirtatious bickering, enjoying the sound of his own quiet breaths, undisturbed by flashes in the corner of his eye or the weight of another presence pressing down on him. “Is it getting lighter?” asked West. He wondered if she felt as sick as he did. Even feeling ill, he felt a pang of regret as they walked back up the stairs. It was peaceful in the basement. Wrong. Disturbing. But peaceful nonetheless. [[Gallery - West's Tour with Pick (with Diary)]]“Okay, West, let’s do this. But if I die here, I am coming back to haunt you,” said Nellie. “I completely understand, and you have my full permission,” said West. “Devi, if it’s too scary for you-” “I’m coming,” Devi grumbled. “Someone has to record your screams for posterity.” West led the way down the stairs. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” West flipped through the guidebook, finding the page for the garden and cacti first, and his stomach dropped. Yes, it was highly stylized, and even the apparent gore that poured from the wound had been artistically rendered in a floral deep green. But it just made him sure that he had been right to worry. Those needles. That smell. Metallic. He flipped the page to the gallery. “Looks like there are a couple big ticket items still being stored here,” West said, sharing the illustrations of the art with Devi as Nellie impatiently shifted forward to where the actual art pieces were waiting for them. “The captions say these are the originals, commissioned by Bradford, and they’ve never left the property. Have to assume a lot of people would want to get their hands on them. For the clout, I mean. Some of them are… modern.” “Not a modern art fan?” asked Devi. “I prefer the Impressionists,” said West. His crew reacted with teasing //oooohs// as they followed West to the Gallery. “Keep the door open,” Nellie instructed West who nodded, happy to let in the small amount of starlight into the spacious room. The shadows made by the art pieces looked more malevolent than the cacti needles, but the room was thankfully ghost-free. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. Well. Some of the pieces were. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. The ghost-free room did not respond. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West, the image of that needle-slice art making him anxious once more to get this night over with. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Fountain of Life - West's Tour (Basement with Locket)]] [[The Triad - West's Tour (Basement with Locket)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour (Basement with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (Basement with Locket)]]A high thick fence enclosed either side of the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, creating a strange tunnel-like effect despite the open night sky above them. There were a few ghosts on the path, ignoring them, and West ignored them in turn, breathing in the salty air. Salt? A mineral taste, at least, not with the graininess of sand, but more a flavor of barbeque. The smell only intensified as the path and fence opened wide around the garden. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others clustered together, all emitting that salty scent. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red. “Hold that position,” said West to Nellie, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. There were large needles just on the other side of that pretty pink and he bit back a warning, worried Nellie would caress more heavily to spite her and split open her hand. A stupid thought. Surely the needles weren’t that sharp. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Instead of following her gesture, West followed the path of the lone ghost who shared the garden with them, a woman in a long lacey skirt and a messy braid down her back. She was intent as she followed the gravel swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the beige-pink hexagon-shaped building in front of them. Its boarded-up windows weren’t very inviting, but that wasn’t stopping the ghost’s progress towards the gallery, so it would not stop the crew’s progress either. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the ghost making its way along the path. Even if she did not show a mere flicker or orb on playback, it at least helped him keep a steady pace. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room, completely bypassing the ghost that frowned when she noticed her audience and disappeared. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “West, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” West flipped through the guidebook, finding the page for the garden and cacti first, and his stomach dropped. There was a picture of the flowers, the needles, and a hand cut nearly in half. Yes, it was highly stylized, and even the apparent gore that poured from the wound had been artistically rendered in a floral deep green. But it just made him sure that he had been right to worry. Those needles. That smell. Metallic. He flipped the page to the gallery. “Looks like there are a couple big ticket items still being stored here,” West said, sharing the illustrations of the art with Devi as Nellie impatiently shifted forward to where the actual art pieces were waiting for them. “The captions say these are the originals, commissioned by Bradford, and they’ve never left the property. Have to assume a lot of people would want to get their hands on them. For the clout, I mean. Some of them are… modern.” “Not a modern art fan?” asked Devi. “I prefer the Impressionists,” said West. His crew reacted with teasing //oooohs// as they followed West to the Gallery. “Keep the door open,” Nellie instructed West who nodded, happy to let in the small amount of starlight into the spacious room. The shadows made by the art pieces looked more malevolent than the cacti needles, but the room was thankfully ghost-free. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. Well. Some of the pieces were. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. The ghost-free room did not respond. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West, the image of that needle-slice art making him anxious once more to get this night over with. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Fountain of Life - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Locket)]] [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Locket)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Locket)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Locket)]]A high thick fence enclosed either side of the path to the garden and eventually the gallery, creating a strange tunnel-like effect despite the open night sky above them. There were a few ghosts on the path, ignoring them, and West ignored them in turn, breathing in the salty air. Salt? A mineral taste, at least, not with the graininess of sand, but more a flavor of barbeque. The smell only intensified as the path and fence opened wide around the garden. “I don’t know what I expected from a garden in the desert,” West chuckled as he filmed a slow circle around them. The plants were all cacti, most of them taller than West who towered over his other crew members by a foot at least. The smallest ones came up to the diminutive Devi’s waste. Every cacti boasted blooming flowers some just one impressive bloom at their “head,” others clustered together, all emitting that salty scent. The blooms varied from a pale pink to a deep bloody red. “Hold that position,” said West to Nellie, getting a close up of her fingers gently caressing a petal. There were large needles just on the other side of that pretty pink and he bit back a warning, worried Nellie would caress more heavily to spite her and split open her hand. A stupid thought. Surely the needles weren’t that sharp. “The gravel patterns remind me of those old Buddhist zen gardens,” said Devi. “Oh shit,” said Nellie, hopping off the gravel to the dirt that surrounded it. “Did we mess up some kind of art piece? Shit!” “No, I mean the layout of the path,” said Devi, gesturing down. Instead of following her gesture, West followed the path of the lone ghost who shared the garden with them, a woman in a long lacey skirt and a messy braid down her back. She was intent as she followed the gravel swirl that brought them to the center of the planted cacti before leading them out and onward to the beige-pink hexagon-shaped building in front of them. Its boarded-up windows weren’t very inviting, but that wasn’t stopping the ghost’s progress towards the gallery, so it would not stop the crew’s progress either. “It’s like a mandala, I think,” said West, filming the ghost making its way along the path. Even if she did not show a mere flicker or orb on playback, it at least helped him keep a steady pace. “Not really occult, but kind of mystic I guess.” Devi shrugged, maybe in agreement, but she was distracted by her headphones. “Anything good?” Nellie asked her. Devi was turning slowly, towards the house, then the cacti, then the wall, then the final room, completely bypassing the ghost that frowned when she noticed her audience and disappeared. “Actually, there might be,” she said. “Coming from the gallery. It’s like… well, we could just be getting an errant radio signal, but I think I hear music. I think it’s coming through the mic, it’s clearer when I point it towards the gallery.” Nellie was about to reach for Devi’s headphones, but West swatted her hand and they stood in silence for almost a minute, barely breathing. “Did you get it?” West asked. Devi grinned and nodded and West fist pumped the air. “I bet we’ll get more inside,” Devi said. “West, maybe you could read the guidebook entry from here? It could make a nice transition voice over.” “Wait, don’t you have to go through Bradford’s room to get to the gallery?” West asked. “Why would there by an entry for a room you couldn’t visit?” West flipped through the guidebook, finding the page for the garden and cacti first, and his stomach dropped. There was a picture of the flowers, the needles, and a hand cut nearly in half. Yes, it was highly stylized, and even the apparent gore that poured from the wound had been artistically rendered in a floral deep green. But it just made him sure that he had been right to worry. Those needles. That smell. Metallic. He flipped the page to the gallery. “Looks like there are a couple big ticket items still being stored here,” West said, sharing the illustrations of the art with Devi as Nellie impatiently shifted forward to where the actual art pieces were waiting for them. “The captions say these are the originals, commissioned by Bradford, and they’ve never left the property. Have to assume a lot of people would want to get their hands on them. For the clout, I mean. Some of them are… modern.” “Not a modern art fan?” asked Devi. “I prefer the Impressionists,” said West. His crew reacted with teasing //oooohs// as they followed West to the Gallery. “Keep the door open,” Nellie instructed West who nodded, happy to let in the small amount of starlight into the spacious room. The shadows made by the art pieces looked more malevolent than the cacti needles, but the room was thankfully ghost-free. “They’re gorgeous,” whispered Devi. Well. Some of the pieces were. “Do you hear the music?” Nellie asked, but Devi shook her head. “It stopped completely when we came inside,” she said. “Is somebody trying to contact us?” Nellie asked. “A music lover, perhaps? Mark? Dawn? Tara? One of their friends who didn’t want the party to end?” They were quiet for a minute. The ghost-free room did not respond. “Maybe they’ll get mad if we poke around,” said West, the image of that needle-slice art making him anxious once more to get this night over with. “Good idea,” said Nellie. “Let’s poke around.” [[The Fountain of Life - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary)]] [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour (with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour (with Locket from the Triad)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour (with Locket from A Constellation)]] West did a slow zoom out of the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but there was something wrong with the colors. They blended into shadows that did not exist, like some darkness was creeping over the paint, pulling the figures back into a void. It felt like… there should be spirits there. Maybe they had already been swallowed by that darkness. West wondered if the others noticed him looking for the ghosts that were not there and tried to think of something light-hearted to say, a quip for the camera. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West said, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued, and if it came out a little forcefully, neither Devi nor Nellie reacted to it. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were bright blue under her fringe, with alight with a strange sorrowful accusation that made West avert his eyes. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that made it look like she was on her way to a Renaissance fair. It was cut low over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair fell in loose curls down her shoulders, and she lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, and West new that it must have been a hard position to hold, but Dawn seemed adept at performing her false relaxation. He left her to it. His eye was drawn to the man beside her. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise, another precarious pose, another performance of ease, but Mark did not play his part quite so well. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. It was so carefully curated it set West’s teeth on edge, like something uncanny, almost veering into the inhuman. Which was ridiculous. Objectively, the man in the picture was just a man, if a very manicured one, his outfit not outrageous for the time. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro was pristine. Maybe it was his smile, that sneer, that made West want to run, that seemed to whisper in his ear// run run run//. Did he want to run from Mark? Was he responding to a threat? Or was a receiving a warning? West shook his head. He was not receiving a warning from a painting. There were no ghosts in this painting. He would feel them. He felt nothing in the darkness creeping over the paint. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn. Her deep brown eyes were wide and afraid, focused on something out of frame, and West felt that urge to run again, or to tell Tara to run, and he swallowed it down. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded almost completely into that suffocating void, like he could have been made of the darkness itself. He was shaped a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting something like a hand on Tara’s shoulder, but everything about him made West’s skin crawl. He did not look like any ghost West had seen. He did not look like the other Benningtons posed around him. So, who was he? If there were no ghosts in the gallery, what was possessing this portrait? “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but West did not think he was. He thought he was something much worse than a dead man. They needed to leave. //Run. // “Right,” said West, keeping his voice calm. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go?” “Hey, guys,” said Devi, stopping West after he took his first few steps towards the door. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” Classic haunting. West was surprised at how relieved he felt. He knew how to handle ghostly music. The normalcy took away some of his urgency, dampened a bit of his fear. “Then turn it up!” West laughed. But as he turned to walk to her, he stumbled over his feet, and without thinking, he reached out to steady himself. His hand pressed against the painting. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands of their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and West heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building. West could still hear that sound through the chaos, some familiar noises mixed in with the static, melodies and lyrics, songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for West to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Just the Way You Are]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[A Constellation - West's Tour (with Locket from the Triad)]] [[The Fountain - West's Tour (with Locket from the Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Locket)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour (with Locket from the Triad and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour (with Locket from the Triad and The Fountain of Life)]] West filmed the boarded-up windows. “Do you want me to do anything in front of those?” Nellie asked. “No, I’m just getting creepy B-roll,” West said. “Okay… Boring…” West pointed the camera at Nellie. “Fine, do something not boring.” Nellie threw her hands up in the air dramatically and wandered next to an uncomfortable Devi. “Maybe we should focus on the art,” Devi suggested. [[The Fountain - West's Tour (with Locket from Gallery 2)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Locket)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[The Triad - West's Tour (with Locket from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain - West's Tour (with Locket from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Locket)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour (with Locket from the Triad and A Constellation)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour (with Locket from A Constellation and The Fountain of Life)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[The Triad - West's Tour (with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour (with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Locket)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour (with Locket from the Triad and The Fountain of Life)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour (with Locket from A Constellation and The Fountain of Life)]] West filmed the boarded-up windows. “Do you want me to do anything in front of those?” Nellie asked. “No, I’m just getting creepy B-roll,” West said. “Okay… Boring…” West pointed the camera at Nellie. “Fine, do something not boring.” Nellie threw her hands up in the air dramatically and wandered next to an uncomfortable Devi. “Maybe we should focus on the art,” Devi suggested. [[A Constellation - West's Tour (with Locket from Gallery 2)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Locket)]] West filmed the boarded-up windows. “Do you want me to do anything in front of those?” Nellie asked. “No, I’m just getting creepy B-roll,” West said. “Okay… Boring…” West pointed the camera at Nellie. “Fine, do something not boring.” Nellie threw her hands up in the air dramatically and wandered next to an uncomfortable Devi. “Maybe we should focus on the art,” Devi suggested. [[The Triad - West's Tour (with Locket from Gallery 2)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Locket)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Locket)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Locket)]]West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (with Locket)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from the Triad)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from A Constellation)]] West did a slow zoom out of the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but there was something wrong with the colors. They blended into shadows that did not exist, like some darkness was creeping over the paint, pulling the figures back into a void. It felt like… there should be spirits there. Maybe they had already been swallowed by that darkness. West wondered if the others noticed him looking for the ghosts that were not there and tried to think of something light-hearted to say, a quip for the camera. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West said, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued, and if it came out a little forcefully, neither Devi nor Nellie reacted to it. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were bright blue under her fringe, with alight with a strange sorrowful accusation that made West avert his eyes. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that made it look like she was on her way to a Renaissance fair. It was cut low over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair fell in loose curls down her shoulders, and she lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, and West new that it must have been a hard position to hold, but Dawn seemed adept at performing her false relaxation. He left her to it. His eye was drawn to the man beside her. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise, another precarious pose, another performance of ease, but Mark did not play his part quite so well. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. It was so carefully curated it set West’s teeth on edge, like something uncanny, almost veering into the inhuman. Which was ridiculous. Objectively, the man in the picture was just a man, if a very manicured one, his outfit not outrageous for the time. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro was pristine. Maybe it was his smile, that sneer, that made West want to run, that seemed to whisper in his ear// run run run//. Did he want to run from Mark? Was he responding to a threat? Or was a receiving a warning? West shook his head. He was not receiving a warning from a painting. There were no ghosts in this painting. He would feel them. He felt nothing in the darkness creeping over the paint. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn. Her deep brown eyes were wide and afraid, focused on something out of frame, and West felt that urge to run again, or to tell Tara to run, and he swallowed it down. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded almost completely into that suffocating void, like he could have been made of the darkness itself. He was shaped a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting something like a hand on Tara’s shoulder, but everything about him made West’s skin crawl. He did not look like any ghost West had seen. He did not look like the other Benningtons posed around him. So, who was he? If there were no ghosts in the gallery, what was possessing this portrait? “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but West did not think he was. He thought he was something much worse than a dead man. They needed to leave. //Run. // “Right,” said West, keeping his voice calm. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go?” “Hey, guys,” said Devi, stopping West after he took his first few steps towards the door. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” Classic haunting. West was surprised at how relieved he felt. He knew how to handle ghostly music. The normalcy took away some of his urgency, dampened a bit of his fear. “Then turn it up!” West laughed. But as he turned to walk to her, he stumbled over his feet, and without thinking, he reached out to steady himself. His hand pressed against the painting. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands of their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and West heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building. West could still hear that sound through the chaos, some familiar noises mixed in with the static, melodies and lyrics, songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for West to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[Just the Way You Are.]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[The Triad - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (Basement with Locket)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[A Constellation - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from the Triad)]] [[The Fountain - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from the Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (Basement with Locket)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[The Triad - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour (Basement with Locket)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from the Triad and The Fountain of Life)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from A Constellation and The Fountain of Life)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from the Triad and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour (Basement with Locket from the Triad and The Fountain of Life)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy.
