Or was a receiving a warning? West shook his head. He was not receiving a warning from a painting. There were no ghosts in this painting. He would feel them. He felt nothing in the darkness creeping over the paint. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn. Her deep brown eyes were wide and afraid, focused on something out of frame, and West felt that urge to run again, or to tell Tara to run, and he swallowed it down. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded almost completely into that suffocating void, like he could have been made of the darkness itself. He was shaped a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting something like a hand on Tara’s shoulder, but everything about him made West’s skin crawl. He did not look like any ghost West had seen. He did not look like the other Benningtons posed around him. So, who was he? If there were no ghosts in the gallery, what was possessing this portrait? “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but West did not think he was. He thought he was something much worse than a dead man. They needed to leave. //Run. // “Right,” said West, keeping his voice calm. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go?” “Hey, guys,” said Devi, stopping West after he took his first few steps towards the door. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” Classic haunting. West was surprised at how relieved he felt. He knew how to handle ghostly music. The normalcy took away some of his urgency, dampened a bit of his fear. “Then turn it up!” West laughed. But as he turned to walk to her, he stumbled over his feet, and without thinking, he reached out to steady himself. His hand pressed against the painting. He felt a sharp pain, like his skin was splitting open, a searing rupture so intense that when he opened his mouth to scream no sound came out. There was a darkness growing from under his palm and a terrible sour smell. Mold? It spread out from his burning hand, over the painting, obscuring the faces of the Bennington children under the new wet growth. “What the hell?” whispered Nellie. West wrenched his hand free. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands of their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and West heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building. West could still hear that sound through the chaos, some familiar noises mixed in with the static, melodies and lyrics, songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for West to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[25 or 6 to 4]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from the Triad)]] [[The Fountain - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from the Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from the Triad and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from the Triad and The Fountain of Life)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from the Triad and A Constellation)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from A Constellation and The Fountain of Life)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from the Triad and The Fountain of Life)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from A Constellation and The Fountain of Life)]] West filmed the boarded-up windows. “Do you want me to do anything in front of those?” Nellie asked. “No, I’m just getting creepy B-roll,” West said. “Okay… Boring…” West pointed the camera at Nellie. “Fine, do something not boring.” Nellie threw her hands up in the air dramatically and wandered next to an uncomfortable Devi. “Maybe we should focus on the art,” Devi suggested. [[The Fountain - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from Gallery 2)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] West filmed the boarded-up windows. “Do you want me to do anything in front of those?” Nellie asked. “No, I’m just getting creepy B-roll,” West said. “Okay… Boring…” West pointed the camera at Nellie. “Fine, do something not boring.” Nellie threw her hands up in the air dramatically and wandered next to an uncomfortable Devi. “Maybe we should focus on the art,” Devi suggested. [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from Gallery 2)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] West filmed the boarded-up windows. “Do you want me to do anything in front of those?” Nellie asked. “No, I’m just getting creepy B-roll,” West said. “Okay… Boring…” West pointed the camera at Nellie. “Fine, do something not boring.” Nellie threw her hands up in the air dramatically and wandered next to an uncomfortable Devi. “Maybe we should focus on the art,” Devi suggested. [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary from Gallery 2)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge and Pick (with Diary)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from the Triad)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from A Constellation)]] West did a slow zoom out of the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but there was something wrong with the colors. They blended into shadows that did not exist, like some darkness was creeping over the paint, pulling the figures back into a void. It felt like… there should be spirits there. Maybe they had already been swallowed by that darkness. West wondered if the others noticed him looking for the ghosts that were not there and tried to think of something light-hearted to say, a quip for the camera. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West said, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued, and if it came out a little forcefully, neither Devi nor Nellie reacted to it. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were bright blue under her fringe, with alight with a strange sorrowful accusation that made West avert his eyes. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that made it look like she was on her way to a Renaissance fair. It was cut low over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair fell in loose curls down her shoulders, and she lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, and West new that it must have been a hard position to hold, but Dawn seemed adept at performing her false relaxation. He left her to it. His eye was drawn to the man beside her. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise, another precarious pose, another performance of ease, but Mark did not play his part quite so well. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. It was so carefully curated it set West’s teeth on edge, like something uncanny, almost veering into the inhuman. Which was ridiculous. Objectively, the man in the picture was just a man, if a very manicured one, his outfit not outrageous for the time. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro was pristine. Maybe it was his smile, that sneer, that made West want to run, that seemed to whisper in his ear// run run run//. Did he want to run from Mark? Was he responding to a threat? Or was a receiving a warning? West shook his head. He was not receiving a warning from a painting. There were no ghosts in this painting. He would feel them. He felt nothing in the darkness creeping over the paint. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn. Her deep brown eyes were wide and afraid, focused on something out of frame, and West felt that urge to run again, or to tell Tara to run, and he swallowed it down. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded almost completely into that suffocating void, like he could have been made of the darkness itself. He was shaped a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting something like a hand on Tara’s shoulder, but everything about him made West’s skin crawl. He did not look like any ghost West had seen. He did not look like the other Benningtons posed around him. So, who was he? If there were no ghosts in the gallery, what was possessing this portrait? “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but West did not think he was. He thought he was something much worse than a dead man. They needed to leave. //Run. // “Right,” said West, keeping his voice calm. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go?” “Hey, guys,” said Devi, stopping West after he took his first few steps towards the door. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” Classic haunting. West was surprised at how relieved he felt. He knew how to handle ghostly music. The normalcy took away some of his urgency, dampened a bit of his fear. “Then turn it up!” West laughed. But as he turned to walk to her, he stumbled over his feet, and without thinking, he reached out to steady himself. His hand pressed against the painting. He felt a sharp pain, like his skin was splitting open, a searing rupture so intense that when he opened his mouth to scream no sound came out. There was a darkness growing from under his palm and a terrible sour smell. Mold? It spread out from his burning hand, over the painting, obscuring the faces of the Bennington children under the new wet growth. “What the hell?” whispered Nellie. West wrenched his hand free. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands of their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and West heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building. West could still hear that sound through the chaos, some familiar noises mixed in with the static, melodies and lyrics, songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for West to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[All Right Now]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from the Triad)]] [[The Fountain - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from the Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from the Triad and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from the Triad and A Constellation)]]Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from A Constellation and The Fountain of Life)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from the Triad and The Fountain of Life)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from A Constellation and The Fountain of Life)]] West filmed the boarded-up windows. “Do you want me to do anything in front of those?” Nellie asked. “No, I’m just getting creepy B-roll,” West said. “Okay… Boring…” West pointed the camera at Nellie. “Fine, do something not boring.” Nellie threw her hands up in the air dramatically and wandered next to an uncomfortable Devi. “Maybe we should focus on the art,” Devi suggested. [[The Fountain - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from Gallery 2)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] West filmed the boarded-up windows. “Do you want me to do anything in front of those?” Nellie asked. “No, I’m just getting creepy B-roll,” West said. “Okay… Boring…” West pointed the camera at Nellie. “Fine, do something not boring.” Nellie threw her hands up in the air dramatically and wandered next to an uncomfortable Devi. “Maybe we should focus on the art,” Devi suggested. [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from Gallery 2)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] West filmed the boarded-up windows. “Do you want me to do anything in front of those?” Nellie asked. “No, I’m just getting creepy B-roll,” West said. “Okay… Boring…” West pointed the camera at Nellie. “Fine, do something not boring.” Nellie threw her hands up in the air dramatically and wandered next to an uncomfortable Devi. “Maybe we should focus on the art,” Devi suggested. [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary from Gallery 2)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]]West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (with Diary)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from the Triad)]]Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 1 - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from A Constellation)]] West did a slow zoom out of the portrait of the Bennington family that took up almost the entirety of one wall. The figures in it were life-size, but there was something wrong with the colors. They blended into shadows that did not exist, like some darkness was creeping over the paint, pulling the figures back into a void. It felt like… there should be spirits there. Maybe they had already been swallowed by that darkness. West wondered if the others noticed him looking for the ghosts that were not there and tried to think of something light-hearted to say, a quip for the camera. “I didn’t think people still had oil paintings made of themselves,” West said, filming each of the faces in the portrait. “Even the rich ones.” “It might have been more normal in the 70s,” Devi suggested. “Nothing about this family was normal,” West argued, and if it came out a little forcefully, neither Devi nor Nellie reacted to it. “Which one is she?” Nellie asked, pointing to the blond with the feathered fringe. “I think that one’s Dawn, the one who hanged herself,” said Devi. Dawn’s eyes were bright blue under her fringe, with alight with a strange sorrowful accusation that made West avert his eyes. Her dress was a much paler blue, willowy, with balloon-sleeves that made it look like she was on her way to a Renaissance fair. It was cut low over her chest, clearly displaying the locket that she wore. Her blonde hair fell in loose curls down her shoulders, and she lounged in the forefront of the picture, on a chaise longue. One elbow was set on the spiralled armrest so her delicate hand could prop up her head, while the other hand sat limply in her lap. She had tucked both her legs on the chaise, and West new that it must have been a hard position to hold, but Dawn seemed adept at performing her false relaxation. He left her to it. His eye was drawn to the man beside her. “The man on the right is Mark, the one who might be buried in the garden,” said Devi. Mark stood side-on to the room, one foot balanced behind him to press against the post of the chaise, another precarious pose, another performance of ease, but Mark did not play his part quite so well. His black shoes came to a point at the toe, his black pants flared at the base, and his shirt was a deep green with puffed sleeves and a series of ruffles that cascaded down his chest. It was so carefully curated it set West’s teeth on edge, like something uncanny, almost veering into the inhuman. Which was ridiculous. Objectively, the man in the picture was just a man, if a very manicured one, his outfit not outrageous for the time. His skin was dark brown, darker than West’s, and his neatly cut afro was pristine. Maybe it was his smile, that sneer, that made West want to run, that seemed to whisper in his ear// run run run//. Did he want to run from Mark? Was he responding to a threat? Or was a receiving a warning? West shook his head. He was not receiving a warning from a painting. There were no ghosts in this painting. He would feel them. He felt nothing in the darkness creeping over the paint. “And that one’s Tara, the one who took care of Bradford,” said Devi. Tara was probably around fifteen years old in the portrait, but she wore a dress that looked like it belonged on a much younger girl. It was pink, covered in white ribbons that matched the white ribbon holding back her dark curls. The bright pink of her dress brough out the reddish undertones of her brown skin. She perched on the edge of the chaise opposite from Mark, to the left of Dawn. Her deep brown eyes were wide and afraid, focused on something out of frame, and West felt that urge to run again, or to tell Tara to run, and he swallowed it down. “The man in the back must be Bradford,” Devi said, but she didn’t sound certain. The figure standing behind the chaise had faded almost completely into that suffocating void, like he could have been made of the darkness itself. He was shaped a man, appeared to have dark hair, and was resting something like a hand on Tara’s shoulder, but everything about him made West’s skin crawl. He did not look like any ghost West had seen. He did not look like the other Benningtons posed around him. So, who was he? If there were no ghosts in the gallery, what was possessing this portrait? “Have you seen any pictures of Bradford?” West asked. “Which one of his kids looked most like him?” Nellie asked. “I have,” said Devi. “And none of them. They all took after their respective moms.” This man could have been Bradford, but West did not think he was. He thought he was something much worse than a dead man. They needed to leave. //Run. // “Right,” said West, keeping his voice calm. “Lovers, plural. Forgot about that. Should we go?” “Hey, guys,” said Devi, stopping West after he took his first few steps towards the door. “I’m getting something on my mic again. Music, I know it, but it’s really faint.” Classic haunting. West was surprised at how relieved he felt. He knew how to handle ghostly music. The normalcy took away some of his urgency, dampened a bit of his fear. “Then turn it up!” West laughed. But as he turned to walk to her, he stumbled over his feet, and without thinking, he reached out to steady himself. His hand pressed against the painting. He felt a sharp pain, like his skin was splitting open, a searing rupture so intense that when he opened his mouth to scream no sound came out. There was a darkness growing from under his palm and a terrible sour smell. Mold? It spread out from his burning hand, over the painting, obscuring the faces of the Bennington children under the new wet growth. “What the hell?” whispered Nellie. West wrenched his hand free. The room exploded in sound and all three crew members clapped their hands of their ears. Devi gave a shriek for the brief moment hers were uncovered after she tore off her headphones, before she clasped her hands to her ears to drown out the noise. Even then, it was painfully loud, warbled words and electric tones. The room plunged into darkness as the light on West’s camera went out along with the dots of light on Devi’s recorder, and every star outside and the moon disappeared. The ground started to shake under their feet, and West heard someone laughing as they struggled to stand upright, the deep crackling voice of a monster. The walls groaned, popped, as the earth shifted under the building. West could still hear that sound through the chaos, some familiar noises mixed in with the static, melodies and lyrics, songs, perhaps hundreds of songs, all playing on top of each other, at once. Suddenly, all the noise stopped except for one tune, playing just long enough for West to recognize it before the Gallery stopped shaking, the light of the stars returned, and the song faded into silence. [[All Right Now.]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from the Triad)]] [[The Fountain - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from the Triad)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from A Constellation)]] [[The Fountain - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from A Constellation)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary)]] “See anything weird?” Devi asked. “No,” said West, slightly lowering the camera to peer down at her. “Why?” “You just seem distracted,” she said. “Thought you might have picked something up on camera.” “Nothing,” West said. It was the truth. There were no ghosts here. “Okay,” Devi said, a doubtful drawl in her voice. “Then let’s keeping looking for weird stuff.” [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[A Constellation - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from The Fountain of Life)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary)]] Six faded white blocks of different sizes were scattered around the room. “Is it a metaphor?” West asked, feeling stupid. “If it is, I don’t get it,” said Nellie, making West feel slightly better. “I think it represents…” Devi said, trailing off as West and Nellie tried to hide their smirks. “Never mind!” “No, Devi, please, what do the white blocks represent?” West asked, pointing the camera at her. She stuck her tongue out for the audience. “I think they represent the limitation of verbal communication,” Nellie said with faux seriousness. West swept the camera over to her. “Or perhaps the limitlessness of visual communication,” he suggested and she nodded sagely. “Fine, I’ll keep my analysis to myself!” Devi said while West and Nellie giggled. [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from the Triad and A Constellation)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle. They stared into the dip of the giant bowl. Devi glared at West, clearly expecting him to say something dismissive, but West was actually… compelled? Is this how modern art was supposed to make you feel? The subtle curve of the bowl, the design spreading through it was hypnotic. It made him feel melancholy. It made him feel sick. “The Fountain of Life has gone dry,” Nellie declared. “It never had water in it,” Devi said. “Look,” West said, pointing his camera into the dip, directing their attention to a detailed etching of a giant V or curving horns. Nellie reached into the bowl, running her hand along the etching. “You know what? I like it,” Nellie said. “It’s simple, but it sends a message.” He was glad Nellie had touched it and not him. He wanted to touch it. He did not know why. He did not know why he felt the need to reach out for things that were going to hurt him, why the things that wanted to hurt him always seemed eager to reach back. He blinked away tears before Nellie or Devi could see them. “I don’t, it gives me the creeps,” said West. “Let’s look at something else.” [[Gallery 2 - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from the Triad and The Fountain of Life)]] West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[The Triad - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary from Gallery 2)]] [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary)]] Nellie, West, and Devi climbed onto the large stone bench that surrounded the fountain at the center of the room in a perfect connected circle.
