[[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary)]]West tried to appreciate the sculpture. He supposed it looked like three women dancing. If you squinted. Or looked past them and just tried to glance at them out of the corner of your eye. Which seemed like a weird way to view a work of art, but probably the right way, because it did do something strange. The way the blur made the trio split in his vision, each trio creating its own trio, gave the illusion of movement. Interesting, perhaps, but it did not change how unnerving their blank, faceless… faces… were. Modern art usually had some metaphorical meaning that was more important than the art itself. Even just thinking that to himself made West feel unbelievably pretentious. “Do you think they’re supposed to be the Greek fates?” asked West. “Maybe they’re the Norse fates,” Devi proposed. “I think art is just full of three women dancing together,” Nellie said. West could tell Devi was about to say something else, maybe argue with Nellie or give a long history about why three women dancing together was artistic, or sexist, or historically significant, but those blank faces were starting to creep him out. “As the leader, I say we leave them to their dance,” West said, turning his camera to capture the rest of the gallery. [[Portrait of the Bennington Family - West's Tour with Sludge (Basement with Diary)]] West gasped. He felt something burning him, more like rage than fire, hot and small and concentrated… He reached into his pocket and pulled out the locket. It wasn’t really hot. It was angry. It was haunted. There was a ghost in the locket. He had seen ghosts trapped in houses, in cupboards, in graveyards of course. He had even seen ghosts haunt people, like a shadow following them, or even something inhabiting their skin. But he had never experienced whatever kind of haunting this was. The locket burned hotter, and West had a flash of an image, the clawed teeth of a bear trap. A trap. The ground rumbled again, tearing him away from this mystery. He looked up to see Devi, frozen in place, Nellie, her eyes glued to the locket in his hand. “That was an earthquake, we have to get out of here!” West shouted at them. Devi seemed to come back to herself, eyes hardening with resolve as she ran out of the gallery. Nellie was a step or two behind her, unable to hide her hesitation. West tightened his grip and ran after them. The mandala of rocks in the garden had been upset by the shaking ground, the path ruined. Devi had put her headphones on again and was listening intently as she stumbled forward, but Nellie stopped right in front of West, halting his progress. “Nellie! Earthquake! Move!” West shouted. “It’s the locket,” she said, her voice unnaturally calm. “Whatever is going on, we made it happen when we took it. When we brought it back to Dawn.” “How do you know it’s Dawn?” Devi asked. Nellie stared at West. He did not know how she knew. He just knew she was right. “You think an earthquake happened because a ghost is mad that we stole her jewellery?” West asked, trying for a scoff that Nellie was not buying. “I don’t think that’s why she’s mad,” Nellie said. “I think… I think she needs help.” The image of the bear trap flashed again in West’s mind. “How do we help a ghost?” Devi asked, grabbing West’s arm when the ground shook again. “We set her free,” said Nellie. [[Take the Locket to the Séance Room]] West gasped. He felt something burning him, more like rage than fire, hot and small and concentrated… He reached into his pocket and pulled out the locket. It wasn’t really hot. It was angry. It was haunted. There was a ghost in the locket. He had seen ghosts trapped in houses, in cupboards, in graveyards of course. He had even seen ghosts haunt people, like a shadow following them, or even something inhabiting their skin. But he had never experienced whatever kind of haunting this was. The locket burned hotter, and West had a flash of an image, the clawed teeth of a bear trap. A trap. The ground rumbled again, tearing him away from this mystery. He looked up to see Devi, frozen in place, Nellie, her eyes glued to the locket in his hand. “That was an earthquake, we have to get out of here!” West shouted at them. Devi seemed to come back to herself, eyes hardening with resolve as she ran out of the gallery. Nellie was a step or two behind her, unable to hide her hesitation. West tightened his grip and ran after them. The mandala of rocks in the garden had been upset by the shaking ground, the path ruined. Devi had put her headphones on again and was listening intently as she stumbled forward, but Nellie stopped right in front of West, halting his progress. “Nellie! Earthquake! Move!” West shouted. “It’s the locket,” she said, her voice unnaturally calm. “Whatever is going on, we made it happen when we took it. When we brought it back to Dawn.” “How do you know it’s Dawn?” Devi asked. Nellie stared at West. He did not know how she knew. He just knew she was right. “You think an earthquake happened because a ghost is mad that we stole her jewellery?” West asked, trying for a scoff that Nellie was not buying. “I don’t think that’s why she’s mad,” Nellie said. “I think… I think she needs help.” The image of the bear trap flashed again in West’s mind. “How do we help a ghost?” Devi asked, grabbing West’s arm when the ground shook again. “We set her free,” said Nellie. [[Take the Locket to the Séance Room]] [[Take the Locket to the Basement]]“That was an earthquake, we have to get out of here!” West shouted at Nellie and Devi. Nellie snapped out of her frozen terror and grabbed Devi’s arm. West trusted they would follow and ran out of the gallery, to the looming cacti, but jolted to a stop when an unfamiliar face materialized in front of him. He heard the sound of skidding rocks as his crewmates stopped short behind him. “West, what the hell?” Nellie hissed by his shoulder. “Um…” The face wasn’t entirely unfamiliar. It was the ghost who had been walking the mandala, with the long braid. But there was something uncanny about her features that West did not have time to consider too hard. The ghost was pointing at him. At his pants? He patted his pocket and pulled out the diary. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked. “I’m… looking…” The ghost nodded, and West began to flip through the diary while she stared down at the pages, frowning, waving her hand impatiently for him to keep going. “Oh my god,” said Nellie. “West, is there a… presence here?” “West doesn’t even believe in that sort of thing,” Devi snapped. “Shut up, both of you, I’m trying to pay attention to the ghost.” Nellie gave an excited squeal and West ignored whatever she whispered to Devi. They could record all they wanted. This ghost wasn’t saying anything. Not with words, at least. West finally reached a page that made her point excitedly before she disappeared. “She wanted me to read this,” said West. “She?” asked Devi, her voice strained. “What does it say?” asked Nellie, leaning close over his shoulder. The three investigators read together: //If He is released, called forth in his Hunger for what was promised, father’s trick of using the key can lock Verziz away but leaves His power out of reach… still hope His power will be His end, but I’ll keep key safe in here for now.// West flipped through the book. Nothing. No key. [[Take Diary to Upper Observatory]] [[Take Diary to Séance Room]] “That was an earthquake, we have to get out of here!” West shouted at Nellie and Devi. Nellie snapped out of her frozen terror and grabbed Devi’s arm. West trusted they would follow and ran out of the gallery, to the looming cacti, but jolted to a stop when an unfamiliar face materialized in front of him. He heard the sound of skidding rocks as his crewmates stopped short behind him. “West, what the hell?” Nellie hissed by his shoulder. “Um…” The face wasn’t entirely unfamiliar. It was the ghost who had been walking the mandala, with the long braid. But there was something uncanny about her features that West did not have time to consider too hard. The ghost was pointing at him. At his pants? He patted his pocket and pulled out the diary. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked. “I’m… looking…” The ghost nodded, and West began to flip through the diary while she stared down at the pages, frowning, waving her hand impatiently for him to keep going. “Oh my god,” said Nellie. “West, is there a… presence here?” “West doesn’t even believe in that sort of thing,” Devi snapped. “Shut up, both of you, I’m trying to pay attention to the ghost.” Nellie gave an excited squeal and West ignored whatever she whispered to Devi. They could record all they wanted. This ghost wasn’t saying anything. Not with words, at least. West finally reached a page that made her point excitedly before she disappeared. “She wanted me to read this,” said West. “She?” asked Devi, her voice strained. “What does it say?” asked Nellie, leaning close over his shoulder. The three investigators read together: //If He is released, called forth in his Hunger for what was promised, father’s trick of using the key can lock Verziz away but leaves His power out of reach… still hope His power will be His end, but I’ll keep key safe in here for now.// West flipped through the book. Nothing. No key. [[Take Diary to Upper Observatory with Pick]] [[Take Diary to Séance Room with Pick]]West gasped. He felt nauseas. The pain from his split hand, split and dripping that black mold, was writhing under his skin. He felt something burning him, more like rage than fire, hot and small and concentrated… He reached into his pocket and pulled out the locket. It wasn’t really hot. It was angry. It was haunted. There was a ghost in the locket, and there was something inside him, something worse. It seeped out of his open hand, covering the locket, a thin sheen of sludge turning the gold a muted gray. He had never experienced whatever kind of haunting this was, whatever trapped the ghost in the jewellery, whatever was seeping inside of him, out of him. The locket burned hotter, like a fever now, as sick as he was and West had a flash of an image, the clawed teeth of a bear trap. A trap, oozing black mold. The ground rumbled again, tearing him away from this mystery. He looked up to see Devi, frozen in place, a hand over her mouth that could not cover the moan that escaped as she stared at West. Nellie made no noise, her eyes glued to the locket in his hand. “What’s happening to me?” West asked, and drool dripped from the corners of his mouth. He wiped it away with the back of his hand, leaving a trail of sludge on his skin. “It’s the locket,” Nellie said, her voice unnaturally calm. “Whatever is going on, we made it happen when we took it. When we brought it back to Dawn.” “How do you know it’s Dawn?” Devi asked. Nellie stared at West. He did not know how she knew. He just knew she was right. “You think an earthquake happened because a ghost is mad that we stole her jewellery?” West asked, uncertain, but what else could explain what was happening to him? It felt like a punishment. A curse. “What do we do? How do we fix this?” “We set her free,” said Nellie. Devi seemed to come back to herself, eyes hardening with resolve as she ran out of the gallery, just a step behind Nellie who was already forging a straight line through the ruined stone mandala. West tightened his grip and ran after them, stumbling to stay on his feet as the earth trembled once more. [[Take the Locket to the Séance Room with Sludge]]West gasped. He felt nauseas. The pain from his split hand, split and dripping that black mold, was writhing under his skin. He felt something burning him, more like rage than fire, hot and small and concentrated… He reached into his pocket and pulled out the locket. It wasn’t really hot. It was angry. It was haunted. There was a ghost in the locket, and there was something inside him, something worse. It seeped out of his open hand, covering the locket, a thin sheen of sludge turning the gold a muted gray. He had never experienced whatever kind of haunting this was, whatever trapped the ghost in the jewellery, whatever was seeping inside of him, out of him. The locket burned hotter, like a fever now, as sick as he was and West had a flash of an image, the clawed teeth of a bear trap. A trap, oozing black mold. The ground rumbled again, tearing him away from this mystery. He looked up to see Devi, frozen in place, a hand over her mouth that could not cover the moan that escaped as she stared at West. Nellie made no noise, her eyes glued to the locket in his hand. “What’s happening to me?” West asked, and drool dripped from the corners of his mouth. He wiped it away with the back of his hand, leaving a trail of sludge on his skin. “It’s the locket,” Nellie said, her voice unnaturally calm. “Whatever is going on, we made it happen when we took it. When we brought it back to Dawn.” “How do you know it’s Dawn?” Devi asked. Nellie stared at West. He did not know how she knew. He just knew she was right. “You think an earthquake happened because a ghost is mad that we stole her jewellery?” West asked, uncertain, but what else could explain what was happening to him? It felt like a punishment. A curse. “What do we do? How do we fix this?” “We set her free,” said Nellie. Devi seemed to come back to herself, eyes hardening with resolve as she ran out of the gallery, just a step behind Nellie who was already forging a straight line through the ruined stone mandala. West tightened his grip and ran after them, stumbling to stay on his feet as the earth trembled once more. [[Take the Locket to the Séance Room with Sludge]] [[Take the Locket to the Basement with Sludge]]West gasped. He felt nauseas. The pain from his split hand, split and dripping that black mold, was writhing under his skin. The ground rumbled again. He looked up to see Devi, frozen in place, a hand over her mouth that could not cover the moan that escaped as she stared at West. “West, you don’t look so great,” Nellie whispered, taking a step back from him. “What’s happening to me?” West asked, and drool dripped from the corners of his mouth. “We need to get him to a hospital,” Devi said. “We need to get him to an exorcist,” Nellie said, making a strange strangled sound that might have been a laugh, or a sob. West didn’t feel like he was possessed by anything, and there hadn’t been a ghost in the gallery to possess him. But there was something inside of him, something terrible and perhaps alive. It felt like a punishment. A curse. “What do we do?” West groaned, his throat thick and tight. “How do we fix this?” The ground shook. “First things first, we get out of here before the place collapses on us,” said Nellie, grabbing Devi’s arm, half-dragging her out of the gallery. West stumbled after them but paused when they reached the garden. The ghost was back, the ghost who had been walking the mandala, with the long braid. There was something uncanny about her features, but West did not have time to consider it too hard. The ghost was pointing at him. At his pants? He patted his pocket and pulled out Mark’s guitar pick. Devi forced Nellie to a half when she realized West was no longer following them. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked. West coughed and something wet slid down the front of his hoodie. The ghost cringed away in disgust then disappeared. West stared at the pick held between his finger tips and watched as sludge oozed out of his pores and a soft black fuzz erupted over the small object pressed against his cursed skin. “A ghost,” West murmured through lips that felt less like lips each passing second. “It… it was trying to tell me something.” “You don’t believe in ghosts,” Devi said slowly. “Seeing is believing,” said Nellie, her eyes bright. “What did it want us to do? Maybe the pick can help you. Let me see it.” [[Give Nellie the Pick]] [[Refuse to Give Nellie the Pick]] West gasped. He felt nauseas. The pain from his split hand, split and dripping that black mold, was writhing under his skin. The ground rumbled again. He looked up to see Devi, frozen in place, a hand over her mouth that could not cover the moan that escaped as she stared at West. “West, you don’t look so great,” Nellie whispered, taking a step back from him. “What’s happening to me?” West asked, and drool dripped from the corners of his mouth. “We need to get him to a hospital,” Devi said. “We need to get him to an exorcist,” Nellie said, making a strange strangled sound that might have been a laugh, or a sob. West didn’t feel like he was possessed by anything, and there hadn’t been a ghost in the gallery to possess him. But there was something inside of him, something terrible and perhaps alive. It felt like a punishment. A curse. “What do we do?” West groaned, his throat thick and tight. “How do we fix this?” The ground shook. “First things first, we get out of here before the place collapses on us,” said Nellie, grabbing Devi’s arm, half-dragging her out of the gallery. West stumbled after them but paused when they reached the garden. The ghost was back, the ghost who had been walking the mandala, with the long braid. There was something uncanny about her features, but West did not have time to consider it too hard. The ghost was pointing at him. At his pants? He patted his pocket and pulled out the diary. Devi forced Nellie to a half when she realized West was no longer following them. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked. “I’m… looking…” West coughed and something wet slid down the front of his hoodie. The ghost cringed away in disgust then disappeared. West began to flip through the diary, but the sludge that now oozed from his fingers like sweat was smudging the words on the page. “We don’t have time for this,” Nellie muttered. “We need to get out of here.” “We need to help him,” Devi said. “How?” asked Nellie. [[Take West to the Séance Room]] West gasped. He felt nauseas. The pain from his split hand, split and dripping that black mold, was writhing under his skin. The ground rumbled again. He looked up to see Devi, frozen in place, a hand over her mouth that could not cover the moan that escaped as she stared at West. “West, you don’t look so great,” Nellie whispered, taking a step back from him. “What’s happening to me?” West asked, and drool dripped from the corners of his mouth. “We need to get him to a hospital,” Devi said. “We need to get him to an exorcist,” Nellie said, making a strange strangled sound that might have been a laugh, or a sob. West didn’t feel like he was possessed by anything, and there hadn’t been a ghost in the gallery to possess him. But there was something inside of him, something terrible and perhaps alive. It felt like a punishment. A curse. “What do we do?” West groaned, his throat thick and tight. “How do we fix this?” The ground shook. “First things first, we get out of here before the place collapses on us,” said Nellie, grabbing Devi’s arm, half-dragging her out of the gallery. West stumbled after them but paused when they reached the garden. The ghost was back, the ghost who had been walking the mandala, with the long braid. There was something uncanny about her features, but West did not have time to consider it too hard. The ghost was pointing at him. At his pants? He patted his pocket and pulled out the diary. Devi forced Nellie to a half when she realized West was no longer following them. “West, what are you doing?” Devi asked. “I’m… looking…” West coughed and something wet slid down the front of his hoodie. The ghost cringed away in disgust then disappeared. West began to flip through the diary, but the sludge that now oozed from his fingers like sweat was smudging the words on the page. “We don’t have time for this,” Nellie muttered. “We need to get out of here.” “We need to help him,” Devi said. “How?” asked Nellie. [[Take West to the Séance Room]] [[Take West to the Basement]]The ground rumbled again. Devi’s hand felt so fragile on his arm, Nellie’s eyes were so still and vacant she looked half-dead. “No, no, we don’t have time for this. We need to get out of here,” he said. “The Séance Room is right by the entrance,” said Devi. “It’s a Séance Pit now, and the door is locked,” West said. “The Upper Séance Room, then,” said Devi. “Above the Groove Room. It leads right down to the pit. We can try to talk to her, figure out what to do. I can almost hear her…” “No. We’re getting out of here,” West said. “We can, I don’t know, come back. If the mansion is still standing.” “West,” Devi began, but Nellie cut her off. “He’s right,” she said. “It’s too dangerous. Let’s go.” She started racing towards the mansion and West was too relieved to do anything but follow her. Devi still seemed distressed, holding the headphones against her ears, listening intently, shaking her head. He wanted to say something to comfort her, but there was no way he was coming back here, and if he started talking, she might notice the lie. He kept expecting her to stop him. As they passed the photos of celebrities in the hall, Devi’s eyes slid over his shoulder, widened, and she nodded slightly. Before West could look behind him to see what she had seen, another quake rocked the mansion and Devi fell forward, completely off balance. Without thinking, West reached out to grab her. The locket clattered to the floor for a second before Nellie scooped it up, sprinting into the Groove Room. “Nellie, no!” Devi righted herself, not off-balance, of course. West cursed and the two rushed after Nellie, but they did not have to rush very far. Nellie had frozen at the base of the stairs. And someone was walking down towards them – the ghost of a woman with dark almond eyes, cropped black hair. West averted his eyes, trying to pretend he did not see the ghost, then noticed Nellie and Devi were staring right at her. “Emma?” Nellie whispered. Emma let out a small gasp and smiled, reaching out her hands to Nellie who reached back before West could even think about if it was a terrible idea. But it did not matter. She was not reaching for Nellie, but for the locket, which she plucked from the confused investigator’s grasp. “Oh, Dawn,” Emma said. “I’ve been waiting here for so long.” Another figure materialized in the room, with soft blond hair and a feathered fringe, throwing her arms around Emma’s shoulders. “I’m sorry, I’m so sorry I made you wait,” said Dawn, and though her voice was remorseful, the ghost couldn’t contain her grin. “Someone put my locket in the library, and I was trapped inside-” Emma hushed her. “We’re together now.” Dawn’s eyes flickered down for a moment, and West braced for another quake that did not come. “What about-” she began, but Emma cut her off. “We’re together now,” she insisted. “Whatever happens in the future, happens. For now, we have each other. Thanks to them.” Dawn stared at the three investigators, and even though they had saved her from the locket, she did not look particularly impressed with what she saw. “You should go,” Dawn said to West. “Compared to the other monsters in this mansion, I’m downright friendly.” West had many questions, but not nearly enough curiosity to stick around and interrogate an unfriendly spirit that had apparently caused an earthquake to return to her dead lover. The thought of staying to prise the secrets of Bennington Mansion out of Dawn was almost as unbearable as the thought of driving for hours back to the hotel with Devi and Nellie who were currently radiating smugness. But he followed his crewmembers out, quickly leaving the ghosts behind him. As far as final investigations went, he supposed reuniting to lost souls was the best possible outcome. [[End of Track]] The ground rumbled again. Devi’s hand felt so fragile on his arm, Nellie’s eyes were so still and vacant she looked half-dead. “No, no, we don’t have time for this. We need to get out of here,” he said. “The Séance Room is right by the entrance,” said Devi. “It’s a Séance Pit now, and the door is locked,” West said. “The Upper Séance Room, then,” said Devi. “Above the Groove Room. It leads right down to the pit. We can try to talk to her, figure out what to do. I can almost hear her…” “No. We’re getting out of here,” West said. “We can, I don’t know, come back. If the mansion is still standing.” “West,” Devi began, but Nellie cut her off. “The Basement is right inside,” she said, her eyes sharp now, a strange desperation tightening her voice. “Everything in this house has pointed to that altar, that imagery, something from Bradford’s occult days. He did something to her down there that trapped her. He must have. Maybe we can use the altar to set her free.” Before West could protest that going into a basement during an earthquake was a terrible idea, Nellie was already running, pulling Devi with her. The locket grew hotter in his hand, and he was overwhelmed with the ghost’s rage, that anger he always tried to avoid on investigations. It was more fury than he had felt in a long time, and though he did not love that he was following Nellie’s footsteps through the secret wardrobe, down to the depths, he mostly just wanted to be rid of the burning fire clenched in his fist. He was so focused on the pain he nearly stumbled into Nellie and Devi who were frozen at the base of the stairs. A man sat cross-legged on the altar. The man was handsome, in an unusual way. His skin was a little too pale. His black hair was pushed messily back from his forehead. His shirt and ripped jeans were too tight, a trying-too-hard rockstar look, or maybe just a poor fit. His eyes were dark. He blinked slowly at them, squinting slightly, and West wondered if he could not see very well. But then the man’s eyes locked on West’s hand. Maybe he could see incredibly well, through West’s flesh, to the burning secret hidden in his fist. He smiled at the crewmembers, and the heat of the locket changed from rage to something to a different kind of intensity. Panic? Fear? West stared harder at the man, yes, definitely a man and not a ghost. But not human, West was sure, no matter how many little human touches there were in that poorly fitting outfit, that purposefully mussed hairstyle, those perfectly placed six freckles that crossed his cheeks. “Who are you?” Devi whispered. “Call me Verses,” the man said. “I’m surprised you don’t know, if you came down here.” Whoever, whatever he was, West did not think it best to engage with him. They needed to get out of there. “Can you help her?” Nellie asked, pointing to West’s hand, and it felt like the locket was screaming. “She’s trapped.” “Oh, yes, I can help,” said the man. “I can free her from that trap. Give her to me.” He held out his hand, but did not move from the altar. West was not going to take a step further. He did not trust the man, but the pain was becoming too much to bear, and West realized he was terrified. He just wanted to leave. He tossed the locket to Verses who caught it deftly. And any presence West had felt in the locket was gone. He shivered. Not free. Not “moving on,” as ghosts sometimes did. Just gone. “Is she…” Devi asked. West grabbed Nellie and Devi, pushing them up the stairs as the man laughed behind them, a terrible hollow sound. “If you find the others, I’d be happy to free them, too,” he called after them, his voice seeming to come from much further away than the basement. At least the earthquakes had stopped. At least nothing grabbed them to trap them in the mansion as they ran to the car. At least the only person to die that night was already dead. [[End of Track]] They ran into Bradford’s Bedroom before West stopped with a hiss. The split in his hand was growing, extending down his arm. The dull locket, gripped so tight, was half-buried in his skin. If it was still skin. As he pulled the locket out of the wound with his free hand, he felt the edges of his torn flesh scrape against his fingers with a roughness almost like burlap or woven hemp. The two girls had stopped at his sound of pain. Devi looked at him, worry etched across her face. Nellie also looked concerned, but her eyes were on the locket. “The Séance Room is right by the entrance,” said Devi. “We need to hurry, West. You’re…” “It’s a Séance Pit now, and the door is locked,” West said. “The Upper Séance Room, then,” said Devi. “Above the Groove Room. It leads right down to the pit. We can try to talk to her, figure out what to do. I can almost hear her…” “Okay,” said West, panic tightening his chest as the skin on either side of the wound began to curl up and away from the sludge beneath. He gripped the locket in his left hand and let his infected arm hang limp as he raced after Nellie and Devi. They passed the photos of celebrities in the hall, and sprinted into the Groove Room, before stopping short at the bottom of the stairs. Someone was walking down towards them – the ghost of a woman with dark almond eyes, cropped black hair. West averted his eyes, trying to pretend he did not see the ghost, then noticed Nellie and Devi were staring right at her. “Emma?” Nellie whispered. West reached out with his good hand, letting the locket hand loose on the chain. Emma let out a small gasp and smiled, plucking the jewellery from his grasp. “Oh, Dawn,” Emma said. “I’ve been waiting here for so long.” Another figure materialized in the room, with soft blond hair and a feathered fringe... and a face entirely distorted by black mold. Emma’s face turned into a mask of horror. “What did you do to her?” West could see wounds opening like seams in Dawn’s arms, what was Dawn, at least. It seemed disoriented and moved with a violent jerk, throwing its arms forward. Maybe it meant to reach out for Emma, maybe not, but its hands were in her hair now. The mold quickly spread over Emma’s featuring as well before both figures fell to their knees, disappearing, leaving only a stain of black sludge on the Groove Room rug. “I’m sorry,” Nellie whispered, over and over. “I’m sorry, I’m sorry.” West thought she was talking to the absent ghosts. But when he turned to look at her, she had Devi maneuvered Devi behind her, and both were backing slowly out of the room, horrified eyes locked on West. He tried to say something but could not speak over the sludge filling his mouth. He tried to take a step towards them, but his leg gave out, unspooled, spilled open. He hit the floor with a soft thunk, too soft, his head feeling strangely deflated against the rug. He saw Nellie and Devi’s feet as the ran from the room. He saw nothing else. [[End of Track]] They ran into Bradford’s Bedroom before West stopped with a hiss. The split in his hand was growing, extending down his arm. The dull locket, gripped so tight, was half-buried in his skin. If it was still skin. As he pulled the locket out of the wound with his free hand, he felt the edges of his torn flesh scrape against his fingers with a roughness almost like burlap or woven hemp. The two girls had stopped at his sound of pain. Devi looked at him, worry etched across her face. Nellie also looked concerned, but her eyes were on the locket. “The Séance Room is right by the entrance,” said Devi. “We need to hurry, West. You’re…” “It’s a Séance Pit now, and the door is locked,” West said. “The Upper Séance Room, then,” said Devi. “Above the Groove Room. It leads right down to the pit. We can try to talk to her, figure out what to do. I can almost hear her…” “The Basement is right here,” Nellie interrupted her, her eyes sharp now, a strange desperation tightening her voice. “Everything in this house has pointed to that altar, that imagery, something from Bradford’s occult days. He did something to her down there that trapped her. He must have. Maybe we can use the altar to set her free.” “Okay,” said West, panic tightening his chest as the skin on either side of the wound began to curl up and away from the sludge beneath. They ran through the wardrobe, down the stairs, and froze. A man sat cross-legged on the altar. The man was handsome, in an unusual way. His skin was a little too pale. His black hair was pushed messily back from his forehead. His shirt and ripped jeans were too tight, a trying-too-hard rockstar look, or maybe just a poor fit. His eyes were dark. He blinked slowly at them, squinting slightly, and West wondered if he could not see very well. But then the man’s eyes locked on West and he scowled, and suddenly he did not look like a man at all. Not a ghost, either. Something terrible and now, something angry. “You corrupted my offering with that filth?” he hissed, and it sounded like the static from before, and if West could have clamped his hands over his ears again like Nellie and Devi were then he would have, but now both hung limp and dead at his sides. “Are you trying to destroy me, too? Or merely mock me? Foolish creatures, you have made a grave mistake. I will have my fill for today as payment for what you took from me.” There was a rush of air, like a vacuum opening around them, all static and pressure and noise and pain. West could hear Nellie and Devi screaming, saw their eyes grow terrified then go blank and lifeless before they fell to the ground. The man looked at him with disgust, and West felt a different kind of pressure like a strong wind push him back towards the stairs. Try to push him back. What was left of his skin could not handle the strain. He felt himself unravel, he saw a spray of sludge on the floor that made the man recoil, even though it never touched him. What would happen if it touched him? West would never find out. [[End of Track]] “Didn’t something fall out of the diary when you opened it?” Devi asked? “Shit,” said West. “Not shit, we know where the key is,” said Nellie excitedly. “We can…” The ground roiled beneath their feet. “Exactly, we have no idea what we’d even be doing with this key,” said West, throwing his arms out for balance. “We need to get out of here.” “We did something, we set something off, we need to stop it,” snapped Nellie. “We released something bad and it’s literally rocking the world.” “Nellie’s right,” said Devi. “Do what you want, West. We’re going to get the key.” West watched them run away from him for a moment before swearing and following them inside, to the library, up the stairs. They all fell to their knees, hands sweeping across the floor, sticking their fingers into the cracks in the wood panels. “I think I found it,” said Nellie, but her voice wavered. “There’s something here, but I can’t get it out.” She was trying to catch the corner with the tip of her nail, but the manicured edge was too short, too round. “Okay, we tried,” said West. “Now can we leave?” There was a straining sound as the panelling rose beneath them in a surreal kind of wave as the earth shook again. But the smooth motion was upset by the sound of a sharp crack, foundations bending too far, breaking. There was a short jerk as the room fell a foot or two. The investigators looked at each other, eyes wide. And then the floor completely gave way. West heard Nellie scream, saw a wall come crashing towards him and felt a sharp pain before all was darkness. [[End of Track]] “Isn’t the Séance Room door locked?” asked West. “A lot of doors are locked,” Devi said slowly. The ground roiled beneath their feet. “Well, we don’t have time to check a lot of doors,” said Nellie, bracing herself against the revolting earth. “And the Séance Room is a suspicious enough place to start.” “And, you know, end if we’re wrong, considering it’s near the front door,” said West. They ran together into the mansion, past the hall of portraits, to the door to the Séance Room. West examined the keyhole. “Do you see anything?” asked Devi. For a moment… A distorted face? Pale, drawn, eyes so black, two deep voids. And then he was being pulled backwards, a hand gripping hard on his shoulder. “Who the hell are you?” Nellie screamed as West righted himself and saw the unfamiliar woman who had grabbed him. Long grey curls covered half her face, but he could see her eyes, filled with rage. And since the others could see her, too, it didn’t matter how unsettling she looked, how her rage made her nearly vibrate off the ground. This was a person, not a ghost. But a person came with its own kind of dangers. “Don’t touch me!” West screamed as the woman started reaching for him again. “Thieves!” she shouted, her voice raspy and harsh. Thieves? West pulled the diary out of his pocket and the woman snatched it from him and began flipping through it, frantic. Nellie was inching backwards, towards the door, but Devi was rooted in spot, eyes wide. “Tara?” she asked. The woman ignored her, glaring up at West. “Where is the key?” she snapped. They didn’t have the key. The door was locked. There was nothing. The woman, Tara, lunged at him with a feral shriek, her fists balling the fabric of his hoodie and forcing him backwards, towards the Séance Room. His back hit the door, and West heard a snapping sound before it broke free behind him. He grabbed at the woman, trying to stay on his feet, but he was already falling, and between her grip on him and his grip on her, she was falling with him. He could hear Devi screaming something but could not make it out over the wind rushing past his ears as he fell. He thought he heard laughter, as hollow as a dying star, before he finally, finally hit the ground and splintered. [[End of Track]] “Didn’t something fall out of the diary when you opened it?” Devi asked? “Shit,” said West. “Not shit, we know where the key is,” said Nellie excitedly. “We can…” The ground roiled beneath their feet. “Exactly, we have no idea what we’d even be doing with this key,” said West, throwing his arms out for balance. “We need to get out of here.” “We did something, we set something off, we need to stop it,” snapped Nellie. “We released something bad and it’s literally rocking the world.” “Nellie’s right,” said Devi. “Do what you want, West. We’re going to get the key.” West watched them run away from him for a moment before swearing and following them inside, to the library, up the stairs. They all fell to their knees, hands sweeping across the floor, sticking their fingers into the cracks in the wood panels. “I think I found it,” said Nellie, but her voice wavered. “There’s something here, but I can’t get it out.” She was trying to catch the corner with the tip of her nail, but the manicured edge was too short, too round. “Let me try,” said West, pushing her out of the way. Before she could protest he fished the guitar pick out of his pocket, using the pointed tip to coax the object from it tight fit in the crack. He managed to get enough of it out to pinch the edge with his fingers, pulling it free. “What is that, a compact?” asked Nellie? “It’s glass,” said West. “A circle of glass. Not really a key.” “A lens,” said Devi. “The telescope.” They looked over at the telescope. The wooden floor rose in a surreal wave under their feet and West ignored his confusion, rushing to the telescope, fitting the lens in place. And the quake stopped. “Was that because of us?” Devi asked. “Don’t care, let’s go,” said West. They hurried out of the mansion, waiting for aftershocks that never came. As they drove away, West shook his head. Ghosts, yes, there would always be ghosts. Ghosts that could cause earthquakes? Ghosts that could be locked away with a telescope lens? Ridiculous. “I bet it was a coincidence,” he muttered, and Nellie smacked him on the back of the head. [[End of Track]] “Isn’t the Séance Room door locked?” asked West. “A lot of doors are locked,” Devi said slowly. The ground roiled beneath their feet. “Well, we don’t have time to check a lot of doors,” said Nellie, bracing herself against the revolting earth. “And the Séance Room is a suspicious enough place to start.” “And, you know, end if we’re wrong, considering it’s near the front door,” said West. They ran together into the mansion, past the hall of portraits, to the door to the Séance Room. West examined the keyhole. “Do you see anything?” asked Devi. For a moment… A distorted face? Pale, drawn, eyes so black, two deep voids. And then he was being pulled backwards, a hand gripping hard on his shoulder. “Who the hell are you?” Nellie screamed as West righted himself and saw the unfamiliar woman who had grabbed him. Long grey curls covered half her face, but he could see her eyes, filled with rage. And since the others could see her, too, it didn’t matter how unsettling she looked, how her rage made her nearly vibrate off the ground. This was a person, not a ghost. But a person came with its own kind of dangers. “Don’t touch me!” West screamed as the woman started reaching for him again. “Thieves!” she shouted, her voice raspy and harsh. Thieves? West pulled the diary out of his pocket and the woman snatched it from him and began flipping through it, frantic. Nellie was inching backwards, towards the door, but Devi was rooted in spot, eyes wide. “Tara?” she asked. The woman ignored her, glaring up at West. “Where is the key?” she snapped. They didn’t have the key. The door was locked. But something in the woman’s rage filled eyes made West sure he needed to give her something, and fast, or there would be terrible consequences. “Oh, yeah, the key,” he said digging into his pocket, noticing how Tara, if that was Tara Bennington, relaxed slightly. “It’s right here.” His hand gripped the guitar pick he found in Mark’s room. He threw it down the hall, and Tara shrieked as she heard the sound of it clatter against a picture frame. She bolted after it and West turned and ran towards the door, glad he did not have to convince Nellie and Devi to run with him. He heard Tara scream in rage, probably when she realized that the guitar pick was not whatever key she was looking for, but by then they were already out the door. The ground continued to shake as the jumped into the car, driving away, but it had to stop eventually. “We didn’t really release something terrible, right?” Devi asked from the back seat, her voice soft. “If we did, it’s Tara’s problem now,” Nellie muttered. West nodded, but he wasn’t so sure. Hopefully, Tara could find the key. Whatever it was. Hopefully, she could undo whatever they started in Bennington Mansion. [[End of Track]] “Let’s go to the Séance Room,” Devi said. “We know it’s a connection to the weirdness of the house, and West is definitely going through weirdness.” “Isn’t the Séance Room door locked?” asked West. The ground roiled beneath their feet. “Well, we don’t have time to reason through our options,” said Nellie, bracing herself against the revolting earth. “And the Séance Room is a suspicious enough place to start.” “Okay, okay, you’re right,” said West. “Let’s go.” They ran together into the mansion, past the hall of portraits, to the door to the Séance Room. Nellie tried the door, which would not budge, then jumped out of the way when West staggered forward to peer through the keyhole. “Do you see anything?” asked Devi. For a moment… A distorted face? Pale, drawn, eyes so black, two deep voids. And then he was being pulled backwards, a hand gripping hard on his shoulder. “Who the hell are you?” Nellie screamed as West righted himself and saw the unfamiliar woman who had grabbed him. Long grey curls covered half her face, but he could see her eyes, filled with rage. And since the others could see her, too, it didn’t matter how unsettling she looked, how her rage made her nearly vibrate off the ground. This was a person, not a ghost. But a person came with its own kind of dangers. “Don’t touch me!” West warned the woman, too late. She stared at her hands, which had gone fuzzy with mold, her eyes widening as she got a clear look at West’s face. “So, this is how it ends?” she murmured, as sludge began to drip from her lips. “What do we do?” Devi asked, her voice high pitched. “Oh shit, what do we do?” “Run,” said West. He fell to his knees. The mush that was left of what used to be his knees. The woman stared over her shoulder at the two girls and nodded, slowly, sadly. “What?” asked Nellie. “Don’t touch me,” said West. “And run.” He heard their footsteps retreating behind him. He watched the woman fall apart in front of him as he fell apart with her. [[End of Track]] “Let’s go to the basement,” said Devi. “It was super weird. And this is super weird. Maybe there’s a connection.” “Flawless logic, Devi,” Nellie hissed. “Do you have a better idea?” The ground shook beneath them. “We don’t have time to think of one,” said West. “Let’s go.” They ran into Bradford’s Bedroom before West stopped with a hiss. The split in his hand was growing, extending down his arm. He gingerly touched the edges of his torn flesh and they scraped against his fingers with a roughness almost like burlap or woven hemp. The two girls had stopped at his sound of pain. Devi looked at him, worry etched across her face. “The Basement is right here,” Devi said, her voice gentle, soothing. “Everything in this house has pointed to that altar, that imagery, something from Bradford’s occult days. Maybe we can use it to, I don’t know, cleanse you of whatever this is.” “Okay,” said West, panic tightening his chest as the skin on either side of the wound began to curl up and away from the sludge beneath. They ran through the wardrobe, down the stairs, and froze. A man sat cross-legged on the altar. The man was handsome, in an unusual way. His skin was a little too pale. His black hair was pushed messily back from his forehead. His shirt and ripped jeans were too tight, a trying-too-hard rockstar look, or maybe just a poor fit. His eyes were dark. He blinked slowly at them, squinting slightly, and West wondered if he could not see very well. But then the man’s eyes locked on West and he scowled, and suddenly he did not look like a man at all. Not a ghost, either. Something terrible and now, something angry. “You would seek to destroy me with that filth?” he hissed, and it sounded like the static from before, and if West could have clamped his hands over his ears again like Nellie and Devi were then he would have, but now both hung limp and dead at his sides. “You come here with so blatant a ploy? GET. OUT.” There was a rush of air, a snap, and short scream. West saw Nellie’s and Devi’s bodies fly backwards up the stairs, like they were pushed by a great wind. His body was buffeted as well, but what was left of his skin could not handle the strain. He felt himself unravel before he even reached the first step, he saw a spray of sludge on the floor that made the man recoil, even though it never touched him. What would happen if it touched him? West would never find out. [[End of Track]] Nellie’s took the pick from West’s grasp. Her hand immediately sprouted black fuzz. “What the hell, what the hell!” she screamed, dropping it, but it was too late. The fuzz spread down her arm, up her neck, to her mouth. “What do I do?” Devi asked, her voice almost inaudible. “Help me!” Nellie screamed, but West grabbed her arm before she could get close to Devi. “Run,” he said staring at her, and Devi cringed away from whatever she saw on his face. “There’s nothing we can do. Run.” Devi ran. Nellie screamed after her, pleas and swears, but could not break free of West’s grip, surprisingly strong despite the fact that his insides felt like they had nearly dissolved. She must have been deteriorating faster than him. They fell together to the disrupted stones of the mandala, and West watched Nellie’s lovely cheek slide off her face to the earth below. He could feel his own skin sloughing off. He hoped his eyes were fall away soon, and he would not have to see his fate reflected in Nellie’s deteriorating features any longer. [[End of Track]] “No,” said West, clutching the pick close to his chest. “Look at it, Nellie. It’s infected.” “Infected?” she asked, taking a step back. “Then what are we supposed to do?” Devi asked. “What was… the ghost… trying to say?” “I don’t know,” said West. He felt something detach inside him, slide with a thunk towards his hips, and had a terrible feeling that it was not something that was ever meant to detach. “I don’t think there’s anything to do.” “What do you mean?” Devi asked. “I think you should go,” West said. “Before you get infected, too.” Devi was shaking her head, but Nellie had already grabbed her arm, was pulling her away. “He’s right,” she said, shakily, eyeing the tear in his hand that had gotten wider, the split growing down his arm that oozed black sludge. “It could spread to us to. We can’t let it get out. Whatever we did, it needs to stay here.” “No, no,” Devi whispered, but she did not fight Nellie as she pulled her away, her eyes full of silent apologies that meant nothing. He expected them to go. It still hurt. It was still the right thing to do. His knees gave out and he fell to the mandala as the earth rolled again, upsetting several of the large cacti that fell over, pulling much of the ground up with them. He felt his body falling apart as he rested a too-soft head against the ground. He could picture his now inhuman face perfectly, a sack of flesh sewn over lumpy mold. Sewn? Why was he imagining stitches? He was not imagining anything. At the base of the cacti, unearthed by the quake, was another figure of mold, of inhuman flesh, a cursed body no longer buried below the garden. West did not know what to do with this revelation. It did not matter. He did not have much time to consider it before his body completely dissolved. [[End of Track]]
